fields.headline: La Battaglia di Legnano
fields.standfirst:
La Battaglia di Legnano
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
La Battaglia di Legnano
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Turfed out of their home by the visiting Kirov, the Royal Opera have given two concert performances on the less sumptuous South Bank. But what was missing in glamour from the venue was made up for by the soloists - or, at least, by one of them. More than anything, this seemed to be a gala concert for Placido Domingo. How else would you explain an almost full house for an almost unknown opera, and a standing ovation for a singer who dropped down a gear in some of the ensembles to save his voice?

Verdi's most overtly patriotic opera, La battaglia di Legnano, hasn't been performed in Britain for 40 years. Taken out of its revolutionary context (it was written in 1848, a year of uprising in Milan), it seems more a series of tableaux than an opera. The subtlety of his later works is not much in evidence - some of the most serious moments are set to jaunty rhythms in a major key with none of the ominous rumblings that might accompany similar moments in, say, Rigoletto, written only three years later.

Domingo may not quite have the stamina left for leading Verdi roles but his voice is still a wonderful instrument, with tone and presence in abundance. Smaller parts may well suit him better these days, but he'd probably upstage the lead. Veronica Villarroel, singing Lida, desperately needs to take diction lessons from him; she wore two different concert dresses but couldn't get her words across in either of them, and though her topmost notes were secure and liquid-toned, her voice got more nasal the lower down it went.

Anthony Michaels-Moore, as Rolando, delivered his revenge aria with aplomb, while there was a promising debut from Orlin Anastassov as Barbarossa. The orchestra seemed to sense that it was a singers' night, relaxing immediately each number finished, but Mark Elder managed to whip them up into something at least approaching revolutionary fervour when necessary.

fields.headline: Virgin's power play
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson yesterday added utilities to his growing list of interests, launching Virgin Energy, an internet-based gas and electricity supplier, and revealing that he was in talks with BT that could create a Virgin branded telecoms business.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson yesterday added utilities to his growing list of interests, launching Virgin Energy, an internet-based gas and electricity supplier, and revealing that he was in talks with BT that could create a Virgin branded telecoms business.

Next month Virgin will start converting Our Price record stores into V.shop outlets where customers will be able to pay utility bills as well as buying CDs.

The new net-based domestic services are to be packaged in a Virgin Home division, part of Virgin.com. They sit alongside Virgin Mobile, Virgin Rail and other private companies of mixed success inside Sir Richard's empire.

While Virgin Mobile has broken all its targets for attracting customers in its first year of operation and the Virgin Atlantic airline has proved consistently profitable, shorthaul airline Virgin Express has made losses. Virgin Rail has been dogged by bad publicity, and smaller businesses such as clothing and cosmetics have also fared poorly.

French-owned London Electricity owns 25% of the new business, which is headed by a former British Gas executive, Jon Kinsey.

It will have a £30m advertising budget and aims to capture up to 300,000 customers within 12 months. Talks are already under way about rolling the service out in continental Europe.

A move into telecoms would use the same blueprint - with BT or another company providing the physical network, and Virgin exploiting its brand name, which has particular appeal to younger consumers.

The company said that if everyone who had not switched supplier since liberalisation moved to Virgin Energy, the annual savings would be more than £630m. Occupiers of a typical four-bedroom house would reduce their bills by £85 a year.

Sir Richard said that customers had been supplied energy for too long by faceless institutions at inflated prices. "We took a look at all the waste and bureaucracy in this industry and knew we could provide a better service at a lower price," he said.

Critics were sceptical, pointing out that most utilities were extending their interests outside gas and electricity where wholesale prices have risen but retail prices have fallen.

Rivals were not so relaxed about the new entrant to an already crowded utility market and keen to question some of the savings figures used by Virgin Energy.

British Gas, which has lost 5m customers since its monopoly was broken in April 1996 but now claims to be winning 14,000 of them back every week, said Virgin would not find it easy.

"Most customers are interested in safe, reliable and experienced service providers. British Gas can give that," said a company spokeswoman.

Mr Kinsey dismissed the safety issue, saying that neither Virgin nor British Gas now had responsibility for the physical supply of gas; that was the job of an independent company, Transco.

Virgin said that it would buy supplies through its partner, a subsidiary of Gaz de France, but did not rule out buying North Sea gas assets in the longer term to ensure supplies.

Virgin Energy will have an initial share capital of £15m. It will employ 30 people at its London head office and 75 at its partner's Exeter call centre.

Virgin Energy's price guarantee promises that customers who have not saved money after switching to the company will receive a refund of the difference plus 20%.

The company also claims an industry first by offering a £1 refund for every 1% of energy consumption saved.

webTitle: Make like a football boss: achieve your goals, then quit

fields.headline: Make like a football boss: achieve your goals, then quit
fields.standfirst: The resignations of three soccer managers whose teams gave perfectly respectable performances in Euro 2000 has baffled pundits. Sandi Mann sheds some light on the subject
fields.trailText: The resignations of three soccer bosses whose teams gave perfectly respectable performances in Euro 2000 has baffled pundits. Sandi Mann sheds some light on the subject
fields.body:
So when is the right time to quit your job?

Now that Italy's coach Dino Zoff has thrown in the towel after their Euro 2000 finals defeat - along with the Dutch and Spanish bosses - many are left wondering why football's top managers seem to be falling over themselves to resign, even when their team has done reasonably well.

Indeed, Italian fans were rather pleased that their team had made it to the finals and had certainly not been calling for Zoff's head. So, is this a case of 'quitting while you're ahead' - and if so, are such apparently unnecessary courses of action restricted to the footballing profession?

There are a number of reasons why anyone, in any profession, begins to think about quitting their job. Declining job satisfaction and increased job stress are the most common factors. The employee who no longer looks forward to going to work, who is bored, hates their boss or is fed up of the long hours, will probably begin to think about moving on. Similarly, the worker who has too much work to cope with, too many new changes to handle, too much pressure from tight deadlines or who has to cope with too few resources, is experiencing workplace stress and may decide that enough is enough.

But can these reasons for quitting be applied to our football top dogs? Perhaps, but it is more likely that another factor is in play; one that kicks off even though you enjoy your job and can cope with the stress. The reason? You've achieved all you can and can do no more. The classic worker who experiences this has been in their job about five years and has accomplished everything they set out to accomplish - won contracts, developed projects, set up new initiatives, overseen a merger, driven profits up, installed a new team, and so on. One day, they just wake up and wonder what's left to do? When more of the same fails to excite, it is time to move on.

Of course, the 'quit while your ahead' motto is an important factor. Zoff's team might not have taken the European Cup, but a 2-1 defeat in the finals took Italy further than most had expected. Getting out while you can still hold your head up means you leave on a high note with excellent references. Deciding when to quit is a bit like trying to decide when to sell your shares - too soon and you could miss out on winning the next World Cup, too late and you'll be sacked for failing to come through the equivalent of a no-pressure friendly against the Faro islands.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Managing Your Boss In A Week

fields.headline: On Raftery's Hill
fields.standfirst:
On Raftery's Hill
Royal Court Downstairs, London
****
fields.trailText:
On Raftery's Hill
Royal Court Downstairs, London
****
fields.body:
No sooner have we recovered from Shelagh Stephenson's Five Kinds of Silence than along comes Marina Carr's not dissimilar study of incestuous abuse. The key difference is that Carr's play is full-bloodedly theatrical, so much so that it risks toppling into Gothic melodrama. It is saved from that by its own self-awareness and by the livid intensity of Garry Hynes's superbly acted production.

Carr's setting is Ireland's rural heartland - Red Raftery's decaying farm filled with the stench of rotting carcasses. The inhabitants have become inured to the smell just as they have to the abnormality of their domestic life. Red's mother is a distrait figure dreaming of her glory days in India. His son, Ded, is a wander-wit. The elder daughter, Dinah, is a drudge who has become, for all practical purposes, her father's wife. Only Sorrel, the youngest, due to marry a local farm-boy, seems to have escaped contamination though the predatory Red puts paid to that.

Occasionally the farm of which I was most reminded was Stella Gibbons's Cold Comfort. When Red announces "There was allas skullduggery in the valley" I hear an echo of Aunt Ada Doom crying "There have always been Starkadders at Cold Comfort." What rescues Carr's play from rustic melodrama is her pitying irony and poetic skill. The former is shown by Red's condemnation of low valley morality: the sin under discussion is precisely the paternal incest he himself practises. And when Dinah says: "We're a respectable family, we love one another," you realise she is both wrapped in self-delusion and expressing a literal truth.

Carr doesn't moralise about her characters: she sees them, if anything, as victims of a society in which wives were taught to see sex as a pious duty. And, oppressive as the play is, it is relieved by the writing's poetic grace. A widowed neighbour, who overcomes his loneliness by humanising his cat, talks of "tears rolling off a her whiskers and pounding the pilla". And when Sorrel's fiance describes his own father as a "wan sad picnic in the rain" you get an instant picture of lugubrious dankness.

But it is Hynes's Druid Theatre production and the performances I shall long remember. Tom Hickey shows how Red's sexual voracity stems from desperation - everything about him, from his scuffed shoes to the way he clamps his hand round a whiskey glass, implies a man long past the end of his tether. Valerie Lilley as his mother, Cara Kelly as the submissive Dinah and Mary Murray as the ruined Sorrel all give flawless support. And Tony Walton's kitchen set, with its twisty staircases and walls seemingly made of moss and dung, reminds us this is a play about a decaying rural Ireland - the hidden face, you might say, of the urban Emerald Tiger.

At the Royal Court, London SW1 (020-7565 5000), till July 29.

fields.headline: Only slightly ludicrous
fields.standfirst:
King Crimson
Shepherds Bush Empire, London
****
fields.trailText:
King Crimson
Shepherds Bush Empire, London
****
fields.body:
After a mere 31 years, King Crimson continue not only to survive, but to evolve. Not that the current line-up, or the music they plays, bear any resemblance to the original band that appeared with the Rolling Stones in Hyde Park in 1969. The single surviving constant is Robert Fripp, whose boffinly excursions on guitar in time signatures that would baffle students of Pierre Boulez or Archie Shepp still sit at the molten core of the Crimson crusade.

Always the theoretician, Fripp thinks of the current Crimson not as a quartet but as a double duo, in which the so-called rhythm section might at any moment stage a coup and take over. This was the band's first UK performance for four years, coinciding with the recent album, The ConstruKction of Light. The new music is a heady mixture of steamhammer rhythms, howling mutant funk and passages of seething noise, though in live performance they introduce some welcome light and shade. With Fripp seated stage right like a technician monitoring a complicated experiment, the frontman function devolves on to co-guitarist Adrian Belew, while Pat Mastelotto mans the drums and Trey Gunn plays "bass touch guitar" like an octopus tormented by fleas.

Musically, nowhere is off limits. Pieces might begin with slow, treated percussion and synthesised voice samples, separated by chasms of silence, then kick up a couple of gears into a smooth, flowing motion with Fripp sailing along in pastoral mode. Crimson's version of funk resembles a multiple air crash, shaking the floor with enormous syncopations before uncaging interludes of freeform mayhem.

If there's a question-mark, it's over Belew's singing, which is never entirely convincing, perhaps because he always looks as if he's about to burst out laughing. He growled out ProzaKc Blues like a Howlin' Wolf impersonator on amateur night, but was barely audible in an otherwise laudable take of Bowie's Heroes. His finest moment was his solo treatment of Complicated, where he managed to remember all the words while finger-picking a fiendishly tricky pattern on acoustic guitar. Overall, Crimson 2000 are brainy, brawny and only slightly ludicrous.

fields.headline: 1 chief executive = 5 roadsweepers
fields.standfirst:
As a local council swaps one boss for a handful of men on the ground, Charlotte Denny asks how long British businesses can defend their fat cats

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: As a local council swaps one boss for a handful of men on the ground, Charlotte Denny asks how long British businesses can defend their fat cats
fields.body:
The news that a Labour council has sacked its chief executive and employed an extra five roadsweepers with his £60,000 salary must have had a few brave personnel managers in some of Britain's bigger companies doing their sums. Just think: for the price of one Matt Barrett, on his annual chief executive's salary of £850,000 plus the same again in bonuses, Barclays could afford to employ 170 extra counter staff. Vodafone could take on another 530 operators in its call centres by booting out Chris Gent and his £6.36m salary and bonuses package, while SmithKline Beecham could afford 300 more chemists with departing chief executive Jan Leschly's £2.2m remuneration package.

Of course, people like Chris Gent and Matt Barrett get paid those sorts of sums to cut staff - the news of Barrett's bonus came out as Barclays announced it was closing 170 branches, bringing the number of jobs lost at the bank to more than 6,500 in the last year. On top of his basic salary and bonus, he is entitled to share options worth £30.5m if Barclays meets its targets. When he was questioned by MPs earlier this year, Barrett estimated that the closures had saved £10m, so he must be well on the way.

But with the average chief executive's salary and bonus package worth 18 times the average worker's, according to one Warwick University study, the usual excuses for why they are worth their weight in gold are wearing a bit threadbare. (For any chief executive earning more than half a million and weighing in at less than 14 stone, that statistic is literally true.) At this year's annual shindig with Barclays' shareholders, Barrett was accosted by one elderly widow, indignant at hearing the news that, on top of his already extravagant salary, he had been paid £225,000 just for crossing the Atlantic from his native Canada and turning up at the office.

"Last September, I received a letter stating that circumstances beyond your control only allowed you to increase my widow's pension by £1 a week. My husband died of a heart attack at the age of 57 in 1966 and I am in my 89th year," Jessie Bonner-Thomas told Barclays' annual meeting. "But circumstances within your control allowed you to give Mr Barrett a £1.3m hello."

In response to Bonner-Thomas's outburst, Barclays' chairman, Sir Peter Middleton, gave the textbook corporate response. Barrett's pay was "in line with industry standards" particularly in North America where he was hired, Sir Peter explained.

Barrett himself was in equally robust form when he met with MPs earlier this year to talk about fat cat pay. He told the Treasury select committee that he was worth every penny of it and that indeed he was a bargain. "These are not ill-gotten gains," he said.

The argument goes that top people's pay must be left to the market and with salaries in the United States dwarfing even the wildest dreams of most FTSE-100 CEOs, British firms must have a free hand to attract international talent. It's true that at any one time, around half the top-paid executives in Britain have been lured from US companies, suggesting that there is some kind of international market for chief executives.

But is it true that companies pay only what the market demands? The Trades Union Congress points out that the real process of determining executives' pay is done by a small circle of people, all directors themselves with a vested interest in making sure that overall pay levels stay as high as possible. In theory, chief executives' pay is supposed to be decided by independent remuneration committees. In practice, the non-executive directors who sit on these committees are usually themselves directors of other companies. "This creates a conflict of interest for the non-executive directors because they have a direct interest in boosting overall levels of executive remuneration," a recent TUC report said.

Just 392 people make up the remuneration committees of 98 of the largest UK companies and 30 directors sit on more than one committee, according to a survey by the independent thinktank Labour Research. Pay-setting appears to be more of a "you scratch my back and I'll scratch yours" arrangement, rather than a fiercely competitive market.

Even if pay packets for chief executives were truly decided in a competitive market, two things still rankle. First, unlike supermodels and sports stars who also earn stratospheric sums by most people's standards, the pay of top business people appears to bear little relationship to their performance.

Once executives enter this magic circle, it seems that they earn the sums regardless of how good they are at their jobs. In fact, if things go wrong, they are often paid enormous amounts to disappear quietly - so-called golden parachute deals.

NatWest's top man, Derek Wanless, for example, was given a £3m payoff to clear his desk last year as the bank began its doomed attempt to fend off hostile takeover bids. Yet according to some commentators, Wanless was to blame for the predators circling around the bank - he had made several unwise acquisitions that opened NatWest up to threat of a takeover. Meanwhile, Dino Adriano, the former chief executive of Sainsbury, received a £1.2m payoff earlier this year to sweeten his sacking after he had introduced a disastrous advertising campaign, allowed the company to be overtaken by Tesco and Asda, and participated in an ill-judged fly-on-the-wall TV programme.

At a time when the chancellor of the exchequer is warning that excessive pay claims will spark inflation and force the Bank of England to push up interest rates, it is hard for ordinary workers to accept that they should show restraint when the top players are throwing moderation to the wind. Last year, CEOs' pay rose by 17.6%, according to research by Incomes Data Services. Over the same period, average earnings rose by around 5%. The pattern is the same across the Atlantic - Business Week estimates that if a US worker earning $25,000 in 1994 had got the same percentage increases as his or her boss, he or she would be earning $138,350 today.

When it was in opposition, Labour made much of the exorbitant salaries earned by the heads of former public utilities. But in power, it has made much less noise about fat cats' pay. Last year, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said it was not for the government to dictate boardroom pay. "To attract world-class players, we need to pay at world-class levels," he said. The only sop he offered to those offended by the size of corporate pay packets was the suggestion that shareholders should have to approve remuneration committees' reports.

Meanwhile, Geoffrey Pook, the chief executive of Erewash council who lost his job to pay for five roadsweepers on £161 per week, has already found another post. He has become acting head of legal services at Rutland County Council and is about to sue his former employers for refusing to renew his contract.

Of course, people like Chris Gent and Matt Barrett get paid those sorts of sums to cut staff - the news of Barrett's bonus came out as Barclays announced it was closing 170 branches, bringing the number of jobs lost at the bank to more than 6,500 in the last year. On top of his basic salary and bonus, he is entitled to share options worth £30.5m if Barclays meets its targets. When he was questioned by MPs earlier this year, Barrett estimated that the closures had saved £10m, so he must be well on the way. But with the average chief executive's salary and bonus package worth 18 times the average worker's, according to one Warwick University study, the usual excuses for why they are worth their weight in gold are wearing a bit threadbare. (For any chief executive earning more than half a million and weighing in at less than 14 stone, that statistic is literally true.) At this year's annual shindig with Barclays' shareholders, Barrett was accosted by one elderly widow, indignant at hearing the news that, on top of his already extravagant salary, he had been paid £225,000 just for crossing the Atlantic from his native Canada and turning up at the office. "Last September, I received a letter stating that circumstances beyond your control only allowed you to increase my widow's pension by £1 a week. My husband died of a heart attack at the age of 57 in 1966 and I am in my 89th year," Jessie Bonner-Thomas told Barclays' annual meeting. "But circumstances within your control allowed you to give Mr Barrett a £1.3m hello." In response to Bonner-Thomas's outburst, Barclays' chairman, Sir Peter Middleton, gave the textbook corporate response. Barrett's pay was "in line with industry standards" particularly in North America where he was hired, Sir Peter explained. Barrett himself was in equally robust form when he met with MPs earlier this year to talk about fat cat pay. He told the Treasury select committee that he was worth every penny of it and that indeed he was a bargain. "These are not ill-gotten gains," he said. The argument goes that top people's pay must be left to the market and with salaries in the United States dwarfing even the wildest dreams of most FTSE-100 CEOs, British firms must have a free hand to attract international talent. It's true that at any one time, around half the top-paid executives in Britain have been lured from US companies, suggesting that there is some kind of international market for chief executives. But is it true that companies pay only what the market demands? The Trades Union Congress points out that the real process of determining executives' pay is done by a small circle of people, all directors themselves with a vested interest in making sure that overall pay levels stay as high as possible. In theory, chief executives' pay is supposed to be decided by independent remuneration committees. In practice, the non-executive directors who sit on these committees are usually themselves directors of other companies. "This creates a conflict of interest for the non-executive directors because they have a direct interest in boosting overall levels of executive remuneration," a recent TUC report said. Just 392 people make up the remuneration committees of 98 of the largest UK companies and 30 directors sit on more than one committee, according to a survey by the independent thinktank Labour Research. Pay-setting appears to be more of a "you scratch my back and I'll scratch yours" arrangement, rather than a fiercely competitive market. Even if pay packets for chief executives were truly decided in a competitive market, two things still rankle. First, unlike supermodels and sports stars who also earn stratospheric sums by most people's standards, the pay of top business people appears to bear little relationship to their performance. Once executives enter this magic circle, it seems that they earn the sums regardless of how good they are at their jobs. In fact, if things go wrong, they are often paid enormous amounts to disappear quietly - so-called golden parachute deals. NatWest's top man, Derek Wanless, for example, was given a £3m payoff to clear his desk last year as the bank began its doomed attempt to fend off hostile takeover bids. Yet according to some commentators, Wanless was to blame for the predators circling around the bank - he had made several unwise acquisitions that opened NatWest up to threat of a takeover. Meanwhile, Dino Adriano, the former chief executive of Sainsbury, received a £1.2m payoff earlier this year to sweeten his sacking after he had introduced a disastrous advertising campaign, allowed the company to be overtaken by Tesco and Asda, and participated in an ill-judged fly-on-the-wall TV programme. At a time when the chancellor of the exchequer is warning that excessive pay claims will spark inflation and force the Bank of England to push up interest rates, it is hard for ordinary workers to accept that they should show restraint when the top players are throwing moderation to the wind. Last year, CEOs' pay rose by 17.6%, according to research by Incomes Data Services. Over the same period, average earnings rose by around 5%. The pattern is the same across the Atlantic - Business Week estimates that if a US worker earning $25,000 in 1994 had got the same percentage increases as his or her boss, he or she would be earning $138,350 today. When it was in opposition, Labour made much of the exorbitant salaries earned by the heads of former public utilities. But in power, it has made much less noise about fat cats' pay. Last year, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said it was not for the government to dictate boardroom pay. "To attract world-class players, we need to pay at world-class levels," he said. The only sop he offered to those offended by the size of corporate pay packets was the suggestion that shareholders should have to approve remuneration committees' reports. Meanwhile, Geoffrey Pook, the chief executive of Erewash council who lost his job to pay for five roadsweepers on £161 per week, has already found another post. He has become acting head of legal services at Rutland County Council and is about to sue his former employers for refusing to renew his contract.

fields.headline: Pearson to float £14bn media firm
fields.trailText: A £14bn media company, 22% owned by Pearson, with television and radio stations spanning 11 countries is to float on the stock exchange later this month to become the largest group of its kind in Europe.
fields.body:
A £14bn media company, 22% owned by Pearson, with television and radio stations spanning 11 countries is to float on the stock exchange later this month to become the largest group of its kind in Europe.

The company, which was yesterday named as RTL, is part of the reshaping of the Pearson media empire announced in April and unites 160 of Pearson programmes such as Baywatch and The Bill.

Shares in RTL are to start trading on July 26, although it will not immediately enter the main FTSE 100 share index because only 10% of the entire company is being sold to investors.

The group is expected later to increase the number of shares available to investors to above the 15% threshold required for inclusion in the crucial index, which is tracked by major investors.

RTL is being formed by meshing together Pearson's television business with Luxembourg-based broadcast and radio group CLT-Ufa, owned by the Bertelsmann empire in Germany and GBL of Luxembourg.

The formation of the company, which will be larger than Pearson, requires the approval of shareholders in Audofina, listed on the Luxembourg and Brussels stock exchanges and the 49% owner of CLT-Ufa, at meetings on July 24 and 25.

As part of the plan to bolster the board of the new company ahead of the stock market flotation, Juan Abello Gallo, chairman of Spanish company Alcaliber, was yesterday named as non-executive chairman, while Martin Taylor, the former chief executive of Barclays bank and current chairman of WH Smith, was appointed a non-executive director.

Didier Bellens, chief executive of the newly formed RTL, said the group would be well positioned in the rapidly consolidating European media sector.

The established shareholders do not intend to reduce their holdings the company, which means that Pearson will own 22%, Bertelsmann approximately 37% and GBL 30%.

The group, which will be based in Luxembourg, is expected to bolster its already large size by making acquisitions, particularly in continental Europe but also in other markets.

fields.headline: Bottomless abilities
fields.standfirst:
Khovanshchina
Royal Opera House, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Khovanshchina
Royal Opera House, London
*****
fields.body:
If you haven't heard Russian opera sung by a Russian company, then you haven't really heard it at all. The line-up that the Kirov fielded for the first night of Mussorgsky's Khovanshchina was as strong as any you'll hear; and if you dropped a stone into some of these voices, it would take a very, very long time to reach the bottom.

The Kirov has strength in numbers, and Khovanshchina, calling for a large chorus and several strong male principals, suits it very well. It's a historical epic on a similar scale as the better-known Boris Godunov, set during the troubled times leading to the accession of Peter the Great. In Mussorgsky's day it was forbidden to show any of the Romanov tsars on stage, so the actual figure of Peter wasn't part of his original conception - though the Kirov did bring him on stage to add to the impact of the closing bars of the penultimate act. The storybook backdrops, of forests, rivers and partly obscured domes, had already created quite an atmosphere.

Khovanshchina has never caught on outside Russia to the same extent as Boris Godunov; it is perhaps less dramatically satisfying because there is no one really central role and therefore less of an opportunity to get inside the characters' heads. But the music is not to blame: in the hands of the Kirov orchestra, from the simplicity of Ivan Tersky's fluid clarinet solo right at the very start to the deafening gong clashes that closed two of the acts, the score sounded glorious. Under Valery Gergiev's baton the score became an organic creation, very much alive but never drawing overt attention to the mechanism creating it.

The Kirov uses a different set of soloists every night - because it can. (How many British companies can say that?) Some of them swap between two principal roles, such as Gennady Bezzubenkov, who on this occasion was singing Dosifei with his mellifluous and seemingly bottomless bass voice, but for the next performance will sing Khovansky, the role taken this time by powerhouse bass Vladimir Vaneev. Golitsyn and Shaklovity were equally strongly sung by Gegam Grigorian and Nikolai Putilin, and Olga Borodina's Marfa was a delight, coaxing out all the role's melancholy in deep, liquid and seemingly effortless tone.

The gremlins in the Royal Opera's surtitle machine unfortunately took over after only half an hour, prompting some rather unrestrained complaints from some areas of the auditorium. It was a testament to the Kirov that the opera still packed a dramatic punch even when most of the audience didn't have a clue what the words meant.

Performances tomorrow and July 12. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Woolwich faces heat over cash machine charges

fields.headline: Woolwich faces heat over cash machine charges
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Woolwich was last night attacked for being one of the last of the major banks to retain the controversial surcharging for cash machine withdrawals which has been dropped by its rivals.
fields.body:
Woolwich was last night attacked for being one of the last of the major banks to retain the controversial surcharging for cash machine withdrawals which has been dropped by its rivals.

The former building society levies a £1 surcharge at 1,500 of its 2,100 hole in the wall machines and justifies the charge because they are in "convenience" locations, including Post Offices, where cash machines would not normally be sited.

Alliance & Leicester also admits that it is piloting surcharges at about 50 "convenience" machines that are sited in rural areas and convenience stores - but not at Post Offices, which account for some of its 200 non-branch locations.

Stuart Cliffe, chief executive of the National Association of Banks and Insurance Customers, warned last night, however, that Woolwich could face investor backlash as a result of the continuing charge.

"Woolwich continues to behave like a dinosaur in the banking industry," Mr Cliffe said. "I'm sure they will see customer reaction as a result of charges."

But Woolwich insisted that the machines are located in areas without "sufficient footfall" to justify their existence without a charge. The charges were "blatantly clear" to card holders, a spokeswoman said. It will drop the charges its own customers face at the start of next year.

fields.headline: Better at happiness
fields.standfirst:
Grupo Corpo
Sadler's Wells, London
***
fields.trailText:
Grupo Corpo
Sadler's Wells, London
***
fields.body:
Brazil's Grupo Corpo dance the way Brazil's footballers play football: loose and lithe. The joy comes from simply playing the game and strutting your stuff without worrying about the result. That takes care of itself.

In just the way a footballer's dribble starts with a subtle shimmy, so the key to the way Grupo Corpo move lies in the hips. It's from this under-rated midfield section that all the playmaking of choreographer Rodrigo Pederneiras begins, liquid ripples eddying through the bodies of his 18 willowy dancers. As a style, it's deceptively effortless.

It's rare to find a contemporary dance company that's so close to its cultural roots. Pederneiras draws heavily from Brazilian influences to construct rambling travelogues that explore the limbo land between folk dance and modern moves while staying (for the most part) just this side of showbiz. When it works, it's an intoxicating blend.

Much the more successful of the company's double bill is the opening Parabelo. Driven by the insistent rhythms of a hypnotic score by composer Tom Ze and poet Jose Miguel Wisnik, Parabelo paints a portrait of a wild, untamed land a world away from the familiar images of beach soccer and Rio carnival. Yet, for all the sharp limb-stabbing, a sense of irrepressible spirit shines through.

Whether tackling a wedding dance with intricately flowing hand patterns or a gymnastically demanding moodily lit duet, Grupo Corpo's dancers prove masters of their art, providing a common thread between the seemingly disparate elements of the dance. It's saying something, but on the finely tuned bodies of Grupo Corpo (it means, simply enough, Body Group), Lycra, that modern dance stand-by, almost looks cool.

The formula doesn't work nearly as well in Benguele, a rather darker look at the melting pot of Brazilian culture. While Paderneiras steers impressively clear of cliche when it comes to being upbeat, his vision of moody (and, as Benguele harks back to Brazil's African connections in the slave era, he needs to be very moody) seemed hack and second-hand, little more than a parade of oppressed shoulder shrugs.

The magic did surface sporadically, particularly in a succession of celebratory female solos that matched anything in Parabelo. These tapped in again to Grupo Corpo's central appeal: neither self-consciously modern, nor painfully, authentically retro, Grupo Corpo mine their own culture with a looseness of spirit that matches their free-wheeling limbs. You can hardly blame them for being better at being happy.

webTitle: Trescothick and Maynard join England one-day squad

fields.headline: Trescothick and Maynard join England one-day squad
fields.trailText: Marcus Trescothick moved closer to an England one-day debut when he and Glamorgan's captain Matthew Maynard were called up by England yesterday as temporary batting cover for the inaugural NatWest triangular one-day series against West Indies and Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
Marcus Trescothick moved closer to an England one-day debut when he and Glamorgan's captain Matthew Maynard were called up by England yesterday as temporary batting cover for the inaugural NatWest triangular one-day series against West Indies and Zimbabwe.

The powerful Somerset opener and Maynard, who stirred the selectors' imagination with a magnificent century for Glamorgan in last month's Benson & Hedges Cup final, will join the 14-strong England party at Lord's on Thursday because of fitness doubts about Nasser Hussain, Nick Knight and Andrew Flintoff.

The pair will remain with England for at least the opening two matches this weekend, against Zimbabwe at the Oval on Saturday and West Indies at Lord's the following day. David Graveney, the chairman of selectors, indicated yesterday that the squad's fitness would then be assessed before determining if they stayed on.

Maynard played the last of his 10 one-day internationals four years ago against Pakistan, but demands for his inclusion have rarely abated in south Wales where he has consistently been hailed as the finest middle-order batsman in Britain.

Trescothick, a former England Under-19 captain, has rebuilt his reputation this season as a robust strokeplayer after a few lean years raised fears that he might fade from view in the manner of another prematurely touted Somerset batsman, Mark Lathwell.

Flintoff, who is doubtful for the 10-match series after withdrawing from the second Test last week with a recurrence of back trouble, is due to play for Lancashire in tomorrow's NatWest Trophy fourth-round tie against Essex. If he fails to prove his fitness, Dominic Cork, the hero of England's Test win over West Indies at Lord's, will also be fancied to join the squad.

Alec Stewart will continue to lead England until Hussain recovers from the broken left thumb he sustained before the Lord's Test. Knight suffered a hairline fracture to his right index finger in the field at Lord's but England are optimistic that he will play some part in the one-day series.

 The South Africa one-day squad arrived in Colombo yesterday for their first tournament since the King Commission began its inquiry into the Hansie Cronje match-fixing scandal. Sri Lanka have dropped the veterans Arjuna Ranatunga and Aravinda de Silva from their squad for the triangular series, which opens with the hosts playing Pakistan tomorrow in Galle.

Shaun Pollock, who has replaced Cronje as captain, faced up to the issues squarely, saying: "Obviously there are those who will be sceptical of South African cricket and we will try to clear that suspicion by giving 120%. No player in any team I lead will have anything to do with this controversy."

A New Delhi court yesterday issued an arrest warrant for the London-based Indian bookmaker Sanjay Chawla to face trial for his alleged role in match-fixing.

webTitle: Arsenal unveil double signing as French connection lures Pires

fields.headline: Arsenal unveil double signing as French connection lures Pires
fields.trailText: Arsenal have beaten off competition from Real Madrid to complete the signing of the French international Robert Pires from Olympique de Marseille.
fields.body:
Arsenal have beaten off competition from Real Madrid to complete the signing of the French international Robert Pires from Olympique de Marseille.

The 26-year-old, whose appearance as a substitute in Sunday's Euro 2000 final culminated in his assist for David Trezeguet's winning golden goal, flew to London yesterday morning to put pen to paper on a four-year deal. His breathless 24 hours were completed as he dashed back to Paris in time for the French celebrations.

The transfer, thought to be worth about £5m, was one of two completed by Arsenal yesterday as they also confirmed the signing of the Brazilian midfielder Edu, real name Eduardo Cesar Daudi Gaspar, from Corinthians for an undisclosed fee.

"The past month has been like a dream for me, firstly to win Euro 2000 and now to join such a great club as Arsenal," said Pires. "I have great admiration and respect for [the Arsenal manager] Arsène Wenger, who has transformed the careers of my fellow countrymen Thierry Henry, Patrick Vieira, Emmanuel Petit and of course Nicolas Anelka."

The winger's arrival represents something of a U-turn, given his comments immediately after Sunday's final in Rotterdam when he suggested he was on the verge of joining Real Madrid. "Madrid is the best club for me," he said then. But in the wake of the French triumph he has opted instead to follow in the footsteps of his three international team-mates currently plying their trade at Highbury.

"I have a new club and I am happy to link up again with my French friends," he said. "I am very much looking forward to some exciting times with the Gunners."

His arrival may spell the end of the Dutch midfielder Marc Overmars' Arsenal career. The 27-year-old has attracted interest from Serie A, with Lazio and AS Roma prepared to meet the £15m asking price.

Edu, who won the Fifa World Club Championship with Corinthians last season, joins his compatriot and former club team-mate Silvinho at Highbury. The 22-year-old has dual Portuguese nationality and will not require a work permit. "I know Arsenal is a club with great history and great supporters and it is my aim to help them win more trophies," he said.

Wenger said: "Both players are very talented, versatile midfielders with fantastic abilities. They will give us an extra dimension."

The Arsenal manager, who will open contract talks with the midfielder Vieira this week, intends to make one more foray into the transfer market before the start of the season. "We are aiming to strengthen the squad as much as possible," he said.

The Aston Villa defender Steve Watson will complete a £2.5m move to Everton today. Bradford have signed Peter Atherton from Sheffield Wednesday on a free transfer.

 Brazil has withdrawn its bid for the 2006 World Cup and will back South Africa at Thursday's meeting in Zurich.

The winger's arrival represents something of a U-turn, given his comments immediately after Sunday's final in Rotterdam when he suggested he was on the verge of joining Real Madrid. "Madrid is the best club for me," he said then. But in the wake of the French triumph he has opted instead to follow in the footsteps of his three international team-mates currently plying their trade at Highbury. "I have a new club and I am happy to link up again with my French friends," he said. "I am very much looking forward to some exciting times with the Gunners." His arrival may spell the end of the Dutch midfielder Marc Overmars' Arsenal career. The 27-year-old has attracted interest from Serie A, with Lazio and AS Roma prepared to meet the £15m asking price. Edu, who won the Fifa World Club Championship with Corinthians last season, joins his compatriot and former club team-mate Silvinho at Highbury. The 22-year-old has dual Portuguese nationality and will not require a work permit. "I know Arsenal is a club with great history and great supporters and it is my aim to help them win more trophies," he said. Wenger said: "Both players are very talented, versatile midfielders with fantastic abilities. They will give us an extra dimension." The Arsenal manager, who will open contract talks with the midfielder Vieira this week, intends to make one more foray into the transfer market before the start of the season. "We are aiming to strengthen the squad as much as possible," he said. The Aston Villa defender Steve Watson will complete a £2.5m move to Everton today. Bradford have signed Peter Atherton from Sheffield Wednesday on a free transfer.  Brazil has withdrawn its bid for the 2006 World Cup and will back South Africa at Thursday's meeting in Zurich.

webTitle: Dutch pay the penalty for style over substance

fields.headline: Dutch pay the penalty for style over substance
fields.standfirst: The co-hosts failed by arrogance to do justice to their talents, writes  Richard Williams
fields.trailText: The co-hosts failed by arrogance to do justice to their talents.
fields.body:
The Hofplein fountain had gushed orange for three weeks, a striking sight at the junction of two of Rotterdam's broad boulevards. Last Friday morning, after the second semi-final, it was suddenly drained of colour. Twenty-four hours later it was spouting blue liquid, but without its former effervescence.

Further along one of the boulevards, in the middle of a cluster of high-rise blocks, a giant image of an orange-shirted Edgar Davids, 40 storeys high, loomed from the glass curtain wall of an insurance office, the highest building in Rotterdam. On one side he appeared to be crashing into the glass. On the other, facing the city centre, he was emerging - a gigantic symbol of strength and victory, achieved through the correct choice of training shoes. In the wake of defeat the image still dominated the skyline. Now, however, its message seemed pathetically hollow.

For the Dutch the point of Euro 2000 had been lost. And their experience, in the wake of bitter and unexpected defeat by Italy, provided a lesson not only for them but for all observers of the tournament, who could only have been struck by the unnecessary sense of disappointment in the air as Rotterdam reluctantly prepared to play host to the two foreign finalists.

The locals tried to console themselves. "We always lose," a young man remarked, "but usually it's to the team that ends up winning." He was thinking of past experiences against Germany and Argentina. Not this time, though. Now, as in the last World Cup, they had lost to the team that was to lose the final, which is not so good.

But he and lots of other Dutch football fans still seemed reluctant to concede that they had actually lost Thursday's match in the Amsterdam Arena. Just as they emerged from defeat in the World Cup finals of 1974 and 1978 feeling that they had, in fact, won a couple of moral victories over less deserving teams, now they were able to see beyond the physical reality of the shot from Dennis Bergkamp that came back off Francesco Toldo's right-hand post in the 13th minute, and the five missed penalties, and to perceive some deeper metaphysical truth to do with purity of motive and inherent worth, a truth that awarded them the real victory.

They are fooling themselves, once more becoming the casualties of their own characteristic form of hubris. To win at football you have to convert your chances. By failing to score the goals that were there for the taking against Italy on Thursday, the Dutch players dishonoured and devalued their own talents in a way which was certainly regretted by those who admire the inherent qualities of their play and are reluctant to adopt an ironic post-modern attitude to the failure of a team to live up to its true worth.

Since they are such a gifted generation it was sad to see them pass into history without earning the right to stand alongside some of their great predecessors. Now the likes of Davids and Bergkamp will forever be remembered as great mercenaries, individuals who did their best work wearing the shirts of clubs in the Italian, Spanish and English leagues but who could not summon the collective spirit to form a great national team.

Quite possibly Frank Rijkaard's inexperience had something to do with this. For all his openness and intelligence, and despite his empathy with the players, it might have been better to give the job to a greybeard with a better idea of how to provoke and cajole them towards the ultimate success. It is not just in English football that such people are in short supply.

But a greater culprit was the weight of public expectation, artificially exaggerated by the insistent commercial interests which projected images of Davids on to the sides of an office block and which in various other guises turned the country orange for the best part of a month. The fact of co-hosting the tournament came a distant second to the belief that the home team would emerge triumphant. In fact there were times when the tournament seemed to become merely an excuse for a demonstration of Dutch footballing superiority, even though their actual performance in the tournament only once - against the bizarre Yugoslavs - touched the heights.

How different this was from France in 1998, when the host nation's public - footballing and otherwise - had no great belief in their own team's excellence but were prepared to be pleasantly surprised as the tournament went on and their representatives made progress. Celebration was the consequence of success. Never did they make the mistake of doing it in advance. As a result there was a real sense of delight in the discovery that their boys were, in fact, rather good at this game.

Without advocating Belgium's alternative position, which was to show little public enthusiasm for their own team and even less interest in the tournament as a whole, it is possible to be deeply thankful, in this respect, that England will not be hosting the 2006 World Cup. At least the Dutch expectation of success had some basis in reality. Goodness knows what heights of self-delusion the English might have attained had they been approaching the competition with home advantage, buoyed up by the misleading popularity and prosperity of the Premier League. Ten years later, the violent expression of thwarted hopes that were seen in Trafalgar Square after defeat by Germany in the semi-final of Euro 96 might have been made to seem insignificant.

Once England and Germany had gone, Euro 2000 was reclaimed for civilisation. And once Holland had been eliminated, it became nothing more nor less than a football tournament. No longer was it pretending to be some sort of cultural or national festival, with a preordained outcome. For three days we had a normal build-up to a normal match between two very gifted and reasonably well matched teams, their prospects discussed in rational terms even by their most passionate adherents. And when it was all over, we could get on with arguing about the wisdom or otherwise of Roger Lemerre's decision to leave out Nicolas Anelka and whether Filippo Inzaghi, similarly ignored by Dino Zoff, might have converted one or two of the chances to put Italy two goals ahead in the second half that were spurned by Alessandro del Piero.

"It was a clash of football cultures," Lemerre said later, before talking with calmness and good sense about evolution and continuity, and about how he hoped that over the next two years to the next World Cup the younger members in the French squad would continue to absorb valuable lessons from their elders.

A clash of football cultures. And, in the end, that is all it was. After a month in which home advantage had threatened to get out of hand, that came as quite a relief.

webTitle: Dragan slays all with his mix of suds and thuds

fields.headline: Dragan slays all with his mix of suds and thuds
fields.trailText: To succeed a major tournament needs a charismatic malefactor and Euro 2000 was no exception.
fields.body:
During the 1990 World Cup I came across a friend of mine, who had previously shown an aversion to sport, watching the Brazil v Argentina game in a pub. "I thought you couldn't stand football," I said. "I can't," came the reply, "but these big championships are just like a soap opera."

True enough. Over the course of twice-daily viewing you get to know the characters, second-guess the plot with all its predictable and at times irrational twists (The England captain booked for diving? Did that seem plausible to you?) and experience drama, tragedy and the odd Ken Barlow moment.

Like soaps, if it is truly to succeed a major tournament needs a charismatic malefactor, a footballing equivalent of JR Ewing or Grant Mitchell. Usually it is impossible to tell who it will be. Which player will wholeheartedly search for the henchman inside himself and not forget about that bit down the back of the pancreas? Or, as The Venerable BD (Barry Davies) himself might put it, "From whence the blackguard?"

The 1974 World Cup finals are remembered for Total Football, but would they have been so enjoyable without the nasty interventions of Brazil's Luis Pereira? The rest of his nation's players are usually associated with the samba; Luis, by contrast, was more a hokey cokey kind of guy. He put his left foot in, he put his right foot in, and he was pretty free with shaking his elbows about too. In fact, so splendidly rugged was the No5 that, moments after being sent off against Holland, cuddly old Jack Charlton nominated him as his player of the tournament. Blessings don't come any more bruising than that.

In Spain in 1982 we were doubly lucky. Not only did we get Claudio Gentile, a notorious Italian hatchetman who once sued a Rome newpaper for describing him as a barbarian (presumably it made him sound too namby-pamby), we also had the German netminder Harald Schumacher. Recalling the citizens of the town in which he grew up, Harald reported: "The men were drunks and the women were sluts." (Still, who among us hasn't waxed sentimental at one time or another?) No wonder he slapped down Patrick Battiston.

Brutality is not always necessary to establish villainous credentials, however, as Diego Maradona proved eight years later with a high camp performance worthy of Joan Collins in Dynasty.

At Euro 2000 we found ourselves at first toasting absent fiends as Germany left behind the baby-faced Andreas Möller, who lit up Euro 96 by strutting goofily about like a malevolent version of Sir Cliff Richard.

The fact that Abel Xavier chose Holland and Belgium to audition for the part of the amiable, domesticated Bigfoot in future series of Harry and the Hendersons, or that Filippo Inzaghi perpetually wore the expression of a small boy who has just been forced to eat a brussel sprout, were irritating but not defiantly bad.

Thank goodness, then, for the Yugoslavs. Sinisa Mihajlovic, perhaps the only player in history whose sending off visibly lightened the mood of his team-mates, might have done enough in other years. But this time he was overshadowed by the dark form of Dragan Stojkovic.

The languid No10 was once as likely to get caught up in the hurly-burly of the game as Gary Lineker is to be the subject of a Quentin Tarantino biopic entitled Reservoir Lugs. Less so, in fact. In Euro 2000, however, he was a man transformed. His country's 4-3 defeat by Spain will be remembered for many things, but to me it will always be synonymous with Stojkovic's breathtaking display of pettiness which was, sad to say, occasionally interrupted by a wondrous backheel, audacious dummy or pinpoint 30-yard pass.

During the course of 90 pulsating minutes the little playmaker did everything to catch the eye short of poking it with his thumb. When Yugoslavia took the lead he gave a sweet little finger-waggling wave to the Spanish bench as if announcing his presence to a kindergarten class.

When Jose Camacho delivered one of his frequent touchline tirades Dragan placed a finger to his lips to ask him to be quiet. Then when Spain grabbed their second equaliser and the Spanish players rushed past him Stojkovic stuck out a leg, tripped Raul over and then fell to the floor clutching his ankle and claiming the Real Madrid forward had kicked him.

I can pay the 35-year-old playmaker no greater compliment than to say that, should they ever recast The Archers, he is a must for the part of Brian Aldridge.

webTitle: New Tory education policy: freedom, accountability, diversity. And uniforms

fields.headline: New Tory education policy: freedom, accountability, diversity. And uniforms
fields.standfirst: Full text: William Hague's speech
fields.trailText: Conservative leader William Hague tonight produced a radical blueprint for  education reform, with a blistering attack on "bureaucracy and government  diktats".
fields.body:
Conservative leader William Hague tonight produced a radical blueprint for education reform, with a blistering attack on "bureaucracy and government diktats".

In his London speech Hague championed virtues like classroom discipline and school uniforms, but also unveiled a startling plan to pump money directly into schools, almost entirely bypassing the local education authorities (LEAs).

The Tory leader claimed that under his formula, every school would get an average of £540 more per pupil, "to spend as best they see fit" - though they will have to cover costs presently paid by LEAs, like school transport.

The extra money would be diverted from the LEAs and from the Department of Education, which Hague accused of lavishing money on "gimmicks".

He promised that a Tory government would free teachers from the burden of bureaucracy. Though the national curriculum would stay, a plethora of plans and targets would be swept away.

Hague said that three "simple but radical" principles would underly Conservative education policy:

 Every school will be a Free School, free of bureaucratic and political control.  Every school will be accountable to its parents, who in turn will be free to apply to whichever school they want.  There will be "diversity", which Hague defined as nobody having a monopoly on the provision of education.

The principle of diversity is likely to arouse the most controversy.

According to Hague, the new Free Schools will be free to determine their own admissions policy - and if they wish they will be allowed to be wholly selective. "That will mean that new grammar schools can be created, reversing a 30 year policy which has done more than anything else to lower standards in our state education system," he said.

Hague also promised to "sweep away the barriers" between state and independent education. Companies, charities and religious groups would be allowed to run existing state schools, funded by the taxpayer. Independent foundations would also be allowed to build new, publicly funded, schools to run themselves.

Hague described his own proposals as "the most exciting and far-reaching development in state education since Rab Butler's 1944 Act", and predicted that they would enrage the "left-leaning liberal establishment".

In that he is doubtless right, for it was the 1944 Act which entrenched the division of secondary education between grammar schools and secondary moderns.

webTitle: American men suffer Brad Pitt complex

fields.headline: American men suffer Brad Pitt complex
fields.trailText: Hot on the heels of the British government's condemnation of the media's bias towards thin people psychologists are saying that men are also suffering from inferiority complexes
fields.body:
Hot on the heels of the British government's condemnation of the media's bias towards thin people and a campaign to have more realistically-sized women as role models, psychologists are saying that men are also suffering from inferiority complexes.

Apparently, muscly stars like Keanu Reeves and Brad Pitt - recently seen with bulging biceps in Fight Club - are causing men to take up body-building in an attempt to emulate their heroes. No bad thing some women might say. But that is missing the point.

Dr Harrison Pope, who contributed to The Adonis Complex, said, "Millions of men are suffering shame, self-doubt and embarrassment because of this damaging emphasis on body image. They are obsessed with their bodies."

webTitle: Mendes donates scholarship to film student

fields.headline: Mendes donates scholarship to film student
fields.trailText: Oscar-winning British director Sam Mendes has donated a prestigious scholarship won for his achievements in the arts to a 25-year-old student from London.
fields.body:
Oscar-winning British director Sam Mendes has donated a prestigious scholarship won for his achievements in the arts to a 25-year-old student from London.

Mendes was recently named as this year's winner of the Shakespeare Prize by the Hamburg-based Alfred Toepfer Foundation. The 34-year-old director has donated the accompanying Shakespeare scholarship to Hugh Welchman, a final year student at England's National Film and Television School.

Hugh aims to use the grant - worth between £15,000 and £20,000 - to co-produce a film with backers from France and Germany.

He is the third NFTS pupil to have been presented with a Shakespeare scholarship. Director John Schlesinger, whose films include Midnight Cowboy, Marathon Man and new Madonna movie The Next Best Thing, offered his to student Anthony Waller in 1981. And in 1992 Lord Attenborough gave his to John Burgan.

fields.headline: Master classes
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Smithers sees the Platos handed out in Norwich at the final regional event of the Teaching Awards
fields.trailText: Rebecca Smithers sees the Platos handed out in Norwich at the final regional event of the Teaching Awards
fields.body:
The Teaching Awards 2000 "roadshow" rumbled into Norwich last week for a memorable grand finale to the 12 regional events that have honoured the achievements of the best teachers in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Barely stopping for a tea-break, the organisers are now supervising the final visits by the judging teams, which will lead to the 14 national winners being named at a glittering ceremony in October, to be televised by the BBC.

In Norwich, 13 teachers from the east of England - arguably one of the largest geographic regions covered by the awards, which put considerable travel demands on the judges - received their coveted Plato trophies and cheques for £3,500. A further 28 were handed special commendations and £500 for their schools.

What struck many of those present at the ceremony was the confidence and maturity of the younger winners barely into their twenties - who were nevertheless stunned by their success - along with the disarming modesty of their more experienced counterparts.

John Marcus Ray, winner of the award for the most creative use of information communication technology in a primary school, said the three pupils he had brought with him had asked him why he was wearing a suit that day. "I told them it was just another day in the office."

Trenica King from Chalvedon School in Basildon, Essex, was greeted onto the stage by a roar of cheers from her young pupils before picking up the award for the most outstanding new teacher in a secondary school. She has been teaching only since 1998, yet among the many glowing testimonials she was praised "for making a lesson on the structure of the NHS interesting", and described as "a brilliant teacher as well as a friend". One youngster even popped up to present her with a piece of framed artwork.

Trenica's counterpart at a primary school was Heidi Buckingham of Camps Hill School, Stevenage, who has also taught only since 1998. She was praised for the maturity with which she quickly assumed extra responsibilities and challenges, including the task of integrating a boy who had been excluded from another local school. She thanked the school for making her so welcome, and her parents for supporting her throughout her training, which included allowing her to return to live at home!

Two of the awards were, appropriately, presented by national winners from last year, who were also among the five national winners recognised for their achievements in the recent birthday honours. Wendy Crockett OBE, also a member of the awards panel for the east region, paid tribute to the hard, often unrecognised and unseen work of men and women who were variously called "learning assistants, learning support assistants, teaching assistants and classroom assistants". "They have many talents, but particularly as communicators," she went on. "They can be unsung heroes because so much of their work is done in the background." Wendy presented the award for classroom assistant of the year to Maxine Lakey of the Gordon Fendick Junior School in Cambridgeshire.

Barbara Berryman MBE, also a member of the east of England awards panel, hailed the many achievements of special needs teachers as she presented the award for excellence in special needs teaching in a primary school to Madeleine Pugh of St. John's School in Bedford. Julia Weston of Deacons School, Peterborough, who received the same award for a secondary school, thanked her pupils and said: "They always do their best and are some of the nicest people I've ever met."

Finally, Michael Weaver from Woodbridge School in Suffolk won the Lloyds TSB award for lifetime achievement. As well as obtaining exceptional exam results from his students, the popular head of the school's history department was described as having a highly imaginative approach to teaching, which included recreating a bomb shelter in his classroom for a lesson about the second world war. Accepting the award from Steve Mitchell of Lloyds TSB, Weaver deservedly got the last laugh when he described his own special relationship with the bank.

"For six years Lloyds TSB held my student overdraft, and for the last 35 years they've held my teacher's overdraft..."

fields.headline: Tools for Schools
fields.trailText: The Tools for Schools scheme to get thousands more computers into classrooms celebrated its first anniversary last week with a reception at the House of Lords.
fields.body:
The Tools for Schools scheme to get thousands more computers into classrooms celebrated its first anniversary last week with a reception at the House of Lords, and the very welcome personal backing of the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers. The scheme, which is supported by the Guardian, recycles nearly-new computers that are surplus to the needs of business and industry, upgrades them to a high standard and distributes them to the most needy schools in the country at a nominal cost.

Among those at the reception were Bob Phillis, chief executive of the Guardian Media Group and Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian, along with representatives of companies that had donated machines and schools that had received them. Byers chose not to deliver his official speech, opting instead to reflect "off the cuff" on his time as David Blunkett's school standards minister, when he saw at first-hand the impact of new technology in the classroom. He said computers helped to "unlock the key to an Aladdin's Cave of knowledge", at the same time giving children confidence and marrying education with the development of key skills.

fields.headline: London weighting
fields.standfirst: Oxford is no longer top of the research league
fields.trailText: Oxford is no longer top of the research league
fields.body:
 King's College, London witnessed the largest absolute increase in research income from 1997-98 to 1998-99, up £43m. University College, London, Imperial College and the universities of Cambridge and Edinburgh all enjoyed increases of over £10m.

 King's College joins the elite group of research heavyweights, earning over £100m in research funds. University College, London, Imperial College and the universities of Cambridge and Oxford, all secured over £150m in research grants in 1998-99. The University Edindurgh attracted £99.8m, just £200,000 short of the £100m mark.

 Among the new universities, Lincolnshire and Humberside saw the biggest percentage increase, with research income up by over 75% to £1.4m. The universities of Middlesex and Greenwich enjoyed the biggest absolute increases, both up by over £2m, with total budgets in 1998-99 of £5.5m and £14.2m respectively.

 Cranfield University saw the biggest drop in research funds, down by £1.2m on the previous year to £35.6m in total. Among the former polytechnics, Staffordshire, Westminster, and Manchester Metropolitan universities witnessed drops of income of £0.8m, £0.4m, and £0.4m respectively, with 1998-99 budgets of £3.2m, £4.5m, and £6.9m.

 Overall research income for the academic sector was up 8.8% from £2.6bn in 1997-98 to £2.85bn in 1998-99. The biggest absolute increase in external research contracts was from charities, up by £30m to £430m. Only the government's research councils allocated more research project grants to universities in 1998-99, spending £560m. Income from block grants supplied by the higher education funding council was up by £130m to £1bn.

University College, London emerges as the richest research university in the country, marking an end to the dominance of Oxford and Cambridge in the research funding stakes, according to the latest complete breakdown of academic research budgets.

The four research giants which make up the golden triangle - Imperial College, University College, London, Oxford and Cambridge - remain in a super-league of their own in terms of research income. They attracted a quarter of the £2.85bn research grants won by the UK academic sector in 1998-99, made up of about 100 universities. They are the only academic institutions earning over £150m a year in research project grants and contracts and general funding-council block grants.

The latest official figures for external research income, registered by universities in 1998-99, come from the sector's official number-crunching outfit, the Higher Education Statistics Agency. Combined with block research grants from the higher education funding councils, which are allocated mainly on the back of the results of the Research Assessment Exercise, the overall figures provide the most up-to-date picture of research income for UK universities. Income from external research grants and contracts for the sector totalled £1.8bn in 1998-99, while grants from the funding councils totalled £1bn.

The emergence of the large London universities at the top of the research funding table has been fuelled by recent mergers with medical schools in the capital.

In 1998, UCL's medical school completed its merger with the Royal Free Hospital School of Medicine in Hampstead and with various postgraduate schools, including the Institute of Child Health, the Institute of Neurology and Neurosurgery and the Eastman Dental Institute. Under the UCL banner these institutions won more than £50m in charity income in 1998-99, £10m more than Oxford and £20m more than Cambridge.

Imperial College has also developed into a heavyweight biomedical earner, merging with the Charing Cross and Westminster and National Heart and Lung hospitals, and the Royal Postgraduate Medical School, and securing £32m in 1998-99.

Biomedical research grants from charities make up an increasingly large share of academic research income. Charities chanelled £430m into universities in 1998-99, representing nearly one in four of all research grants and contracts - and this before the Wellcome Trust expanded its huge research budget. Despite government policies to focus resources into the highest research- rated research groups and university departments, charitable support is also the most skewed of all research funds: the four golden-triangle universities secured more than a third of a charity grants.

But the big four perform well across the board. In terms of research council project grants - won through individual academic proposals - Cambridge, which gets £43.5m, and Oxford top the rankings, but UCL and Imperial are not far behind.

Overall the sector received £560m from research councils in 1998-99. The four also won most grants from the European Commission. When it comes to income from funding councils, distributed to institutions as one block grant, UCL pips the Oxbridge institutions for the highest ranked university, winning £58.4m.

It is only when figures are compiled for relatively smaller income streams, from government departments and industry, that this pattern changes. With an income of £13.5m, King's College, London, emerges as the biggest winner of other government sources, including local health authorities. Other institutions performing well include UCL, Manchester and Birmingham. Cranfield University, for postgraduates, is the third-largest earner of grants from companies. Imperial tops this list, with £15.8m on its books for 1998-99.

The University of Greenwich is the highest research earner among former polytechnics. With £14.1m, the new university has a larger income than a host of old universities. This is mainly through taking over the Natural Resources Institute.

As a consequence of the increasing concentration of research funds on the academic elite, the south-east of the country is fast becoming the region of research riches. Bolstered by its own medical mergers, King's College enjoyed one of the biggest percentage increases in research income of all universities - up by 60% on the previous year.

UCL, Imperial, Oxford and Cambridge, and King's by themselves won nearly 30% of all research grants in 1998-99, securing £800m in total. And all this before the government and the Wellcome Trust decided to locate a £500m synchrotron X-ray facility near Oxford, rather than in the north-west.

fields.headline: Masters of mystery
fields.standfirst: MAs may impress but they certainly confuse.  Donald MacLeod  on a proposed shake-up
fields.trailText: MAs may impress but they certainly confuse. Donald MacLeod on a proposed shake-up
fields.body:
Eight out of 10 employers are confused by Britain's plethora of degree titles, the higher education quality watchdog said today as it stepped up the pressure to abolish Oxford and Cambridge MAs.

John Randall, chief executive of the Quality Assurance Agency, made it clear that his proposed framework to clarify what qualifications mean would have no place for anomalies like Oxbridge MAs which involve no extra study and are automatically available to graduates after three years - provided they have not been convicted, bankrupted or divorced. He is also taking on the ancient Scottish universities which award MAs after four years of undergraduate study. (Chancellor Gordon Brown, that scourge of tradition, holds just such an MA from Edinburgh.)

Also in the firing line are many MBAs (Master of Business Administration), which the agency believes do not involve postgraduate level study.

A survey for the agency of UK employers found 81% confessed it was fairly or very difficult to understand what higher education qualifications meant. Almost all thought the same title should represent the same general level of achievement, no matter which institution awarded it.

They were particularly confused about the Masters title. More than 60% thought a Cambridge MA was for postgraduate study, and half believed the same about an Edinburgh MA.

"This degree of confusion helps no one - what we need is a clear framework of qualifications that every one can understand," said Randall.

The agency's proposed framework aims to ensure that a title like "masters degree" always represents the same general level of achievement. There will be four undergraduate levels up to the honours degree and two postgraduate levels - Masters and Doctors.

Doctorates and diplomas, both often abbreviated to "D" were a rich source of confusion, said the agency. Most employers recognised a PhD but only 22% knew a Doctor in Business Administration (DBA) was a higher qualification than the Diploma in Higher Education (DipHE). Nearly a third thought a Diploma in Management Studies (DMS) outranked the prestigious Doctor of Music (DMus). Even first degrees caused difficulty. Only 29% realised that the Bachelor of Arts (BA) was on the same level as the Bachelor of Laws (LLB).

Warning that many MBA programmes would not reach the Masters level, Randall said: "The Masters title should only be used for qualifications that are genuinely at postgraduate level. Clarity in the use of the title is essential to maintain the international standing of UK higher degrees at a time when there are moves to harmonise qualification titles across Europe."

He believes the need to tidy up the qualifications system has become more urgent as the European Union moves to harmonise academic qualifications. The Bologna agreement last year between EU states was being enthusiastically taken up in eastern European countries aiming at membership. "Our professional progression in other European countries may depend on holding a Masters degree that is genuinely at Masters level."

This meant that not only might British graduates find it difficult to move around Europe but that UK universities would find it hard to promote their MBAs and other degrees in growth areas like Hungary and the Czech Republic.

In response, Cambridge said its MA predated the idea of a masters degree as an additional qualification and signified membership of the university - administrative staff, say, were awarded them. "It is traditional and historical. Most people know about it," said a spokeswoman.

Results of the market research and position papers on the National Qualifications Framework are on the agency's website at: www.qaa.ac.uk
