fields.headline: Right-wing coalitions, Wing commanders, and Wavering wingers
fields.trailText: ZOFF LAD
fields.body:
ZOFF LAD

Sharp-knifed Italian pundits searching for a scapegoat following the Azzurri's tearful Euro 2000 exit generally settled on either: a) the generous timekeeping of Swedish referee Anders Frisk; or b) the unique finishing skills of Alessandro Del Piero. But in this sea of rationality there was one man swimming freestyle against the tide. A man with the gall to claim that Italy's defeat was "dishonorable," and observe that "even an amateur would have realised we would have won by man-marking [the rather disappointing on the night] Zidane". The name of this virtuoso? Why none other than "outspoken" AC Milan president, media magnate, and rightwing pin-up Silvio Berlusconi.

So withering were Berlusconi's post-match put-downs that Zoff struggled to get any sleep last night. On wakening, the gruff-even-on-a-good-day coach decided there was only one thing to do; and that was to quit. "I was offended as a man," he explained at a news conference. "I cannot continue to work under these conditions. I don't take lessons in dignity from Mr Berlusconi." But before anyone could shout 'shock resignation', Berlusconi bounced back, telling the Italian media: "I can't believe it. I never offended anyone, least of all Zoff," before adding with a smile: "I never denigrated his work - I made a technical criticism, and I stand absolutely by this." Even though it was wrong.

Unfortunately for Signor Silvio, Zoff's resignation has sparked an immediate chorus of "Don't go Dino" from players, politicians and business leaders alike. Berlusconi, sensing that his rightwing coalition - which has made gains in recent elections - could lose some votes, started to backtrack. "This left has really gone all the way," he joked unconvincingly. "Most fans agree with what I said anyway. But let's get real - with the country in the condition it's in, does it seem serious to transform a soccer critique into a state affair?" Which is exactly what the populist rabble-rouser Berlusconi has done. Not that we're knocking it are you listening William Hague?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HELP A DON TODAY

Finances are currently a bit dicey at Aberdeen FC. So much so in fact that chief executive Gordon Bennett (as in "Gordon Bennett!") has today announced he will be forcing players to pay for their own cups of tea and getting rid of their toaster. "We have to run within our means or end up in liquidation," Bennett warned with a smile, as he thought of the 95p he'll save each week by not buying a jar of Mellow Birds.

The Fiver doesn't like to see professional footballers, particularly those of the quality of Andy Dow, go without their soldiers and so we would like to request that any Fiver reader who has a spare piece of electrical equipment - and let's face it yuppie scum, you must have some - they might send it to a Mr Gordon Bennett, Pittodrie Street, Aberdeen, AB24 5QH.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CHOCKS HOWAY!

Pay attention! Squadron leader Fiver here, with some dashed important news for you all, so buck up and buckle down. See this blackboard to my right covered in pointy arrows? Yes? Well this represents the transfer activities of club A and club B. But for our purposes, we'll call them Newcastle and Spurs.

Now club A, that's Newcastle, have a strong interest in Belgian johnny Emile Mpenza. I will denote him with an X. According to reports in the North East, manager Bobby Robson and chairman Freddie Shepherd are today in Germany (I think we all know where that is, what?!) talking over an £8m move with his club FC Schalke. But according to reports in London, which I will denote with an X, Spurs are hoping to hijack the deal. Hijack! Where?

According to my chappie on the inside, person X would prefer a move to destination X, a transfer I will denote with an X. "Emile told me that Schalke is OK but he doesn't feel very comfortable in Germany", whispered Belgian agent Marc Wilmots. "He would like to sign the contract with Tottenham within the next few days."

Which could leave Newcastle fishing in the canal with a spatula. But, be prepared, cub scout law, Newcastle have a dashed cunning back-up plan. Yes, they have Wimbledon's Carl Cort in their cross hairs. Like Mpenza, this chappy bunks in Lanky House, so I will denote his long legs with an X. But, and I will denote this back door banditry with an X, the jolly Magpies face competition from a rival club who want to sign not only Cort but Dons full-back Ben Thatcher too.

"We are not denying we have been speaking to Wimbledon and it is true that we have an offer on the table," said the director of football at this mystery club. "We are waiting to see if the bid is accepted so that we can speak to the players." But who are these bally fiends, whom I will denote with an X? Why none other than the Hotspurs of Tottenham. Yes, the very same! So X +X times X minus X = X. But keep it to yourselves - careless talk costs quids don't you know.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I thought Desailly had become a man, but he's remained a horse, trotting along with blinkers on. They (the French team) had no respect for the defeated. They are extremely arrogant." Italy's Fabio Cannavaro certainly isn't bitter.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE LEGACY OF LONELY NIC

Robert Pires's move to Arsenal had been called off more times than Filippo Inzaghi when the French international winger finally signed for the Gunners yesterday and said: "The past month [ie 24 hours] has been a dream for me. First to win Euro 2000 and now to join such a great club as Arsenal." These remarks warmed the hearts of miserable Gooners everywhere, who had thought that the 26-year-old would rather have played for Madrid. Which is obviously preposterous.

"I would have preferred to have played for Real Madrid," Pires said today, as he opened his heart to slightly obsessive Spanish sports daily Marca. webTitle: Tesco denies that it's in Real talks

fields.headline: Tesco denies that it's in Real talks
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Talk that Tesco is about to make a major acquisition just refuses to go away. Earlier this year the share price of Britain's leading supermarket was badly hit on speculation of a bid for Marks & Spencer.
fields.body:
Talk that Tesco is about to make a major acquisition just refuses to go away. Earlier this year the share price of Britain's leading supermarket was badly hit on speculation of a bid for Marks & Spencer.

Now the group's shares are in trouble again. At one point yesterday they fell by more than 6% before recovering to close at 201.5p, 3.5p lower on the day, following reports over the weekend that it was in advanced talks to buy Germany's biggest hypermarket chain, Real.

At a time when all the leading food retailers are looking to bulk up across Europe's mature markets, the acquisition of Real, owned by Swiss group Metro, would give the company a major presence at the heart of Europe's biggest economy. Analysts at Goldman Sachs point out that there would be a strategic fit with the business Tesco is building in Poland, and it would also represent a setback for Wal-Mart's European ambitions.

Nevertheless, it is difficult to see how the acquisition of Real fits neatly with Tesco's stated aims of expansion in eastern Europe and Asia and via the Internet. As analysts are quick to point out, Tesco has been good at keeping its word.

At the reported purchase price of £3bn, Tesco would be paying around 60% of sales, a high price according to Goldman Sachs for an asset where earnings have been under pressure. Limited synergies and the competitive retailing environment in Germany would most likely make a deal dilutive, Goldman said.

Yet, at a time of increasing consolidation across the European food retailing market following the arrival of Wal-Mart from the United States and the merger of French groups Carrefour and Promodes, Tesco is probably wise to never to say never.

While Real is not a priority for Tesco, it may have taken the view that if it does not buy it somebody else will. Wal-Mart is widely rumoured to have held talks with Metro.

Tesco shares are now 20p off their year high and yesterday's dip may provide a good buying opportunity especially if, as more sceptical market watchers point out, the Real speculation is no more than an artificial attempt to close the discount at which Metro shares trade to the company's sum-of-the-parts valuation.

webTitle: Relatives 'too scared to identify Dover victims'

fields.headline: Relatives 'too scared to identify Dover victims'
fields.trailText: Only one of the 58 Chinese people who suffocated in a lorry at Dover last month has been positively identified, leading to fears that the others may be buried in anonymous graves, Guardian Unlimited has learned.
fields.body:
Only one of the 58 Chinese people who suffocated in a lorry at Dover last month has been positively identified, leading to fears that the others may be buried in anonymous graves, Guardian Unlimited has learned.

The investigation into the deaths has been making steady progress with several arrests in Britain and the Netherlands, but the task of identifying the victims is taking much longer.

Tan Wah Piow, a London-based lawyer who has been in touch with seven people whose family members were on the lorry, says relatives of the dead are reluctant to come forward because of their own dubious legal status, having almost certainly been smuggled into Britain themselves. Mr Tan believes that at least one-third of the victims had relatives here, probably more. He says he is in contact with a man whose brother died at Dover two weeks ago but he is too afraid to come forward.

The Home Office, which does not want be seen as a soft touch for asylum seekers, refuses to make special allowances for the victims' relatives. "There can be no possibility of granting general amnesties to those who may or may not be in a position to identify the bodies," an official said.

Mr Tan has suggested to government officials that the police should give him photographs of the dead to enable relatives to look at them, but to no avail. The Home Office declined to comment on specific ideas but said it would be guided by the police, while Kent police say any decision on ideas for identification would have to be taken at the political level. Identification is not made easier by the fact that none of the victims carried documentation, although the two survivors can presumably provide some information. The police believe they are close to identifying about half of the dead.

For the time being the bodies in Dover lie in limbo, with the relatives in the UK reluctant to come forward. "They cannot afford to jeopardise their status here," Mr Tan said. "They are all working and the last thing their families want is for the living relatives to be returned to China."

Since he became involved in this case, Mr Tan has come across similar horror stories. He recently learned of a case in which a Chinese woman died when she fell off a lorry. The body remained unclaimed because her husband, who is in Britain, was too afraid to come forward.

Mr Tan, who left Singapore in 1976 to avoid national service, says he is baffled by the government's stance. "The Home Office has adopted a strange position," he says. "I still can't comprehend why it wants immigrants to identify themselves before they are allowed to see the corpses." Because of the international dimension, Mr Tan says, China is now clamping down on information at the village level. "Journalists have been removed from Fujian province and it is difficult to get information."

Chinese police officers from Fujian province, where the dead are thought to have originated, arrived in Britain last week to help with the inquiries and Kent police say they think their Chinese colleagues know some of the names of the dead.

Britain is a popular target with Chinese asylum seekers - more asylum seekers come to Britain from China than any country - and 575 arrived here last month. The gangs that organise Chinese illegal migration, known as snakeheads, are believed to have targeted western Europe in greater numbers after a recent clampdown in Canada and the US.

A small number of migrants flee for political reasons, fearing that they will be detained, often without trial, because of their association with illegal protest organisations or religious groups such as the banned Falun Gong. But most economic migrants come from south China, particularly the coastal provinces of Guangdong, Fujian and Zhejiang. Would-be migrants typically pay up to £20,000 for the snakeheads to take them out China.

The 58 who arrived in Dover would have felt that they had safely completed their odyssey after reaching British soil. Now their bodies lie unclaimed. "Unless families come forward, the corpses are going to turn cold before long," Mr Tan said, adding that the coroner was free to dispose of them as he wished. "They can be buried or be given away for scientific experiments."

webTitle: Argentine relatives seek damages over Belgrano sinking

fields.headline: Argentine relatives seek damages over Belgrano sinking
fields.trailText: Britain was taken to court today by relatives of 323 Argentine sailors who died when the light cruiser General Belgrano was sunk during the Falklands war.
fields.body:
Britain was taken to court today by relatives of 323 Argentine sailors who died when the light cruiser General Belgrano was sunk during the Falklands war.

The families claimed at the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg that Britain broke war conventions by torpedoing the Belgrano. According to one of the two Argentine lawyers bringing the case, Jorge Olivera, the attack was intended to frustrate peace negotiations being brokered at the time by Peru.

"The sinking of this ship was outside of the 200-mile exclusion zone established by the British around the archipelago," he said. "At no time did the Argentine cruiser enter the exclusion zone." It was not immediately clear under which articles of the European Human Rights Convention the lawyers were bringing the complaint.

The ship, a survivor of Pearl Harbour, was sunk by three torpedoes on May 2, 1982, after being tracked for 36 hours by the British nuclear submarine HMS Conqueror. The casualties represented nearly half of Argentina's losses in its attempt to take over the islands it calls the Malvinas, which cluster at the base of South America.

Tam Dalyell, the Labour MP who was one of a small group of backbenchers who protested about the sinking at the time and who helped uncover the truth about the sinking, backed the relatives' account.

"Mrs Thatcher did not want to be denied a military victory - which was what the Falklands war was more about than helping the Falklanders," he said.

However, the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, questioned the need for the case. "If the relatives feel such action is necessary that is a matter for them, but we must not forget that, at the time, Britain was at war with Argentina," he said.

The Falklands war claimed around 1,000 lives before British forces regained control of the islands. Argentina never sought damages against Britain after the war. After nearly a decade of icy relations, the two countries restored diplomatic relations in 1990, although Argentina still maintains its claim to the islands.

fields.headline: How to beat travel sickness
fields.trailText: Prevention and Treatment
fields.body:
Prevention

Always travel so your eyes will see the same motion that your body and inner ears feel. Look out of the window as much as possible.

Place children in a high car seat so that they can look out.

Sit by the window in a plane and go up on deck on a ship.

Don't read, but look at distant scenery. Avoid facing backward.

Make sure your car is well ventilated. Don't travel on an empty stomach. A high carbohydrate snack, such as a bowl of cereal, is recommended. Avoid food with strong odours and anything greasy.

Get the sick bag ready when... Your children look sleepy or apathetic. Look out for signs of pallor, headache, sweating and drooling. Older children will be able to complain that they feel nauseous.

Treatment

Drugs

Over-the-counter treatments contain hyocine and antihistamines, and offer good protection. They can, however, make you drowsy and aren't usually suitable for children under three. Best taken 20 minutes before travel.

Acupressure wrist bands

A popular non-drug alternative thought to work by stimulating acupuncture points in the wrists. Anecdotal evidence as to their effectiveness abounds, but there's little scientific proof. In one Italian study in 1990, a doctor in Milan distributed wristbands to the parents of children aged 2-15 known to suffer travel sickness. In 55 cases (88.7%) the results were excellent. In the remaining cases there were moderate improvements. At around £7.50 a pair they are a costly try-it-and-see. Sea Bands make them in child sizes. They need to be positioned accurately, which is bad news if your child is likely to fiddle with them.

Homeopathic remedies

Nelson Travella is a formulated remedy with ingredients including theridion, tabacum, petroleum, cocculus and nux vomica. Can be safely used for children of all ages. Little scientific evidence to support claims. Start to take two hours before travelling and then hourly. Available from Boots, £4.20.

Herbal treatments

Good evidence that ginger might work. Chew on pieces of crystallised ginger, or if your child does not like the taste give them ginger tablets to swallow. Available from health food stores.

Aromatherapy

Peppermint oil has been thought to settle the stomach. Sprinkle some on a hankie and sniff. Only for children over one.

Travelwell

A new audio tape which is meant to desensitise the vestibular system in the inner ear. Special frequencies and pulses are apparently concealed within the music, but it has received no firm scientific backing so far. Must be played on a personal stereo. Can be used for children. Available from Boots, £9.99. For details go to www.travelwell.co.uk.

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: Matthew Norman: I suppose it's the down side to being one of Britain's elite corps of semi- professional hypochondriacs, but tonight at dinner a slight acquaintance speared an artichoke heart into her mouth, looked me in the eye and said: "By the way, Matthew, how is your bottom?"
fields.body:
Tuesday
I suppose it's the down side to being one of Britain's elite corps of semi- professional hypochondriacs, but tonight at dinner a slight acquaintance speared an artichoke heart into her mouth, looked me in the eye and said: "By the way, Matthew, how is your bottom?" After the momentary shock had worn off a more acute sense of amazement struck when the answer came to me. "Funny you should ask, but it's absolutely fine," I said very slowly, a little punch drunk from the unfamiliarity of the sentiment. "Never been better."

Wednesday
Awake nervy and distrait after a typically troubled night, feeling threatened by some nebulous foe. For many years, as I often had cause to observe, my bowels have been not so much irritable as psychotic, perhaps borderline sociopathic. As for haemorrhoids, all I will say is that if Anusol had a frequent user scheme, I might be on some Caribbean beach now at the company's expense. At the moment, however, I am weighed down by the knowledge that merely by noting the dearth of pain - something I ascribe to a new, healthy diet - is a stamped self-addressed invitation to fate that fate is unlikely to turn down.

Thursday
The RSVP envelope arrived by first post. The pile is tucked away about a quarter inch up the rectum, on the right hand side. It throbs a little.

Friday
The pile is unchanged, and in a stable condition - certainly more stable than me. Yet there is nothing new about this awesome psychosomatic power to create symptoms. Once, when I was 20 and convinced that I required a new heart, I spontaneously developed a water swelling or oedema on the left ankle - something I had no conscious idea was a classic symptom of coronary disease. By this standard, a pile is nothing.

Saturday
The pile has doubled in size and in pain overnight. "Oh for God's sakes," says Rebecca when I update her, "if it's that bad why don't you call Sarah and pop round to her emergency surgery?" The truth is that I can't... I can no longer consult my personal physician Dr Sarah Jarvis about any matter that requires the donning of latex gloves. We have simply broken bread together too often for internal examinations to pass in the cheery, matter of fact, nothing-more- natural-in-the-world manner of old.

Sunday
While she is preparing the traditional Sunday lunch (I doubt there's a home cook in the country who can heat up a quarter pounder with cheese and large fries like my wife), Rebecca's patience with my moaning runs dry and irritably she tosses off a psychological theory. "If it was thinking about the absence of anything wrong that brought on the piles (that plural is correct; the second arrived this morning), why don't you find something else that's all right to worry about and they might go away?"

It sounds crazy, but what harm can it do? "OK," I say, "but what?" "I don't know, something inanimate. The mobile phone? Or the car had its service last week, and that's going well? Or the microwave? Oh my God, the micro..." While she is removing the melted polystyrene boxes with a pair of plastic tongs, I head for the phone to call Domino's.

Monday
Rebecca's mental trick seems to have worked. Yesterday evening, I transferred the object of my neurosing to a different area, and although both piles remain, the original is smaller and has ceased to throb, while Johnny Come Lately has shrunk even more markedly. "Do you know, I think you could be onto something," I tell Rebecca when I ring from the mobile this evening. "I'll take rooms in Harley Street," she says, almost pleasantly. "By the way, I thought I'd get fish and chips for supper. How long do you think you'll be?" "I don't know," I tell her. "The AA said they could be anything up to an hour and a half."

fields.headline: The great egg race
fields.standfirst: One in 80 babies in this country is now born with laboratory help. But how has infertility treatment become such big business when there is little evidence that we are becoming less fertile?  Sarah Boseley  reports
fields.trailText: One in 80 babies in this country is now born with laboratory help. But how has infertility treatment become such big business when there is little evidence that we are becoming less fertile? Sarah Boseley reports
fields.body:
Bologna, the Italian city famous for having more arcades than anywhere else in Europe, also had probably the largest collection of fertility experts anywhere on the planet last week. A glance at the crowded lecture theatres of Bologna's conference centre would suggest they must be proliferating faster than embryo cells can divide.

If there is a growth industry within medicine, this is it. The European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology, whose annual conference this was, was buzzing with the excitement of being at the cutting edge. Only 20 years since the birth of Louise Brown, the first test-tube baby, the technology has galloped ahead so fast that one baby in around 80 in the UK is now born with laboratory help, while in the Nordic countries, it is one in 50.

What does this say about human fertility? In spite of millions of years of practice, are we losing the ability to make babies in the ordinary way of the species? There are some who say we are.

Environmentalists point the finger at sperm counts, which some studies have shown to be dropping. There are huge anxieties over the effects of "gender-bending" chemicals - scientifically known as endocrine disruptors. These are man-made substances used in plastics, dyes, solvents, resins, paints, plastic containers, detergents and pharmaceuticals. They are highly pollutant, break down very slowly and accumulate in the fatty tissues of the human body.

Worst of all, they mimic the female hormone oestrogen or interfere with the male hormone testosterone. Birds and fish living in areas such as near paper mills, where quantities of these chemicals are released into the water, have been found to have reproductive defects. WWF (the World Wide Fund for Nature) believes that there is sufficient evidence to indict these pollutants for some male infertility problems, such as declining sperm counts.

But scientific studies have not yet come up with clear answers. Some have shown alarming drops in the numbers and motility (swimming ability) of sperm. Others have not. While some European studies suggest drops of 50% or more in the second half of the 20th century, a major American study from the Keck school of medicine at the University of Southern California, published in March, found nothing of the sort. Semen samples from 1,385 men who were seeking fertility treatment between 1994 and 1997 - a group that might be expected to have low sperm counts - turned out to have more than the usual amount of abnormalities in their sperm, but sperm quantities no different from the average in the 1950s.

Furthermore, all these men were blue collar workers who would have been more likely than most to be exposed to industrial pollutants in their jobs. The Medical Research Council's reproductive biology unit in Scotland is now embarking on a major study to try to find some definitive answers, recruiting 1,000 men to send in samples of their sperm by post for analysis.

There has been some evidence that sperm counts rise as well as fall over the years, and that high counts result in high birth rates. Some say particular professional groups are more likely to have problems - the wives of taxi drivers and lorry drivers whose scrotums overheat during the hours on the road are said to have more problems than most. But the same should go for any sedentary lifestyle. Tight pants have also been blamed. While there is every reason to worry about the effects of polluting chemicals on the planet, most fertility doctors tend to dismiss suggestions that falling sperm counts are a reason for their rapidly increasing workload. Lord Winston, in his book "Making Babies", says: "There is very little serious evidence at all that men are less fertile now than they used to be." Not only were sperm counting techniques entirely different in the 1950s - the period usually used as the baseline - but also the social and economic background of men that attended fertility clinics, he says.

Last month a study in the Lancet medical journal turned the argument on its head when it reported that couples were conceiving faster than they used to. Michael Joffe, an epidemiologist at Imperial College school of medicine in London, interviewed 646 men and 894 women aged 16 to 59, asking them to recall how long it took to achieve their first pregnancy. While he admits that asking people to think back four decades is not foolproof, he found a clear trend that more women were conceiving within four to six months of trying for a baby in the early 90s than they were in the early 60s - 80% compared with 65%. They are not having more or better sex (some experts believe orgasm is more likely to lead to conception), Joffe says - they have better timing. Couples today more often try to have sex on the days the woman is ovulating.

"Another conclusion should be that, at present, the near-panic sometimes expressed in the lay press about the effects of environmental pollution on sperm quality and male fertility is not justified," said an editorial in the Lancet. That was Egbert de Velde's view at the Bologna conference. The Dutch gynaecologist was deeply concerned that couples are rushing into fertility treatment that is not only expensive but can be dangerous. Women have died from hyper-stimulation - the effects of the chemical battering given to their ovaries to make them produce more than the normal one egg in a cycle.

"A lot of couples who have tried for half a year give up, thinking it is not normal and rush to do the fertility thing. Because infertility, especially in the US, is extremely commercialised, they are accepted with open arms. I think that is a development that is regrettable because a lot of couples, if they had waited - not for many years but for another year - would have quite a big chance of conceiving spontaneously without all the risks and complications of IVF," says de Velde.

Commercially, IVF is big news. There were more than 200,000 treatment cycles of IVF and ICSI (the technique where a single sperm is injected into an egg) carried out in Europe in 1997, at a cost to the individual or the state of around £3,000 a time. Organon, Serono and the other big names involved in fertility drugs were big sponsors of the Bologna jamboree.

If there is a panic rush to the clinics, as Dr de Velde believes, it is being fuelled by an awareness of the ticking clock. With every year that passes, a woman's chances of having a child get slimmer - especially past the age of 35. In the UK, fertility treatment is another postcode lottery - in some areas couples can have a cycle or two of treatment on the NHS. In others, there is nothing or an endless waiting list. The huge cost of treatment is to blame - health authorities blanche at the thought of the hole in their budget that would be created if everybody was to be funded.

Clare Brown, president of the International Federation of Infertility Patient Associations (IFIPA) and also executive director of CHILD, the UK support organisation, is wary of telling women to wait. "Up to 34, once you have been trying for a year or so and there is nothing, you should at least start to get the ball rolling," she says. "Over 35 you should not wait longer than six months or so. You are going to be investigated first. That can take time."

In her view, even if sperm counts are declining, it is just as likely that we are hearing more about infertility - and therefore assuming there is more of it - because of all the treatments that are now available. Couples with problems now come forward when they would have hidden away. "In the past, they wouldn't have said they didn't have children because they were infertile. They would have said, 'If it doesn't happen, it doesn't happen,'" says Brown.

At the IFIPA stand in Bologna, she was amazed by the doctors from Indonesia, Mexico, Iran and elsewhere who arrived to talk about the need for support groups for the infertile in their own country - not because there are more of them than there have ever been, but because the treatments are becoming available for the first time.

We have had them for 21 years now, when the UK led the world with the birth of Louise Brown. And yet now the UK has one of the worst records in Europe for enabling the childless to get help. Health authorities have diverse criteria for paying for treatment - if they do it at all. Some will bar a couple if they have previously paid for a failed attempt privately themselves - even if they spent their life savings or borrowed to the hilt to do so. "It is totally unfair," says Brown.

In the rapidly advancing world of fertility treatment, there is huge excitement, great promise and the most terrible misery for many couples. At Bologna it was clear that technology is advancing at a terrific rate. But how many of the infertile are going to be able to afford what the scientists have to offer?

fields.headline: Pass the sickbag...
fields.standfirst: There's nothing quite like a long car journey with a child - or even an adult - suffering from travel sickness. But why do we get ill on the move? And how can we prevent it?  Jane Bartlett reports
fields.trailText: There's nothing quite like a long car journey with a child - or even an adult - suffering from travel sickness. But why do we get ill on the move? And how can we prevent it? Jane Bartlett reports
fields.body:
There is one thing I can never have too many of when I am on a long car journey with my children. Plastic bags. Two of my three young ones suffer acutely from what researchers in space and aeronautical medicine call "sense spatial disorientation" - travel sickness, in other words. On a recent six-hour car journey to Cornwall we managed to get through seven changes of clothing, and by the time we arrived they were sitting in the back naked. At least the four-year-old can now ask for a bag when he feels the urge to regurgitate the contents of his tummy, but the toddler explodes without warning, torrents of projectile vomit splattering the back of the driver's seat.

There was one moment of sheer panic when I had to share a bag between them as they simultaneously heaved. So far the baby is immune, but I suspect it is only a matter of time.

Summer holidays are made of such moments. Whether it be boat, car, train or plane, travelling is frequently a stomach churner, especially when it comes to the children. Apparently up to 90% of us suffer from travel sickness at some stage, a harmless but deeply unpleasant condition that does no favours for your car's upholstery. According to recent research by the Gallup Organisation, boats are the worst: 70% of the people interviewed had felt queasy on a boat, 60% in a car and 57% in a bus or coach.

Researchers believe that our sense of balance is to blame. It is maintained by a complex interaction within the nervous system, which involves four different processes: the inner ear which monitors the directions of motion; the eyes which tell you where you are in space and the directions of your motions; skin pressure receptors which tell you which bits of your body are touching the ground or a seat; and muscles and joint sensory receptors which tell which bits of your body are moving. The central nervous system endeavours to make sense of all this information.

The symptoms of travel sickness appear when the central nervous system receives conflicting information from its messengers. Basically, your body is being thrown around but your eyes do not detect the motion.

John Golding, a psychologist at the University of Westminster, who researches motion sickness for the Medical Research Council, says that animals get it too. In fact it occurs right down the evolutionary chain to frogs; even fish can get seasick if their aquarium is transported around. "It's likely to have some sort of evolutionary survival purpose," he says.

One theory is that feeling disorientated by motion sets off a type of toxin detector designed to protect us from consuming poisons. The sensations of feeling off balance and dizzy are similar to those we might experience when we've consumed something toxic (too much alcohol for example). "It's the exact calibration of the imbalance you feel when poisoned," says Golding.

Children are more susceptible than adults, especially between the ages of 8 to 13. Younger children are less likely to get it because their sense of balance has not yet stabilised. "After that the system of calibration probably gets tuned up, but there are individual differences," says Golding. Women are slightly more prone to it than men, and get extra queasy when pregnant or menstruating.

Oddly, you are unlikely to feel nauseous riding a horse, but take the sick bag if it's a camel. Our urge to throw up is affected by the vibrational frequency of the mode of transport. Fast, short jerky motions which have a high frequency are less distressing than long, swaying motions which move at a lower frequency. Going round bends and roundabouts lowers the frequency, which is why a long a winding road is almost sure to get the children going.

The good news is that we learn to adapt long-term to motion, which is why children tend to grow out of it eventually. We also adapt short term, getting our sea legs, as the sailors would say. In fact we can adapt so well that some people who have been at sea for an extended period feel sick when they are back on land.

How to beat travel sickness

Prevention
Always travel so your eyes will see the same motion that your body and inner ears feel. Look out of the window as much as possible.

Place children in a high car seat so that they can look out.

Sit by the window in a plane and go up on deck on a ship.

Don't read, but look at distant scenery. Avoid facing backward.

Make sure your car is well ventilated. Don't travel on an empty stomach. A high carbohydrate snack, such as a bowl of cereal, is recommended. Avoid food with strong odours and anything greasy.

Get the sick bag ready when... Your children look sleepy or apathetic. Look out for signs of pallor, headache, sweating and drooling. Older children will be able to complain that they feel nauseous.

Treatment

Drugs
Over-the-counter treatments contain hyocine and antihistamines, and offer good protection. They can, however, make you drowsy and aren't usually suitable for children under three. Best taken 20 minutes before travel.

Acupressure wrist bands
A popular non-drug alternative thought to work by stimulating acupuncture points in the wrists. Anecdotal evidence as to their effectiveness abounds, but there's little scientific proof. In one Italian study in 1990, a doctor in Milan distributed wristbands to the parents of children aged 2-15 known to suffer travel sickness. In 55 cases (88.7%) the results were excellent. In the remaining cases there were moderate improvements. At around £7.50 a pair they are a costly try-it-and-see. Sea Bands make them in child sizes. They need to be positioned accurately, which is bad news if your child is likely to fiddle with them.

Homeopathic remedies
Nelson Travella is a formulated remedy with ingredients including theridion, tabacum, petroleum, cocculus and nux vomica. Can be safely used for children of all ages. Little scientific evidence to support claims. Start to take two hours before travelling and then hourly. Available from Boots, £4.20.

Herbal treatments
Good evidence that ginger might work. Chew on pieces of crystallised ginger, or if your child does not like the taste give them ginger tablets to swallow. Available from health food stores.

Aromatherapy
Peppermint oil has been thought to settle the stomach. Sprinkle some on a hankie and sniff. Only for children over one.

fields.bodyText: There is one thing I can never have too many of when I am on a long car journey with my children. Plastic bags. Two of my three young ones suffer acutely from what researchers in space and aeronautical medicine call "sense spatial disorientation" - travel sickness, in other words. On a recent six-hour car journey to Cornwall we managed to get through seven changes of clothing, and by the time we arrived they were sitting in the back naked. At least the four-year-old can now ask for a bag when he feels the urge to regurgitate the contents of his tummy, but the toddler explodes without warning, torrents of projectile vomit splattering the back of the driver's seat. There was one moment of sheer panic when I had to share a bag between them as they simultaneously heaved. So far the baby is immune, but I suspect it is only a matter of time. Summer holidays are made of such moments. Whether it be boat, car, train or plane, travelling is frequently a stomach churner, especially when it comes to the children. Apparently up to 90% of us suffer from travel sickness at some stage, a harmless but deeply unpleasant condition that does no favours for your car's upholstery. According to recent research by the Gallup Organisation, boats are the worst: 70% of the people interviewed had felt queasy on a boat, 60% in a car and 57% in a bus or coach. Researchers believe that our sense of balance is to blame. It is maintained by a complex interaction within the nervous system, which involves four different processes: the inner ear which monitors the directions of motion; the eyes which tell you where you are in space and the directions of your motions; skin pressure receptors which tell you which bits of your body are touching the ground or a seat; and muscles and joint sensory receptors which tell which bits of your body are moving. The central nervous system endeavours to make sense of all this information. The symptoms of travel sickness appear when the central nervous system receives conflicting information from its messengers. Basically, your body is being thrown around but your eyes do not detect the motion. John Golding, a psychologist at the University of Westminster, who researches motion sickness for the Medical Research Council, says that animals get it too. In fact it occurs right down the evolutionary chain to frogs; even fish can get seasick if their aquarium is transported around. "It's likely to have some sort of evolutionary survival purpose," he says. One theory is that feeling disorientated by motion sets off a type of toxin detector designed to protect us from consuming poisons. The sensations of feeling off balance and dizzy are similar to those we might experience when we've consumed something toxic (too much alcohol for example). "It's the exact calibration of the imbalance you feel when poisoned," says Golding. Children are more susceptible than adults, especially between the ages of 8 to 13. Younger children are less likely to get it because their sense of balance has not yet stabilised. "After that the system of calibration probably gets tuned up, but there are individual differences," says Golding. Women are slightly more prone to it than men, and get extra queasy when pregnant or menstruating. Oddly, you are unlikely to feel nauseous riding a horse, but take the sick bag if it's a camel. Our urge to throw up is affected by the vibrational frequency of the mode of transport. Fast, short jerky motions which have a high frequency are less distressing than long, swaying motions which move at a lower frequency. Going round bends and roundabouts lowers the frequency, which is why a long a winding road is almost sure to get the children going. The good news is that we learn to adapt long-term to motion, which is why children tend to grow out of it eventually. We also adapt short term, getting our sea legs, as the sailors would say. In fact we can adapt so well that some people who have been at sea for an extended period feel sick when they are back on land. How to beat travel sickness Prevention Always travel so your eyes will see the same motion that your body and inner ears feel. Look out of the window as much as possible. Place children in a high car seat so that they can look out. Sit by the window in a plane and go up on deck on a ship. Don't read, but look at distant scenery. Avoid facing backward. Make sure your car is well ventilated. Don't travel on an empty stomach. A high carbohydrate snack, such as a bowl of cereal, is recommended. Avoid food with strong odours and anything greasy. Get the sick bag ready when... Your children look sleepy or apathetic. Look out for signs of pallor, headache, sweating and drooling. Older children will be able to complain that they feel nauseous. Treatment Drugs Over-the-counter treatments contain hyocine and antihistamines, and offer good protection. They can, however, make you drowsy and aren't usually suitable for children under three. Best taken 20 minutes before travel. Acupressure wrist bands A popular non-drug alternative thought to work by stimulating acupuncture points in the wrists. Anecdotal evidence as to their effectiveness abounds, but there's little scientific proof. In one Italian study in 1990, a doctor in Milan distributed wristbands to the parents of children aged 2-15 known to suffer travel sickness. In 55 cases (88.7%) the results were excellent. In the remaining cases there were moderate improvements. At around £7.50 a pair they are a costly try-it-and-see. Sea Bands make them in child sizes. They need to be positioned accurately, which is bad news if your child is likely to fiddle with them. Homeopathic remedies Nelson Travella is a formulated remedy with ingredients including theridion, tabacum, petroleum, cocculus and nux vomica. Can be safely used for children of all ages. Little scientific evidence to support claims. Start to take two hours before travelling and then hourly. Available from Boots, £4.20. Herbal treatments Good evidence that ginger might work. Chew on pieces of crystallised ginger, or if your child does not like the taste give them ginger tablets to swallow. Available from health food stores. fields.headline: A score of successes
fields.standfirst: It was a real challenge picking winners for our BBC Proms competition
fields.trailText: It was a real challenge picking winners for our BBC Proms competition
fields.body:
Launching a competition is rather like holding a party. The envelopes are all licked, the invitations posted and the fretting starts. Will any of you turn up? What cheek to assume that you can't find better ways to spend your time.

On the other hand, if we were going to challenge you, the nation's young composers, to send in your finest wares for appraisal by strangers, we couldn't be doing it with a more prestigious partner than the BBC Proms. Nor could we have wished for a classier endorsement than the blessing of Sir Simon Rattle.

Notwithstanding, the legs were trembling on deadline day - June 1 - during that walk down to the Guardian post room. Needlessly, as it happened.

Four mailsacks groaning with Jiffy bags were plumply hogging the floor. It was truly moving to be entrusted with so much artistic endeavour, the fruits of so much creative toil.

"It takes me 20 minutes to write one bar," revealed Elizabeth Levine, one of the three winners, whose piece, Four Vicious Violins, lasts for 76 bars.

It was soon apparent that you had flooded us with a good deal of impressive music. Judging was going to be hard. And indeed there was some impassioned discussion in that final meeting when the three of us - the composers Gary Carpenter and Andrew Kurowski, and I - met to thrash out the verdicts.

We couldn't just pick three winners. We decided we had to commend a further five. And beyond those were others who were truly impressive and hard to release ungonged. The works submitted to the Guardian/BBC Proms young composers' competition present a reassuring glimpse of the future of music.

"The fact that we ended up with more than three outstanding pieces from the 12 to 16 age range is very encouraging," said Carpenter. "We had entrants, and not just the prize-winners, whose work would be taken seriously by any of the major conservatories."

"I had no idea the entries would be quite as characterful and impressive as they were," said Kurowski. "Some did more predictable things, others really let their imaginations drive them on. Making the decision was difficult because there were so many avenues one could follow, so many reactions one could discover."

So, what marks out the winners? Invention, certainly.

"The refusal to sit back on the laurels of convention," said Carpenter, citing Elizabeth's piece for continuing at every stage to explore and be inventive, and not to surrender to trite solutions. "It takes no prisoners."

Also, technical facility that is at least as advanced as you could expect from youngsters of the winners' ages. Homage to Leo, a sonatina for violin and piano by 12-year-old Lucius Tracy Kelly, displays admirable technique. It won for its "quality of invention and technical acumen".

Composing, like any art, is about taking decisions and not plumping for the easy option. There were many pieces with tasty beginnings - a grabby opening theme, arresting rhythm or beguiling harmony, or any combination - which then ran out of puff. The quality of decisions taken at this crucial junction marked out the potential winners from the rest.

The judges noted that many of you plumped for repetition at this point and kept it up to the end. You were very fond of your recurring basses.

Now there is nothing wrong with this device, which is almost as old as music. It's a great survivor, the ground bass, and fundamental to a number of contemporary musical varieties. But so familiar is it, and so stuffed is music with passacaglia masterpieces, that to win a competition with it requires something special.

We think we heard that in Merlin, by the third winner, Ollie Haydon-Mulligan, who is 14. (Incidentally, there is no gradation of winner: they are all joint first.)

Merlin, for guitar - played by Ollie - and bass and sampled drums is a piece of funky jazz underpinned by a variety of hypnotic recurrent patterns.

"He didn't settle for a conventional drum-bass line, he used the medium," says Carpenter. "He was concerned with decent compositional values. It's a subtle combination of computer and performance."

Ollie, who started playing in a band when still at primary school and now attends Haverstock comprehensive school in north London, revealed that Merlin began "as a mistake".

"I was working on another song and this bass line started happening. It was weird timing and I wasn't sure what was going on. I kept working at it and it sort of developed."

A great many of you used computers, some simply to stand in for instruments and players not available to you. Some used them as a composing tool, which is fine, but compositional values still needed to be observed.

Many of you, quite understandably, used the computer to produce handsome scores, which again had pitfalls. Some scores proved inaccurate - not a factor in the decisions but the judges felt it needed comment, particularly for those of you with professional ambitions.

Elizabeth, who is a pupil at the Purcell School, one of the four specialist music schools in England, is very clear about what she wants to do: "I'd like to be a famous violinist."

Although composing runs in her family - her dad, Alex, is a composer - it comes second to performance for her, and she was surprised to win.

Four Vicious Violins is an unusual title and instrumental combination. "The violin is a sweet instrument. I wanted to explore another side of it."

Lucius says he has been "writing properly" for three years, and is considering composing as a career. Homage to Leo is a memorial to a pet cat who died. Its three dance movements, waltz, ballet and pavane, portray Leo. "He was a very playful, bright and active cat," Lucius says.

The winning entries can be enjoyed on Radio 3, which is broadcasting a programme about the competition during the interval of the Prom on Tuesday July 18. The concert starts at 7pm and the interval broadcast at 7.35pm.

Elizabeth and Lucius turn out to share the same teacher, Alison Cox, head of composition at the Purcell School. Lucius, who attends Colet Court School in Barnes, west London, goes to Alison's home for lessons.

She deserves credit for the high standards of the dozen or so entries from Purcell pupils and it is fascinating to hear her discussing teaching methods. Well aware of the heavy burden on class music teachers and loath to criticise, she feels nevertheless that more training in composition-teaching is needed. "We are the only country in the world where every school child does composing, but sadly there is a shortage of teachers who really know how to teach it."

There is also a serious dearth of opportunity for young composers in the 12-16 age group to compete with one another. "The Guardian/BBC Proms competition responds to that need wonderfully."

The winners - which you can hear by clicking on the titles, providing you have Real Audio installed on your browser (free from the Real Audio website):

Ollie Haydon-Mulligan, 14, of Haverstock School, London NW1: Merlin
Lucius Tracy Kelly, 12, of Colet Court School, London SW13: Homage to Leo
Elizabeth Levine, 14, of The Purcell School, Bushey, Herts: Four Vicious Violins

Commended by the judges

Alex Campkin, 15, of Westminster School, London SW1: MRI Brain Scan
Melissa Daly, 15, of The Purcell School: On The Subject of Anthropods
Jason Noghari, 15, of The Purcell School: Wind Quintet
Ryan Penfold, 14, of The Purcell School: Trio for clarinet, bassoon and piano
Paul Wilson, 15, of St Peter's School, York: Interlude for viola and piano

webTitle: Trimble calls for end to Drumcree violence

fields.headline: Trimble calls for end to Drumcree violence
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland's first minister David Trimble today condemned the loyalist violence which has erupted around Drumcree in the last two nights, but criticised the parades commission for rewarding local residents' "intransigence" in opposing the Orangemen's parade.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's first minister David Trimble today condemned the loyalist violence which has erupted around Drumcree in the last two nights, but criticised the parades commission for rewarding local residents' "intransigence" in opposing the Orangemen's parade.

After a meeting with the parades commission - which yesterday banned Portadown Orangemen from marching down the Nationalist Garvaghy Road next Sunday - the Ulster Unionist leader said violence would not advance any cause. Mr Trimble said: "Whatever decisions I've taken, there is no place for violence and riot and the incidents that we have seen over the last few days."

However, Mr Trimble, who is MP for the Portadown area, said he was "very disappointed" that the parades commission did not act on a proposal from Portadown unionist councillors which he said would have helped resolve the Drumcree crisis in a fair way.

The councillors had proposed that a parade go ahead on Garvaghy Road, but that it be followed on Monday by a civic forum involving both Orangemen and Garvaghy residents to negotiate a long-term resolution.

Mr Trimble said he understood the commission's intention in holding out a "vague offer" of a future parade. But he said their ruling had been too ambiguous.

"The commission had made the mistake of rewarding intransigence by saying they cannot envisage circumstances in which there will be a walk without local accommodation." That had been a critical mistake and as a result a great opportunity had been lost.

Mr Trimble also criticised Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party for trying to exacerbate the situation by holding a debate in the assembly today calling for the expulsion of Sinn Fein. "I am afraid we are seeing here again irresponsible action from the DUP," he said.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson described the violence at Drumcree as "thuggery - nothing more, nothing less".

He said no amount of violence would force a change in the decision to ban Sunday's parade.

Mr Mandelson said: "It is not what the vast majority of people in Northern Ireland want. It is not what the vast majority of members of the Orange Order want and they like me will support the police in whatever action they need to take to deal with this thuggery."

A Portadown parade banned from the Garvaghy Road several years ago was eventually forced through after days of loyalist violence across the province. But Mr Mandelson warned: "Nobody by force of arm, use of violence, by bullying and intimidation is going to get any change of any decision, any law, any conclusion, that I, the parades commission or anyone else will have reached."

Meanwhile Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams appealed to unionist political and community leaders to put pressure on the Orangemen to end the Drumcree protest. He also said nationalists throughout Northern Ireland should remain calm but vigilant over the coming days.

Speaking at Stormont ahead of the DUP-inspired debate to exclude Sinn Fein from the power-sharing executive, Mr Adams said: "I think people have to remain vigilant.

"They have to remain calm. I would say to them even though they are under siege and under curfew, to try and see the big picture.

"There are big changes coming. But the bigots and rejectionists cannot stop the changes."

fields.headline: Cannabis research produces pain breakthrough
fields.standfirst: Abstract of the article in Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience
fields.trailText: Chemicals in cannabis could be used to relieve pain without causing the patient to get high, researchers have shown.
fields.body:
Chemicals in cannabis could be used to relieve pain without causing the patient to get high, researchers have shown.

A team of British scientists has demonstrated that cannabinoids, the active ingredient in cannabis, acts on the spinal cord as well as the brain.

The discovery paves the way for new cannabinoid-based drugs to be developed which target the spinal cord to fight pain but by-pass the brain and so do not cause the euphoric high associated with the drug.

Dr Andrew Rice, a member of the team based at Imperial college, London, said: "We have achieved a really important step in terms of divorcing the psychoactive side-effects of cannabis from their pain-relieving effects.

"In order to develop clinically useful drugs based on cannabis, it is important to show that the receptors for cannabinoids are found in the spinal cord, particularly the areas concerned with pain processing. And that's what we've done."

He said the potential for cannabis in pain relief could be developed in several ways.

Drugs based on cannabinoids could be developed which lock on to spinal receptor molecules, or they could be delivered directly to the spinal cord.

The research was reported in the journal Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience.

In the 1970s morphine-like opioid receptors were also shown to be present in the spinal cord. This led to epidural pain killers, commonly used during childbirth, after surgery and for chronic and cancer pain.

Cannabinoids may be better pain relievers than morphine in cases where nerve injury caused opioid receptors in the spinal cord to disappear, said Dr Rice.

webTitle: Pagan worship, yobs and cheese rolling - a glimpse of Britain through US eyes

fields.headline: Pagan worship, yobs and cheese rolling - a glimpse of Britain through US eyes
fields.standfirst: Today Americans celebrate their independence from the British. But, two centuries on, what do they really think of us? Not much, if a new film is anything to go by, reports  Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: Today Americans celebrate their independence from the British. But, two centuries on, what do they really think of us? Not much, if a new film is anything to go by, reports Duncan Campbell
fields.body:
It took place appropriately enough on Lincoln Boulevard in Los Angeles. There, outside the Cock 'n' Bull pub, in all its expat Union Jack-bedecked splendour, was the local fire brigade engaged in an angry argument with a group of English football fans. The firefighters were telling the fans that the pub was now so full of supporters wanting to watch the live Euro 2000 game that they could not enter, for to do so would create a fire hazard. To make it worse, some fans who had stepped outside for a cigarette - smoking being banned in all bars in California - found themselves excluded, too.

There we had it. Two nations forever intertwined by their shared history staring hard at each other's caricatures: the boozy, football-loving, loser Brit and the big, self-important, bully Yank.

That same night we were treated to two more equally cherished caricatures when The Patriot (pictured), in which Mel Gibson plays the part of a militiaman fighting for independence from Britain, opened in time for July 4 and Independence Day. There were the heroic, democratic American winners and - boo! hiss! - there were the cruel, sadistic British losers.

A year ago, after moving to Los Angeles and flicking between television news stations to see if I was missing anything, I noted that in two weeks there was only one item of news about the UK. It was a report of a "cheese race" in the Cotswolds in which ruddy-faced locals ran and tumbled down a hill in pursuit of a large cheese. As I switched between the 75 channels available, it became clear that almost every news programme had bought this item. "Those English," chuckled one news anchor. It was a reminder of where Britain fitted on the national radar - a distant eccentric blip somewhere in the outer atmosphere.

The Fourth of July is as good a time as any to consider the state of the relationship between our two nations. I don't think it's giving away too much of the plot to say that The Patriot is essentially a transatlantic Braveheart. It's an important history lesson. Reporting on Stonehenge last year, the New York Times headlined its story: "The stiff upper lip quivers in the teeth of an eclipse." Now the waves have started again. The British embassy in Washington estimates there are around 2m Britons in the US. The British consulate in LA reckons there are as many as 500,000 people with British connections in southern California doing jobs across the spectrum. There are Brits in the entertainment business and now a sizeable number working - some illegally - in construction where, as one carpenter informed me, you can work all year round because of the weather as long as you don't mind getting up at 7am on a Saturday so you can watch Premiership games live in the pub.

When Brits hit California they can have conflicting emotions. The English novelist Christopher Isherwood writes in his diaries in 1940 of an attack of self-pity when at a dude ranch in Yucca Loma. He told his friend: "I hate all Americans. I don't belong here. I shall have to go back to Europe." But he revised his views: "Actually, in my sane moments I love this country. I love it just because I don't belong here, because I'm not involved in its traditions, not born under the curse of its history. I feel free here. I'm on my own. My life will be what I make of it." Scotsman Robert Louis Stevenson, writing 60 years earlier than that, spoke of the American as "the coming man" and in a poem tells him: "You speak another tongue than mine/Though both were English born./I towards the night of time decline/You mount into the morn."

Poor, dear, old Britain seems to be the current view from here, declining fast into the night, breathlessly recounting her little Oscar triumphs and still imagining that a British accent makes a person more interesting. "These colonials are our brethren," Lord Cornwallis (Tom Wilkinson) remarks in The Patriot, as he contemplates the latest atrocity carried out on the Americans by the evil Colonel Tavington (Jason Isaacs). But how much do we each still feel we are each other's brethren?

Looking back at the old Manchester Guardian it is clear that we have battled this problem for years. In 1956, DW Brogan was telling readers about the "Elvis the Pelvis phenomenon" and recounting how "the American people have, like us, a great many serious things to think about right now but one of the less serious, if not totally unimportant things, they debate is the Elvis phenomenon... in a muddled and often angry frame of mind. But back to the big screen. The Patriot opens at a time that Robert Altman is having a retrospective of his films, including Nashville, which was made around the bicentennial celebrations of the revolution. It included that wonderful, satirical and specially written song We Must Be Doing Something Right To Last 200 Years which summed up America's mock-modest national self-importance. Talking about the film at a public gathering in LA, Altman said that when John Lennon was killed a few years later, "I got a call from the Washington Post asking if I felt responsible, because there was an assassination of a celebrity in my film. I said 'That's what the film's about. Do you feel responsible for not heeding my warning?'" Which goes to show that one of the two main British criticisms of Americans - that they have no sense of irony - should have been disposed of years ago.

The other criticism - that they can't make tea - is, sadly, true. But that, as those of us who learned about American history at school will know, is how this whole damn thing started.

webTitle: Queen's cash freeze is long overdue

fields.headline: Queen's cash freeze is long overdue
fields.standfirst: Cap-doffing to a generous monarchy sits ill with the facts of recent inflated subsidies, says Westminster correspondent David Hencke
fields.trailText: Cap-doffing to a generous monarchy sits ill with the facts of recent inflated subsidies, says Westminster correspondent David Hencke
fields.body:
Today's announcement that the Queen has decided to accept a 10-year freeze on the millions spent every year on the Civil List is not as generous as it might seem. In fact, the Queen could have afforded to offer us the services of the Royal Family free of charge for at least the next three years.

The truth is that the Royal Family is flooded with cash because of two previous generous settlements. In the 70s Harold Wilson offered quite a generous settlement because high inflation was genuinely leaving them strapped for money. Ten years ago John Major then offered a deal based on a 7.5% annual rise in inflation for a decade. This money was on top of a fund that was already in the black - thanks to Harold - and it has gone further into surplus as a result.

Apart from one year inflation has never reached 7.5% - so the Queen through prudent investment has been able to increase the value of her taxpayers' kitty every year. Prince Charles - who is not on the civil list - has been able to cash in on a steadily rising income from the Duchy of Cornwall. And the Queen also has a private income from the Duchy of Lancaster which has added to her wealth.

The taxpayer still meets much of the upkeep of the Royal Palaces and the Queen is even benefiting from charging to go into Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace - the proceeds going to the restoration of Windsor Castle after the disastrous fire.

So the public should not be feeling sorry for a cash-strapped Royal Family - nor should they be overlavish with their praise for Her Majesty's generous gesture in agreeing to freeze the handout.

It is only the very least we should expect.

webTitle: Three held after family dies in house fire

fields.headline: Three held after family dies in house fire
fields.standfirst: Information from the South Wales police
fields.trailText: Two men and a woman have been arrested in connection with the murders of three generations of a family, police say.
fields.body:
Two men and a woman have been arrested in connection with the murders of three generations of a family, police say.

A 38-year-old man and a 33-year-old woman were arrested by South Wales Police on suspicion of the murders of grandmother Doris Dawson, 80, her daughter Mandy Power, 34, and grand-daughters Katie, 10, and eight-year-old Emily.

The victims were found battered to death at their home in Clydach, near Swansea on June 27 last year. The house was also set alight.

Officers who have spent more than a year investigating the killings have arrested a second 38-year-old man on suspicion of conspiring to pervert the course of justice.

All three are being questioned by detectives in the South Wales police force area.

Detective Superintendent Martyn Lloyd-Evans, who has led the murder hunt, said: "Anyone with any information can still come forward to the incident room with any details they have and have not yet disclosed to us."

The arrests come just days after police issued a new E-fit picture of a woman they wanted to trace in connection with their inquiry and a nationwide appeal for information on the Crimewatch television show.

fields.headline: Don't bank on it
fields.standfirst: While factions at the World Bank argue over the merits of growth and the redistribution of wealth, the gap between rich and poor remains
fields.trailText: When Jim Wolfensohn, the head of the World Bank, was asked last week why he has lost his second senior development economist within the space of a few months, the former Wall Street banker was unflustered.
fields.body:
When Jim Wolfensohn, the head of the World Bank, was asked last week why he has lost his second senior development economist within the space of a few months, the former Wall Street banker was unflustered. The explanation for the resignation of Ravi Kanbur, an eminent academic brought in to edit the Bank's high profile World Development Report, was simple, he told reporters. It was all an argument about the order of the chapters in the WDR.

Outsiders are unconvinced. The departure of Kanbur, following last year's resignation of the bank's chief economist, Joe Stiglitz, has exposed a growing rift at the Washington-based body, the world's largest development fund.

On the one side are the ultra-orthodox economists who believe that if poor countries adopt a set of tried and tested policies - conquer inflation, slash government budgets and open their economies to trade - they will reap the benefits in economic growth. According to this school of thought, growth is good for everybody, and even the poorest households share in rising wealth.

On the other side are those like Prof Kanbur and Prof Stiglitz who argue that growth alone is not enough. The quality of growth matters and policies should make sure that the poor get the most benefit from rising prosperity. With 1.2bn people living on less than a $1 a day, the current patterns of global growth will not halve the numbers living in poverty by 2015 - the internationally agreed development target - unless there is radical redistribution of income between rich and poor. Rich countries, and rich people in poor countries, will have give more of their incomes to lift the poorest out of destitution.

Under Mr Wolfensohn's rule, the bank has leaned toward the latter school of thought. It has made much play out of repositioning itself as the "listening bank", not just a bunch of macho economists but a sensitive pro-poor institution, unlike its neighbour the IMF.

But with the departure of Mr Kanbur, a supporter of pro-poor policies, the ultra-orthodox school appears to be triumphing. According to former colleagues, the Cornell University professor left after the bank's research department, the bolt hole of most of the ultras, tried to interfere with the forthcoming World Development Report to put the emphasis back on growth as the most important factor.

A taste of the research department's views can be found in a recent World Bank report by David Dollar and Aart Kraay which uses statistical evidence from a study of 80 countries over four decades to claim that the poor benefit equally with the rich from rising incomes, that reducing government spending and cutting inflation are even better for the poor than for the rest of the population and that neither democracy nor spending on health or education makes any difference to growth.*

"Contrary to popular myths, standard pro-growth macroeconomic policies are good for the poor as they raise mean incomes with no significant adverse effect on the distribution of income," the paper notes. It has been described as the most aggressive assertion yet of the ultra's position and its timing, right in the thick of the row over the WDR, was surely not an accident. The debate has now spilled outside the walls of the bank and is polarising opinions across the development community.

Dollar and Kraay's critics focus on three areas. First, while the statistical case they present appears watertight, most of their evidence stops in the first half of the 1990s - before the rapid acceleration of globalisation which critics argue has skewed the benefits of growth in favour of the rich. "You wouldn't expect to see the real big distributional shifts happening until after 1994," says Kevin Watkins, senior policy adviser at Oxfam. The Dollar-Kraay argument also depends on the quality of the data. As Watkins notes, the quality of the statistics from most developing countries is dreadful.

Second, a closer inspection of Dollar's own data suggests that in many cases, the poor are not benefiting on a one for one basis, despite the headlines. The use of broad aggregates obscures a more complex reality.

Third, the critics argue, even if the conclusion that the poor benefit equally is correct despite the data, it is still wrong to ignore income distribution for the simple reason that reducing poverty takes much longer in a country with a wide gap between rich and poor.

"Highly unequal countries are bad at converting growth into poverty reduction, because they have to grow faster than more equal countries to achieve the same level of income gain for the poor," says Mr Watkins. In other words, if the poor have a smaller slice of the pie to begin with, then even if the overall pie is growing, their slice will not expand by as much as it would in a country where the pie is divided up more equally.

To take a simple example, in Brazil the poorest fifth of the population account for just 2.5% of national income, whereas in Indonesia the same group accounts for 9%. Even if the incomes of all groups are growing at the same rate, Brazil has to grow four times as fast as Indonesia to deliver the same rise in living standards.

Oxfam argues that the World Bank paper represents a hankering for certainties of the golden era of free markets policies in the 80s when policymakers on both sides of the Atlantic assumed that the benefits of growth would trickle down to the poorest. The ruined inner cities of America and the sink estates of Britain are a testament to how shortsighted those policies were. But while new governments in Washington and Westminster have rediscoved redistribution, social security safety nets and the importance of health and education spending, they seem content to allow the institutions which set policies for the world's poorest countries to continue to impose the old, failed nostrums of the past.

*Growth is Good for the Poor, David Dollar and Aart Kraay, Development Research Group, the World Bank, March 2000.

Charlotte Denny is the Guardian's economics reporter.
