fields.trailText: Edmundo, Emmanuel Petit, Duncan Ferguson...and Nicky Butt. Just some of the big names on the move according to today's papers. But where are they off to?
fields.body:
Chelsea have been offered Brazilian striker Edmundo for £6m reports the Sun. The troubled 28-year-old Vasco da Gama star wants to leave the club after rows with team-mates. But whether Chelsea need another striker - or want to buy the man dubbed 'The Animal' - is another matter.

Emmanuel Petit is a target for Barcelona, according to Planet Football's 'Spanish sources.' "Barcelona is a great team, with massive ambition, and it is a perfect club for me," was Petit's view before Euro 2000. Have things moved on or is this just a recycled story? Hmmm.

Newcastle are touting around striker Duncan Ferguson at a knock-down price - but can't find any takers. Rangers are the latest club to turn him down. Chairman David Murray said: "Ferguson is being actively offered about but we have not even made an enquiry about him."

Martin O'Neill is preparing a £4m bid for Belgian defender Joos Valgaeren. An approach for the 24 year-old has been confirmed by the player's agent Guido Mallants. He told the Daily Record: "There is strong interest from Celtic in Joos and I spoke with the manager last week about the possibility of a transfer. There is also some interest from England, but Joos would be interested in coming to a big club like Celtic." Another Scottish player potentially on the move is John Collins. Last night he had 'secret' talks (the story is reported in every paper) with Fulham - whose manager Jean Tigana is an old friend - and could sign if Everton's £3m asking price is met.

Lee Hendrie is demanding "tell me where I stand" talks with John Gregory when pre-season training starts on Friday. Hendrie told the Daily Star: "I've heard other clubs are interested in me and I want to know where I stand with Villa."

Tottenham have confirmed they are in talks with Wimbledon over the possible signing of Ben Thatcher and Carl Cort. "There is an interest and we have been speaking with Wimbledon," admitted director of football David Pleat. Dons manager Terry Burton will make a last-ditch attempt to persuade the pair to stay.

Romanian midfielder Constantin Galca will decide on his future in the next few hours. The Espanyol midfielder - now a free agent - has four options: re-sign with Espanyol or move to Celta Vigo, Napoli or Tottenham.

Sporting Lisbon are poised to make a £5m offer for Manchester United's Nicky Butt. Apparently they will guarantee him a first-team place and European action part of a "tempting package aimed at unsettling Butt before the start of next season" reports Teamtalk. Oh yeah.

West Ham striker Paul Kitson could be on his way out of Upton Park. QPR are favourites to land the striker.

fields.headline: 80s Brat Pack director returns
fields.trailText: Quintessential 80s director John Hughes is set to make a return to our screens with two new projects revisiting the teen-angst genre for which he is best known
fields.body:
Quintessential 80s director John Hughes is set to make a return to our screens with two new projects revisiting the teen-angst genre for which he is best known. Although Hughes has not directed since 1991's Curly Sue, he has channelled his energies into writing and producing, with mixed success.

Rumour has it that Hughes is involved in a remake of his most famous film, The Breakfast Club. The 1984 favourite, which starred Molly Ringwald, Emilio Estevez and Judd Nelson, followed the fortunes of a group of kids forced to spend a Saturday detention in school. A huge hit with 80s teenagers, it launched a generation of teen idols (collectively known as the Brat Pack) and became a reference-point for misunderstood adolescents everywhere. A budget of $25m has been allocated to the project; no cast has yet been announced.

Hughes has also committed to write, direct and produce an as yet untitled 'modern day Cinderella story' for an eight-figure sum according to Mr Showbiz.

The film will apparently be shot in Hughes's favourite location, Chicago, and will feature a 'well-known female star'. It is thought production could start next spring, with a release date of Christmas 2001.

webTitle: Hopkins mines his Welsh history for new role

fields.headline: Hopkins mines his Welsh history for new role
fields.trailText: Sir Anthony Hopkins is planning a return to his Welsh roots with a role in a film about the 1994 struggle of Welsh coalminers
fields.body:
Sir Anthony Hopkins is planning a return to his Welsh roots with a role in a film about the struggle of the Welsh coalminers.

The Oscar-winning actor is tipped to appear in Tower, a £7m drama based on the true story of the Welsh miners who took on the Conservative government and won.

Hopkins has apparently been keen to find a truly Welsh story that would bring him back to the UK, and the account of the closure of the last 'deep mine' in the Rhonda Valley greatly moved him. Cynics might also suggest that the role would provide something of a PR offensive for the actor, who has been dogged by criticism over his recent acceptance of American citizenship and his role in the infamous Barclay's Bank commercials (see our news story).

In 1994, 239 miners organised an international campaign to fend off the government's plans for closure, and buy out the mine's owners. The Welsh star, who is currently filming Silence of the Lambs sequel Hannibal alongside Julianne Moore, will play the part of a recently retired miner who leads the younger workers on a march to Westminster.

Notting Hill star Rhys Ifans is also tipped to join the cast as the most passionate and militant of the miners.

The film will be scripted by Colin (Chariots of Fire) Welland and will be backed by Working Title, the company behind Notting Hill, Four Weddings and a Funeral and Elizabeth.

fields.headline: Poetry
fields.trailText: Poetry isn't what it was. Thank goodness.
fields.body:
Poetry isn't what it was. Thank goodness. It isn't where it was, either. Poets and their books have been released from the confines of dry and dusty tomes on high shelves and are now "out there" thanks to the energies of such evangelists as Michael Rosen and Benjamin Zephaniah, and initiatives like National Poetry Day. Poetry readings are even listed next to cinema listings in the press. Poetry could become dangerously mainstream!

Jenny Joseph's poem Warning was once voted the nation's favourite poem and appears in her first collection for children, All the Things I See (Macmillan £9.99). That feisty direct tone ("When I am an old woman I shall wear purple") is characteristic of much of her work but her anthology proves she is much more than a one poem wonder.

Sometimes her work can be playful and light, but she rarely ties her ideas up too glibly, always leaving a thought in the air, like an invitation to return.

Brian Patten's Juggling with Gerbils (Puffin £3.99) looks more pugnacious than it turns out to be with its orange day-glo jacket. Young readers will love the whimsical musing ("The Secret Rhyme for Orange"), and his airy brushes with anarchy ("Devil of a Dancer"), interspersed with wonderful Chris Riddell illustrations.

Single-subject collections are a risk. How does the anthologist maintain interest when the point of a poetry book is to dip in and out for variety? Cat in the Dark (Frances Lincoln £10.99), subtitled "a flurry of feline verse" is a delight, thanks to Fiona Waters' excellent selection of poems and Sophy Williams' rich, intriguing artwork.

Cats tend to elicit strong reactions, but even "non-cat" people will enjoy the range, from Colin West's wary "Auntie Agnes's Cat" to Margaret Mahy's exuberant "Cat in the Dark". This is giftbook territory, but well worth the investment. Children will love the sum as well as its parts.

Walker Books has recently published an innovative range of plays based on some of its most popular picture story books. Big Talk (Walker £10.99) takes a similar approach, but to poetry.

Paul Fleischman's poems for four voices colour-code each voice so that the children read their parts, sometimes in unison, sometimes solo. It's a clever idea, ideal for paired reading work with 7- to 11-year-olds, and could lead to further experimentation in the performance of poetry.

Five Finger-Piglets (Macmillan £4.99) is a splendid introduction to the work of Carol Ann Duffy, Jackie Kay, Roger McGough, Gareth Owen and Brian Patten. Illustrated by Peter Bailey it offers a selection from each, enough for a child to get their teeth into and gain a sense of the poet's style and preoccupations.

The Ring of Words (Faber, £8.99) is a terrific, intelligent anthology, edited by Roger McGough and illustrated by Satomi Kitamura. Although themed, it is consistently surprising.

webTitle: Fiji rebels wounded in parliament shooting

fields.headline: Fiji rebels wounded in parliament shooting
fields.trailText: Shooting broke out today between Fiji's military and hostage takers who are holding 27 members of the ousted Indian-led government in parliament.
fields.body:
Shooting broke out today between Fiji's military and hostage takers who are holding 27 members of the ousted Indian-led government in parliament.

Five people were injured, rebels said. There were no immediate reports of deaths.

Rebel spokesman Jo Nata said the military fired the first shot shortly after a news conference by rebel leader George Speight to comment on the swearing in earlier in the day of an all-Fijian temporary government.

"There is a little war," Nata said. "One of our people was shot at, a dogfight ensued. Several people have been evacuated."

But military spokesman Lt Col Filipo Tarakinikini blamed the rebels for opening fire first, saying they shot at an army patrol as it passed close to parliament.

Tarakinikini said the situation had calmed down by late Tuesday afternoon.

Nata also confirmed reports that Speight supporters in the town of Labasa on the island of Vanua Levu confiscated weapons from a military barracks. "Our people and military (loyal to Speight) have control there," he said.

At the press conference, Speight said he did not expect the new government to rule for long. Immediately after the conference, some Speight supporters attacked a photographer for the Fiji Times newspaper, accusing him of feeding information from the compound to police.

The attackers were pulled off by other Speight supporters and the incident apparently did not spark the gunfight. Fiji Radio reported that there was an exchange of gunfire lasting between 10 minutes and 15 minutes between troops and armed rebels. Two ambulances were at the scene.

Nata said five injured people had been taken away for treatment. Four of them were taken to a Suva hospital with gunshot wounds to their legs.

"There is blood all over the place," Fiji Radio reporter Malakai Veisamasame said.

Reports suggested that after the gunfight there were negotiations between Speight supporters and the military, but more gunfire was heard later.

Local residents living close to parliament began evacuating the area after the shooting.

Earlier Tuesday, banking executive Laisenia Qarase was sworn in as prime minister in an appointment that provoked the anger of the hostage takers, who had demanded a role in naming any new government.

In a speech after being sworn in, Qarase said he accepted the job as a "call for national unity." He urged the gunmen to release the hostages immediately so Fiji could begin rebuilding its shattered economy.

Qarase said his government would give priority to protecting indigenous Fijian rights, but that "no communities will be excluded ... in our multiracial and multicultural society." He also revealed that he had received several anonymous threats since being chosen as prime minister, but that he did not fear for his life.

Dressed in traditional Sulu skirts, 19 indigenous Fijian men swore to "be faithful and bear true allegiance to the Republic of the Fijian Islands" during a ceremony today at military headquarters in the capital, Suva.

The ceremony could not be held in parliament, where rebels led by former insurance executive Speight have been holding the ousted government hostage for more than six weeks in what they call a battle for indigenous Fijian rights.

Defying the hostage takers, the country's military leader on Monday named the temporary civilian government but said he will retain power until the captives are freed.

Commodore Frank Bainimarama - who assumed power 10 days after rebels stormed parliament on May 19 and took the government hostage - appointed the interim leaders without input from the gunmen, who had demanded a role.

Speight warned Monday the army may pay a high price for "completely ignoring" him. "There's a very big possibility of making a lot of people really upset," he said.

Two members of the Indian minority refused cabinet posts offered to them by the military.

Bainimarama said the interim government would rule for 18 months and set guidelines for a new constitution.

Qarase, the new prime minister, is known more as a manager than a politician, although he once served in Congress. He has been head of the Merchant Bank Fiji and is a former director of the Fiji Development Bank.

webTitle: Euro-leaks leave voters high and dry

fields.headline: Euro-leaks leave voters high and dry
fields.standfirst: While europhiles and sceptics may pull out economic evidence to support or oppose Britain's  entry into the single currency, ultimately questions of political sovereignty will decide a referendum, argues Hugo Young
fields.trailText: While europhiles and sceptics may pull out economic evidence to support or oppose Britain's entry into the single currency, ultimately questions of political sovereignty will decide a referendum, argues Hugo Young.
fields.body:
Leaks are a wonderful stimulus to debate. Facts or predictions that appear in open government papers can seem banal, but, when coated with the aura of leaked secrets, they become irresistibly potent.

Today's leak of a paper from the British ambassador in Japan, assessing Japanese business opinion on the consequences of sterling staying outside the euro - the second official leak in two days - marks a new phase in the agonised British debate.

The instant reaction from enemies of a euro-sterling merger was revealing. Lord Hanson, one of their leading business backers, said that not only the leak but the contents of the paper were orchestrated. Our man in Tokyo was part of a political plot!

This showed, I think, the hysteria of which some eurosceptics are capable when confronted with inconvenient official judgments, after years of dominating the argument. To suggest the ambassador was giving bent advice was defamatory, and the foreign secretary has understandably demanded an apology and retraction.

On the other hand, both the leaks were plainly arranged by responsible ministers. They weren't pieces of anti-government subversion, but part of the intellectual and political battle over the substantive issue of euro entry, which is going on in and out of government. Tomorrow, counter-evidence will be produced, in the form of official figures showing a rosy picture of inward investment over the last two years. It will be seized on by sceptics as evidence of the euro's irrelevance.

These figures will be exploited for whatever contribution they can make to the propaganda of either side. They will leave the average voter, already uneasy at being asked for an opinion on such an esoteric matter as currency manoeuvring, even more confused than before. They are important bits of evidence, albeit contradictory. But their main effect, in my view, is to highlight that the real argument that in a referendum will not be about economics, which are always disputable, but about the political case for adjusting the definition of British sovereignty.

One truth about these rival contentions on inward investment should not, however, be neglected. There is a long lag between the decision and the happening. Figures for 1998 don't tell us much about 2002.

There is still a wide perception, in Japan and the US, that sterling will eventually enter the euro. Their decisions made hitherto are based on that assumption. If it became quite clear that Britain was removing entry from the agenda for the indefinite future, we would be in new and unpredictable terrain.

webTitle: Cook demands apology for euro leak 'slur'

fields.headline: Cook demands apology for euro leak 'slur'
fields.standfirst: The leaked memo: extracts
fields.trailText: Foreign Secretary Robin Cook is demanding an apology for a claim that the UK ambassador to Japan deliberately wrote a report highlighting unease about the Government's attitude to the euro so it could be leaked.
fields.body:
Foreign Secretary Robin Cook is demanding an apology for a claim that the UK ambassador to Japan deliberately wrote a report highlighting unease about the Government's attitude to the euro so it could be leaked.

Mr Cook said the claim by eurosceptic businessman Lord Hanson was an "outrageous slur" on Sir Stephen Gomersall.

But Mr Cook said: "The suggestion that I instructed Sir Stephen Gomersall to doctor a report so that it could be leaked is an outrageous slur on a distinguished diplomat and on ministers.

"I am sure that when Lord Hanson reflects on what he has said, he will want to retract it and apologise. He should do so promptly."

webTitle: Japan envoy's warning for Blair on euro

fields.headline: Japan envoy's warning for Blair on euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The British ambassador to Tokyo, Sir Stephen Gomersall, has warned Tony Blair that future Japanese investment in the UK could be jeopardised by uncertainty over the exact direction and pace of European integration.
fields.body:
The British ambassador to Tokyo, Sir Stephen Gomersall, has warned Tony Blair that future Japanese investment in the UK could be jeopardised by uncertainty over the exact direction and pace of European integration.

Below are edited extracts from Sir Stephen's restricted memo to the prime minister, which was leaked to the Times.

"Many Japanese investments in the UK have been affected by the high pound/euro exchange rate. Losses on the bottom line of manufacturers have brought about some closures, plans to increase sourcing from outside the UK, and consideration of reweighting ... towards eastern Europe and the euro zone. Some significant projects are at risk ...

"Six months ago we flagged up increasing concern about the level of sterling and uncertainty about British policy on the euro. We assessed that in the absence of new develop ments Japanese companies would probably sit tight for another year or so in the hope that the government will succeed in moving public opinion towards acceptance of euro membership.

"However ... companies are beginning to see pound/euro uncertainty as a long term disincentive to investment in Britain.

"More generally, a perception has been spreading among economic opinion formers that the UK is not at present a safe bet.

"Major manufacturers such as Toshiba, Hitachi, Panasonic and Sony are shifting their production ... outside the UK, mainly to eastern Europe (where wages are much lower) rather than to the euro-zone ... they are in most cases attempting to introduce more value-added products in order to keep the UK operations ticking over until the way forward becomes clearer.

"But it cannot be assumed they will necessarily stay. The president of Toshiba told me on June 14 that he did not want to have to close their factory in Plymouth, but did not know whether they could afford to hang on until the UK joined the euro. There are other investments such as NSK Barings and Komatsu earth movers, which are hanging on a knife edge, or where expansion which would normally have come to the UK is being re-evaluated for exchange rate reasons.

"[There is a] need to address the deeper doubts now being raised about the UK, and the possibility of more serious losses. Those manufacturers who have major continental markets want the uncertainty and the problems of planning and operating in two different currencies removed.

"There is at the very least a need for reassurance at the political level that the declared policy is on track. Any sign that the government was back tracking from its timetable for decision taking could, I believe, trigger a much stronger move towards disinvestment."

webTitle: Never mind the economics, the euro is a political issue

fields.headline: Never mind the economics, the euro is a political issue
fields.standfirst:
The DTI paper tells us what we may not want to hear, but need to know

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: An unfamiliar scenario for the sterling-euro psychodrama has been apparent from the start. There always could come a time when the economic case for entry grew very strong - but the politics had become unmanageable.
fields.body:
An unfamiliar scenario for the sterling-euro psychodrama has been apparent from the start. There always could come a time when the economic case for entry grew very strong - but the politics had become unmanageable. Economic evidence might eventually sweep aside the sceptic case. But the anti-Europe political build-up would have made the referendum impossible to win. By making five-part economics the single test, the government invited this possible outcome. By declaring the political objections to entry to be nonexistent it exposed itself to the danger, once the economic hurdle was crossed, that they would become, instead, overwhelming.

We now have a foretaste of this. From inside the Department of Trade and Industry comes a stark prediction about the damage done by the high pound, and the effect on foreign investors of the perception that sterling might stay out indefinitely. The DTI official's paper may only be an opinion. But it is not distorted by political calculation. It accords, moreover, with the judgment most people are bound to make, however uncomfortable that might be. Sooner or later, whatever else may be said about the euro, inward investors will make big decisions that give as much attention to sterling's indefinite absence as to the alleged advantages of the Anglo-Saxon business environment. That's putting it as modestly as I can. In the private candour of the DTI, the word is imminent meltdown.

This is a helpful development. The argument begins to get more real. Though the final testing of the economic situation is supposed to wait until after the election, it's never too early to be aware of threats to manufacturing. The DTI paper is a depth-charge against the suave complacencies of Eurosceptics. But it explodes into a political environment determined to resist it: the government because it can't admit, with an election imminent, that there's any threat from anywhere to its wondrous economic record, the opposition because the verdict challenges every Hagueite analysis of how little the euro matters. The paper blows apart both versions of how the euro should be approached. Though economic in content, it exposes the evasions of two groups of politicians.

First, the Tories and other sceptics. However strong the economic case might become, it's apparent these people will not be satisfied. Behind each hurdle stands, inexorably, another. Economic convergence might be happening - but we're now told it's worth nothing until it has weathered unnumbered economic cycles. Interest rates may be getting closer - but let's await their next divergence. The pound is high now - but no business makes decisions on the basis of temporary fluctuations. And so on. The list of impossibilities is long. It can be guaranteed, whatever the circumstances, to go on getting longer.

These politicians plainly have a problem, and it is not about economics. They writhe with such ingenuity to refine, and refine again, the economic tests, that their resistance can only originate deeper down: at the source of the integrationist project, its very essence, its political meaning. They don't like any part of it. They detest every small shift to further integration, never mind the euro which is a massive one. They cannot find a single good thing to say about the European Union.

David Owen and his faction of ageing respectables are of this company. So is William Hague. They have a profound political position, which they have every right to adopt - except for the gross dissembling that attaches to it. They refuse to address the consequences of Britain receding to the margins of Europe, though that is what they want. They're not prepared to admit that their case against the EU is political, or that the economic case against the euro is a weapon of convenience masking this political case, an adjunct to the bigger argument, not answerable by economic developments that might rebut it. They won't say never to the euro, for reasons of pure cynicism: they know middle England doesn't like saying never to anything. But never is what they would like. It's the only stance consistent with the secret political attitude at the heart of their position.

That's the sceptic contribution to the British debate. It is intolerably evasive. But the government's evasions are worse. Grandly stating, as ministers have done since 1997, that constitutional objections to the euro do not hold water, and the political implications are not worth discussing, has become untenable. The DTI paper foreshadows the consequences. It tells us what we may not want to hear but ought to know. Yet the pretence that greater integration of the EU is not a political project could deliver a fatal blow to the perception, however clear it becomes, that only inside the euro does Britain have a chance of preserving industry and saving jobs.

Integration is, of course, political, and those who favour it should be proud to say so. Ministers are among these people. Their policies, as Mr Blair keeps saying, are designed to keep Britain at the centre of the EU, a committed member now in highest standing. Yet, on the political dimensions of the EU, they're in denial. They barely admit that these exist. Mr Blair's reminders that we are a European country are clearer than those of any predecessor for 25 years, but they remain defensive, conditional, sometimes apologetic. Confronted with an invitation to admit that any future progress is going to be a step towards some modicum more of political integration, all ministers search their copious vocabulary to rephrase the question and deny the possibility.

This is no way to prepare the country for the argument that will have to happen. For one thing, it leaves Britain mute in the debates other members are having. An important discussion begins in Germany and France about the future shape of the EU. It's limited by national interest, but is also speculative, stimulating, free. There is everything to play for here. Joschka Fischer and Jacques Chirac joust and disagree. All Mr Blair says is that he must wait until October before voicing an opinion. How dismal! But how reflective of the neurotic concerns that pass for policymaking, in a nation where the political nature of the European project has been ruled out of order, undiscussible, an offence against the gospel of the Five Conditions of the Treasury.

Worse, such silence is a denial of what more people are beginning to understand. The sceptics say the euro is about more than economics, and, though less than honest in their conclusions, they are right. The government hides from that analysis. It is making a big mistake, as events will show and the debate ranges beyond its retention. The economics, strong though they might be, will never be enough. There are too many bolt holes for challenge and delusion. The case will be won only for what it is: a choice about the existential future of the offshore island, between geography and history.

fields.headline: New euro leak rattles ministers
fields.standfirst:
'Swaths' of firms ready to quit UK

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: 'Swaths' of firms are ready to quit the UK unless the government does more to embrace the euro.
fields.body:
Britain's ambassador to Japan has issued a sharp private warning that swaths of Japanese firms will pull out of Britain unless the government does more to embrace the euro, according to a fresh leak from government.

The leak of a telegram to London from Stephen Gomersall comes the day after the publication of a separate memo from Andrew Fraser, the chief executive of the Invest in Britain bureau, forecasting manufacturing meltdown unless the government states that membership of the euro is indispensable for British industry. The memo was sent to the industry secretary, Stephen Byers.

Government sources are concerned that there is an organised leaking campaign by pro-Europeans within Whitehall designed to shift Treasury policy before the general election. The same sources, denying there will be a change in policy, suggested that Tony Blair will seek to allay Japanese fears about the euro when he travels to Okinawa on July 20 for the G8 summit.

Mr Gomersall, who has discussed with Mr Fraser the despondent mood of Japanese investors in Britain, fears the government has in recent weeks given the impression that British determination to join the euro is waning. Both Mr Fraser and Mr Gomersall have listed Japanese firms on the brink of cutting back in Britain.

Among the Japanese companies which have already threatened to scale back their British operations are Nissan, which last week said it was considering relocating the production of its Micra model, NSK, which has cut 400 jobs at its Ferrybridge plant, and Canon, which has made 200 people redundant in Scotland.

Although Japan represents only 3% of inward investment in the UK, Martin O'Neill, chairman of the Commons in dustry select committee, said the Japanese commitment was psychologically crucial to British manufacturing.

The row comes ahead of figures due to be released tomorrow, which will show that inward investment in Britain is booming. The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said the inflow, drawn to Britain's low tax regime, proved Britain could thrive outside the euro. He also effectively accused Mr Byers of leaking the memo as part of his tactical war with the Treasury over the euro.

The former Tory chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, warned not to read too much into tomorrow's figures, saying: "This year's results reflect decisions taken several years ago. Decisions taken today would be very different - as firms like Nissan, Vauxhall and Toshiba have said."

Mr Fraser himself condemned the leak saying: "I think the advice we give ministers should first of all be robust and honest and, secondly, it should be kept private".

But he admitted the exchange rate was still too high: "There's no question that some low margin manufacturers have been under pressure. The weakness of the euro in conversion terms has surprised everybody," he said.

Britain in Europe, the pro-euro campaign group, also pointed out that UK outward investment in net terms was still higher than inward investment.

The Engineering Employers Federation (EEF) also said the government's euro policy was inappropriate and will today reveal after three successive quarters of improvement since last year, that conditions are deteriorating.

The EEF accused the government of playing russian roulette with manufacturing jobs.

The pressure on manufacturing was also underlined by a key business survey published yesterday showing the sector growing at its slowest rate for a year in June.

The monthly poll by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply showed output and orders almost ground to a halt last month.

City economists said that, faced with poor sales abroad, manufacturers were concentrating on cutting costs to remain profitable, running down stocks of goods on storeroom shelves and, increasingly, shedding labour.

Labour backbench figures, such as Mr O'Neill, are pressing the government to declare in the autumn that it will hold its economic assessment of whether Britain has converged sufficiently 12 months after the election.

Mr O'Neill said the only tests that really matter are the exchange rate, inflation and interest rates.

Eurosceptics said the two memos amounted to "scaremongering". Nick Herbert, director of Business for Sterling, the anti-euro campaign group, said: "This hysterical memo has been leaked to distort the situation over inward investment, for political purposes. Their own figures clearly show a rise in inward investment."

Yesterday, Downing Street said the language of the Fraser memo was exaggerated.

fields.headline: Prisons inspector condemns 'battery chicken' cells
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: The chief inspector of prisons has launched a vigorous protest over the use of "the smallest cells I have seen anywhere in the prison service" to hold women at Eastwood Park prison, near Bristol.
fields.body:
The chief inspector of prisons has launched a vigorous protest over the use of "the smallest cells I have seen anywhere in the prison service" to hold women at Eastwood Park prison, near Bristol.

The "battery chicken" cells which Sir David Ramsbotham said "look overcrowded with a bed and chair let alone a lavatory and a basin", measure just six feet wide by eight foot long - little bigger than the size of an average double bed.

The chief inspector said the cells in the prison's A-wing were "way below any acceptable standard, except in the case of an emergency, and should be taken out of use until three cells can be knocked into two, or sanitation removed and electronic locking installed, allowing at least some space for the occupant".

"They were not designed for the use to which they are currently being put, and should, at best, only be used as emergency bedrooms," he added.

The size of the cells was first criticised by Judge Stephen Tumim, Sir David's predecessor, when the jail was being converted into a women's prison four years ago. Judge Tumim told the home secretary that they were less than half the size of those in other women's prisons and were smaller than the minimum size laid down in the prison service's official standards.

There is barely room to stand up in these purpose-built cells in which the bed takes up half the floor space, a quarter is taken up by the toilet, and there is a fold-down table and a wall-mounted cupboard. At the time of the original protests the prison service said the cells could only be enlarged at disproportionate cost and insisted they would only be used for sleeping. But Sir David's inspection report made clear that they were still being used to hold women during the day.

A prison service spokeswoman said it was hoped to convert the cells but no date had been set.

"They are only used as bedrooms and the inmates spend an average of 11.7 hours in out of cell activity each day," she said. "It is not feasible to close them down because of the increasing number of female prisoners coming into the prison system."

Sir David's report said Eastwood Park was struggling to deal with its 268 women inmates because of a "deplorable" lack of senior female officers but had considerable potential for development.

He said he was disappointed to find there were no female governor grades in the management team.

"The staff is a curious mix - a number of older, mainly male staff from the old HMP Pucklechurch, and a number of newly recruited, relatively inexperienced, mainly female staff - too few of whom had been trained to work with women."

He said inmates accused staff of turning a blind eye to bullying and even appearing to congratulate one woman who attacked a known drug dealer.

The director-general of the prison service, Martin Narey, praised the enthusiasm and dedication of the staff at Eastwood Park, saying the rising number of women prisoners meant it had to cope with a very mixed population.

He said work was under way on Sir David's proposal that there should be a mother and baby unit at the prison.

At the time of the original protests the prison service said the cells could only be enlarged at disproportionate cost and insisted they would only be used for sleeping. But Sir David's inspection report made clear that they were still being used to hold women during the day. A prison service spokeswoman said it was hoped to convert the cells but no date had been set. "They are only used as bedrooms and the inmates spend an average of 11.7 hours in out of cell activity each day," she said. "It is not feasible to close them down because of the increasing number of female prisoners coming into the prison system." Sir David's report said Eastwood Park was struggling to deal with its 268 women inmates because of a "deplorable" lack of senior female officers but had considerable potential for development. He said he was disappointed to find there were no female governor grades in the management team. "The staff is a curious mix - a number of older, mainly male staff from the old HMP Pucklechurch, and a number of newly recruited, relatively inexperienced, mainly female staff - too few of whom had been trained to work with women." He said inmates accused staff of turning a blind eye to bullying and even appearing to congratulate one woman who attacked a known drug dealer. The director-general of the prison service, Martin Narey, praised the enthusiasm and dedication of the staff at Eastwood Park, saying the rising number of women prisoners meant it had to cope with a very mixed population. He said work was under way on Sir David's proposal that there should be a mother and baby unit at the prison.

webTitle: Police fear missing girl was abducted

fields.headline: Police fear missing girl was abducted
fields.standfirst: Parents make an emotional plea for their 'little princess' to be returned as search teams fail to find any trace of eight-year-old
fields.trailText: The distraught parents of the missing girl Sarah Payne yesterday made an emotional appeal for their daughter's safe return, as fears mounted that she had been abducted.
fields.body:
The distraught parents of the missing girl Sarah Payne yesterday made an emotional appeal for their daughter's safe return, as fears mounted that she had been abducted.

The eight-year-old, from Surrey, vanished on Saturday evening after playing with her brothers and sister in a cornfield just 150 yards from her grandparents' home in the village of Ferring, West Sussex.

A hunt by 150 officers and 80 volunteers through nearby fields proved fruitless. Dense crops and overgrown woodland hampered the search. A bloodhound, diving teams and a helicopter fitted with sensors were also called in.

Yesterday the girl's parents, Sara and Michael Payne, both 31, made an emotional appeal at a news conference in Littlehampton. Mrs Payne told reporters she just wanted the family's "little princess" home.

"You can't imagine what Sarah means to us, we're a strong family and we don't survive well apart," she said. "We need her home now, today, as quickly as we possibly can.

"Her brothers and sisters are really not coping very well without her. She is our life. Our family name for Sarah is 'our little princess' and that's just what she is. She is a soft, gentle little girl."

Police were trying to track down a white Transit van and a grey Ford Mondeo seen in the area by her eldest brother, Lee, 13, and appealed to their drivers to come forward.

Detective Superintendent Alan Ladley, leading the hunt, said it looked likely that the youngster had been snatched as she walked back to her grandparents' house.

The family was on a regular weekend visit to Ferring. After spending the day at the beach Sarah and her brothers Lee and Luke, 11, and sister Charlotte, six, were playing "dinosaurs" in the field when Sarah decided to walk back to the house.

Fears that she has been snatched are being fuelled by the fact that the route she would have taken was so short. Police are confident that she would have been found if she was still in that area. They are interviewing local paedophiles.

Yesterday the inhabitants of Ferring spoke of their disbelief that such an incident could happen in their small village.

Sarah was last seen wearing shiny black nylon shoes with Velcro fastenings and a blue Fred Perry-style tennis dress. Her blonde hair is cut in a bob.

Anyone with information about the disappearance should contact Sussex police on 0845 607 0999.

webTitle: Loyalist gunfire raises stakes in Drumcree standoff

fields.headline: Loyalist gunfire raises stakes in Drumcree standoff
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland: special report
Orange Order site links
Garvaghy Road Residents Coalition
Portadown District Orange Lodge No 1
Parades commission
fields.trailText: Police in Northern Ireland moved in late last night to clear demonstrators from Drumcree hill in a dramatic escalation of the Orange Order protest after masked loyalist gunmen fired a volley of shots into the air in a nearby housing estate in Portadown, Co Armagh.
fields.body:
Police in Northern Ireland moved in late last night to clear demonstrators from Drumcree hill in a dramatic escalation of the Orange Order protest after masked loyalist gunmen fired a volley of shots into the air in a nearby housing estate in Portadown, Co Armagh.

They began the operation after coming under a barrage of stones, bottles and firecrackers for the second night running, and quickly cleared the area around the Church of Ascension. But sporadic violence was continuing, and demonstrations were spreading throughout Northern Ireland.

The Loyalist Volunteer Force show of strength was under an Ulster Freedom Fighters banner. The mainstream paramilitary group arrived at Drumcree openly to join the Orange Order's protest over its parade on Sunday, banned from the nationalist Garvaghy Road.

The LVF move indicated the two loyalist groups were working together, a devastating blow to the RUC, which had hoped only dissidents would seek to become involved. It was the first such demonstration in Northern Ireland in several years.

Under a UFF banner on a loyalist housing estate, an LVF spokesman in balaclava and paramilitary uniform read a short statement backing Portadown orangemen. It accused the government and IRA of trying to force a united Ireland.

To loud applause, he told the crowd that the murdered loyalist leader Billy Wright had not died in vain. He cried: "No surrender" before two gunmen each fired three times into the sky.

UFF commander Johnny Adair, one of the most feared terrorists in Northern Ireland, looked on. He had earlier joined 50 loyalists beneath the same UFF banner as they marched to police lines at the Church of Ascension, supporting the Orange Order's right to march.

There were signs that the protests were spreading. The Portadown district Orange Order master Harold Gracey had demanded that when the first of the two marches was blocked on Sunday.

Roads were blocked in loyalist areas of Belfast, and several vehicles were set alight. There were reports of further demonstrations in Lisburn and Armagh, and there had been similar protests in south Down the previous night.

Orangemen engaged in several flying pickets in Portadown in an effort to stretch the security forces, again as Mr Gracey had demanded. Police struggled to keep orange supporters and nationalists apart.

Mr Adair, who is on early release under the Good Friday agreement, had served five years of a 16-year sentence for directing terrorism when he was freed last September. His involvement in the dispute is against advice from loyalist politicians, and marks a dramatic escalation of the difficulties facing the RUC and army.

Last night's developments followed the parade commission's decision yesterday to ban next Sunday's march, as the loyalists had expected.

It had already refused permission for a similar march two days ago.

But it did hold out the possibility of an Orange Order march down the Garvaghy Road within eight months if the Portadown lodge ended protests, accepted the ban this coming Sunday and entered mediation.

fields.headline: Conservation flag hoisted in UK
fields.trailText: The United Nations flag was raised in Cambridge yesterday over the world conservation monitoring unit, the first UN agency to be opened in Britain in 50 years.
fields.body:
The United Nations flag was raised in Cambridge yesterday over the world conservation monitoring unit, the first UN agency to be opened in Britain in 50 years.

The unit is part of the UN Environment Programme and provides basic information on the state of all animals and plants on the planet. Klaus Toepfer, the Unep executive director, said it provided an early warning system for decision makers in government, the private sector and conservation and development organisations.

Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, said in a message that environmental trends were "deeply worrying - and may even be getting worse".

He said: "Human beings continue to plunder the global environment. Unsustainable practices remain deeply embedded in the fabric of our daily lives."

He said a big public information effort was needed, governments must make and enforce environmental agreements and laws, the effect on the environment of decisions must become central to policy, and all this must be based on sound scientific information. The monitoring centre was there to provide that.

"Unpleasant ecological surprises lie ahead but the start of the new century could not be a more opportune time to commit ourselves, people as well as government, to a new epoch of conservation and stewardship."

The British government has put £500,000 towards the centre and it is being supported by BP Amoco, Rio Tinto and Vauxhall, some of the big companies accused of damaging the environment.

Lord Holme of Cheltenham, an executive of Rio Tinto, the world's biggest mining company, is providing all his company's environmental assessments of its projects to the centre to be put on computer for public scrutiny and use, as is BP Amoco.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, said: "This centre will operate with no political or industrial interference."

fields.headline: Fierce bidding for Thatcher's handbag
fields.trailText: How much am I bid for an old bag? Well, that depends on whose arm it spent its formative years.
fields.body:
How much am I bid for an old bag? Well, that depends on whose arm it spent its formative years.

On the opening day of bidding in a charity auction of handbags donated by famous owners, a black Salvatore Ferragamo handbag with which Lady Thatcher intimidated political friend and foe alike had attracted a bid of £61,100.

A tiger-print number of uncertain origin donated by Cherie Booth, meanwhile, had fetched just £100, while Mo Mowlam's black Jaeger clutch bag had limped to £26.

Bidding will remain open for a further nine days, but the combined allure of bags donated by 12 other celebrities, including Jerry Hall, perennial Wimbledon failure Annabel Croft and actor Lynda Bellingham, are unlikely to match the huge sum offered for the former prime minister's trademark accessory.

The auction, the proceeds of which will go to Breast Cancer Care, opened yesterday at Handbag.com and within hours Lady Thatcher's bag had received 20 bids, boosting it from a reserve price of £50 to £391.

A further flurry of bids last night saw the asking price reach five figures. There was no indication of the bidders' identity, nor of their motivation for wanting to buy a £300 handbag for the price of one of Lady Thatcher's lectures.

Cherie Booth's offering required 13 bids to reach £82. But these were riches compared with offers for Ms Croft's "pretty pink number" (£30) and a heart-shaped tinsel-fringed bag donated by GMTV's Lorraine Kelly (£32).

Lady Thatcher's bag was bought when she was at the height of her powers in the mid-80s, and was, she said, "used for many special occa sions. I would only let it go for a good cause".

She once described her handbag as the only safe place in Downing Street, while colleagues came to see it as symbolic of her philosophy.

"She cannot see an institution without hitting it with her handbag," Julian Critchley, a backbench Tory critic, once said. And the term "to handbag" entered the political lexicon.

A closer ally, Nicholas Ridley, once remarked in Mrs Thatcher's absence at a cabinet committee meeting: "Why don't we start? The handbag is here."

fields.headline: Queen to pay staff pensions
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Queen is to pay pension contributions for the royal household's 300 staff for the first time, the prime minister will announce today as part of a deal freezing civil list funds for the next 10 years.
fields.body:
The Queen is to pay pension contributions for the royal household's 300 staff for the first time, the prime minister will announce today as part of a deal freezing civil list funds for the next 10 years.

Tony Blair will tell the Commons that Buckingham Palace and the Treasury have agreed to peg the civil list at £7.9m a year until 2011 - the same level it has been since 1991.

The settlement was agreed in principle more than a year ago and is intended to rectify the over-generosity of the previous 10-year deal, agreed under Margaret Thatcher's last Conservative government, which gave the Queen a 50% rise on the assumption of an annual inflation rate of 7.5% from 1991 to 2001.

A much lower inflation rate than predicted resulted in a civil list overpayment of £30m but, instead of requiring the Queen to pay back the funds, the Treasury agreed to freeze payments for 10 years, with any extra royal spending to be taken from the £30m reserve. In return for this windfall, the Queen has accepted new responsibilities, including the cost of pension contributions for all staff working in the royal palaces.

Details of the surplus must be released to MPs before October 15, when the royal trustees - who include the prime minister and the chancellor, Gordon Brown - make their 10-yearly statement on civil list spending.

About 70% of the civil list funds are used to pay staff who deal with state papers, the organisation of public engagements and receptions undertaken by the Queen as well as the costs of official entertainment during state visits.

Mr Blair is also expected to confirm that the Queen Mother will continue to receive £643,000 a year from the civil list and the Duke of Edinburgh £395,000 a year.

The civil list, which dates back to the 17th century, was renewed annually between 1975 and 1990, when the Queen and the government agreed to a 10-yearly review.

fields.headline: Slurring the proles
fields.standfirst: Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: There was a build-up to yesterday's crime summit between Downing Street and the Association of Chief Police Officers. Using emotive rhetoric, government representatives have been talking about the "shame" of Britain's "yobs".
fields.body:
There was a build-up to yesterday's crime summit between Downing Street and the Association of Chief Police Officers. Using emotive rhetoric, government representatives have been talking about the "shame" of Britain's "yobs", about "drunken louts", "thug bars" and the need for zero tolerance on "yobbery".

Tony Blair's language was particularly florid, revealing his anxieties about drunken thugs who kick down gates and hurl traffic cones. But when the rest of us worry about violent crime, do we also worry about louts, yobs and thugs or something different and more complex?

The drunken football fans in Charleroi provided the press with the perfect excuse to indulge their snobbish cliches about hooligans. Downing Street's readiness to use these as symbols of Britain's violent disorder was more surprising. Outside those rarefied portals the tattooed skinhead hardly embodies popular anxieties. Indeed, in the inner city and country villages this figure may be tangential both to the problems and people's fears.

I speak from personal knowledge. I live in an area of London where violent street crime has increased by 35% in the last two years. Most locals have had direct experiences, especially if there are teenagers in the family. The scenarios are boringly predictable; typically the victims are in their early teens, the attackers a few years older. The typical weapon is a knife and the typical spoils bikes and mobile phones.

In Lambeth six mobiles were stolen like this between November 96 and October 97 and 2,500 between 98 and 99. "It has become," says assistant commissioner of the Met, Andy Trotter, like "dinner money theft."

Complex causes lie behind these crimes. Relative affluence exists alongside relative deprivation. There is a growing "must-have" consumer culture in which crime is seen to pay. There is a perception that the police are ineffective. Gender and race also come into it. White boys are the main targets, regardless of their background. Hereabouts, demonising drunken louts seems strangely irrelevant.

For others, the real problems of violent crime and antisocial behaviour lie on estates which appear to be beyond the rule of the law. There the problems are twocking, ram raiding and intimidation of residents, sometimes racially motivated. Residents worry about overt drug dealing bringing a culture of violence, aggression and intimidation. In such cultures of antisocial behaviour, residents struggle to draw the line between normal and unacceptable delinquency.

Clearly it was a country town Blair had in mind when he spoke of the cone-throwing drunk being marched by the local bobby to a cash machine in the market square. But even here the rhetoric of the skinhead thug seems inadequate.

Certainly there are worries about drunkenness and disorder, but the talk in country towns is about students and school children, pouring out of the pubs and clubs at the weekend hopelessly drunk. Along with the fear of fighting and property damage, there is also fear for those involved. Will they drive and cause a pile up, will they hurt themselves, will they overdose?

Such worries are about what's wrong with the kids and with society itself when young people no longer have a clear sense of what is acceptable. When it comes to actual crimes what country residents fear is organised property crime; their houses being broken into; things they value being stolen; not feeling safe. That, as the Police Association has been saying, amounts to a community not feeling protected, not feeling the presence of the police, whether those fears are real or not.

What's common to all these situations is the feeling that people cannot rely on self-policing to hold minor delinquency this side of the law, or on external policing to enforce it. This is a new situation, and neither the police nor the public have had time to understand this feeling or the meaning of the rising crime figures. There are many reasons why people feel unsafe and anxious about violent crime and these may require different solutions in different areas.

What is shared, though, is the need to feel the government is analysing the situation in a clear-headed, accurate way and that it will come up with solutions that are just and protect all groups equally. This is not done by inventing a skinhead slur where all problems of violent crime are reduced to the problems of drunken louts. This is bogeyman politics, spinning working-class men as hate figures to hide the fact that when it comes to violent crimes, something in the cocktail of current politics and social trends isn't working too well.

fields.standfirst:
Mo Mowlam says the royals should move, but why stop with them?
North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Before she was obliged to backtrack for conduct unbecoming a member of a respectable rightwing government, Mo Mowlam was almost on to something when she suggested that the royal family should move house.
fields.body:
Before she was obliged to backtrack for conduct unbecoming a member of a respectable rightwing government, Mo Mowlam was almost on to something when she suggested that the royal family should move house.

It's right to move entrenched, privileged people out of their anachronistic London palaces, but the royals, frankly, are neither here nor there. It's Mo who should move - and Tony and Gordon and the rest of them. The real anachronism is the Palace of Westminster. Moving out of London would be the greatest single contribution to the regeneration of Britain our largely impotent politicians could make.

All the other major English-speaking countries have their political capitals well away from their biggest cities. And no other substantial European country is as centralised as this one: even France has its hottest and sexiest region at the far end of the country. Britain, however, just has London. In almost any field of endeavour, it is necessary to go there to reach the peak of your profession, excepting only academe and football. No institution knows this cruel reality better than the Manchester Guardian.

The consequence has been an overwhelming tilt of population and resources toward the south-east. This was bad enough 25 years ago. Since then the north's traditional industries have declined or collapsed while the south-east's have grown ever more powerful; Europe has become more important to us, the open seas less; and the Channel tunnel has made things even worse. There is no foreseeable way to reverse this trend. Not merely is the infrastructure unable to cope, there is no way politicians can make it cope.

Yet they don't have to add to the problems themselves. Congressmen and their hangers-on don't commute to downtown Manhattan; our political industry could move out of London, taking the civil servants, the embassies, the lobbyists and much of the media with them. Property prices would become more realistic; the roads and railways would become a little less clogged. London would remain the financial, artistic and almost-everything-else capital, and would fulfil those functions far more efficiently. It would still be one of the world's great cities - indeed it would be a greater one because it would work better.

And so would parliament. Get the MPs out of their pretty but outmoded slum and give them facilities fit for serious legislators rather than whipped curs, and maybe they would behave accordingly. They would lead better, more enjoyable lives. They would be more in touch with how non-metropolitan people live and by golly this government would benefit from that.

Of course, there would be short-term inconvenience, because London would still have a role to play. But modern communications solve problems that would have been intractable even five years ago. There would be costs too. But they would be dwarfed by the long-term savings, and we ought to have learned enough about how NOT to plan a new parliament to make it possible to aim for architectural excellence without grandiloquence in the new capital. I would expect our prudent chancellor to be tigerish about cost over-runs.

Doubtless some people would bemoan the loss of tradition. But maybe London could stay as capital of England, with a new capital of Britain as a whole. And Westminster could still do the flummery - the State Opening, Budget Day, that kind of stuff - while serious business is conducted elsewhere.

But where elsewhere? For pure geographical dead- centredness, the new capital probably ought to be built somewhere near the beautiful North Riding town of Hawes, which might be good news for the makers of Wensleydale cheese. Since this is William Hague's constituency, it might emphasise the bipartisan nature of the project.

However, the people of Hawes are really too phlegmatic and decent to have to put up with politicians. And there is the unfortunate matter of the town's name which, when spoken rather than written, might cause unfortunate misunderstandings as far as MPs are concerned.

There are, however, plenty of alternative sites. York has historical resonance, feasible transport links and - as long as you keep away from the centre - a fair amount of lebensraum. I would be willing to listen to representations from Ripon, Wakefield, Lancaster and Chester. The best site of all might be near Crewe, though that might make people think I'm joking, and this is deadly serious. A move would be good for the new capital and its whole region; good for London; and good for Britain.

I envisage the Blairs living in a nice Georgian manor of the sort advertised in Country Life, for a fraction of the price of their comparative hovel in Downing Street. Why not?

matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

fields.headline: Legalise cannabis, says Labour adviser
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A key government adviser last night advocated the legalisation of cannabis as part of a radical overhaul of political and cultural institutions in Britain.
fields.body:
A key government adviser last night advocated the legalisation of cannabis as part of a radical overhaul of political and cultural institutions in Britain.

Lord Haskins, a Labour peer and chairman of the better regulation taskforce, said the BBC should take advertising, the Church of England should be disestablished and the country's main sporting bodies dumped.

In a wide-ranging speech that surprised delegates at the Radio Academy's annual gathering in Glasgow, Lord Haskins predicted a complete break-up of the United Kingdom, leading to economic and cultural decline, if his warnings were not heeded.

Lord Haskins's views - particularly on the BBC - are likely to be taken seriously, as he is regarded as an important adviser to the government in areas of regulation.

The BBC's charter is due to be reviewed in 2006, and the debate over its future is under way.

But it was the peer's remarks about drugs that caused most surprise. "The state perseveres with some moral regulations which are mainly symbolic and largely ineffective in protecting the young, such as rules against under-age selling of tobacco, drink and lottery tickets, and total bans on drug selling," he said. "Such regulations are, if anything, counterproductive. The excitement of breaking them becomes a stimulant."

Such rules simply "criminalise the market", he said.

Lord Haskins said he believed cannabis should be legalised, and that harder drugs could be made more readily available on prescription as part of medical programmes to treat addicts.

The peer's stance is sharply at odds with government policy. The home secretary, Jack Straw, has taken a tough line on illegal substances, and will not countenance any relaxation of the laws governing hard drugs. He is also opposed to the decriminalisation of cannabis - let alone its legalisation. The government's only concession to campaigners has been to permit limited trials to test the drug's medical benefits.

In last night's lecture, which was sponsored by the Guardian Media Group, Lord Haskins delivered a wide-ranging attack on the state of regulation in Britain, and called for radical institutional reform.

Bodies such as the MCC (now the England Cricket Board), the Football Association, the Lawn Tennis Association and the Royal and Ancient Golf Club should be scrapped. "They gave the world the games of cricket, football, tennis and golf, but have, through their privileged, unaccountable incompetence, reduced British sport to the third division."

He could see no need for the restrictive licensing laws, which served only to encourage hooliganism, nor any justification to maintain an established church.

Any attempt to regulate the internet "to prevent it from doing moral damage to us" would be a "fruitless exercise". People should be free to download pornography if they wanted, so long as it did not harm a third party.

The monarchy should be reformed, and the House of Lords abolished. He also criticised Prince Charles's stance on GM foods, saying advances in technology were of great advantage to poorer countries.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Links
fields.body:
Links

Broadcaster Yes Television has signed a wide range of e-content deals to bring leading websites on to digital television. It said it would integrate its internet protocol-based VOD service with e-content taken from partners' web sites. The deals are with Sportingbet.com, Gameswire.com, and Landmark Communications' Weather Services International.

 Access

More than 10m people have access to the internet for the first time, according to a survey published yesterday. The Internet pollster MMXI Europe study found that Freeserve and the BBC's site BBC.co.uk were consistently ranked in the top 10 of global sites used by British surfers.

fields.headline: Orange signs up record numbers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Orange, Britain's third largest mobile operator, has signed up a record 1.2m customers in the past three months confirming the country's strong appetite for wireless communications.
fields.body:
Orange, Britain's third largest mobile operator, has signed up a record 1.2m customers in the past three months confirming the country's strong appetite for wireless communications.

Orange, which was sold by Vodafone to France Telecom for £27bn in May, said its total customer base had grown to just over 7m at the June quarter. It ranks in market share behind Vodafone and BT, which are expected to release their sales figures later this week.

Orange's explosive growth is expected to position it as the fastest growing mobile group of Britain's four operators.

Graham Howe, Orange deputy chief executive, said: "These are impressive results, with the customer base growing by 4.2m in the last year."

Orange and France Telecom together cover 22 countries with their mobile interests. Orange said it added 212,000 net new contract customers in the quarter, making its total base 2.75m overall

The less profitable "prepay" customers grew by 984,000, taking that total subscriber base to 4.4m.

Analysts expect the number of handsets among Britain's 59.1m population to have risen to more than 30m by the end of June. They forecast mobile sales of 3.1m-3.4m in the quarter.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
10 x 10
9.20pm, BBC2

The highlands of Scotland is the setting for this tender fictional short about a young woman stuck in a dead-end job selling hot dogs from a roadside van. She harbours dreams of going to New York but her boss ridicules the idea. Each day, a mysterious and quiet old man emerges from the forest for a cup of tea and the woman decides to find out what he is up to. What follows, transforms her life. Written by Denise Whittaker and directed by Sarah Gavron.

TV To Go
10.50pm, BBC1
Anyone who has ever been tempted to take a pickaxe to their computer will take some comfort from this one-off comedy sketch special featuring Pauline McLynn from Father Ted. Centring on the dehumanising effects of technology and modern consumerism, the programme contains some truly amusing moments: like the all too familiar incidence of workers e-mailing colleagues who are sat just feet away; the "buy now pay nothing for twenty years" advertisements; and the supermarket manager interrogating a disloyal customer for daring to buy a pint of milk from another store. "No one leaves the loyalty club", he spits. Welcome relief for technophobes and the consumer-weary alike.

Under The Knife
11.05pm, Channel 4
It's difficult to see why anyone would want to watch a series about surgical operations. Perhaps programme makers feel we have become so anaesthetised to hospital docusoaps that the only route left is to frighten the bejezus out of us. Such programmes can of course be a source of shared information for sufferers. Which must surely be the reason why social worker Mike agreed to have a surgical procedure on his penis aired on national television. Mike suffers from Peyronie's disease, a condition which causes a thickening of the erectile tissue, making it difficult to achieve a full erection. Here we see him undergoing an operation to correct the problem. We even get to follow his progress three weeks later as he gets his first chance to find out if it's worked.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Watch this
(Stuart Rosenberg, 1967) 8pm, Sky Cinema

Paul Newman is the prisoner who maintains inner freedom despite the brutalities of a deep South chain gang. The hardnut action is lightened by a witty streak - such as the egg-eating contest. Strother Martin is the vicious camp boss; fellow convict George Kennedy won an Oscar.

Passion Fish
(John Sayles, 1992) 8pm, FilmFour
A quietly intimate tale of two women: Mary McDonnell is May-Alice, a TV soap star returning to her Louisiana roots to lick her wounds after losing the use of her legs in a car accident. She dismisses a succession of helpers and hits the bottle, until Alfre Woodard's Chantelle arrives and insists she gets a grip.The developing relationship between the two is touching and always absorbing.

Les Miserables
(Bille August, 1998) 10pm, Sky Premier
Yet another adaptation of Victor Hugo's sullied 19th-century classic, but despite convincing period re-creation, August's version overstays its welcome and views events with a cloying black-and-white morality. Liam Neeson reprises his Oskar Schindler worthiness as reformed criminal-turned-mayor Valjean (who doesn't age a hair during t30-odd years); and there's a touch of Dick Dastardly to Geoffrey Rush's determined policeman Jabert, whose lifelong mission it is to hound him. Uma Thurman and Claire Danes provide some much-needed diversions.

Scream
(Wes Craven, 1996) 10.20pm, FilmFour
A masked psycho-killer is stalking the teenies in a small American town called Woodsboro. It looks like any other teeny-slasher venue, but Craven and scriptwriter Kevin Williamson are steeped in the black arts of horror movies and refuse to do it straight. From the moment the killer asks terrified Drew Barrymore to name the killer in Friday The 13th, it's clear this is as much knowing comedy as blood-and-guts fest. The film that made a star of Neve Campbell, it was good enough to spawn two sequels.

fields.headline: Chang goes fly-fishing without bugs
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText:
The "red-eye" overnight flight from New York, arriving London first thing in the morning, tends to be packed with high-powered executives, bankers and lawyers on their way to early meetings in the City.

So to see Steve Chang, founder and chief executive of Nasdaq-listed anti-virus company Trend Micro, huddled up in first class last week was no surprise.
fields.body:
The "red-eye" overnight flight from New York, arriving London first thing in the morning, tends to be packed with high-powered executives, bankers and lawyers on their way to early meetings in the City.

So to see Steve Chang, founder and chief executive of Nasdaq-listed anti-virus company Trend Micro, huddled up in first class last week was no surprise. Yet instead of travelling for a t te-à-t te at Goldman Sachs or Morgan Stanley, Mr Chang was stopping off in town to catch a performance of the musical The King and I before heading to Iceland for a family salmon fishing holiday.

As his employees and advisers never tire of saying: Mr Chang is a bit different.

In 1998 the then 43-year-old entrepreneur set up Trend Micro with his wife Jenny in their garage in California, using $5,000 (£3,300) of savings. Having moved to the US from Taiwan in the 1980s to complete a master's degree in computer science, he was quickly immersed in the business of virus-busting software. There were then only 30 know viruses, while today there are an estimated 30,000 web bugs biting and the demand from corporations wanting to minimise disruption to their systems from the likes of the Melissa and Love Bug viruses has transformed Trend Micro into a company valued at $10bn, with the Chang family stake worth $4.5bn.

Despite his wealth and success Mr Chang still dresses for work in a company T-shirt and chinos. Colleagues say they often struggle to keep up with him, such is his passion and energy for the job.

"In the past we only ever took calls from IT officers but now the calls all seem to come from chief executive level," Mr Chang says of the increased awareness of the threat viruses pose. "They want to know why their server is down and why their email is not working. They don't realise how much they rely on it until it is taken away from them."

Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft, Lucent Technologies, and Sun Microsystems are among blue chip clients which in 1999 helped Trend Micro record sales of $133m, net income of $21m and employ 851 people in 15 countries. The British office, in Maidenhead, Berkshire, serves companies and operations including BT, NTL, Deutsche Bank and the London fire brigade. Mr Chang is courting several of the City's leading financial institutions and leading internet providers.

Trend's key advantage at the moment is that it prevents viruses from entering corporate email and intranet systems, rather than just protecting individual computers.

"It is not enough to simply protect your desktop computer with viruses now being spread by email," Mr Chang says. "You need to prevent the virus at the gateway level and stop it before it enters your system."

He hopes that by partnering with leading internet access providers he can offer to protect home internet users for around £1 per month.

Trend Micro operates in a competitive market with large US corporates like Symantec and Network Associates - owner of the Dr Solomon's anti-virus brand - competing for the same client base. Mr Chang concedes that when a virus strikes, customers have to be totally satisfied with his company's response or they are likely to move to a rival.

"Within two hours of the ILOVEYOU virus being detected we notified all our customers and developed an antidote. Recently, however, one of the major brokerage houses we deal with on Wall Street was hit and its systems were down for two hours.

"Our programmers developed a cure incredibly quickly but the chief executive was still unhappy because it had delayed him filing details of one of the IPOs [initial public offerings, or share flotations] he was handling to the securities and exchange commission. We have to be a customer-focused service company as well as a technology product company."

Mr Chang has built up a 30,000-virus collection stored on 14 PC servers in a locked vault in Taipei. He even calls himself an "e-epidemiologist".

An in-house team of highly paid programmers is on call 24 hours a day in case a new virus manifests itself.

The Changs themselves are based in Tokyo; the book Mrs Chang has written charting the growth of Trend Micro is one of the biggest selling in Asia.

As father and sons spend this week fishing in Iceland, she plans to put her feet up in a hotel and set about scripting a film based on her book.

Unlike the viruses, it is a story they hope continues to spread.

He hopes that by partnering with leading internet access providers he can offer to protect home internet users for around £1 per month. Trend Micro operates in a competitive market with large US corporates like Symantec and Network Associates - owner of the Dr Solomon's anti-virus brand - competing for the same client base. Mr Chang concedes that when a virus strikes, customers have to be totally satisfied with his company's response or they are likely to move to a rival. "Within two hours of the ILOVEYOU virus being detected we notified all our customers and developed an antidote. Recently, however, one of the major brokerage houses we deal with on Wall Street was hit and its systems were down for two hours. "Our programmers developed a cure incredibly quickly but the chief executive was still unhappy because it had delayed him filing details of one of the IPOs [initial public offerings, or share flotations] he was handling to the securities and exchange commission. We have to be a customer-focused service company as well as a technology product company." Mr Chang has built up a 30,000-virus collection stored on 14 PC servers in a locked vault in Taipei. He even calls himself an "e-epidemiologist". An in-house team of highly paid programmers is on call 24 hours a day in case a new virus manifests itself. The Changs themselves are based in Tokyo; the book Mrs Chang has written charting the growth of Trend Micro is one of the biggest selling in Asia. As father and sons spend this week fishing in Iceland, she plans to put her feet up in a hotel and set about scripting a film based on her book. Unlike the viruses, it is a story they hope continues to spread.

fields.headline: Indigovision plans float to raise £40m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Indigovision, the online video specialist, yesterday announced plans to float on the London exchange despite dramatic falls in dot.com and technology stocks over recent weeks.
fields.body:
Indigovision, the online video specialist, yesterday announced plans to float on the London exchange despite dramatic falls in dot.com and technology stocks over recent weeks.

The move, scheduled for next month, is designed to raise around £40m for the company, which will be used to help finance further expansion in the internet video market.

Indigovision will be valued at about £125m.

Alan Blunt, marketing vice- president, said the company would prove popular with investors because it had put together a complete package for businesses that wanted to send video images over the net. The software encompasses all elements of visual communication, from acquisition and compression to recording and viewing.

Oliver Vellacott, chief executive officer and founder of the six year old Edinburgh based company, said: "We believe the market for visual communications is about to experience rapid growth. Our technology, VideoBridge, enables full motion real time video to be transmitted worldwide, with digital quality and security, using local or wide area networks, wireless links or the internet."

Indigovision reported sales of £150 000 in the year to July 1999, but they are predicted to reach £1m for the year to July 2000.
