fields.headline: Cellnet accused of unfair subsidy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, has accused the BT's mobile-phone subsidiary, Cellnet, of subsidising its own service providers at the expense of independent operators.
fields.body:
Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, has accused the BT's mobile-phone subsidiary, Cellnet, of subsidising its own service providers at the expense of independent operators.

The announcement was a further blow to BT which has suffered a disastrous year. The company's share price recently plunged to an 18 month low after a profits warning, though the shares yesterday followed the rest of the FTSE and ended 46p higher at 900p.

Oftel said that BT Cellnet had used its network business to subsidise its own tied service providers, BT Lumina and BT Mobile. The subsidy ensured BT Lumina and BT Mobile could sustain losses after they failed to cover their costs on services supplied to customers.

In a draft ruling, Oftel said the 30 independent service providers selling airtime on BT Cellnet's network did not receive the subsidy and so were prevented from competing equally with BT Lumina and BT Mobile.

The operators selling Cellnet airtime include Kingston Communications, Genesis and Sony.

David Edmonds, director-general of the telecommunications regulator, said: "Oftel's review of the mobile market in 1999 found that competition was increasing. I am proposing that BT Cellnet should take action to resolve this problem to ensure that competition continues to develop."

Oftel has called on BT to submit quarterly financial details of new customers to its mobile subsidiary and show it is complying with the watchdog's demands.

BT rejected Oftel's draft ruling, stating that it did "not unfairly cross-subsidise its service-provision activities".

It said the formula used as the basis for Oftel's cross-subsidy decision no longer applied to the mobile phone market, which had changed dramatically in the past seven years.

Oftel also investigated Vodafone, but found it was not cross-subsidising its service providers.

fields.headline: Upwardly mobile commerce
fields.standfirst:
The arrival of wireless internet access is breeding a second wave of web portals

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: For those still fixated with e-commerce, forget it - you're woefully out of date. The latest thing is m-commerce, as in mobile phone.
fields.body:
For those still fixated with e-commerce, forget it - you're woefully out of date. The latest thing is m-commerce, as in mobile phone.

The arrival of wireless internet access has led not only to a new breed of jargon but to a second wave of web portals - this time designed to exploit the mobile. Just as the land grab which occurred a number of years ago and left the likes of Yahoo!, America Online and, in this country, Freeserve on top in PC internet access, so the battle has begun anew in wireless.

In a recent note, Merrill Lynch forecast that the European mobile portal market would be worth £14bn by 2005 and £63bn by 2010.

The model is similar to existing PC-based portals which act as an entry point and guide to the web, relying on a mix of advertising and, in this case, m-commerce. The existing mobile portals tend to provide news, sports and share price information, TV listings and weather presented for the smaller screens of a mobile.

The growing ubiquity of mobile phones has led analysts to predict that wireless will become the main means of accessing the internet within a few years. Certainly the value awarded to mobile portals was apparent when Vodafone used its alliance with Vivendi of France for the impending launch of Vizzavi as the trump card in its hostile takeover of Mannesmann.

The potential prize has prompted a rapid fire series of entrants into the market. BT Cellnet has been an innovator and launched the mobile version of its Genie web portal in January. Malcolm Appleby, head of new applications at Genie, says the model for the company is to build the mobile web portal in parallel to the company's PC-based service launched in 1997.

Elsewhere, ITouch, which is 70% owned by Tony O'Reilly's Independent News & Media last week announced plans for a £300m stock market flotation. The Carphone Warehouse is getting in on the act to add some sparkle to its forthcoming float with its own portal Mviva which will be loaded on to handsets sold through its stores.

Mviva is being launched with America Online which has suddenly found itself facing the same kinds of problems vexing Microsoft. Until now AOL has primarily been linked to the PC and needs to adapt to the so called Martini-approach - any time, any place, any where. Yahoo! has a 50-50 joint venture with Telecom Italia Mobile and is unlikely to stop there.

For now, though, the independents will have a difficult time breaking into the market. In marked contrast to the development of the internet on fixed wires, the mobile phone networks are alive to the opportunity of the internet. They will be keen to extend their reach from collecting call revenues to shares of commerce and advertising.

In the short term most users will lack the wherewithal to switch to a different portal and will use the network's own by default. The networks, however, will only have a brief time in which to establish their brands before the market is blown open.

"It's much less easy for users to roam away from the portal on wireless internet, so the incumbents will have a huge advantage if they get their acts together," said internet analyst Gerard Van Hamel Platerink at investment bank Schroders Salomon Smith Barney. "But they realise they only have a small window. It will become easier and easier to move around as technology develops, particularly voice activation which will allow you to simply say, for instance, 'go to Yahoo.com'."

It has already been established that the networks will not get away with any attempts to shield users from portals or websites other than their own.

France Telecom recently lost a court case brought by an independent portal and was forced to publish details of a code which unlocks the handset. British Telecom has also been rebuked by regulator Oftel for making it difficult to remove Genie as a handset's home page.

Mobile internet portals will begin to realise their potential with technologies due to arrive in the next few years. GPRS will introduce an "always on" function which means access to data and websites will be far faster. The real step change will be in 2002-3 when the third generation mobile phone services will introduce high bandwidth services and make the experience of surfing on a handset virtually the same as a PC. At that point it will be far easier to navigate the wider web and far more content will be reconfigured for mobile devices.

On your handset

Mviva

Operator: Carphone Warehouse/AOL

Content from Abbey National, Loot, Lastminute.com

Subscribers to come from 800 UK outlets

Genie

Operator: BT
Content from Virgin Music, BBC, Excite

900,000 subscribers

iTouch

Operator: Independent News & Media
No content providers announced

Will be accessed from other portals

Vizzavi

Operator: Vodafone/Vivendi

No content providers announced

Potential 70m subscribers

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: A stunning return to form by market heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch helped the FTSE 100 to its biggest one-day points gain in five months on Monday.
fields.body:
A stunning return to form by market heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch helped the FTSE 100 to its biggest one-day points gain in five months on Monday.

With good supporting performances from Wall Street and the rest of the telecoms sector, the FTSE 100 ended the first day of the third quarter 157.7 points higher at 6,470.4. Over the past two sessions the blue chip index has risen more than 230 points.

But dealers were not carried away by the performance, noting that volume remained low and the strong gains came courtesy of a handful of stocks. The market also has to grapple with the meeting of the Bank of England monetary policy committee and the key US employment report later this week.

Vodafone, the FTSE 100's biggest stock, closed 26p higher at 267p, on hopes that the forthcoming round of third generation mobile phone licences in Europe may not cost as much as originally feared. Strong second quarter subscriber figures from Orange also gave the stock a boost.

BT also joined in the fun, notching up a gain of 46p to 900p, despite Oftel telling its Cellnet division to stop subsidising its mobile phone division. Elsewhere in the sector, Colt Telecom picked up 200p to close at £24.00 and Cable & Wireless advanced 46p to £11.65. Technology issues were also well bid helped by Nasdaq's advance. Logica was the pick, up 131p at £16.95, closely followed by Bookham, 77p better at 3,923.

But media stocks were broadly lower hit by reports of a negative note from ABN Amro. The broker was said to have lowered its investment recommendations on Pearson (down 101p at £19.99) and Reed (down 16p at 559p). EMI nevertheless managed to buck the trend, closing 80p stronger at 680p, a reaction, dealers said, to Friday's artificially low closing price.

Banking stocks were out of favour after HSBC, off 2.5p at 753, slashed its basic mortgage rate by almost 1%. Halifax, Britain's biggest mortgage lender, was the worst affected, losing 39p to 595p. Northern Rock also suffered, falling by 12p to 328p.

Lower down the market, Hartford Group, owner of the Pharmacy restaurant in west London, shed 5.5p to 16.5p after warning on profits, but Jellyworks finished 2.5p stronger at 34.5p. Shortly after the market closed the internet investment group said it was considering its options in light of consolidation in the sector.

webTitle: Police push Blair into yob fines climbdown

fields.headline: Police push Blair into yob fines climbdown
fields.standfirst: Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday made one of his most humiliating climbdowns when he was forced by a revolt of Britain's top police officers to abandon his plan for £100 instant fines to tackle drunken louts only 72 hours after its launch.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday made one of his most humiliating climbdowns when he was forced by a revolt of Britain's top police officers to abandon his plan for £100 instant fines to tackle drunken louts only 72 hours after its launch.

The fatal crash-landing of the high-profile law and order initiative was all the more painful for Mr Blair because it had been developed in Downing Street as a cure to the cabinet's bout of "post-Women's Institute tension", which has seen rows over Europe and the royal family and criticism of the Blair style by the Labour-supporting novelist Ken Follett.

"One or two chief constables said it was not a goer," said the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, after a two hour Downing Street "seminar" to discuss the rise in violent crime.

"The prime minister was using a metaphor when he spoke about young hooligans being frogmarched to cashpoints. The discussion focused on fixed penalty fines. The idea of the police collecting money did not seem a feasible thing to do," said the minister.

In place of on-the-spot fines the police said they were keen to look at ideas such as fixed penalty tickets, which can be challenged in court, to tackle growing volumes of low level violent crime such as minor robbery and fighting.

"We do not want to see any change in the practice where magistrates' courts are seen as the appropriate forum for collecting fines. We want to find ways of intervening in a more simple way," said Sir John Evans, chief constable of Avon and Somerset and chairman of the Association of Chief Police Officers. He said the police favoured penalties which simplified the justice process and did not involve going to court.

Fixed penalty fines might work to tackle low level disorder: "The person would be arrested, taken to the police station and, if appropriate, a fixed penalty ticket might be issued. It would allow the officer to be back on the street without hav ing to go through the bureaucracy of a court appearance."

Other ideas "kicked around" during the seminar included extending bans on drinking in public places and introducing attendance centres where louts could be sent on arrest to cool their heels. The extension of powers to ban public drinking would involve giving back to police the power of arrest of anybody they see drinking but who is not yet drunk. In the past this has foundered on the fact that it bans both the white wine country picnic as well as alcoholics in the local park.

Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, last night said the episode had been a humiliating climbdown for Mr Blair: "Anyone with an ounce of common sense would have seen that this scheme was unworkable."

webTitle: Patent court backs CAT against rivals

fields.headline: Patent court backs CAT against rivals
fields.trailText: Cambridge Antibody Technology scored a crucial victory in the patent courts last night, defeating a challenge to its core technology from three overseas rivals.
fields.body:
Cambridge Antibody Technology scored a crucial victory in the patent courts last night, defeating a challenge to its core technology from three overseas rivals.

The European Patent Office in Munich upheld the biotech company's "McCafferty" patent for its method of mimicking the human immune system in laboratory conditions.

This technology, called phage display, is central to CAT's ability to find antibodies useful in tackling disease. The company has a library of tens of thousands of antibodies.

The patent was under attack from Morphosys of Germany, Dyax of the United States and Sweden's BioInvent. They claimed that the phage display process was in widespread use before CAT secured its patent in 1996.

CAT's chief executive, David Chiswell, said: "The McCafferty patent reflects the pioneering work performed by CAT on the phage display of antibodies and this decision reinforces our strong global intellectual property portfolio in this field."

The news came after the market close but CAT's shares yesterday rose 12p to £30.02.

Based in Melbourne, south of Cambridge, CAT has a market value of some £800m. It has a product for rheumatoid arthritis in phase three clinical trials and hopes to forge technological partnerships with global drugs corporations.

webTitle: A sterling effort on overseas investment

fields.headline: A sterling effort on overseas investment
fields.standfirst: National assets up for grabs
fields.trailText: The figures on inward investment due on Wednesday will be "absolutely stunning," according to one of the many Whitehall insiders being quoted yesterday as the storm raged over the leaking of a civil service memo predicting Armageddon for all manufacturers based in Britain.
fields.body:
The figures on inward investment due on Wednesday will be "absolutely stunning," according to one of the many Whitehall insiders being quoted yesterday as the storm raged over the leaking of a civil service memo predicting Armageddon for all manufacturers based in Britain.

On the surface, the figures, even though we haven't seen them yet, are being presented as evidence that as a country we are doing just fine outside euroland. The memo, on the other hand, says that whatever the recent past, in the immediate present the strength of sterling could well see investment sucked out of Britain - and everyone from Kenneth Clarke, the onetime Tory chancellor, to Sir Ken Jackson of the engineering union was called out to help ram home the pro-euro message.

But before getting too immersed in this debate, politicians and pundits alike should probably stop and think what exactly inward investment is.

Televisually, the phrase throws up images of Korean businessman cutting the ribbon on new hi-fi assembly plants in former mining communities. In reality it is more about foreign investors buying assets on British soil and/or developing those assets further.

The genuine explanation for "stunning" British inward investment figures for 1998 and the "absolutely stunning" ones projected for 1999 is that the world's highly developed economies have been going through a mergers and acquisitions fest the like of which has never been seen before.

During 1998, cross-border mergers and acquisitions activity amounted to $544bn (£360bn); last year the figure doubled. All this buying and selling of assets is reflected in various countries' inward and outward investment statistics. Were it not for the way that Britain's outward investment is healthier than inward investment, anyone crowing about this Wednesday's figures would effectively be celebrating the piecemeal sale of the British economy overseas.

By way of example, Sweden pushed Britain down to third place in the inward-investment league tables last year, with some $20bn of inflows totalling $78bn reflecting just one deal - the merger between the Swedes' leading drugs group Astra with Britain's Zeneca. The new company is now based in London, W1.

In fact, the latest figures published by the United Nations conference on trade and development, the global authority on the subject of foreign direct investment, show that Britain overtook the US as the biggest overseas investor for the first time since 1988 last year, with inflows of $63bn and outflows of $212bn.

And how did little ol' Britain manage this? Well, start by looking at the strength of sterling.

With one click

The future is bricks and clicks, not bricks and mortar, or so the business-school mantra goes. But yesterday's astonishing 1% cut in mortgage rates by HSBC, undercutting all the new internet or phone banks, turns that piece of wisdom on its head.

The timing was especially cruel for Jim Spowart, the mortgage guru who took Standard Life Bank from nothing to 15% of the market last year, and yesterday unveiled the cutting-edge, home-loan products from his new £120m e-venture, Halifax's Intelligent Finance. IF has already lost the edge to HSBC, which is offering rock-bottom rates to common or garden branch customers who never go near a PC.

Immediately the cry of "loss leader" is being howled by HSBC's rivals, which is odd as loss-leading is the basic strategy of all dot.com entrants into financial services. It is the strategy behind every mortgage product charged at less than the base rate.

fields.headline: Virgin's £7.5bn east coast promise
fields.trailText: Virgin Rail yesterday promised to provide new or completely rebuilt trains on the east coast main line between London and Scotland if it is awarded the franchise to operate the route by the shadow Strategic Rail Authority.
fields.body:
Virgin Rail yesterday promised to provide new or completely rebuilt trains on the east coast main line between London and Scotland if it is awarded the franchise to operate the route by the shadow Strategic Rail Authority.

It put forward a £7.5bn plan to develop a new high-speed line with money raised from the government, Railtrack and private business.

Unlike its main competitor, GNER, which now holds the franchise, Virgin does not believe that tilting trains will reduce travelling time by more than 15 minutes between London and Edinburgh.

It said its proposals would lead to immediate improvements on the route. All journey times would be speeded up and capacity would be increased by 40%.

Sir Richard Branson, Virgin chairman, said: "This is truly a proposal that will deliver a 21st century railway for the east coast main line."

Under the plan, cities such as Sunderland and Lincoln would be provided with direct rail services to London for the first time, and there would be a train service between Yorkshire and Stansted, Britain's fastest expanding airport. Sir Richard said the proposals would allow the company to challenge the domestic airlines operating between London and Scotland. "It will provide a real alternative to the clogged motorways."

The plan, which is backed by Virgin's partner Stagecoach, has at its heart a new 120-mile stretch of line through middle England, mainly farmland.

Virgin believes the line would cause minimum inconvenience and would be cheaper than the refurbishment of the existing line, which has to pass through key bottlenecks.

The final decision rests with the SSRA and its chairman, Sir Alastair Morton. On present evidence the SSRA is unlikely to approve the scheme. It is recognised for its innovation, but some railway experts believe that the planning implications are too difficult for the challenge to be taken up.

Will Whitehorn, Virgin's executive director, said that diesel locomotives would be fitted at the back to provide extra power and increased acceleration. This would lead to increased reliability across the east coast line. Virgin also plans to rebuild the existing fleet of electric trains, to be called Virgin Vitesse.

Sir Richard is concerned, however, that Railtrack's plans to upgrade the east coast main line may produce even bigger delays than are being experienced on the upgrade of the west coats main line between London to Glasgow.

Mr Whitehorn claimed that this was the advantage of opening up the first new line in Britain for decades. If approved, it would run from Northallerton in north Yorkshire to south of Peterborough.

Virgin's partner, Bechtel, said the timetable over a 10-year period was "demanding but achievable". Journey times over this period would be reduced from four hours 25 minutes from London to Edinburgh now, to three hours 11 minutes in 2009.

fields.headline: IMI
fields.trailText: Engineering group IMI got a kick in the nuts and bolts yesterday when investment bank Lehman Brothers cut its recommendation from "neutral" to "underperform."
fields.body:
Engineering group IMI got a kick in the nuts and bolts yesterday when investment bank Lehman Brothers cut its recommendation from "neutral" to "underperform."

The move coincided with a counter-attack against the financial community from the metal-bashing sector. The Engineering and Marine Training Authority (Emta) lambasted the City and politicians for starving what it saw as the country's real wealth creators by funnelling too much investment into e-commerce.

IMI shares slid 10p to 273p as Lehman lowered its earnings per share forecasts 6% to 30.7p for this year and 8% to 32.6p for next. IMI's 2000 earnings estimates were chopped from £169m to £159m.

Analysts argued that the business would be hit harder than expected by a slowdown in British building activity and the brakes being applied to US economic growth.

Lehman argues that the combination of low earnings growth and further forecast risk was likely to result in an underperforming share price.

That was tough news to swallow for IMI whose share price has clawed itself up from below 200p in early February to its Friday close at near a year-long high.

IMI is a well run company that has worked hard to keep itself fit in difficult times. Chief executive Gary Allen bought innovators such as plastic pipe specialist Polypipe and closed down loss-making plants such as its copper producing facility at Walsall.

IMI is not massively hi-tech but its no doubt the kind of firm that Mike Sanderson of the Emta would like to see more support for. He told the all-party parliamentary engineering group that politicians, the City and the media were obssessed with dot.com firms.

Too much time and money was wasted on low-value e-commerce firms dependent upon unreliable technology, he believed. "A civil servant said to me recently: 'Why should we worry about shipbuilding when we have new industries like e-commerce?'

"My answer was: 'Look inside a Trident submarine at technology that could destroy the planet if it went wrong - then recall how many times your e-mail has gone down'."

fields.headline: GUS takes home Burberry licence
fields.standfirst: £137m deal sets the scene for a sale
fields.trailText: Great Universal Stores yesterday increased speculation about the imminent disposal of Burberry by unveiling a £137m deal to take control of the luxury goods company's Spanish licensing arm.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores yesterday increased speculation about the imminent disposal of Burberry by unveiling a £137m deal to take control of the luxury goods company's Spanish licensing arm.

The move to buy the thriving Barcelona business from the Mora family, which established it 35 years ago, follows the renegotiation of the licensing agreement for Burberry in Japan.

GUS, the catalogue retail group, has come under pressure from disgruntled shareholders to hive off some of its more attractive businesses. Shares are down 40% this year but recovered 6p to close at 431p yesterday on news of the deal.

Analysts said that GUS's bringing Burberry Spain under its control was seen as an inevitable step towards a sell-off. GUS has indicated in the past that Burberry and various other parts of the business were non-core assets.

There has been speculation that Experian, its financial information arm, is also being dressed up for an early flotation or demerger.

Finance director David Tyler declined to comment on possible disposals but said the company was aiming to increase shareholder value. He said plans to bring together its ailing home shopping division with Argos, its catalogue retail chain, were proceeding well.

GUS group profits in the 12 months to March 31 fell from £450.4m to £379.6m, influenced by the relentless decline of its traditional agency home shopping business.

But Burberry Spain has been a runaway success, with sales increasing by 20% per annum over the last five years. Spain is the second biggest country of operation behind Japan, the only other franchised part of the Burberry empire.

Burberry has become one of Spain's leading clothing brands selling £260m worth of men's, women's and children's wear per year, the local market having warmed to the new Thomas Burberry casual brand. The Spanish company now has 800 staff.

Rose Marie Bravo, chief executive of the Burberry group, said the Spanish management team would remain with the business. "We are taking control of the brand. This will lead to greater consistency throughout the business," she said.

The worldwide Burberry business doubled its trading profits to £21.7m last year boosted by a new range of handbags, scarves, and other accessories.

webTitle: Bottle stopper Balls Bros moves on

fields.headline: Bottle stopper Balls Bros moves on
fields.trailText: The real Old Lady of Threadneedle Street, Maureen Gilmurray, retires this week when the Balls Brothers winebar where she has worked for almost 30 years closes down.
fields.body:
The real Old Lady of Threadneedle Street, Maureen Gilmurray, retires this week when the Balls Brothers winebar where she has worked for almost 30 years closes down.

The drinkery itself, the oldest Balls outlet, has been a source of lubrication to officials from the Bank of England, the Liffe market, and many scores of brokers and fund managers, for some 40 years. Richard Balls, a fifth-gener ation Balls and now managing director of the chain of wine bars, says he thinks it used to be a bank manager's office - judging by the sumptuous panelling.

The whole triangular site around what is known as Threadballs, previously owned by the Royal Bank of Scotland, which runs round from Threadneedle Street up towards the stock exchange on Old Broad Street, is being redeveloped.

Mr Balls says the 16-bar chain should announce the opening of a new wine bar later in the year. But the firm is not following fickle wine bar fashion: there will not be a stock market flotation: "We will stay an independent concern. We want to continue doing things in a way that feels right."

For Ms Gilmurray, the right thing is a return to the west coast of Ireland. "I've earned the rest," she says.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: KLM holds out hope for deal
fields.body:
KLM holds out hope for deal

KLM Royal Dutch Airlines hopes it and British Airways will reach agreement over the terms of their planned merger and key personnel issues by the end of this week, a spokesman said.

The companies have as yet reached no deal, said Dig Ishta, denying press reports to that effect.

Asked if a deal will be in place by the end of the week, he said: "I hope so, but I can't say ... We are under time pressure. We cannot go on forever."

Rum do over brand names

The European Union has asked the World Trade Organisation to look into a dispute between two world leading drinks manufacturers over which has the rights to a particular trade mark in the US. Bacardi, of Cuba, and France's Pernod Ricard, are battling over the "Havana Club" brand, under which both are marketing versions of a rum drink.

Watchdog scolds banks

Banks and building societies were yesterday scolded by a financial watchdog after a mystery shopping survey of 1,500 branches found that four in 10 fail to meet basic standards of information on charges and interest rates.

The survey, carried out by the Banking Code Standards Board, found that 40% of bank customers are not told about debit or credit interest rates on their current accounts, and one in five are not told about overdraft charges. However, 56% of the those surveyed rated their overall experience of dealing with banks and building societies as good or excellent.

Eureko heads towards float

Eureko is just the basic platform of what could eventually become a major force in the European insurance market, said chief executive Joao Talone.

Eureko, an alliance of eight mutually owned insurers including Friends Provident, yesterday announced a two-track road towards flotation.

Two members, Achmea of Holland and Banco Comercial Portugues, outlined plans to pool their insurance assets to move in the next two years towards an initial public offering of their stock.

The other six companies, to be known as the Eureko Alliance Partners, will have looser ties, but will also have the option of joining the floating Euriko at some later point.

Glaxo boss gets second job

Sir Richard Sykes, the chairman of Glaxo Wellcome, has confirmed that he will become rector of Imperial College in January, after the pharmaceuticals group's merger with SmithKline Beecham.

Sir Richard will succeed the retiring Lord Oxburgh at the college, which specialises in science, technology and medicine.

He is likely to be paid about £200,000 for the job, compared to his present salary of £1.2m.

webTitle: IBT fights for support in row over reforms

fields.headline: IBT fights for support in row over reforms
fields.trailText: Directors of the £270m International Biotechnology Trust are struggling to drum up support from shareholders in an increasingly acrimonious battle with Millennium Partners, a New York arbitrage firm that is calling for reforms.
fields.body:
Directors of the £270m International Biotechnology Trust are struggling to drum up support from shareholders in an increasingly acrimonious battle with Millennium Partners, a New York arbitrage firm that is calling for reforms.

The abrupt resignation of the trust's principal, Jeremy Curnock Cook, on Friday has failed to satisfy disgruntled shareholders, who are concerned about poor corporate governance and an unsteady relationship with NM Rothschild, which manages the fund's investments.

One of IBT's biggest shareholders yesterday called for the management of the trust to be put out to tender, with Rothschild invited to re-pitch.

He said: "The board have left it very late in the day to defend themselves. There are still some issues which remain unresolved. I really can't recall anything like this before."

The trust has been engulfed in a swirl of controversy since it emerged that Mr Curnock Cook holds share options worth more than $1m (£670,000) in a number of the biotech companies in which IBT has invested.

At an extraordinary meeting on Friday, shareholders will consider resolutions to remove two further directors and to "reorganise and reconstruct" the rest. The deadline for proxy votes is tomorrow. Millennium owns 10% of the shares.

IBT's broker, Merrill Lynch, is said to have been taken by surprise by the extent of the allegations made against the trust.

Many shareholders are concerned about Rothschild's commitment to the biotech sector - the bank said last year it wanted to withdraw from life sciences, but has subsequently changed its mind.

IBT's board argues that despite all the concerns, the trust has prospered, outperforming the Nasdaq biotech index by 90% over the past 18 months. A spokesman said: "It would be unique to see a trust that's performed so well disappear."

AThe shares slipped 3.5p to 257.5p.

webTitle: Warning fails to dent Hartford ambitions

fields.headline: Warning fails to dent Hartford ambitions
fields.trailText: The owners of trendy Notting Hill eaterie Pharmacy, are pressing ahead with plans for a second unit in the heart of London's West End despite yesterday issuing a profits warning that wiped 25% off the value of its shares.
fields.body:
The owners of trendy Notting Hill eaterie Pharmacy, are pressing ahead with plans for a second unit in the heart of London's West End despite yesterday issuing a profits warning that wiped 25% off the value of its shares.

Market sources say management are also looking at possible mergers with other restaurant and late-night bar operators. Hartford Group shares fell 5.5p to 16.5p after it said poor spring and early summer weather conditions had hit trading and that pre-tax profits for the full year to December 31 would be "significantly lower than expected".

Finance director Doug Gardner said Hartford was examining ways of broadening its trading base to justify the cost of its overheads through unspecified mergers.

Analysts say Hartford has the potential to offer Ofex-listed companies such as Poo Na Na and K-Bar a route onto AIM.

Four of Montana's six restaurants have outdoor dining, which has flopped, but Pharmacy - which was set up by pop artist Damien Hirst and PR guru Matthew Freud - did not and remained profitable, Mr Gardner said.

"We felt we had to put out a statement because it doesn't look like being just a 10% or 20% divergence from the predicted numbers."

The restaurants affected are part of the Montana group which merged with Hartford earlier in the year. Trading under names such as Utah, Idaho and Dakota, they operate in wealthy London districts including Richmond, Wimbledon and Highgate.

Montana planned to open up to five new units this year but those ambitions are now being scaled back. However, the new 1,600 sq ft, £2m Pharmacy will still go ahead. The original restaurant captured headlines when it put Prozac in the window and suppositories in the toilets.

Four of Montana's six restaurants have outdoor dining, which has flopped, but Pharmacy - which was set up by pop artist Damien Hirst and PR guru Matthew Freud - did not and remained profitable, Mr Gardner said. "We felt we had to put out a statement because it doesn't look like being just a 10% or 20% divergence from the predicted numbers." The restaurants affected are part of the Montana group which merged with Hartford earlier in the year. Trading under names such as Utah, Idaho and Dakota, they operate in wealthy London districts including Richmond, Wimbledon and Highgate. Montana planned to open up to five new units this year but those ambitions are now being scaled back. However, the new 1,600 sq ft, £2m Pharmacy will still go ahead. The original restaurant captured headlines when it put Prozac in the window and suppositories in the toilets.

webTitle: Norris takes PR job at Citigate

fields.headline: Norris takes PR job at Citigate
fields.trailText: Steve Norris, the former transport minister and Tory candidate for London mayor, has joined public affairs firm Citigate as a PR man.
fields.body:
Steve Norris, the former transport minister and Tory candidate for London mayor, has joined public affairs firm Citigate as a PR man.

Mr Norris takes with him a roster of clients from Steve Norris Limited, an advisory business he has built up since leaving parliament after the 1997 election. It includes London bus operator FirstCapital and the Aviation and Travel Consultancy. He will devote the majority of his time to lobbying on behalf of Citigate clients but continue to serve on the board of the new transport authority for London.

Citigate's managing director of public affairs Warwick Smith said: "Steve joins as a normal salaried member of staff. We're not buying his business but we're delighted to have him on board.

"As a successful businessman and great communicator, Steve will bring to us and our clients a rare mix of talent from which we and they can only benefit."

Mr Norris, whose announcement coincided with the inauguration ceremony for mayoral candidate Ken Livingstone, said: "I have known Citigate Public Affairs as an MP, a minister and a client. Their political understanding is first rate and they have impressed me in all three roles with their commitment to quality, transparency and delivery."

The two men started talking about the possibility of Mr Norris joining Citigate almost one year ago over a beer at the Conservative Party conference. He served as transport minister for the Conservative government from 1992-6 and despite a series of public gaffes as a politician is lauded by former colleagues for his understanding of London transport issues.

webTitle: Bout of airport failures 'did put safety at risk'

fields.headline: Bout of airport failures 'did put safety at risk'
fields.trailText: Safety was compromised during the recent bout of computer failures at Heathrow, which led to cancellations and delays to thousands of passengers, an official complaint to the national air traffic service (Nats) confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Safety was compromised during the recent bout of computer failures at Heathrow, which led to cancellations and delays to thousands of passengers, an official complaint to the national air traffic service (Nats) confirmed last night.

A letter from Graham Clarkson, chairman of the air traffic controllers' organisation at Heathrow to Bill Semple, chief executive of the service, makes it clear that staff are concerned about safety implications.

The letter says: "Our members feel that on occasions during the computer failure safety definitely was compromised until some action was taken. The members feel that Nats continually denying that . . . is not helping the situation."

Mr Semple has arranged to meet Mr Clarkson and senior colleagues to try to assuage their fears. A spokesman for Nats said last night that the service did not know the details of the staff's complaints and was waiting to hear more.

But the managers maintained that safety had never been compromised during three separate incidents that occurred last month at the Heathrow control tower.

Controllers say that problems occur immediately after the computer breaks down and they have to revert to a manual system. It takes some minutes to summon extra staff to deal with the situation.

Last night's disclosure coincided with a new and significant development on the gov ernment's controversial plans to partly privatise Nats.

A leaked document from Nats, which as an organisation officially supports the plan, reveals that senior executives are worried that the plans could put passengers and planes at risk.

It shows that the civil aviation authority is proposing price cuts in air traffic control charges of between 21% and 35% over the next five years and efficiency savings of the same order.

The proposals assume that there would be a cut of up to 29% in capital expenditure, although increased capital in vestment has been put forward by ministers as the main reason for privatising the service.

Nats says that the CAA's proposals may dissuade "some potentially excellent partners from participating in the sale process at all. This would be an unfortunate and unwelcome outcome for the business and for the government."

It accuses the CAA of a "high risk strategy" and one that runs counter to its regulatory duty.

Nats said last night that the document was only part of the consultation process which was still continuing.

fields.headline: Fair-weather friends
fields.standfirst:
The sheer amount of personal squabbling in this government is leading to a risk of political meltdown
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: So vicious, so very personal have the attacks on the prime minister become that I can't help but wonder whether the succession of disenchanted courtiers, from Ken Follett to Lord Tom Sawyer, have borrowed a copy of Leo Abse's controversial psychoanalysis published shortly before the last election which was provocatively titled The Man Behind the Smile: Tony Blair and the Politics of Perversion.
fields.body:
So vicious, so very personal have the attacks on the prime minister become that I can't help but wonder whether the succession of disenchanted courtiers, from Ken Follett to Lord Tom Sawyer, have borrowed a copy of Leo Abse's controversial psychoanalysis published shortly before the last election which was provocatively titled The Man Behind the Smile: Tony Blair and the Politics of Perversion. The astonishing broadside against political androgyny furthered by Follett's withering comparison, of spin doctors to "rent boys" would certainly suggest so.

Of course Follett, who sometimes resembles a well manicured version of Sir Les Paterson, has been joined by fair-weather friends from the fourth estate, such as Paul Johnson and Simon Heffer, so the counter-claims now issuing from across the swirling battleground simply cannot be true. Are we really given to believe that Ken Follett is bitter at not being offered a peerage, or furious that his glamorous wife, Barbara followed her boss Jack Cunningham into oblivion, having reached the dizzy heights of parliamentary private secretary? Who could possibly think such things?

And what of the prime minister's very own Rasputin, the focus group supremo, Philip Gould, whose "secret memos" have an alarming habit of leaking at embarrassing moments? Tony Blair, he claimed, was "all spin and presentation" and said things "to please people not because he believes them". Now few could possibly believe that Philip Gould is busying himself pulling the strings on his life-belt, yet such treachery from the heart of the Tudor Court must have cut Tony Blair to the quick.

Blair's reliance on unattributable briefings has proved to be the faultline for this government from the day it took office. It may take British politics a long time to recover from a quasi-presidential leadership that relied on others to do the dirty work of politics - to the extent that they, the spin doctors, inevitably became the story.

This way of doing things was copied by other ministers, and the curse of titanic personality clashes has continued ever since. An early and perennial casualty was John Prescott, frozen out of a secret strategy meeting of Blair's inner court prior to the election in Jonathan Powell's New Forest home. So goaded was Labour's deputy leader he subsequently delighted in comparing Peter Mandelson to a crab in a bottle on Channel 4 News, although he subsequently attempted to distance himself from hard-hitting remarks about Mandelson's role as lobby briefer extraordinaire which he had given to the makers of the BBC's Wilderness Years in the Winter of 1995.

In short succession came Paul Routledge's explosive biography of Gordon Brown, revelling in the chancellor's belief that he was betrayed by Peter Mandelson during the succession battle to succeed John Smith. The claim that Brown was "psychologically flawed" was the most damaging of all the early unattributable briefings. It is believed to have emanated from Alastair Campbell. No unplanned aside in a restaurant, this. This Abse-esque observation of the chancellor's alleged state of mind was first given to the Mirror's political correspondent, but when it failed to appear, was given to the Observer's Andrew Rawnsley.

Clare Short and Michael Meacher have been frequent targets of the unattributable briefers. Short went as far as to complain in the New Statesman about the "creatures who inhabited the dark". Meacher, arguably one of the success stories of this Labour government, along with Short had his political obituary written up in the Sun before he had taken office. "Senior sources" had claimed of both that they "wouldn't be around for long". Their longevity in office probably owes much to their abilities, but the constant briefing had to be denied by No 10, so much so that the original objective - their imminent sacking - never took place.

Now the deflating of the dome and last month's bombing of Blair's speech to the Women's Institute have encouraged some of the prime minister's fair-weather friends to take flight. He is surrounded by a baying pack, a victim of his own casuistry. He has simply failed to inspire true affection in the party he leads and the public increasingly associate New Labour with control freakery, ballot rigging and second-rate millionaire celebrities. Labour's better achievements in office are often lost by default. As the alarm bells ring ever louder, the clamour goes out for a return to cabinet government, for elected ministers to take precedence over unelected advisers.

But why has it taken so long? Why didn't those who might proudly claim first-rate minds, those such as Robin Cook or Gordon Brown, do more to steady the tiller years ago? Why hasn't the cabinet, collectively, been unable to bury personal squabbles and called a halt to the asset stripping that has left the Labour party morally hollowed-out and abandoned by tens of thousands of members? If the last Labour government fell over great issues of policy, such as Scottish devolution and the Winter of Discontent, this New Labour government now risks a meltdown over personality clashes.

 Mark Seddon is editor of Tribune.

fields.headline: Avraham Shapira
fields.standfirst:
Religious powerbroker of Israel's turbulent politics
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Few Israeli politicians trod the tightrope of religion and state power with greater dexterity than Avraham Shapira, the former head of the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Yisrael party, who has died aged 79.
fields.body:
Few Israeli politicians trod the tightrope of religion and state power with greater dexterity than Avraham Shapira, the former head of the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Yisrael party, who has died aged 79. An avuncular figure, whose easy-going ways belied political savvy and financial acumen, he made a striking impression. Vast of girth, invariably toting a cigar, with sidelocks tumbling out of a huge black skullcap and a laconic smile playing on his lips, he had been a familiar fixture in the Israeli parliament, the Knesset, since 1981.

Agudat Yisrael (Union of Israel) began in 1912 as an anti-Zionist group. It softened its stance after the Holocaust, yet remained, at best, agnostic towards the secular state of Israel - unlike the "modern Orthodox" Zionist trend of the National Religious party. That said, its constituents - black-gabardined haredim (or "God-fearers") from Jerusalem and B'nei Brak - came to rely on government handouts to run their myriad schools, welfare bodies and yeshivot, or rabbinical academies. Aguda's ultimate decision-makers are the secretive, extra-parliamentary Council of Torah Sages.

In the Knesset, Shapira was the party's master tactician. Financial skills, rather than piety or learning, made him the perfect choice. Where most clever Orthodox boys spend their productive years pouring over holy books, Shapira helped his father run a furrier business. He established his own thriving carpet company in 1959. At its peak, the group employed 1,600 workers and made $100m a year.

Shapira inveigled Aguda into successive administrations, becoming government chair during the 10th Knesset (1981-84). In the following session (1984-88), he helped broker the Labour-Likud coalition, chaired the influential finance committee, and for three years headed the Bank of Israel advisory board.

He deserves some credit for pulling his country out of its economic morass, but rumours spread that he was siphoning state funds into his now ailing business; he certainly used his influence to guarantee a market monopoly for his carpet business. In 1995, the firm was liquidated after state bailouts ended, and Shapira was charged with embezzling company funds to buy a luxury seaside villa in Caesarea.

He defended his community with passion, for example, by blocking moves to draft yeshiva boys and religious girls into the army by periodically threatening to withdraw his party's small but pivotal bloc from fragile coalitions. He switched Aguda's allegiance from Labour to Likud in 1988, and then scuppered Yitzhak Shamir's government in 1990.

Throughout, Shapira strove to obey the Talmud's imperative of "building a fence around the Torah". In 1985, he tried to ban imports of pork, claiming this would "purify the Jewish people". However, the subsequent influx of lapsed Jews from the Soviet Union led to a proliferation of clandestine pig-eating - much to Shapira's chagrin.

On the issue of Israeli-Arab relations, Shapira tended to be dovish, or at least open to persuasion. Shimon Peres, the former prime minister - and a personal friend - praised him as a "rare individual who worked to draw the secular and religious closer to each other".

Yet, at times, Shapira seemed less tolerant. In 1997, he called for a task force to stop people desecrating the sabbath, and he consistently blocked Reform and Conservative Jews from joining state rabbinical councils. If he was so opposed to these "destroyers of religion", demanded critics, why did he cooperate daily with secular politicians?

Shapira, however, saw no contradiction. To do God's will, he reasoned, one had to indulge in the "necessary evil" of politics. Indeed, his own ascent was miraculous given his background. Born in Romania, and raised the strict haredi way in Lwow, Poland, he fled the Nazis and took refuge in Switzerland. In 1949, his family emigrated to Israel.

After re-election in 1992, Shapira faced new obstacles. Agudat Yisrael was subsumed in a fractious coalition called United Torah Judaism. Meanwhile, religious oriental Jews had bolted from an Aguda dominated by rabbis of European origin, and formed their own party, Shas. By the 1990s, this had increased its tally of seats, and was emulating Shapira's success in winning government financial support.

In 1996, Shapira's mentor, Pinhas Menahem Alter, Rebbe of the Gur Hassidim, ordered him off Aguda's electoral list. Meanwhile, the courts stopped just short of repossessing his properties. The final ignominy came with a damning biography, The Honcho.

Still, few could actually hate this operator with chutzpah. He leaves behind a burgeoning haredi community that has seldom felt more confident. He is survived by his wife, four sons and two daughters.

 Avraham Shapira, politician and businessman, born 1921; died June 26 2000

webTitle: Suicide bomb attacks kill scores of Russian troops

fields.headline: Suicide bomb attacks kill scores of Russian troops
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Chechen guerrillas killed or maimed up to 200 Russian troops in a series of suicide bombings in four towns, Russian officials said yesterday, admitting that the kamikaze lorry attacks marked a menacing escalation in the 10-month Chechen war.
fields.body:
Chechen guerrillas killed or maimed up to 200 Russian troops in a series of suicide bombings in four towns, Russian officials said yesterday, admitting that the kamikaze lorry attacks marked a menacing escalation in the 10-month Chechen war.

The attacks late on Sunday left at least 42 Russians dead and 120 injured, exposing the vulnerability of Russian garrisons to the suicide bombers who drove lorries packed with explosives at high speed towards the high-profile targets.

The worst carnage occurred at Argun, nine miles east of the Chechen capital Grozny, where the huge explosion at a dormitory housing Russian interior ministry troops left rescue workers digging frantically through the rubble yesterday to retrieve corpses. At least 31 dead had been found by last night and the death toll was mounting.

"I suddenly saw a huge truck coming at high speed. It crashed through the barrier and then something horrible began. The glass from surrounding windows shattered, the earth shook," said a Russian catering worker at the site.

The lorry driver, who was killed instantly, rammed the large Kamaz vehicle carrying an estimated five tonnes of explosive through the dormitory gate. The force of the explosion threw parts of the vehicle for hundreds of yards and left a crater 15ft deep and 30ft wide.

The two-storey building looked yesterday as if it had been at the centre of an earthquake. Entire walls were sheared off, revealing rows of soldiers' twisted metal bunks. Servicemen sat disconsolate in the rubble. Around the same time on Sunday evening, a kamikaze driver also struck in Gudermes, east of Grozny, and the seat of the Russian-installed Chechen government. There were two truck blasts there, killing at least eight Russians, as well as in nearby Novogroznensky, where three were killed, and in the town of Urus Martan to the south, where two were killed.

Yesterday Urus Martan was blocked off by Russian troops amid rumours that small groups of guerrillas had infiltrated the town and Grozny to stage further hit-and-run attacks aimed at sapping the morale of the Russian forces in the province.

The Chechens claimed that up to 200 Russians were killed in the the suicide attacks and bragged that they had another 500 suicide bombers ready "to die for Islam".

"The attack by the Mujahedin has shown the world that the Kremlin adventure in Chechnya has no future," said the Chechen guerrilla leader, Khattab, according to the rebels' website.

The Russian president Vladimir Putin convened an emergency meeting with his interior and defence ministers to discuss what to do next.

The Russians responded to the Argun attack by sealing off the town and spraying it with indiscriminate fire from machine guns and helicopter gunships, hitting a refugee hostel and injuring 11 refugees.

webTitle: Scientists predict big rise in animal tests

fields.headline: Scientists predict big rise in animal tests
fields.trailText: The government is braced for a massive increase in scientific experiments on animals over the next few years as the completion of the human genome project causes applications for research licences to flood in.
fields.body:
The government is braced for a massive increase in scientific experiments on animals over the next few years as the completion of the human genome project causes applications for research licences to flood in.

Official figures due out next month will show a rise in the number of animal experiments for the second year running after 20 years of decline.

But senior scientists accuse ministers of refusing to cut red tape which they claim slows down the licensing of animal experiments because an increase in research would be "politically unacceptable".

It is understood that the Home Office, which issues the licences, is seeking ways to play down the increase in applications for fear of offending animal-loving voters ahead of the election, expected next year.

A pre-election statement in 1996 - the same year Labour received a £1.1m donation from the animal rights group, the Political Animal Lobby - committed the party to attempting to reduce the numbers of animal experiments.

Colin Blakemore, professor of neuroscience at Oxford University, said: "As the consequences of the human genome research work through, I would not be at all surprised if there is a 10% increase year-on-year in the total number of animals applied for over the next five years."

Frustration is growing at the licensing logjam, where an application can now take six months or more, compared with days or weeks in other countries. The science minister, Lord Sainsbury, is to meet senior medical researchers next month in response to a warning that scientists will leave Britain to work abroad because bureaucratic delays are impeding research.

One high-profile academic was told by a senior figure involved in government oversight of research involving animals that a rise in the numbers of experiments would be "politically unacceptable before an election".

Scientists - who are reluctant to speak out publicly for fear of jeopardising government research funding - say in private that bureaucracy in licensing processing is being used to limit research.

Government concern is said to have prompted a request to scientific attachés in UK embassies overseas that they unearth figures indicating that British research achieves more scientific benefit for each animal involved in experiments.

The extreme sensitivity of the Labour party to public opinion on animal research was demonstrated in January when it emerged that the party's staff pensions fund had invested £10,000 in shares in Huntingdon Life Sciences, Europe's largest animal research laboratory. The shareholding was swiftly sold off following protests.

The government has already failed to act on promises in its 1996 document, New Labour - New Life for Animals, that it would support a royal commission on animal experimentation and would try to reduce the number of experiments.

Dr Mark Matfield, executive director of the Research Defence Society which lobbies for animal experiments on behalf of academics and the pharmaceutical industry, predicted figures out next month would show numbers of animal experiments had risen from 2.66m in 1998 to around 2.7-2.75m in 1999, a year-on-year increase of 2 to 2.5%.

Scientists insist they do not want British legislation regulating animal experiments - which they say is the strictest in the world - to be watered down. However, they argue that additions and alterations to the 1986 Animals (scientific procedures) Act - particularly the ethical review process introduced last year - have created a morass of red tape.

Nancy Rothwell, professor of physiology at the University of Manchester, said: "Writing a project licence application is one of the hardest things scientists do. There are continual changes in criteria: what was acceptable last year may not be acceptable now and certainly will not be in six months."

webTitle: Kidnap fears grow as parents call for return of 'little princess'

fields.headline: Kidnap fears grow as parents call for return of 'little princess'
fields.trailText: The distraught parents of the missing girl Sarah Payne yesterday made an emotional appeal for their daughter's safe return, as fears mounted that she had been abducted.
fields.body:
The distraught parents of the missing girl Sarah Payne yesterday made an emotional appeal for their daughter's safe return, as fears mounted that she had been abducted.

The eight-year-old, from Surrey, vanished on Saturday evening after playing with her brothers and sister in a cornfield just 150 yards from her grandparents' home in the village of Ferring, West Sussex.

A search by 150 officers and 80 volunteers through nearby fields proved fruitless and dense crops and overgrown woodland hampered the search. A helicopter fitted with sensors, a bloodhound and diving teams were also called in.

Yesterday her parents, Sara and Michael Payne, both 31, made an emotional appeal at a news conference in Littlehampton. Mrs Payne told reporters she just wanted the family's "little princess" home.

"You can't imagine what Sarah means to us, we're a strong family and we don't survive well apart," she said. "We need her home now, today, as quickly as we possibly can.

"Her brothers and sisters are really not coping very well without her. She is our life. Our family name for Sarah is 'our little princess' and that's just what she is. She is a soft, gentle little girl."

Police were trying to track down a white transit van and a grey Mondeo seen in the area by her eldest brother, Lee, 13, and appealed to their drivers to come forward.

Detective Superintendent Alan Ladley, leading the hunt, said it looked likely that the youngster had been snatched as she walked back to her grandparents' house.

The family were on a regular weekend visit to Ferring. After spending the day at the beach Sarah and her brothers Lee, and Luke, 11, and sister Charlotte, six, were playing "dinosaurs" in the field when Sarah decided to walk back to the house. Her eldest brother followed soon after but did not see her again.

Fears that she has been snatched are being fuelled by the fact that the route she would have taken was so short. Police are confident that she would have been found if she was still in that area. They are interviewing local paedophiles.

Yesterday, the mainly retired inhabitants of Ferring spoke of their disbelief that this could happen in such a small village.

As the sense of foreboding grew, prayers were said for Sarah at St Mary's Church, less than a mile from where she vanished. The Rev. Bryan Marshall, vicar of the parish, said: "It causes deep distress always when a child is involved".

Sarah was last seen wearing shiny black nylon shoes with velcro fastenings and a blue Fred Perry style tennis dress. Her blonde hair is cut in a bob.

Anyone with information about the disappearance should contact Sussex police on 0845 6070999.

webTitle: Knockout mice and the race for a genetically modified cure

fields.headline: Knockout mice and the race for a genetically modified cure
fields.standfirst: Animals will be crucial to gene research but tests remain highly controversial
fields.trailText: Jack Straw may not be sure where all the prisoners are at any one time, let alone all the asylum seekers. But the Home Office he runs can be sure of one thing: every last mouse is accounted for. Every laboratory mouse, that is, and every lab chicken, rat, monkey, sheep, pig, dog or cat. Each animal, and there are millions of them, has its own Home Office record. To the government's unease, the pile or records is growing.
fields.body:
Jack Straw may not be sure where all the prisoners are at any one time, let alone all the asylum seekers. But the Home Office he runs can be sure of one thing: every last mouse is accounted for. Every laboratory mouse, that is, and every lab chicken, rat, monkey, sheep, pig, dog or cat. Each animal, and there are millions of them, has its own Home Office record. To the government's unease, the pile or records is growing.

The cause, overwhelmingly, is mice - specifically mice that have been bred or engineered to have missing genes, so-called "knockout mice", or added genes, "transgenic mice".

Different as they may look, mice genes are similar to our own, and the GM mouse business is booming as private and public sector scientists race to design what they call "mouse models" of human illnesses. These are mice engineered to mimic thousands of conditions, from Alzheimer's disease to obesity.

They are valuable commercially - breeding sets can be worth hundreds of thousands of pounds - and, scientists argue, valuable for all humankind, because a congenitally ill mouse can be used to test cures for the equivalent illness in humans.

Conflicting

With the deciphering of the human genome, the quest to find out what each gene does will intensify, and tens of thousands more transgenic and knockout mice will be bred, traded, run through mazes, dieted, autopsied and injected with drugs before the human "book of life" is understood to the satisfaction of scientists.

The pressure is on for a government that is, as ever, torn between conflicting ways of doing the right thing: backing the workers on the 21st-century high frontiers of biotech research, who complain that animal experiment bureaucracy is holding them back, or supporting the anti-vivisection lobby, who complain that restrictions are not tight enough.

Last year all research institutions with licences to carry out animal research were required to set up ethical review committees, with lay members, to assess the value and scale of any animal experiments.

"The procedure for licensing is hard, there's no doubt about it," said Geoff Butcher, chairman of the committee at the Babraham Institute near Cambridge in England's biotech heartland, which carries out extensive mouse experiments.

"I personally have no evidence that there is any manipulation behind this. I think there is a serious problem at the level of the number of Home Office inspectors."

Inspectors are the civil servants who process research institutions' applications to carry out experiments.

"I think they are extremely overworked, and do have a hard time getting the paperwork through at a decent rate."

When one institute has to collaborate with another, trying to mesh the work of the two ethical review committees was "unbelievably burdensome", he said.

"The procedures are hard work. Many of them can be handled at a decent rate if you employ the people to do it, but you can't. Like many other ethical review committee chairs I'm trying to be an active scientist myself and it takes a huge amount of time."

Most scientists insist that there is no alternative to the use of animals, although this is fiercely contested by anti-vivisectionists, who argue that more experiments can and should be done on samples of human cells in the lab.

"To go straight from a cell culture to the living human is an enormous scientific leap," said Mark Matfield of the Research Defence Society, a pro-animal experiments lobby group. "The animal forms a crucial stepping stone from test-tube techniques to the human volunteer in terms of development of drugs.

"If you started testing drugs in humans which had never been in any living thing before, you would kill a lot of volunteers."

Organisations such as the Dr Hadwen Trust, which campaigns for scientific alternatives to animal experiments, point to recent EU decisions allowing statutory animal tests to be replaced by test-tube techniques as signs that vivisection may not be necessary.

Addiction

Gill Langley, scientific adviser to the trust, questioned the value of transgenic and knockout mice in studying human genetic characteristics.

She cited research published in the journal Science last year, where three labs performed exactly the same experiment on exactly the same strains of mice. One strain of knockout mouse behaved completely differently in each of the labs: the same mouse, which had already been hailed in another journal as showing evidence of an alcohol addiction gene, proved as sober as regular mice.

"Genetic engineering is a very powerful technology, which has excited a lot of scientists, but it also has enormous power to cause harm to animals. It must be stringently curbed," Dr Langley said.

"The fact that Britain has created a reputation for itself of being concerned about animal welfare means it must be consistent, and must be very careful about genetic engineering.

"We in Britain may take longer to license research on animals than other countries, but if you are going to protect animals, it is going to take a lot of form-filling.

"If one country has high moral standards, then the answer is to go into Europe and the world to exert influence to spread the same moral standards."

webTitle: From anthrax vaccine to Aids drugs, testing is set to continue - for now

fields.headline: From anthrax vaccine to Aids drugs, testing is set to continue - for now
fields.trailText: The great geneticist JBS Haldane once complained that his wife was encouraged by the government and press to poison rats with phosphorus.
fields.body:
The great geneticist JBS Haldane once complained that his wife was encouraged by the government and press to poison rats with phosphorus.

He on the other hand had to get the signature of the president of the Royal Society, and another leading scientist, then apply to the home secretary "before I can even kill a mouse in a slightly novel manner".

That was in 1927. More than 70 years on, bureaucracy is still an issue but according to drug companies, biochemists, researchers, neuroscientists and geneticists the need for animal experiments is as great as ever.

The two worlds, however, are not strictly comparable. Then, in an essay entitled "Some enemies of science", Haldane could pillory the hypocrisy of fox-hunting peers who introduced bills to prohibit animal experiments. Now hunters are under pressure too, and public attitudes have changed profoundly.

In the scientific community there has been debate for years. Opponents have argued that many animal experiments have produced misleading results. In the 60s, tobacco firms could claim tobacco smoke did not cause cancer, because it did not cause lung cancer in rodents. A drug company scientist pointed out that of the 19 chemicals known to cause cancer in humans, only seven caused cancer in rodents. A heart drug that was highly effective on rats turned out to increase the chance of death for a human cardiac patient.

The technology moved on, too. Many scientists, having learned what they could from living creatures, moved on to see what drugs did to cells cultured in petri dishes, with sometimes more precise results. Epidemiology - the study of what happens to populations over decades - began to show a clearer picture of factors in cancer, heart disease and diabetes. Drug firms are already talking of computer-based experiments to come, modelling how a virtual drug will behave in a virtual human.

But proponents counter that without animals, Louis Pasteur would not have developed his anthrax vaccine, and Joseph Lister could not have developed antiseptic treatments that have saved millions of lives. Animals in this century died necessarily in the development of heart surgery, hypertension treatments, anti-ulcer drugs and organ transplants.

Now the battle is stepping up: the human genome project has unravelled human DNA and detected genes linked to cancer, diabetes and transplant rejection. But biologists still have to work out precisely what these genes, and their proteins, actually do. More knowledge, they argue, will mean more experiments, for a time.

Scientists argue that most experiments are strictly controlled, and involve very little pain, and that some tests are anyway in the service of animal welfare rather than human health. The public - though largely prepared to tolerate intensive farming for the sake of cheap meat - is uneasy about the idea of animal experiments, but also in favour of new treatments for disease. A Mori poll for New Scientist last year found that when asked: "should scientists experiment on animals" 24% were in favour, 64% against.

But this clarity disappeared if pollsters prefaced the question with a statement that scientists believed the experiments would speed up research into treatments for Aids or leukaemia or better painkilling drugs. Then 45% approved of the experiments, 41% were against.

In the lab

Mouse protection test

Used to test toxicity of antibiotics. Involves giving the antibiotic to three species - usually a mouse, a rat and a large animal like a rabbit or a dog. If all three suffer no ill effects, the antibiotic is likely to be safe in humans; if all three are poisoned, it is too dangerous. Sometimes only one species is affected, which means further tests are needed

Raising antibodies

An animal is injected with a substance. A week later, the same animal has a further injection of the same substance. The animal's immune system responds by producing antibodies, which can be purified from its blood, analysed and used for further research

An animal, usually either bred or genetically engineered to simulate a human illness, will be given a medicine and studied to see if it has the desired effect. For a drug to combat high blood pressure, for instance, researchers would probably use a species of rat called a "spontaneously hypertensive rat." There are mice bred to test treatments for numerous human ailments - Alzheimer's mice, muscular dystrophy mice, cancerous mice, obese mice, bald mice

Gene hunting

Used in mutated or "knockout" animals, which have had genes altered or knocked out, when it is not known which genes have been removed or what they do. The animals, usually mice, are subjected to dozens of tests of strength, stamina, intelligence and metabolism

Autopsy

Often used as the culmination of other experiments. The animal is killed using an overdose of anaesthetics and its inner organs examined

Brain experiments

Often used in fundamental research, where medical relevance is unclear. Scientists at Oxford in 1998 and Cambridge in 1999 trained monkeys to respond to stimuli in certain ways, then chemically damaged areas of their brains to see how their performance changed. In 1999, Bristol researchers implanted microscopic wires into the brains of cats, then electrically stimulated the nerves in their legs, to see how their brains responded

fields.headline: Spinning out of control
fields.standfirst:
Follett's story is more fact than fiction

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Follett is used to getting readers to the edge of their seats, conjuring a thrill-a-minute ride with mere words on the printed page...and now he's done it again - in the pages of our sister paper, the Observer.
fields.body:
Ken Follett is used to getting readers to the edge of their seats, conjuring a thrill-a-minute ride with mere words on the printed page. He's done it with airport blockbusters like Eye of the Needle and On Wings of Eagles and now he's done it again - in the pages of our sister paper, the Observer.

His denunciation of the "rent boys" of spin, who spread poison against their Labour confreres, has set the Westminster village ablaze. It's not only journalists who have gone nuclear in response, but the Labour high command itself.

Within minutes of the Follett salvo breaking the surface, the Downing Street machine denied the author's central charge - that spinners engage in vicious, anonymous briefing - by engaging in a vicious, anonymous briefing against him. They called him "self-indulgent" and "pathetic," and dismissed his critique as a "rant."

Yesterday Alastair Campbell weighed in, all but accusing Mr Follett of lying. Both those moves backfired instantly. For they kept the controversy alive, even enabling the Mirror to run a "Labour at war" headline: further proof that the party's much-vaunted news managers are not the geniuses they're cracked up to be.

What might have prompted the thriller-writer who once served as Labour's chief fundraiser to blow his top? It seems his friendship with Mo Mowlam played a part: he was doubtless distressed to see her taking a drubbing for the semi-republican remarks she made to Saga magazine (suggesting the Queen move house), and he wanted to leap to her rescue.

That, too, backfired of course; Mo has suffered much more than she has benefited from Ken's diatribe. She has had to wave aside his claims as "rubbish" and insist that no one has briefed against her. In a neatly ironic twist Dr Mowlam's detractors now cite the Follett episode as proof that "everything Mo touches turns to disaster" - thereby confirming everything the author had claimed and the minister had denied.

For there is much truth in the Follett broadside: the badmouthing of colleagues is a definite vice of this government. On the very day the author fired off his critique, the Sunday Times ran a bitchy account - sourced to Labour - detailing which ministers were on, and which were off, the party's A-list for the next election campaign.

Mo and John Prescott would be despatched to "the regions," away from national view, while Tessa Jowell would be allowed to do a bit "so long as she had some media training". Most political journalists will tell of ministers who have slated their colleagues over a drink, or of senior Downing Street apparatchiks who privately let it be known who's up and who's down.

For journalists, and therefore readers, this is a valuable resource: if politicians have these opinions it's right that we, the voters they serve, know about them. After all, no one wants to go back to the days of a closed, secret governing elite whose debates and divisions remained unknown to the rest of us. But while the backroom briefing might be a staple of political reporting, and therefore in the interest of newspapers, it cannot be good for the government - certainly not when it reaches the levels of viciousness achieved under this administration.

Internecine vitriol destroyed John Major and it kept Labour out of office for 18 years: that "Labour at war" headline would have struck Tony Blair as a blast from the nightmarish past. So, like Mr Follett says, the PM needs to send out the order: private chats can continue, they always have and always will; but the politics of personal destruction has to end.
