fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
How reassuring to hear that rumours of governmental obsession with "spin" are false. Take Clare "Bomber" Short, as Max Miller might have put it. Recently the Hammer of Belgrade gave an interview to Simon Retallack of the Ecologist, and when later Simon realised his tape recorder had packed up, he asked Bomber's press officer Mary McCullum - who'd been there herself with a recorder - for a transcript. Perhaps unaware that Simon's machine had worked for the first 15 minutes, Mary provided a wildly doctored "transcript", from which every silly or contentious remark of Bomber's was excised... Not just her hectoring accusations that Simon was biased, uninformed and a hypocrite; but also embarrassingly misinformed answers concerning the World Bank's proposed project to settle Chinese farmers on traditionally Tibetan land. Also gone were misleading replies to questions about remarks made three years ago to Simon about the WTO being "a big con... the biggest bullies in the world getting their own way about everything," not to mention equally trenchant critiques of the IMF and the World Bank. Poor show, Bomber, and even poorer timing.

 In what we think may (if it hasn't been everywhere else already) be a sort of world exclusive (and it'll go down a storm in Tibet), we learn that Frankie Dettori will be making his comeback sooner than expected following his aircrash. Dettori tells friends in Newmarket that he will return to the saddle at the York meeting on August 12.

 A dilemma causes anguish at the Spectator. This Thursday, I and several colleagues will be gate-crashing a party at the magazine's office in Doughty Street. This will be Boris the Jackal Johnson's first summer bash as editor (or "gaffer" as he is known to staff), so it's a big evening for the mop-haired enforcer. Unfortunately, on the same evening is the candidate's selection meeting for Michael Heseltine's Henley constituency - the safe Tory seat the Jackal has his eye on. It's a hideous problem, but the Speccie's slightly eccentric American publisher Kimberley Fortier believes she has it cracked. She suggests a helicopter be hired to whisk the Jackal to his various engagements. Could you make it up?

 After his savage removal as BBC political editor, Fatty "Robin" Oakley is having a leaving party with an intriguing difference. Guests are being charged £20 for a ticket on the riverboat he is hiring for a trip down the Thames.

 The Diary has often mentioned the zany wit of Labour general secretary Margaret MacDonagh, so few will be surprised by the letter on the page opposite. It refers to an item here in which, "tongue firmly in cheek" as the Daily Mail might have it, we noted Mugabe's transparent attempts to rig the election and congratulated Mr Tony Blair on sparing a crack squad from Millbank to advise him. Margaret, Margaret, what are we to do with you? I was tempted to wheel out the gag about some escaped lunatic stealing your letterheads, but I don't have the strength to say anything except to beg you... please, please, try to get yourself a life.

 Good to learn from yesterday's media section that former News of the World editor Phil Hall has found a job working for Max Clifford. "I've been doing a lot of frothy showbiz stuff," says Phil, "and to do something that's worthy and worthwhile is great." I wonder if Phil and Margaret might not become friends?

 Hats off to Mr Tony, by the way, for that splendid "spot fine for thugs" speech. I hope this doesn't seem churlish in the wake of such a triumph - but I do hope that the rapturous reception for this brainwave doesn't blind Mr T to the fact there is no rule that says you must write all your major speeches in the back of the car on the way to the meeting.

webTitle: Tension rises as terror group joins Drumcree standoff

fields.headline: Tension rises as terror group joins Drumcree standoff
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland: special report
Orange Order site links
Garvaghy Road Residents Coalition
Portadown District Orange Lodge No 1
Parades commission
fields.trailText: Loyalist Johnny Adair, one of the most feared terrorists in Northern Ireland, last night arrived to join protesters on Drumcree hill outside Portadown, Co Armagh, bringing up to 80 members of the Ulster Freedom Fighters from the Shankill Road in Belfast with him.
fields.body:
Loyalist Johnny Adair, one of the most feared terrorists in Northern Ireland, last night arrived to join protesters on Drumcree hill outside Portadown, Co Armagh, bringing up to 80 members of the Ulster Freedom Fighters from the Shankill Road in Belfast with him.

Adair, freed from the Maze prison under the terms of the early release scheme in the Good Friday agreement, marched his men to the police lines with a banner, but then walked away from confrontation. He insisted he was opposed to violence, but his arrival raised tension after clashes between protesters and police the previous night.

The development came as Orangemen in Portadown yesterday rejected an offer from the parades commission which held out the prospect of them marching down the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road in as little as three months, so ending the two-year-old standoff at Drumcree.

As Northern Ireland faced up to more than a week of violence, the commission, as expected, banned next Sunday's annual parade. It cited the Portadown lodge's refusal to engage with residents.

But it laid out a possible solution, which it hoped would allow the Orangemen a limited march along the contested route within three to eight months.

David Jones, spokesman for the Portadown Orangemen, said Tony Blair had made a similar offer last year, holding out the prospect of a march in the autumn if they backed off from confrontation with the security forces after their service at Drumcree. He had failed to honour his pledge.

Tony Holland, chairman of the commission, said the conditions which might lead to a future march included a decision to comply with the ruling for Sunday's parade and an immediate end to all protests. He also stipulated the Orangemen should become involved in the South African lawyer Brian Currin's mediation efforts and take part in any civic forum. During yesterday's press conference, Mr Holland appeared implicitly to criticise Mr Blair's involvement last year. He said: "When you give a body legal powers, if you then have outside interference which cuts across the exercise of those powers, its not likely to be particularly helpful."

Mr Jones yesterday warned that Portadown lodge was finding it difficult to control violence. He said Orangemen had warned Mr Blair of possi ble trouble if he failed to fulfil his pledges last year.

Mr Jones said: "Mr Blair then made no efforts at all to resolve the dispute."

Rioting erupted at Drumcree late on Sunday after a rehearsal parade was halted at police lines outside the church. Seven RUC officers suffered minor injuries as they were pelted with missiles.

Demonstrations in support of the Orangemen at Drumcree spread to Belfast and South Down.

Denis Watson, Co Armagh grand master, said the order was checking to see if Mark Harbinson, from Stoneyford, Co Antrim, who had addressed the crowd while the Portadown lodge was at church, was an Orangeman. He was wearing an Orange sash when he spoke of Drumcree as Ulster's Alamo, and suggested: "The war begins today."

webTitle: Theft of mobile phones by children fuelling rise in robbery, says Straw

fields.headline: Theft of mobile phones by children fuelling rise in robbery, says Straw
fields.trailText: The theft of mobile phones, mainly by schoolchildren from other schoolchildren, is a major factor fuelling the rise in robbery and the headline violent crime figures, the home secretary has admitted.
fields.body:
The theft of mobile phones, mainly by schoolchildren from other schoolchildren, is a major factor fuelling the rise in robbery and the headline violent crime figures, the home secretary has admitted.

The alarm among ministers at the 36% rise in recorded robberies in London and other big cities in the past year lies behind the decision to hold the crime seminar at Downing Street yesterday but Jack Straw has made it clear that the major factor in this increase is the onset of the age of mass ownership of mobile phones, especially among schoolchildren.

Ministers say that mobile phone thefts now account for one third of all robberies in some London boroughs, and many of them are committed by schoolchildren against their peers. "Before mobile phones, children would have got bullied and had their dinner money stolen which wouldn't necessarily be reported to the police, while mobile phone thefts are being reported the whole time," said a Downing Street source.

Talks with mobile phone companies are to get under way to examine whether the security of the phones can be improved.

Research published today shows that contrary to popular belief most robberies do not involve a lot of planning but many are carried out on the spur of the moment. As one robber told the Leicester University researchers: "All you have to do is walk up to a counter and ask for money from those who have been told to give it to you."

The study, by Martin Gill of Leicester University's Scarman Centre, based on interviews with 340 robbers says that prison is not a deterrent because they do not expect to get caught. Robbers look for an "easy" target and are particularly concerned that there should be a good escape route. Some said they were encouraged to start after seeing how easy it looked on television.

Most believe the chances of them being caught are "very low" and told the researchers that guns are easy to get hold of because of a plentiful supply on the black market. Although only about half carried a gun that was capable of firing a lethal shot - the rest carried imitation guns or real but un loaded weapons - they claimed they took them along to reduce the chances of injury as witnesses were less likely to argue with a gun.

Dr Gill said his research also showed that some robbers felt that they had done their victims a favour, by providing them with an event and something to talk about in an otherwise dull life. It was claimed that some victims exaggerated their losses or injuries to get robbers a longer sentence. And when robbers did find themselves being sent down for longer than they expected they blamed the judge for being a "mean bastard" or a "raving lunatic" or claimed that they had suffered from racial prejudice, poor legal representation or a corrupt legal system.

 Commercial Robbery, Martin Gill, Blackstone Press, £19.95.

webTitle: 'Wild West' border town plagued by the inner-city curse of drugs

fields.headline: 'Wild West' border town plagued by the inner-city curse of drugs
fields.standfirst:
Drugs in Britain: special report
Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: Wrexham is a tough place. The border town in north Wales is not quite the Wild West it used to be 20 years ago, when drunken brawls on a Friday and Saturday night were a way of life. But people still prefer to sort out problems in their own way.
fields.body:
Wrexham is a tough place. The border town in north Wales is not quite the Wild West it used to be 20 years ago, when drunken brawls on a Friday and Saturday night were a way of life. But people still prefer to sort out problems in their own way.

Take Susan Ryan and her daughter Emma. On millennium eve another of Susan's daughters, Jessica, was feeling ill and her mood swings were the talk of a party at their home in Glan Gors. At one point Jessica started to cry. Then she became violent.

Her father restrained her by sitting on her. In the pandemonium Mrs Ryan, 42, discovered she had been given some "smack" to "celebrate" 2000 by a drug addict who lived close by.

Mrs Ryan and Emma, 18, went to the addict's house. They had words with the woman. Then they kicked and punched her. They forced her to kneel and ordered her to say "I am scum, I am scum."

When the beating was over, Mrs Ryan called the police. In March she and Emma pleaded guilty to causing actual bodily harm. Magistrates were sympathetic, saying the women had been severely provoked. They were sentenced to 80 and 60 hours' community service respectively.

Wrexham has overcome challenges before. The town could have been damaged beyond repair by the closure of coal mines, breweries and steel works in the 1970s and 80s, but it got on with the business of survival and reinvented itself. Today it faces different challenges. One is drugs.

Vulnerable to crime

The curse of many inner cities has started to corrode this and many other provincial towns. Wrexham is vulnerable to organised crime because the police and the people are unsure how to defend themselves. The dealers who speed down the M53 from Liverpool and the M56 from Manchester know it.

They regard Wrexham's two council estates, Caia Park and Plas Madoc, as virgin territory. They have brought with them what one local councillor calls "a poverty of expectation, and a sense of overwhelming despair".

Heroin is cheaper in Wrexham than almost anywhere else in the country. Children aged seven have been caught smoking cannabis. Wrexham's coroner warned recently that one person overdoses on methadone every month. And where there are drug dealers, there are loan sharks. Both carry guns.

It would be unfair to exaggerate the problem. Wrexham is not overrun by junkies and in recent years the police have managed to cut crime on limited resources. But drugs are a menace and they will not go away.

"We know it's going on, but we're not quite sure how bad it is," said one officer. "At least we could see the drunks when they were fighting."

Wrexham is the largest town in north Wales, with a population of 125,000. It can be dated to the 12th century and during the civil war it supported the royalists, who were defeated by the roundheads at the battle of Rowton Moor outside Chester in 1645.

Wrexham's most famous son is George Jeffreys, who became lord chief justice in 1683. He was better known as Hanging Judge Jeffreys, or the Blood Judge, a nickname earned for the brutal way in which he conducted the trials of supporters of James Scott, Duke of Monmouth, who had plotted to overthrow James II.

In recent years, Wrexham's claims to notoriety have rested with the local football club's occasional charges in the FA Cup, and the child abuse scandal at the Bryn Estyn children's home.

Wrexham is surrounded by wonderful Denbighshire hills to the west and some of the smarter parts of Shropshire to the east. But the town has neither beauty nor charm.

There is hostility to England, but more to affluent south Wales, particularly Cardiff. In some ways, this resentment is hard to fathom. When Wrexham lost its traditional industries, it turned to food manufacturers. It is now a prosperous town, with major employers like Kellogg's and Cadbury's.

Although Wrexham has a reputation for being rough, the crime figures tell a different story. There has not been a murder in Wrexham for two years. The three attempted murders were "domestics" and solved easily.

The town has 183 police officers who deal with most of the 22,000 incidents reported in the division, which covers the eastern part of north Wales. Crime seems to be falling. There were 3,700 crimes reported in April and May last year, 3,500 this year.

Violent crime has dropped by 35% over the course of the year, the number of burglaries has fallen slightly and detection rates for crime overall have risen.

CCTV success

Some of the town's anti-crime initiatives have proved a great success. Four years ago Wrexham county borough council spent £250,000 setting up CCTV cameras around the town centre to deter vandals, thieves and drunks. The cameras had an immediate impact, so the council put up more. There are now 40 cameras watching the shopping parades, two others monitor the car parks on the Plas Madoc estate, and four could soon be mounted in Caia Park.

Security guards at the major stores are equipped with a "Shoplink" radio, which keeps them in touch with officers in the CCTV control room. They tip each other off if troublemakers or thieves are on the prowl. A similar scheme links Wrexham's pubs and clubs.

"We've always had trouble in the town centre at turfing out time," said Detective Chief Inspector Chris Corcoran, 47. "Since we've had the cameras, we've made more arrests. And because we had people caught on film, we got more convictions. The cameras cut out the need for lengthy investigations. With this system, you need one officer and the CCTV footage to get a guilty plea. They have been a tremendous success."

Other issues which worry city forces hardly register in Wrexham. There have been only two reported racial incidents in the past 12 months.

The town is 99% white and the force has struggled to recruit any officers from ethnic minorities. "We want to recruit our officers locally, but we don't have any racial communities to recruit from," said Mr Corcoran. "If we recruit from elsewhere, we could end up isolating them."

A more pressing problem is the need to recruit women, and officers who can speak Welsh. There has been a revival of the language in recent years and 15% of the town is bilingual. Like many of his generation, Mr Corcoran is not, but his children are taught Welsh at school.

The Caia estate, where he grew up, requires his closest attention. It is a sprawl of 3,000 terraced homes on the outskirts of the town. It had a reputation as one of the roughest places in Wales. One local politician, who asked not to be named, said: "Twenty years ago, Caia was like the Wild West. Juvenile crime was out of control. I think the council would have liked to fence it off and throw food in once a week."

Instead, the council supported a community project called The Venture. This began as an adventure playground for children, but has expanded over the past 22 years to offer services like a homework club and outreach work. The playground, built by children on the estate, is still the heart of the scheme.

Thanks to The Venture, crime on Caia fell spectacularly during the 1980s and early 90s, but then the atmosphere began to change. "There had always been some drugs on the estate - glue-sniffing and things like that," said Malcolm King, manager of The Venture.

Liverpool dealers

"But we noticed harder drugs were being sold here seven or eight years ago. It seems the dealers in Liverpool were looking for new markets, and they came to Wrexham. The drugs flooded in. The heroin addicts were easy to spot _ shrivelled up and gaunt-eyed."

He added: "Drugs have eaten their way into parts of the estate and we have struggled to keep cohesion. Once we've lost a child to drugs, it is very hard to get them back. I resent that. There are good kids on the Caia. They should have a chance in life."

The police are unsure how big the problem has become. There are no statistics on drug dealing. The evidence comes from anecdotes and from the number of addicts - one a month - who end up in the morgue.

On millennium eve another of Susan's daughters, Jessica, was feeling ill and her mood swings were the talk of a party at their home in Glan Gors. At one point Jessica started to cry. Then she became violent. Her father restrained her by sitting on her. In the pandemonium Mrs Ryan, 42, discovered she had been given some "smack" to "celebrate" 2000 by a drug addict who lived close by. Mrs Ryan and Emma, 18, went to the addict's house. They had words with the woman. Then they kicked and punched her. They forced her to kneel and ordered her to say "I am scum, I am scum." When the beating was over, Mrs Ryan called the police. In March she and Emma pleaded guilty to causing actual bodily harm. Magistrates were sympathetic, saying the women had been severely provoked. They were sentenced to 80 and 60 hours' community service respectively. Wrexham has overcome challenges before. The town could have been damaged beyond repair by the closure of coal mines, breweries and steel works in the 1970s and 80s, but it got on with the business of survival and reinvented itself. Today it faces different challenges. One is drugs. Vulnerable to crime The curse of many inner cities has started to corrode this and many other provincial towns. Wrexham is vulnerable to organised crime because the police and the people are unsure how to defend themselves. The dealers who speed down the M53 from Liverpool and the M56 from Manchester know it. They regard Wrexham's two council estates, Caia Park and Plas Madoc, as virgin territory. They have brought with them what one local councillor calls "a poverty of expectation, and a sense of overwhelming despair". Heroin is cheaper in Wrexham than almost anywhere else in the country. Children aged seven have been caught smoking cannabis. Wrexham's coroner warned recently that one person overdoses on methadone every month. And where there are drug dealers, there are loan sharks. Both carry guns. It would be unfair to exaggerate the problem. Wrexham is not overrun by junkies and in recent years the police have managed to cut crime on limited resources. But drugs are a menace and they will not go away. "We know it's going on, but we're not quite sure how bad it is," said one officer. "At least we could see the drunks when they were fighting." It can be dated to the 12th century and during the civil war it supported the royalists, who were defeated by the roundheads at the battle of Rowton Moor outside Chester in 1645. Wrexham's most famous son is George Jeffreys, who became lord chief justice in 1683. He was better known as Hanging Judge Jeffreys, or the Blood Judge, a nickname earned for the brutal way in which he conducted the trials of supporters of James Scott, Duke of Monmouth, who had plotted to overthrow James II. In recent years, Wrexham's claims to notoriety have rested with the local football club's occasional charges in the FA Cup, and the child abuse scandal at the Bryn Estyn children's home. Wrexham is surrounded by wonderful Denbighshire hills to the west and some of the smarter parts of Shropshire to the east. But the town has neither beauty nor charm. There is hostility to England, but more to affluent south Wales, particularly Cardiff. In some ways, this resentment is hard to fathom. When Wrexham lost its traditional industries, it turned to food manufacturers. It is now a prosperous town, with major employers like Kellogg's and Cadbury's. Although Wrexham has a reputation for being rough, the crime figures tell a different story. There has not been a murder in Wrexham for two years. The three attempted murders were "domestics" and solved easily. The town has 183 police officers who deal with most of the 22,000 incidents reported in the division, which covers the eastern part of north Wales. Crime seems to be falling. There were 3,700 crimes reported in April and May last year, 3,500 this year. Violent crime has dropped by 35% over the course of the year, the number of burglaries has fallen slightly and detection rates for crime overall have risen. Four years ago Wrexham county borough council spent £250,000 setting up CCTV cameras around the town centre to deter vandals, thieves and drunks. The cameras had an immediate impact, so the council put up more. There are now 40 cameras watching the shopping parades, two others monitor the car parks on the Plas Madoc estate, and four could soon be mounted in Caia Park. Security guards at the major stores are equipped with a "Shoplink" radio, which keeps them in touch with officers in the CCTV control room. They tip each other off if troublemakers or thieves are on the prowl. A similar scheme links Wrexham's pubs and clubs. webTitle: Volcanic Widdecombe gets into a lava

fields.headline: Volcanic Widdecombe gets into a lava
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Experienced vulcanologists know the signs. The slight rumblings, the occasional spitting noises, the almost imperceptible earth tremors. These tiny events, unnoticed by most bystanders, indicate to the expert an imminent eruption.
fields.body:
Experienced vulcanologists know the signs. The slight rumblings, the occasional spitting noises, the almost imperceptible earth tremors. These tiny events, unnoticed by most bystanders, indicate to the expert an imminent eruption.

Mount Widdecombe is much the same. She sat on the bench before yesterday's law and order debate rumbling gently. The odd harumph escaped her. The green leather of the bench could be seen shaking like the Millennium Bridge.

As an old hand who has often stuck his seismograph on the flanks of this great natural phenomenon, I knew what terrible event was about to occur.

Suddenly it did. The Speaker called the debate and a great roaring noise immediately filled our ears. The sides of the mountain bulged alarmingly. A shower of debris, or at least the shadow home secretary, crashed onto the despatch box.

"The more desperate the prime minister and the home secretary become, the bigger fools they make of themselves! Gimmicks! On-the-spot fines for drunken yobs! Senior police officers are queueing up to call the idea ludicrous and ridiculous!"

By this time the mountain was spouting fire. "When the said yob has straightened himself up enough to say that he doesn't have the £100, and the policeman has accompanied him to the cashpoint, and in his drunken state he has recalled his Pin number, and produced his bank card, and instantly got out the £100..." she spat, and a river of contempt flowed like lava towards Mr Straw.

"If that is the best he can manage in the face of rising crime, it is pathetic. Yes! It. Is. Pathetic!"

Here I must briefly abandon my metaphor, since Miss Widdecombe does not only erupt. Unlike a volcano, she can also make gestures to enhance the effect of her words. "They sound tough for the headlines," was accompanied by a terrific flapping motion, as if she were shaking out a crumb-infested tablecloth.

"I notice none of them are leaping up to defend this policy," she cried, and made sinister beckoning signs, rather like Count Dracula: "come to me, my beautiful creatures of the night".

"What is the point in condemning the courts for over-lenient sentences when even those they give are not served?" she yelled, pointing furiously at Mr Straw ("yes, that man is the father of my baby!") then smashing her hand down, like Joe Grundy finishing off a ferret.

Allegedly there are some 4,000 vacant spaces in British prisons. "Are there indeed 4,000 spaces? Why are there 4,000 spaces? Where are the 4,000 spaces?" She makes Edith Evans's famous "a ha-a-a-nd-bag?" line sound like the merest sotto voce mumble.

"A shambles! It is a shambles! Yesterday we even heard of one criminal who was let out, having been electronically tagged on his wooden leg. He simply substituted the tagged leg for another false leg and went out drinking! Until all hours!" She began to deliver karate chops to an imaginary pile of bricks.

Jack Straw pointed out in his earnest way that the Tories had cut prison sentences too. He kept trying to intervene. He would try placing one foot in front of the other and rising to his feet, but the blast from the mountain and the furious, frantic finger, hurled him back down again.

Even when she had finished, and he was allowed to reply, she remained, like Vesuvius after an eruption, muttering and shouting and spouting, getting in a second speech by means of her spluttering, rumbling, angry commentary on his.

Now no flowers or trees will grow at her feet for many years to come.

webTitle: My spats with Mandelson, by Ireland's bruiser

fields.headline: My spats with Mandelson, by Ireland's bruiser
fields.standfirst:
Dublin's blunt speaking foreign minister confirms relations were fraught. But such straight talking helped rescue the peace process
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Dublin's blunt speaking foreign minister confirms relations were fraught. But such straight talking helped rescue the peace process
fields.body:
The Irish foreign minister, Brian Cowen, has confirmed for the first time that personal relations between himself and the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, have been fraught.

But he believed the poor relationship had a positive side effect during the last five months of negotiation. In their talks the two did not waste time but got straight down to matters of substance.

In a rare interview, Mr Cowen said of his spats with Mr Mandelson: "I believe sometimes the media regard a good relationship as one which is pretty anodyne, with a unanimous view about nothing." He was branded by London as too green and unsympathetic to the Unionists. But those straight talking sessions in Dublin, Belfast and London helped rescue the peace process, which in February reached a low point with Mr Mandelson's suspension of Northern Ireland's devolved government.

Devolved government is now back and working, the IRA has opened arms dumps to international observers, and prospects for a lasting peace are the best for decades.

As always with Northern Ireland, there are heavy qualifications, with the weekend's bombing of a rail line by dissident republicans and the annual stand-off with Orangemen at Drumcree.

But Mr Cowen, speaking in his office in Dublin, was optimistic: "I genuinely think we are all in a process that is irreversible." A few still hankered for the "old supremicist days" of Unionist domination but a new set of relationships had been established. "No matter what hiccups and reverses arise, that is the reality and the reality is not going to change."

Mr Cowen last week met representatives from the nationalist community caught up in Drumcree and expressed disappointment that the Orange Order will not engage in dialogue. But he and Mr Mandelson have opted for low profiles over Drumcree - basically both keeping out of it.

Mr Cowen, 40, is seen as a potential leader of Fianna Fail and future taoiseach. In a sign of growing normality on the island, the Irish press has been focusing in recent days not on Drumcree but on the Dublin government's domestic problems over political donations and other scandals, over which it survived a confidence vote yesterday. The next leader will be whoever is left untarnished. Mr Cowen, inevitably, played down his leadership ambitions: "It is not an abiding desire I have when I get up in the morning." But he did not rule it out in the future.

He has the face of a bruiser, and looks, by his own admission, like the dishevelled TV detective Colombo. His nickname in Dublin is the disrespectful Biffo - brutally, Big Irish Fucker from Offaly - an urban putdown for someone from the boglands. Hurt by it, he dismissed "just the usual, anti-intellectual, insulting, personalised remark that passes for comment in this country".

Sharp

Thirty seconds in his company is enough to destroy the label. He is sharp and thoughtful, a solicitor before he became a member of the Dail at 24. He has a gift for mimicry and, in private over a couple of pints, can reproduce Northern Ireland talks with a cast that includes Mr Mandelson, Mr Blair and the leaders from Sinn Fein and the Unionist parties. After spells as labour, transport and health minister, he became foreign minister on January 26. He met Mr Mandelson for the first time in Dublin on February 2 and again a week later in London. Relations between this odd couple have been turbulent ever since.

Those first meetings were held against an awkward backdrop, with the prospect of Mr Mandelson suspending the devolved government, as he did on February 11. The problem then was to get devolved government back, with many pessimistic that it would take a year, if at all.

Mr Cowen's view was that in order to persuade republicans that there was something in it for them, the British-Irish talks had to be broadened to take account of "demilitarisation". He wanted evidence for the republicans that the number of soldiers on patrol would be reduced, the watchtowers taken away and a police force introduced that had the confidence of both communities.

His blunt approach with Mr Mandelson, in language peppered with swear words, was matched by equally frank exchanges with Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, Martin McGuinness. The rapport he established with Mr McGuinness was important in persuading the IRA to reveal the arms dumps.

Technique

A hint of Mr Cowen's negotiating technique was provided when he spoke warmly of his grandfather, a cattle dealer, whom he admitted he took after: "He was very colourful and pretty forthright. He did not believe in long negotiations when buying cattle. It was either up for sale or was not."

The British government is privately scathing about him, saying he had been missing at critical junctures, had left the "heavy lifting" to the taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, and, at least in the beginning, had little understanding of Northern Ireland. A British source said: "He has a Fianna Fail constituency that is republican friendly. He is greener than most. We felt he did not deliver the message (to Sinn Fein) or exert pressure in the way we were entitled to expect."

Some of that sentiment came out in a leaked memo written by a British official of spirited exchanges between Mr Mandelson and Mr Cowen at a dinner in Dublin on April 18, saying Mr Cowen "can usually be reliably counted on to tack to the green at every opportunity".

The suspicion among officials in Dublin is Mr Mandelson leaked the memo, though Mr Mandelson has denied having seen it. Mr Cowen dismissed the memo as an inaccurate reflection of his views: "This attempt to stereotype really impresses nobody."

For the time being, he will be concentrating more on foreign affairs beyond Irish shores while Mr Mandelson is expected to spend more time in London preparing for the general election.

webTitle: Orthodox students to escape army duty

fields.headline: Orthodox students to escape army duty
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: A bill before the Israeli parliament yesterday to exempt 30,000 students at Orthodox religious colleges from three-years' conscription into the armed forces or an equivalent public service has aroused widespread and unusually bitter opposition.
fields.body:
A bill before the Israeli parliament yesterday to exempt 30,000 students at Orthodox religious colleges from three-years' conscription into the armed forces or an equivalent public service has aroused widespread and unusually bitter opposition.

About 100,000 people have signed a petition against the bill, which provides ultra-Orthodox seminarians with a blanket exemption from conscription to the age of 23 and will let those who opt to go into the army serve only four months.

They see it as a betrayal of an election promise by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, and say it enshrines the concept of a two-tier society in which secular Jews go to war while their ultra-Orthodox peers continue to study at state expense.

It has also antagonised members of Mr Barak's One Israel party and other secular politicians. But it has the overwhelming support of the religious parties, including Shas, which has vowed to withdraw its vital support from Mr Barak's coalition government if it does not go through.

At present seminarians can apply individually to be excused conscription at 18 by promising to devote their lives to the study of the torah. Exemption is usually granted.

Mr Barak said yesterday that he still supported the ideal of a citizens' army, but that it was not practical to compel ultra-Orthodox Jews to serve.

"It makes no sense to send the military police into the yeshivas [Orthodox seminaries] and to force them to become fighter pilots," he told Israel Radio.

But Zvi Kesseh, 69, who fought in the war of independence and has a grandson in the army, said: "We want to save ourselves from this slavery to the ultra-Orthodox. We finance them from morning to night, and it has to stop."

Military service for the ultra-Orthodox has been a contentious issue ever since Israel was created in 1948, because it goes to the heart of the debate on whether it should be a secular or theocratic state.

Ultra-Orthodox rabbis say exemption is as crucial to the state as military service, because seminaries are the repositories of religious knowledge.

webTitle: Blair to freeze civil list for 10 years

fields.headline: Blair to freeze civil list for 10 years
fields.trailText: The prime minister is today expected to announce a deal freezing the size of the civil list for the next 10 years.
fields.body:
The prime minister is today expected to announce a deal freezing the size of the civil list for the next 10 years.

Tony Blair will tell MPs in the Commons that the Treasury and Buckingham Palace have agreed to peg the civil list at £7.9m a year until 2011.

The announcement comes less than a week after the Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, was forced to make an embarrassing apology for suggesting that the royal family should move out of Buckingham Palace and into "a good modern building" in an effort to modernise the monarchy and save taxpayers' money.

The settlement to be announced today was agreed in principle over a year ago and is intended to rectify the over-generosity of the last 10-year deal, agreed under Margaret Thatcher's last Conservative government, which gave the Queen a 50% rise in her civil list money.

This set out the funding provided by the taxpayer for the upkeep of the royals on the assumption of an annual inflation rate of 7.5% from 1991 to 2001. But inflation figures over the decade were far lower than predicted, resulting in a civil list overpayment to the Queen of £30m.

The Treasury has agreed to freeze payments for the next 10 years, rather than require the Queen to hand back the overpayment, with any extra royal spending to be taken from the £30m reserve.

Details of the surplus must be released to MPs before October 15 when the royal trustees - who include the prime minister and the chancellor, Gordon Brown - make their 10-yearly statement on civil list spending.

Ms Mowlam's remarks prompted palace officials to defend royal spending, insisting that the royal family had done its best to economise, saving £5m on maintenance and travel expenses in the past year.

Two reports issued by Buckingham Palace claimed that maintenance of the occupied royal palaces was cut by £800,000 to £15m last year - a fall of nearly £9m in the past eight years - and that an increased use of chartered helicopters had reduced the cost of travel from £12.8m to £8.6m.

About 70% of the civil list funds are used to pay staff who deal with state papers, the organisation of public engagements and receptions undertaken by the Queen as well as the costs of royal garden parties and official entertainment during state visits.

fields.headline: Union chief accused of £130,000 fraud
fields.standfirst: 'Whistleblower' tells employment tribunal she was sacked over allegations that general secretary hid money in shell bank accounts
fields.trailText: Allegations that Roger Lyons, the general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union defrauded the union of nearly £130,000 from "shell" bank accounts were made yesterday in an unfair dismissal case being brought under the government's whistleblower legislation.
fields.body:
Allegations that Roger Lyons, the general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union defrauded the union of nearly £130,000 from "shell" bank accounts were made yesterday in an unfair dismissal case being brought under the government's whistleblower legislation.

Marcia Solomon, 32, a former secretarial assistant to Nelson Mendes, the union's head of finance, claims she saw cheques worth about £34,000 drawn from fake union branches - £5,000 payable to her boss and £29,000 to the general secretary.

She also alleged in a written memo to John Chowcat, then assistant general secretary, that "payments from shell accounts amounting to nearly £130,000 in the year 1997" were made to Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes. The shell accounts were in the names of two defunct branches.

She also passed details of Mr Lyons' and Mr Mendes' expense accounts to Mr Chowcat - placing details of "financial irregularities" on his desk. She alleges Mr Mendes tried to conceal the accounts after being seen leaving his office in the early hours after removing numerous box files.

The union says an investigation by its accountants, HW Fisher and Company, did not find any evidence of financial impropriety against Mr Lyons or Mr Mendes. It also says the accountants' findings were cleared by the certification office for trade unions, which found HW Fisher's report "admirably thorough".

Mr Chowcat - who is to give evidence on Ms Solomon's behalf at the employment tribunal in central London - also withdrew the allegations of impropriety against Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes. He later left the union, receiving a £250,000 payment after signing a confidentiality agreement. The tribunal decided yesterday that details of the agreement would have to be released to the hearing.

Lawyers for both sides outlined the case yesterday. Jason Galbraith-Marten, for Ms Solomon, said she was bringing two cases against the union - for unfair dismissal and wrongful dismissal. An action for racial discrimination had been withdrawn.

He told the hearing that Ms Solomon would have to prove "she acted in good faith" under the new whistleblowing legislation in reporting the alleged fraud and impropriety to Mr Chowcat.

She intended to argue that she had a genuine belief that both were engaging in fraudulent activity and reported them to Mr Chowcat as he had responsibility for staff matters.

Sarah Moor, for the MSF, said the union's case was that she knew the allegations were untrue when she made them. She could not claim protection from dismissal as a whistleblower and had been dismissed for "gross misconduct".

The union denies Mr Mendes destroyed evidence and says she passed the information on to Mr Chowcat because of his dislike for Mr Lyons. It also points out that she did not cooperate with the union's inquiry into the matter.

The union is not challenging the details of Mr Lyons' expenses - which included using his union's credit card to pay for a 25p croissant and buying two radios, a video recorder, linking to the internet at home and buying a leather briefcase and luggage trolley.

He also charged "sustenance" figures of £4 after meeting Tony Blair and £19.65 after meeting Gordon Brown. He claimed these were to buy drinks at the Red Lion public house in Whitehall after the meetings.

He also regularly spent money on takeaways and wine when he returned home. He was cleared by the accountants of breaking union rules.

Mr Lyons - who earns nearly £97,000 a year from his a job and as a member of the competition commission - has opted not to give evidence.

Today Ms Solomon, who earned £19,500 a year in her MSF job, will give evidence.

webTitle: Bungling Israeli agent on trial for espionage

fields.headline: Bungling Israeli agent on trial for espionage
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The self-avowed Mossad agent who went on trial at Switzerland's supreme court in Lausanne yesterday is believed to be the first member of the ultra-secretive Israeli agency to be arraigned outside Israel.
fields.body:
The self-avowed Mossad agent who went on trial at Switzerland's supreme court in Lausanne yesterday is believed to be the first member of the ultra-secretive Israeli agency to be arraigned outside Israel.

The Israeli defendant, charged only under one of his two aliases, Issac Bental (the other is Jakob Track) admitted charges of espionage for a foreign country - a charge which could bring a sentence of 20 years imprisonment - and illegal phone-tapping.

The charges stem from a bungled spying operation on a block of flats in a sleepy suburb of the Swiss capital, Berne, more than two years ago.

Bental, who provided the two aliases but declined to give his real name for security reasons, and five other members of a Mossad surveillance squad were apprehended after an elderly neighbour reported strange noises emanating from the cellar next door.

The surveillance target, Abdallah El-Zein, a Lebanese citizen whom Swiss authorities suspected of being a member of Hizbullah, will appear today as a witness in the trial.

Mr El-Zein, married to a Swiss, has denied any links with Hizbullah.

"[Mossad] explained to me that [El-Zein] had been responsible for terrorist acts," Bental testified.

Israel paid a £1.2m bail to secure their agent's release in return for a promise that he would return to Switzerland for the trial. Bental, who describes himself as a 46 year-old mathematician, computer engineer and Mossad agent from Tel Aviv, appeared under discreet security.

A local reporter described the proceeding as "surreal", after the panel's five judges chose not to delve into the accused's real identity. But evidently, Bental's identity was not the only subject that needed clarification.

"What exactly is Mossad?", Judge Hans Wiprächtiger asked the accused.

"I cannot say, I'm sorry, the reasons are known," Bental replied.

Through a Hebrew translator, Bental, of medium build with a crew cut, said he currently earned £1,300 a month in "continuous education". He admitted that his technical skills were "not the result of a conventional training", but denied that he had ever killed or injured anyone.

The charge sheet, which owes a lot to statements Bental made during questioning by Swiss federal police after being apprehended, suggests that second-rate spy novels may owe more to fact than fiction.

Shortly after midnight on February 19 1998, three Mossad agents are said to have entered Wabersackerstrasse 27 in Köniz. While Bental, Dan Shifrin and Shely Ravlin - probably forged identities too - were busy inside the cellar of the building, Ron Metzer and Daniela Tefler sat in a car outside, ready to alert their colleagues by radio if anything went wrong.

Bental told the court that Mr Shifrin was the head of the operation and he was only there to execute orders after arriving in Switzerland, regarded as "friendly territory", earlier in the year.

The team, equipped with duplicate keys that local residents normally have to fight their landlords to obtain, had already visited Wabersackerstrasse on January 26 to locate Mr El Zein's telephone line.

After they received a diplomatic bag with bugging equipment from a mysterious accomplice in a cheap hotel next to the station in Bümpliz, another Bernese suburb, the team must have felt assured that they were merely engaged in a routine, low-risk surveillance operation. But they had not accounted for Swiss noise by-laws after 10pm, which in some cases even outlaw flushing the toilet, and notoriously prim Bernese habits.

Arriving on the scene, the local police patrol found two men and a woman with Israeli passports claiming to be tourists who thought the concrete apartment block was an ideal location for a lovers' threesome.

A "diplomatic bag" Bental said he was carrying for a friend aroused the policemen's attention because of its broken seal and the wire and pliers sticking out of a side pocket.

During the call, one of the two lookouts feigned a heart attack.

Bewildered local police eventually released all the suspects except Bental before they called in federal counterparts, who quickly realised they had more than a suburban burglar on their hands.

Legal experts say Bental is unlikely to face more than a one-year suspended sentence, the result of some behind-the-scenes bargaining between the Swiss and the Israelis.

It is also thought that the Swiss judiciary will go easy on Bental as the alleged espionage was not conducted against Switzerland. A verdict is expected on Friday.

webTitle: Divorced wife seeks Lords ruling on half share of £4.5m family business

fields.headline: Divorced wife seeks Lords ruling on half share of £4.5m family business
fields.trailText: A divorced wife who worked as an equal partner for 33 years helping her husband to build up a £4.5m farming business took her claim for a half share of the assets to the House of Lords yesterday.
fields.body:
A divorced wife who worked as an equal partner for 33 years helping her husband to build up a £4.5m farming business took her claim for a half share of the assets to the House of Lords yesterday.

Pamela White's case, the most important divorce case to go to the Lords for at least a decade, could pave the way to a better deal for divorced wives who worked alongside their husbands in family businesses.

Mrs White, 64, felt "a burning sense of injustice", according to her QC, Paul Coleridge, when she was awarded a lump sum of only £800,000 by a high court judge, Mr Justice Holman, in 1996, although her share of the partnership assets totalled £1.5m. Her husband's share was twice hers because his family had injected more capital into the business and one farm was bought at a favourable price because her husband's father had been the tenant.

The judge dismissed as unreasonable her desire to go on farming on her own, though she had been a farmer before her marriage in 1961 and had worked as an equal partner at Blagraves Farm, near Taunton, Somerset, while bringing up three children.

Mr Justice Holman ruled that the farming business would no longer be viable if Mrs White's husband, Martin, 63, had to transfer land to her or sell land to raise the cash to buy out her share. In effect, the judge ordered Mrs White to transfer nearly half her share of the assets to her husband, who was already richer, while letting him keep all his assets.

When the case went to the court of appeal in 1998, the three judges criticised Mr Justice Holman for basing his ruling on longstanding principles used in "big money" divorce cases. These give the wife a lump sum not based on a share of the family wealth but on her "needs" - enough to buy a suitable house and spend the rest of her life in reasonable comfort.

The judges said these rules were outdated in cases where husband and wife were in an equal business partnership, and ruled that Mrs White could keep £1.5m - the portion of the partnership assets which she legally owned. Yesterday her lawyers asked five law lords to award her a half share of assets valued at £4.5m in 1996. Her husband is asking for the appeal court award to be cut back.

Julian Lipson, a family law partner in the London law firm Withers, said: "The House of Lords will no doubt take the opportunity to say what the law is in 2000, because the law in 2000 is different from what it was in 1980, when the courts were more paternalistic." He said the outcome of the case could help wives with expensive houses, held in joint names of husband and wife, because they could argue in future that they were entitled to their legally owned half share as a minimum .

The appeal court judges said the Whites' case need never have come to court if their advisers had concentrated on the fact that the couple were in a business partnership and divided the property according to the shares of partnership assets they actually owned. If they had done that "they would have saved much anguish and very considerable legal costs", said Lord Justice Thorpe.

He added: "It offends my sense of fairness that a wife who has worked equally and not nominally in partnership should exit with anything less than her legal entitlement in the absence of extraordinary features."

The Lords' judgment is expected to be reserved tomorrow and delivered in the autumn.

webTitle: 'Patient power' to help modernise the NHS

fields.headline: 'Patient power' to help modernise the NHS
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The government is preparing to unleash patient power in the NHS by giving patients' representatives a central role in a "modernisation board" to oversee radical reform of the service.
fields.body:
The government is preparing to unleash patient power in the NHS by giving patients' representatives a central role in a "modernisation board" to oversee radical reform of the service.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will announce plans for the board tomorrow at a final meeting of the advisory teams that are preparing strategy for the national plan for health, due for publication this month.

He is expected to promise patients' representatives a third of the seats on the board, to be known as the national council for the NHS. It will monitor implementation of the national plan and blow the whistle if it is being subverted by forces of conservatism in the health service.

It would be the first time patients have had any direct power over delivery of services in hospitals and primary care providers.

"They will help shape the way care is delivered and ensure the standards patients can expect. Mr Milburn is keen that patients have a big stake in the future of their NHS," a Department of Health source said.

The patients would get up to one-third of seats on the modernisation board. Another third would go to doctors, nurses and other NHS staff.

Mr Milburn is thought to favour giving the final third to managers of the best hospitals, trusts and health authorities given "green light" status - top ranking in the performance tables he proposed.

The modernisation board may be seen as an attempt to mobilise support from the health interest groups that have been contributing to preparation of the national plan.

Mr Milburn is understood to have been impressed by the commitment to reform shown by leaders of the royal colleges and the British Medical Association and wants their support to continue. His advisers maintain, however, that the modernisation board will be more than a device to hang on to loyalty of potential critics.

"Mr Milburn is convinced the radical proposals in the national plan will need equally radical forms of implementation if the ambition of modernising the service is to be realised," the source said.

The modernisation board is expected to have up to 30 members. It will be linked to taskforces overseeing priority programmes of reform.

The taskforces will include "frontline modernisers" in the NHS and outside experts. About 100 people will be appointed to the board and task forces.

Mr Milburn will announce the proposals tomorrow on NHS Day - the 52nd anniversary of the founding of the service. He will present the modernisation board as an example of decentralisation, "depoliticising the NHS and liberating the talents of NHS staff".

Day-to-day management of the service will remain in the control of the NHS executive, under a new health supremo combining the roles of chief executive and permanent secretary at the Department of Health.

The modernisation board is intended to be more than a talking shop and have real influence over how the national plan is implemented. "For the first time patients' groups will have a seat at the table, making sure reforms are implemented," the source said. They are expected to include representatives of the Patients Association, and the Consumer Association.

Patients would have the biggest single voice, alongside representatives of doctors, nurses, other health service professionals and managers.

"In this way he wants to encourage wider ownership of the NHS national plan," the source said.

webTitle: The day democracy finally conquered corruption

fields.headline: The day democracy finally conquered corruption
fields.standfirst: More about the Mexican presidential election
fields.trailText: It was the old Mexican dictator Porforio Diaz who was credited with the saying that "he who counts the votes wins the elections".  This cynical view of democracy led to Mexico once being described by the writer Mario Vargas Llosa as "the perfect dictatorship".
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell  in Los Angeles and  Jo Tuckman in Mexico City
fields.body:
It was the old Mexican dictator Porforio Diaz who was credited with the saying that "he who counts the votes wins the elections". This cynical view of democracy led to Mexico once being described by the writer Mario Vargas Llosa as "the perfect dictatorship".

Now that the votes have been counted and the Institutional Revolutionary party (PRI) has lost for the first time in 71 years, Mexicans are waking up this morning to a world that many of them believed they would never see.

The role played by the PRI in the civic life of Mexico is hard to overestimate. It was a cradle-to-the-grave party, one that appeared to have control over everything from schools to health care, broadcasting to real estate.

Even when the first polls suggested earlier this year that Vicente Fox's National Action party (Pan) had a realistic chance of winning, few people believed that the PRI would allow it to happen.

The PRI had grown out of General Plutarco Elias Calles's National Revolutionary party 71 years ago, as Mexico moved away from dictatorship towards democracy. But it soon became clear that the country's elections had a tendency to operate on the "vote early and vote often" principle and that they offered little possibility of challenge from either right or left.

The combination of patronage and persuasion allied with bribery, corruption and vote-rigging ensured that to win a PRI candidacy was to guarantee passage to power.

Those who sought office had to pay their dues on their way up. The presidential candidate was, until last year, chosen by the dedazo method - the pointing finger of the PRI hierarchy.

Even when an opposition candidate seemed to have won, it could be taken from them. In 1988, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the presidential candidate this year for the left-of-centre Democratic Revolution party (PRD), was generally accepted by observers to have won but it was clear when the government electoral computer crashed in mid-election with Cardenas ahead and started working again with the PRI's Carlos Salinas de Gortari ahead, that dirty tricks were at play.

But over the last decade or so, the old invincibility of the PRI started to slip, most notably in the rural areas that they had taken for granted. President Zedillo, one of the party's most astute leaders and the first since 1964 to come from outside the masonic confines of the Mexico City elite, saw which way the wind was blowing last year.

It was he who helped engineer a primary election for the PRI candidate for the first time, to give a whiff of democratic procedures. For a while this strategy seemed to be working. But gradually Mr Fox and his allies persuaded voters to think the unthinkable.

The result is a new government and a new president the US clearly feels it can work with. What remains to be seen is whether Mr Fox will be able to carry out his policies to address the enormous disparities between rich and poor.

fields.headline: Mexicans toast Fox victory
fields.standfirst:
Election surprise: 71 years of 'perfect dictatorship' end as former Coca-Cola executive crushes ruling PRI
More about the Mexican presidential election
fields.trailText: Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary party yesterday accepted defeat in the country's presidential election and its fall from power after a political monopoly lasting 71 years.
fields.body:
Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary party yesterday accepted defeat in the country's presidential election and its fall from power after a political monopoly lasting 71 years.

The PRI conceded victory to Vicente Fox, a former Coca-Cola executive who heads a movement dedicated to the sole task of kicking the ruling party out. With 91% of the vote counted yesterday, Mr Fox held 43%, the PRI's Francisco Labastida 36%, and the left-wing veteran Cuauhtemoc Cardenas 17%.

Turnout was 74%, according to the Federal Electoral Institute, which organised what was generally considered to be the freest and fairest poll in Mexican history, which has been marred by fraud throughout the long PRI regime.

Mr Fox's National Action party will also be the biggest party in congress and senate.

As the results sank in, delirious Fox supporters brandishing huge foam fingers with Fox's trademark victory sign chanted "Vicente! Vicente!" and danced in human chains through the swelling crowds. Fifteen thousand supporters swarmed Mexico City's Angel of Independence monument early yesterday morning in a blizzard of confetti.

The victory was not only unprecedented, but much more decisive than had been expected, with almost all commentators judging the race too close to call before the vote.

In a country where 40m live in poverty, Mr Fox had reached out beyond the urban, educated and conservative constituency of his own party. The crowd that cheered the president-elect as he made his victory address added a note of good-tempered warning. "Don't let us down", they chanted over and over again.

The new government is due to take office on December 1, three months after the new congress and senate begin work, but the transition away from what was essentially a one-party government began minutes after the release of an exit poll late on Sunday that made it clear the PRI had lost.

In a historic national address that stunned the nation, President Ernesto Zedillo congratulated Mr Fox on his victory. "I commit myself to ensuring a smooth and transparent handover of power," he said.

Mr Labastida acknowledged defeat in a much terser manner before disoriented supporters who had gathered to celebrate victory at the PRI campaign headquarters. "Our party is still alive, and it will stay alive and know how to recuperate," he said.

The European Union welcomed the election results. "I would like to congratulate the Mexican people for their demonstration of poll maturity and democratic will," Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy representative, said.

Mr Fox, though clearly jubilant, has been careful to avoid rubbing salt too deeply into the PRI's cavernous wound, calling on supporters to be generous in victory, more than aware that the current meekness of the defeated party could disappear when the extent of the defeat sinks in.

He promised to form a government including representatives from all political parties.

Mr Fox paid repeated tributes to President Zedillo for accepting the defeat and to the electoral authorities for safe guarding the legitimacy of the elections.

Mr Fox's win was well received by the Mexican financial markets, with industry happy to see a transfer of power to a business-friendly executive.

Rise and fall of one-party government

1929 President Plutarco Elias Calles creates National Revolutionary party (to become Institutional Revolutionary party)

1934-40 President Lazaro Cardenas becomes national hero with social reforms and nationalisation of oil industry

1968 Hundreds of students massacred in Tlatelolco square, Mexico City, during pro-democracy movement

1985 Response to Mexico City earthquake exposes underlying government corruption

1988 Anti-system movement backs PRI defector Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, who loses election to Carlos Salinas de Gortari after government-controlled electoral computers crash

1994 Uprising of Zapatista rebels in Chiapas; PRI presidential candidate Luis Donaldo Colosio assassinated, and Ernesto Zedillo wins largely clean presidential election

1995 Economic crisis makes ex-president Salinas Mexico's most hated man

1997 PRI loses congress and mayorship majority in capital

1999 PRI initiates presidential primaries, won by Francisco Labastida, Zedillo's favourite

webTitle: Mayor predicts big tube cash rise

fields.headline: Mayor predicts big tube cash rise
fields.standfirst: Livingstone's London: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott is to bury the hatchet with Ken Livingstone by showering the new London mayor with money in this month's government spending review to improve the London underground.
fields.body:
John Prescott is to bury the hatchet with Ken Livingstone by showering the new London mayor with money in this month's government spending review to improve the London underground.

Government sources confirmed last night that Mr Livingstone's negotiations with the London transport minister, Keith Hill, have been going well and that the tube can expect an injection of millions of pounds of extra money. Mr Livingstone indicated yesterday that he believed London could win a 50% increase in its £1.8bn transport funding allocation when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, unveils his spending plans later this month.

Speaking at the first meeting of the Transport for London board, which will oversee the tube and buses in the capital, Mr Livingstone said he was encouraged by his talks with the transport department. "I am confident that we will see an increase of 50%," he told the meeting. The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is still involved in intense negotiations with the Treasury, but government sources indicated that transport in London would be one of the winners after the attention which was focused on the decaying tube during the mayoral campaign.

A big injection of cash for transport in London would go a long way to smoothing relations between Mr Livingstone and the government, which have still to recover from his decision to stand against Frank Dobson in the mayoral contest. Mr Livingstone made clear yesterday that he was still determined to join the Labour party, hopefully by the time of its annual conference in the autumn.

Speaking at his inauguration as mayor Mr Livingstone said: "If I am kept out for the next four years I would have to stand as an independent for a second time. Can you imagine a rush of Labour candidates coming forward to inherit Frank Dobson's role?" The new mayor's opponents made clear that they would not shirk from holding him to account. Trevor Phillips, Labour chairman of the Greater London assembly, warned: "This is a democracy, not a Kenocracy." Lady Hamwee, Liberal Democrat leader in the assembly, added: "We are here to remind him that when he opens his mouth he speaks for Londoners."

Livingstone's coalition

Ken Livingstone yesterday unveiled the teams that will assist him as London mayor. The 30 men and women who will sit in his cabinet and on the new transport for London board hail from all sides of the political spectrum. Among them are:

Cabinet

Nicky Gavron accepted the job of deputy mayor after weeks of wrangling. Some members of the Labour group feared Ms Gavron had been picked by Mr Livingstone because she would be malleable.

Darren Johnson has been handed the environment portfolio after making a strong impression as Green candidate in the mayoral contest.

Glenda Jackson, Labour MP and former transport minister, who has accepted the homelessness portfolio, became friendly with Mr Livingstone during the battle for the Labour nomination after they were both victims of a pro-Dobson whispering campaign.

John McDonnell, who will run local government, is one of a group of left wing Labour MPs who have rounded on Millbank over its treatment of Mr Livingstone.

Kumar Murshid, a Labour councillor in Tower Hamlets who will run the regeneration portfolio, made his name as the head of a group helping victims of race attacks.

Lee Jasper, who will take charge of race relations, is one of Britain's most prominent black activists.

Diane Abbott, who will run women and equality, was another Labour MP who made no secret of her distaste for the way in which Millbank treated Mr Livingstone during the mayoral contest.

Transport for London board

Dave Wetzel has kept a low profile since his days as chair of the GLC transport committee. He will be Mr Livingstone's deputy.

Jimmy Knapp, the gruff RMT general secretary, joked yesterday that he was well qualified for his new job despite his Scottish roots. "I'm the only Scot here, but after 28 years in London I think I'm entitled to a place."

Susan Kramer, Liberal Democrat candidate for London mayor, made a strong impression during the campaign with her boffin-esque grasp of transport funding.

Steve Norris, former transport minister and Tory candidate for London mayor, will lighten proceedings. At yesterday's opening meeting he described himself as a "general hack".

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Former US senator George Mitchell, awarded a peace prize in recognition of his work in brokering the Good Friday agreement. The tireless negotiator can now add the Tipperary International Peace Award to his mantlepiece. Previous winners include Nelson Mandela and Mikhail Gorbachev.

Macho man of day

Greater London assembly chairman Trevor Phillips warned London mayor Ken Livingstone not to use the mayoral office to pursue personal political goals. Mr Phillips said: "If you decide to use your position to advance politics that are not in the interests of Londoners ... we will, I promise, kick your ass." A nation waits.

Bid of the day

The internet auction war for Lady Thatcher's infamous handbag rages out of control. Well, almost. With just eight days of bidding left some 16 bidders have so far pushed the price up to £341. Meanwhile a Cherie Blair handbag has attracted eight bids and is yours for £51. A sole bidder has offered £20 for Mo Mowlam's.

Today

Commons: Health questions. Local government bill, remaining stages. Lords: Government resources and accounts bill, report. Terrorism bill, third reading.

webTitle: France plans more protection for EU workers

fields.headline: France plans more protection for EU workers
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: France will use its EU presidency to rush its European partners into approving measures which will increase the protection workers enjoy under the social chapter - and make it easier to allow some member states to integrate faster.
fields.byline: Paul Webster  in Paris, Ian Black  in Brussels, and  Michael White
fields.body:
France will use its EU presidency to rush its European partners into approving measures which will increase the protection workers enjoy under the social chapter - and make it easier to allow some member states to integrate faster.

The first working day of the six-month presidency, during which the 20 EU commissioners were invited to Paris, was dominated by attempts to reconcile growing differences between president Jacques Chirac and the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, more evident since the president's Berlin speech last week.

But this did not delay preparation for a "European social agenda" that will be discussed at ministerial level at the weekend and for French embassies in the EU to signal a dynamic approach on innovations as diverse as an EU food authority to new initiatives against the misuse of drugs in sport.

In London, the French ambassador, Daniel Bernard, summoned business leaders and opinion formers to hear his government's message - which included a clear commitment to what the French call "reinforced cooperation" which will allow a small group of countries to take initiatives without being blocked by a single country's veto.

Mr Bernard made plain that a higher political profile for Euro-11, the 11-strong committee which runs the single currency, is a priority for France, including the possible appointment of a political "Monsieur Euro" to act as the single currency's political chief.

In their different ways both Tony Blair and William Hague are saying they will accept such changes, provided British interests are protected.

In Paris, the labour minister, Martine Aubry, daughter of Jacques Delors, said a "social Europe" would be the dominant theme over the next six months, a move that implicitly rejects Mr Chirac's determination to ensure constitutional matters should come first.

Two other ministerial meetings will be held in France this month will cover the environment and culture.

The French social initiative, which will be discussed in Paris on July 7 and 8, will try to extend French experiments Europe-wide, including the 35-hour week and the compulsory consultation of workers' representatives over business strategy.

Britain has reluctantly adopted EU social chapter directives and France wants to make up for lost time since the 1997 Luxembourg summit when the new socialist administration failed to force Mr Chirac and the then German chancellor, Helmut Kohl, into sponsoring a single European policy on unemployment.

In the new debate, France would demand much stronger guarantees in the face of flexible working practices favoured by Britain.

fields.headline: Hacker jeopardised shuttle mission
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: A computer hacker put the lives of space-shuttle astronauts at risk by overloading the Nasa space agency's communications system during a crucial docking stage of a mission three years ago, it was disclosed last night.
fields.body:
A computer hacker put the lives of space-shuttle astronauts at risk by overloading the Nasa space agency's communications system during a crucial docking stage of a mission three years ago, it was disclosed last night.

The shuttle Atlantis was attacked as it docked with the Russian Mir space station while they travelled at 17,360 mph some 236 miles above central Europe.

The equipment that monitors the heartbeat, pulse and medical condition of the crew, which included the British-born Michael Foale, was targeted, said the BBC's Panorama programme. Nasa was forced to switch to the monitors on the accident-prone Mir, the world's first permanently manned space station.

Roberta Gross, inspector-general at Nasa, which faced 500,000 cyber attacks last year, said: "We had an activity at a Nasa centre where a hacker was overloading our systems to such an extent that it interfered with communications between the Nasa centre, some medical communications and the astronaut aboard the shuttle."

Asked how serious the attack was, she said: "Nasa has a lot of fail-safes and it makes sure that there's not just one way of communicating, so the transmission ultimately went through. But it shows the potential that hackers have for doing some real damage to Nasa's mission and astronaut safety."

The main purpose of the mission was to replace Mr Foale, who was not told at the time of the unidentified hacker's attack. Ms Gross said that the agency faced growing problems with hackers.

"We invite the public in because it is an exciting place and we want them to see it and so that's part of our mission," she said. "The problem is that hackers come in and they stay in. You take Nasa's mission and you take its vulnerabilities, then you can see how serious it can be. Everybody knows there's a problem at Houston, a potential vulnerability or someone is able to supersede the system that we set up, that's dangerous."

The targeting of Atlantis is perhaps the most spectacular instance of a cyber attack, but is only one of an at least 10 a day the space agency defends.

Four hundred computer viruses are said to be active globally at any one time and they cost business an estimated £8bn last year. Nasa has a team of internet detectives armed with the power of arrest dedicated to tracking down hackers. It has links with police forces worldwide.

But United States senator John Kyl told Panorama: "There is a point here that you can't attack the US frontally because of our military power, but you can attack us at our weak spots. Clearly the internet, and the reliance on technology generally, offers an opportunity to attack both the civilian sectors as well as the military sectors that give countries leverage that they would not otherwise have."

Four hundred computer viruses are said to be active globally at any one time and they cost business an estimated £8bn last year. Nasa has a team of internet detectives armed with the power of arrest dedicated to tracking down hackers. It has links with police forces worldwide. But United States senator John Kyl told Panorama: "There is a point here that you can't attack the US frontally because of our military power, but you can attack us at our weak spots. Clearly the internet, and the reliance on technology generally, offers an opportunity to attack both the civilian sectors as well as the military sectors that give countries leverage that they would not otherwise have."

fields.headline: Drug 'hoax' shuts assembly emails
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Embarrassed officials have been forced to shut the electronic bulletin boards in the national assembly for Wales after a junior employee advertised cannabis for sale.
fields.body:
Embarrassed officials have been forced to shut the electronic bulletin boards in the national assembly for Wales after a junior employee advertised cannabis for sale.

The unnamed clerical support worker, who is understood to have worked in the assembly's health division, was asked to leave the Cardiff Bay building after posting what he claims was a hoax email message on the internal computer system last week.

The message used cockney rhyming slang to suggest a small quantity of the drug was for sale. The man, who was on his last day of work in the assembly, was interviewed by senior staff before being shown the door.

A spokeswoman said an investigation was being held to determine whether or not the message was a hoax. She added: "To our knowledge no drugs were sold." But the matter had been referred to the police.

The email was placed on the bulletin board on the assembly's intranet system where members customarily use the small ads space to advertise more prosaic needs.

Internal rules stress that the sale and wanted boards are strictly for personal items and that adverts of a commercial nature are not allowed.

Although the precise nature of what is permissible is unclear, staff are warned that when it comes to "profitable hobbies" the best test might be whether the taxman would consider the income negligible.

Yesterday, both boards had been suspended.

It is not the first time the assembly's computer system has been the cause of embarrassment. On one occasion a schoolboy visiting the building sent a threatening message to a friend from the assembly's debating chamber. Unfortunately the email was also picked up by an assembly member.

More recently an official sending an aide memoire to his own home computer accidentally emailed confidential documents to journalists suggesting the beef on the bone ban could be reintroduced.
