fields.headline: Slurs and sneers
fields.trailText: I refer to a short piece in the Guardian Diary (June 27), which suggests that staff from the Labour party have been helping the election campaign of Robert Mugabe. No one from the party staff has given any support whatsoever for Mr Mugabe or Zanu-PF.
fields.body:
I refer to a short piece in the Guardian Diary (June 27), which suggests that staff from the Labour party have been helping the election campaign of Robert Mugabe. No one from the party staff has given any support whatsoever for Mr Mugabe or Zanu-PF. Both the Labour party and the Labour government have expressed deep concern about the threats posed to democracy by Mr Mugabe and his party. We have also condemned the violence and intimidation surrounding the recent election, which appear to have been inspired by Mr Mugabe and his associates. The suggestion in your Diary is a slur on the integrity of the Labour party and its staff.
Margaret McDonagh
General secretary, The Labour party

 Vikram Dodd alleges that I expressed support for the Lawrence family "in their battle for compensation from Scotland Yard" (June 30). Mr Dodd had asked me specifically what my position on this was. I had informed him that it would be quite inappropriate for me to be prescriptive about a matter such as this. This in no way detracts from our unconditional support for the Lawrence family in their pursuit of justice.
Cheryl Carolus
South African High Commissioner

 Following William Hague's solo appearance on BBC Question Time last Thursday, Mark Lawson (Comment, July 1) wrote "It must be rare for a 60-minute interview with a party leader to produce no newspaper headlines at all". I refer you to "Hague dilutes Tory waiting-list pledge" (Guardian, Page 3, June 30). The story was the direct result of comments Mr Hague made on the programme and which you accurately attributed to Question Time.
Nick Pisani
Editor, Question Time

 In Bel Littlejohn's in depth analysis of the life of the Queen Mother (Comment, July 3) she omitted to mention the incestuous relationship with her brother Charles II and the resulting offspring who grew up to be the notorious Lady Godiva. The Queen Mother was, in her day, a noted exponent of the javelin and the flute. There are some amusing anecdotes about occasions when she confused the two.
David Thomas Bridgend, Mid Glamorgan
dthcym@tesco.net

 I certainly wrote the letter that appeared in the Guardian on Saturday. Can we be certain Ron Drennan (Letters, July 3) could read it? When sneering at the lucidity of we base proletarian types, Ron boy, it helps if you spell our names correctly.
Garry Bushell
The Sun

 Re your article stating that Railtrack will shut a large part of the network for 10 days over Christmas (July 3): in fact, a reduced service will operate from December 27 with two trains an hour for Virgin and Silverlink both northbound and southbound.
Robin Gisby
Railtrack

fields.headline: Follett filleted
fields.trailText: Ken Follett's recent comments (Spin the king in a town called malice, July 3) ring true to the many of us who remember the news coverage last winter of Blair's speeches vilifying Ken Livingstone. I have a vivid memory of the prime minister, as it seemed to me, so publicly consumed with personal loathing that he had become incapable of considering the issues involved in an objective, even-handed manner.
fields.body:
Ken Follett's recent comments (Spin the king in a town called malice, July 3) ring true to the many of us who remember the news coverage last winter of Blair's speeches vilifying Ken Livingstone. I have a vivid memory of the prime minister, as it seemed to me, so publicly consumed with personal loathing that he had become incapable of considering the issues involved in an objective, even-handed manner.

Someone who reacts in this way towards one person is capable of behaving in the same way towards others. Hence it is believable that Blair is increasingly surrounded by sycophants and yes men while those who would like to tell him the truth back off for fear of personal attacks in the Livingstone manner.

Blair should start looking at himself as others see him. Friends and colleagues in the Labour party deserve to be listened to. And so, by the way, do Labour voters.
Marie Burnand
High Wycombe, Bucks

 Michael White suggests that Ken Follett's remarks at the weekend are only reported because a disciplined and cohesive government has made politics dull.

He may be right. But Mr Blair's problem in dealing with the criticisms of these peripheral characters is that he cannot demonstrate that he, and not they, speaks for the Labour mainstream.

The 1997 changes to the rule book have dismantled the means for the party as a whole to express an opinion, while MPs have lost much of their credibility thanks to ruthless whipping and the encouragement of sycophantic questions to the PM on Wednesday afternoons.
Simon McKeown
London
simon.mckeown@geo2.poptel.org.uk

 Ken Follett says Blair's administration depends on vilifying people. Labour responds: Follett is "sad", "lurid", "over the top", showing "why he is better known for his fiction than his judgment". He "joins the ranks of the disappointed and disgruntled who opt for the easy voice of opposition".

Having folletted the Labour party, maybe Ken isn't the one to talk. But Labour's response makes his point for him.
John Nicholson
Mancheste
john@ukpha.org.uk

 Who are the journalists who were given the original "character assassination" briefings and who gave them? Both groups should reveal their identities. In the wider interest of democracy they should name themselves - or be named.
John Moger
Braunston, Northants

webTitle: Blair's on-the-spot comment hit the mark

fields.headline: Blair's on-the-spot comment hit the mark
fields.trailText: I write not as a member of a religious group but as the president of the Global Ethic Foundation at the University of Tübingen, who invited Tony Blair to inaugurate there a series of high level yearly lectures on a global ethic which seems to us of decisive importance in this age of globalisation. Tony Blair fulfilled his task perfectly. Your leader (July 1) misses the point in all three "mistakes" allegedly made there by Tony Blair.
fields.body:
I write not as a member of a religious group but as the president of the Global Ethic Foundation at the University of Tübingen, who invited Tony Blair to inaugurate there a series of high level yearly lectures on a global ethic which seems to us of decisive importance in this age of globalisation. Tony Blair fulfilled his task perfectly. Your leader (July 1) misses the point in all three "mistakes" allegedly made there by Tony Blair.

1. He did not "misread his audience" but got a standing ovation from his academic audience in all the three halls full of students, professors and townspeople.

2. Confronted with the fact of endemic alcohol-induced excess also in Britain, the prime minister dared to make a marginal and tenta tive suggestion of on-the-spot fines instead of on-the-spot arrests. This remark was ridiculously inflated by your biased leader-writer to "something Orwellian".

3. The greatest error is not that "Mr Blair once again looks rattled" but that your leader-writer revealed himself as a petty polemicist who says not one word about the main topics of Mr Blair's great speech: that "ethical values should guide us in the era of globalisation", that "community" as an ideal is distinct from the state and that "equal worth" is not to be identified with either equality of outcome or equality of opportunity.

But all this criticism will soon be forgotten. For Tony Blair and his audience what remains important is that the prime minister showed him self a statesman with vision and substance and at the same time in touch with ordinary people. That is the reason why his speech and his discussion with the audience were such a great success, which would merit a fair evaluation in his own country's newspapers.

"Fairness", an English word introduced into the German language, was for me all my life a specifically British value in sport, academia and politics. But, having granted to Tony Blair an unusually long "honeymoon", many British media seem now to follow the unfair law of news for commerce: first praise your hero to the skies and then criticise him to hell!

Prof Hans Küng
President, Global Ethics Foundation
University of Tübingen

fields.headline: The scholarly Bill Gates
fields.trailText: I was angered at your coverage of the proposed Gates Cambridge Scholarships (How Bill Gates bought Cambridge, July 3). The scholarships would enhance the graduate environment that already exists at Cambridge: the top British graduate students study side by side with some of the brightest minds from around the world.
fields.body:
I was angered at your coverage of the proposed Gates Cambridge Scholarships (How Bill Gates bought Cambridge, July 3). The scholarships would enhance the graduate environment that already exists at Cambridge: the top British graduate students study side by side with some of the brightest minds from around the world.

Cambridge is an international university, and is already committed to attracting outstanding graduate students from both the UK and overseas. Students and academic staff from overseas greatly enrich the intellectual life of the university. I am convinced that a free exchange of students and staff is essential to any university at the top of the world league.

The overseas alumni of all British universities are one of the country's greatest assets. Overseas students leave Britain with the impression that education is highly valued here, and that research and teaching are conducted to the highest standards. This creates an international network - many of them powerful people in leadership positions - who remember their time here with great fondness. These unofficial ambassadors take their impressions of the UK, and their loyalty to their UK universities, home with them.

The proposed Gates Cambridge Scholarship programme is additional to existing scholarship schemes and places at Cambridge. No British student will be squeezed out of a place to make way for a Gates Scholar. The university and colleges already offer a range of other programmes to assist UK students in financial need.

We have more than 30,000 overseas alumni. These are already an impressive bunch, and Gates Cambridge Scholarships would help us make sure we continue to attract the brightest minds worldwide, regardless of their personal finances.
Prof Sir Alec Broers
Vice-chancellor
University of Cambridge

webTitle: Fiji rebels angry at military's new government

fields.headline: Fiji rebels angry at military's new government
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Defying the gunmen holding Fiji's deposed government hostage, the country's military leader named an interim civilian government yesterday, but said he will retain power until the captives are freed.
fields.body:
Defying the gunmen holding Fiji's deposed government hostage, the country's military leader named an interim civilian government yesterday, but said he will retain power until the captives are freed.

Commodore Frank Bainimarama, who assumed power 10 days after rebels stormed parliament on May 19, appointed the interim leaders without input from the gunmen who had demanded a role.

The move sidelined the rebels holding 27 members of the ousted Indian-led government at gunpoint in the name of indigenous Fijian rights.

The coup leader, George Speight, warned that the army may pay a high price for "completely ignoring" him. "There's a very big possibility of making a lot of people really upset."

After Mr Speight's raid on parliament, the army gave in to most of his demands, including firing the prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry - a hostage and the first ethnic Indian to lead Fiji. The army also threw out the 1997 multiracial constitution.

Indians were first brought to Fiji more than a century ago by English colonialists seeking indentured labourers for rich sugar-cane fields. Today, they make up about 44% of Fiji's population, while indigenous Fijians account for about 51%.

Mr Speight, a failed businessman, claims to be acting for indigenous Fijians angered by Mr Chaudhry's refusal to raise rents charged to Indian sugar-cane farmers on land communally owned by indigenous people.

Notably absent from the new government are members of Fiji's Indian minority.

"We approached two well-qualified members of the Indian community, but they declined," Mr Bainimarama said.

The interim government will rule for 18 months and set guidelines for a new constitution. The old one "will not be reinstated", he said.

The new government should work for Fiji's poor indigenous majority, and for "the protection of the rights of Indians and other communities that are an integral part of our nation".

Mr Bainimarama will remain head of state until all the hostages are released, the gunmen turn over their weapons, and public order is restored.

A banking executive, Laisenia Qarase, was named prime minister. Known more as a manager than a politician, he has been head of the Merchant Bank of Fiji and is a former director of the Fiji Development Bank.

fields.headline: Ex-ministers join spin fray
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's efforts to prevent further damaging squabbling over Ken Follett's attack on Tony Blair's "rent boy" spin doctors yesterday failed to prevent fresh criticism of the Downing Street style of government.
fields.body:
Labour's efforts to prevent further damaging squabbling over Ken Follett's attack on Tony Blair's "rent boy" spin doctors yesterday failed to prevent fresh criticism of the Downing Street style of government.

Not only did the millionaire novelist's MP wife, Barbara, implicitly back Mr Follett's criticism, but former ministers such as Tony Benn and Doug Henderson also weighed in.

Mrs Follett told a local government conference: "I came into politics to make big changes - not just to vote for small ones." She will be questioned about the outburst on July 28 when her constituency management committee next meets. Stevenage agent Bruce Jackson said her husband, a local party member, almost certainly warned her what he was writing. "I think she's probably bothered because of the hype, but the party in Stevenage is not bothered," Mr Jackson insisted."He would do nothing to damage Barbara or the Labour party."

More intriguing is the view of some MPs that Mr Follett spoke out because he feels that Mo Mowlam, a friend, has been the victim of unfair whispering - something she quickly denied after his article.

With the Tories eager to stir up trouble, the Hagueite strategist, Andrew Lansley, used a Commons debate to launch an attack on the government's "obsession with spin". Even Lady Thatcher came back to join the row. Announcing she is to write a new book on leadership the former premier said: "In this age of spin doctors and sound bites, the ever-present danger is that leaders will follow fashion and not their instincts and beliefs."

Mr Henderson, dropped at the last reshuffle, told Radio 4's Today that Mr Follett "was reflecting what a lot of people have been thinking but not saying publicly".

Mr Benn provided an historical context at the Tom Paine festival in Lewes, East Sussex, celebrating the author of The Rights of Man. "If Tom Paine was alive today, he would understand exactly what New Labour is all about - running Britain like some medieval monarchy, determined at all costs to hang on to power, surrounded by courtiers, some of whom won their position by flattery, and supported by rich and powerful people, some of them seeking personal favours for themselves," he declared.

With the Tories eager to stir up trouble, the Hagueite strategist, Andrew Lansley, used a Commons debate to launch an attack on the government's "obsession with spin". Even Lady Thatcher came back to join the row. Announcing she is to write a new book on leadership the former premier said: "In this age of spin doctors and sound bites, the ever-present danger is that leaders will follow fashion and not their instincts and beliefs." Mr Henderson, dropped at the last reshuffle, told Radio 4's Today that Mr Follett "was reflecting what a lot of people have been thinking but not saying publicly". Mr Benn provided an historical context at the Tom Paine festival in Lewes, East Sussex, celebrating the author of The Rights of Man. "If Tom Paine was alive today, he would understand exactly what New Labour is all about - running Britain like some medieval monarchy, determined at all costs to hang on to power, surrounded by courtiers, some of whom won their position by flattery, and supported by rich and powerful people, some of them seeking personal favours for themselves," he declared.

fields.headline: Hague's £4bn pledge to schools
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: William Hague will today launch another provocative assault on the government when he declares that the Tories will abolish local education authorities, allowing schools to spend £540 more per pupil.
fields.body:
William Hague will today launch another provocative assault on the government when he declares that the Tories will abolish local education authorities, allowing schools to spend £540 more per pupil.

Buoyed up by his controversial interventions on law and order, the Tory leader will take on the prime minister in Labour's territory by pledging to transform Britain's education system through his Free Schools Concept.

Under his plan, the Tories would hand over funds to schools directly from Whitehall, giving head teachers control of £4bn, which works out at £540 per pupil. The initiative would free schools of "bureaucratic and political control" and allow head teachers to decide how to spend more in areas which are currently controlled by local education authorities.

"LEAs as we know them will cease to exist," Mr Hague will tell the rightwing thinktank Politeia in a speech tonight. "Schools will be paid on a per pupil basis. And because £4bn will no longer be kept back by Whitehall and local councils every school in the country will get on average £540 more per pupil as best they see fit."

Tory sources made clear last night that Mr Hague believed that LEAs created an unnecessary layer of bureaucracy by providing facilities such as school buses and maintenance departments on a council-wide basis. Mr Hague was struck by the experience of a school in his Richmond constituency which has lost a teacher at the same time as the LEA is spending £98,000 fitting new windows which it does not need.

Mr Hague will say tonight that schools are best placed to decide on facilities. "Headteachers and governors will be free to manage their own budgets, free to employ their own staff, free to set their teachers' pay, free to determine their own admissions policy. Free schools mean higher standards for pupils, better discipline in our classrooms, real choice and real accountability for parents."

He will qualify his remarks by making clear that local councils would retain control over a few key areas, such as truancy and deciding how to provide for pupils with special needs.

Labour was swift last night to dismiss Mr Hague's initiative. David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said the government had already handed £1bn to schools.

"Since 1997 we've delegated school meals, repairs and administration budgets that the Tories in power refused to do the minute the local government lobby opposed them," Mr Blunkett said. "We have made huge progress in developing a schools budget so that every penny that can be delegated to schools is delegated."

Mr Hague's speech is designed to appeal to centre ground voters, many of whom were appalled by his recent provocative interventions on law and order and asylum. He hopes to outflank Labour by pledging to match government funding on health and education and then setting out policies with a Tory flavour.

His Free Schools Concept, which could allow parents to set up their own state-funded schools if local schools fall below standard, is meant to have a Thatcherite edge with the reassurance that government funding will be safe.

Labour insists it is unrattled by Mr Hague's attempts to steal its clothing.

Last week Mr Hague was forced to water down his pledge to provide a guaranteed waiting time for patients. He told Question Time that the guarantee would only apply to patients suffering from serious conditions.

fields.headline: Myths Copeland exploded
fields.trailText: Further to Yasmin Khan's comments (Letters, July 3), coverage of the trial of David Copeland failed to grasp the most important issue: how can we create a society in which young people who are concerned about their sexuality can get the help they need to become happy adults, whether heterosexual, gay, lesbian or bisexual?
fields.body:
Further to Yasmin Khan's comments (Letters, July 3), coverage of the trial of David Copeland failed to grasp the most important issue: how can we create a society in which young people who are concerned about their sexuality can get the help they need to become happy adults, whether heterosexual, gay, lesbian or bisexual?

The year David Copeland was born, I was struggling with my own gay identity and had a nervous breakdown, largely as a result of the coverage of the Jeremy Thorpe trail and the prevailing negative stereotypes and attitudes toward gay men. I was fortunate to contact London Lesbian & Gay Switchboard, who reassured me and put me in touch with a befriending organisation. I am now a happy gay man.

Probably around the time Copeland was starting to become anxious about his identity, the media was full of the original section 28 debate and all the anti-gay messages that it encouraged. It is small wonder if he felt isolated and threatened and internalised all the hate that was stirred up.

And what do we offer a teenager today? More positive messages about being lesbian or gay, for sure, but still there is no equalised age of consent and the renewed section 28 debate has provided another platform for a public expression of hatred and bigotry.

The Social Exclusion Unit, the principal driver of government social policy, routinely ignores the needs of lesbians and gay men, in spite of appeals to take them seriously.

I wonder if the Blairs have considered their clear opportunity to influence positively the environment in which little Leo and his generation will grow up, and the prevailing attitudes against which they will develop their own identity? Failure to act on the causes of bigotry will only see it flourish.
Martin Jones
London

 Before we forget the trial and conviction of David Copeland, and our relief and satisfaction gives way to indifference, we should step back and consider our collective responsibility for the society that produced Copeland.

Some years ago I was the target of vicious anti-gay violence, and experienced the whole gamut of emotions, including the desire for retribution. But neither then nor now is that sufficient. I avoided reading or listening to reports of Copeland's trial but, finally, I read Saturday's Guardian (Bomber gets six life terms, July 1) and I found myself sobbing, for the pain and humiliation of my own experience, for the victims of Copeland's bombs and their families and friends, but also for Copeland. We need to feel compassion for someone so racked by unhappiness, inadequacy, self-loathing and hatred that they are driven to such acts of barbarity.

It's not enough to shrug our shoulders and blame something or someone else while we continue to buy the newspapers that spread blatant xenophobia. Neither can we continue to elect the same politicians who collude in that (or make damaging compromises on issues such as section 28) or allow public institutions to drag their feet, if at the same time we do not make our voices heard loud and clear. And that means in every arena, local, regional or national that touches our lives.
Steve Stannard
London

 Amongst all the totally justified outrage over Copeland, certain questions seem to have been missed. How was he able to purchase £1,500 worth of fireworks, to enable him to make the bombs? Are there no controls on the sale of explosives?
Brian Robinson
Brentwood, Essex

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Newlywed dies on honeymoon
fields.body:
Newlywed dies on honeymoon

A newlywed plunged more than 200ft to his death from a balcony while on his honeymoon, it emerged yesterday. Russell Armstrong, 23, from Portsmouth, Hampshire, was holidaying in Benidorm.

One in four skip lunch breaks

One in four office workers do not take a lunch break, according to a poll of 1,000 staff. Six out of 10 leave the office for 30 minutes or less. In contrast, office workers in Spain take 90 minutes.

Drug raid Briton freed

Police have freed Lorraine Fraser, 27, a British woman arrested in a drug raid in Sihanoukville, Cambodia. Police said she had nothing to do with the drugs found but five foreigners, including two other Britons, are still being held.

Morton portrait of Queen

The biographer Andrew Morton is turning his attention to the Queen with an unauthorised documentary portrait to be screened on ITV as part of its autumn season. The writer, who penned Diana: Her True Story, will present an hour-long documentary.

Cabbie returns forgotten baby

A mother was reunited with her baby 30 minutes after leaving him in a London cab. The driver eventually spotted the boy in the back and returned him to his home in Hammersmith, west London.

webTitle: Drug case Briton sentenced to hang

fields.headline: Drug case Briton sentenced to hang
fields.standfirst: Hunger strike threat by nurse condemned in Malaysia
fields.trailText: David Chell has threatened to go on a protest hunger strike after a court in Penang yesterday found him guilty of attempting to smuggle heroin and sentenced him to death by hanging.
fields.byline: Frances Harrison  in Kuala Lumpur, Simon Bowers  and Paul Kelso
fields.body:
The 57-year-old psychiatric nurse from Stoke-on-Trent described Malaysian justice as "a joke" after a judge, sitting without a jury at Penang high court, sentenced him to hang for attempting to smuggle 189.86 grams (6.7 oz) of heroin.

He was arrested in October 1998 at the Bayan Lepas airport after a security guard claimed to have discovered the drugs stuffed in 133 condoms and hidden in Mr Chell's underpants as he prepared to board a flight to Australia.

Chell, who has been in jail for 21 months, told the judge, Zaleha Zahari: "You should be ashamed of yourself, madam. I hope you will not sleep for a year."

He has filed an appeal, which it is thought could take between a year and 18 months.

Karpal Singh, Chell's chief defence lawyer, had told the court there were sufficient inconsistencies to cast reasonable doubt on the case.

He said there was no fingerprint evidence linking the heroin to Chell and contradictory statements had been made by a security officer. A relevant page from a police station logbook was found to have been ripped out, he told the court.

In a letter seen by the Guardian, Chell described Malaysia as a "hypocritical and craven country" and said he would refuse food should he be found guilty.

"I intend to go on an immediate hunger strike and non-cooperation with the prison regime," he writes.

"I want everyone in the UK to press MPs to get the British high commission in Kuala Lumpur to visit [me] _ to let the prison know that outside eyes are still on me."

In his letter, Chell gives his version of events leading up to his arrest which he claims was the result of a failed bribery attempt. He alleges that police were tipped off by a third party that he would be passing through the airport carrying a large amount of cash.

Throughout his trial Chell insisted the drugs were planted on him. He told the court that his only contact with heroin had been in his professional work with drug addicts which helped earn him a scholarship to Keele University in the 1970s.

But giving her verdict, the judge said she could not see any reason why witnesses would want to frame Chell.

Chell's friends and family in Britain yesterday responded to the verdict by demanding intervention from the British government. Alex Bromiley, a former colleague, said: "This is clearly a miscarriage of justice."

But the Foreign Office yesterday said the case was still at this stage a matter between Chell and his locally appointed lawyer.

Norma Shaw, 57, who has known Chell and his family for for 44 years, said he had expected to be convicted. "He is very angry and frustrated but he anticipated the result," she said. "His family also expected it but are still very shocked."

Ms Shaw's daughter, Sarah, also a close family friend, said: "It is no longer he [who] is on trial and subjected to worldwide scrutiny, but the very concept and practice of Malaysian law."

In a fax sent to friends in Stoke-on-Trent yesterday, Chell said he would fight on and managed to joke that perhaps the food in the prison's "condemnation" block would be an improvement on what he had been getting.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
White farmers offer to sell
Zimbabwe's white farmers' union said yesterday that more than 200 white-owned farms would be offered for immediate sale to President Robert Mugabe's government for black resettlement.
fields.body:
White farmers offer to sell
Zimbabwe's white farmers' union said yesterday that more than 200 white-owned farms would be offered for immediate sale to President Robert Mugabe's government for black resettlement.

The offer came on the last day for commercial farmers to object to Mr Mugabe's seizure of 804 white-owned farms for redistribution to landless peasants. Reuters, Harare

Jews' memorial vandalised
Vandals painted swastikas on the main Jewish memorial in Riga yesterday, a day before Lativa commemorates its Jewish Holocaust victims, police said.

"The monument had swastikas daubed on it, it was reported early this morning," a spokeswoman said. The monument is at the site of a synagogue that the Nazis razed on July 4, 1941, killing dozens of Jews inside. Reuters, Riga

US marine held over schoolgirl
Japanese police said yesterday they had arrested a US marine for molesting a 14-year-old girl on the southern island of Okinawa, just weeks before President Bill Clinton attends the Group of Eight summit there.

The Okinawa prefectural government has protested to the US military. AP, Tokyo

Legislators face investigation
The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, has announced that a number of legislators will be investigated for destabilising the country by fanning unrest and unnerving financial markets . Cabinet secretary Marsilam Simanjuntak said Mr Wahid had told the attorney general's office to go ahead with the inquiry. Reuters, Jakarta

Chinese to put Viagra on sale
After more than a year of clinical trials, China announced yesterday that it has approved sales of the anti-impotence drug Viagra, according to the Xinhua News Agency. AP, Beijing

webTitle: Historic triumph lights up the future for France

fields.headline: Historic triumph lights up the future for France
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of French supporters crowded the Place de la Concorde yesterday to cheer the winners of the European football championship, as politicians, the media and business started assessing the feel-good factor flowing from a unique achievement.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of French supporters crowded the Place de la Concorde yesterday to cheer the winners of the European football championship, as politicians, the media and business started assessing the feel-good factor flowing from a unique achievement.

To celebrate the first time the same national team has won the world and then the European cups, even the staid newspaper Le Monde splashed the story alongside an unprecedented colour photograph.

Headlines in national papers describing the players as "the kings of Europe" caught the mood of a country whose self-confidence has grown by leaps and bounds in its efforts to deal with social and economic shortfalls since a Socialist government was elected in 1997 - a year before the world cup.

The prime minister, Lionel Jospin, whose political popularity stands at over 60% and who was in Rotterdam to congratulate the winners, seems the most likely leader to gain from national euphoria as France heads for local, parliamentary and presidential elections in the next 22 months.

He described the 2-1 victory over Italy as a timely omen for the start of the country's six-month EU presidency.

Having already taken credit for a drop of a million in the country's jobless to 9.8% and a leap in economic growth, the leftwing administration can also thank its footballers for putting a brake on racism.

The team, which has players of Algerian, West African, Caribbean and central European origins playing alongside Gallic French, was already treated as an international example of racial harmony in 1998 after defeating Brazil.

The sports minister, Marie-Georges Buffet, said yesterday that the multi-ethnic side proved that France had created a harmonious society "that could do great things together" - a claim that has been supported by the drop in support for the anti-immigration National Front party.

"The image of ethnic mixing is at the origin of a collective spirit that meets every test," the leftwing daily Libération said in its leader. "France's victory, its secret, is without doubt based on the winning combination of two styles - physical and technical."

The rightwing Figaro agreed, adding: "[Zinedine] Zidane and his heroic teammates are more than just footballers. They represent a France which wins, a France which dreams."

The ethnic mixture was evident among the 400,000-strong crowd which filled the Champs Elysées on Sunday night and the gathering outside the Crillon Hotel on the Place de la Concorde where the players appeared on the balcony like royalty. The biggest cheer was reserved for Zidane, whose Algerian origins would have divided the country ten years ago.

Although France shows every sign of an economic boom, the feel-good factor will have to be kept alight for nine months before municipal elections test the real popularity of the government

webTitle: LA leads America back to union militancy

fields.headline: LA leads America back to union militancy
fields.standfirst: Membership rises as actors strike and teachers march
fields.trailText: As the strike by US actors enters its 10th week and other workers take to the streets to press for higher pay, Los Angeles has become the the unofficial capital of union activity in the United States.
fields.body:
As the strike by US actors enters its 10th week and other workers take to the streets to press for higher pay, Los Angeles has become the the unofficial capital of union activity in the United States.

The militancy, which has led to arrests and shut down parts of the city, is being heralded as the rebirth of union activism in the US.

William Daniels - Dustin Hoffman's father in the film The Graduate - is leading one of the bitterest strikes in entertainment history as head of the Screen Actors Guild which, with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, called the strike against advertisers who want to pay actors lump sums rather than repeat fees. The mainly low-paid actors say it will leave them much worse off.

Meanwhile, teachers have taken their dispute to the streets, homecare workers have brought city centre traffic to a halt and hotel workers have been gathering outside Loew's hotel in Santa Monica to win union recognition there and in other hotels in the city.

The hotel workers are led by Maria Elena Durazo, president of the local Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees union (Here). Like her, many of the activists are from Latino immigrant families.

"Some people may not realise it yet but the city is better off with all this union activity because we are organising people in a productive way," she said. To leave the frustrations festering would be to create the climate that led to the Los Angeles riots of 1992.

But last year membership increased after 10 years of decline. It is noticeable that many of the growing number on picket lines and at rallies are much younger than the traditional image of union activists.

"For many decades, labour was like an institution, a dinosaur," the organising director of the LA county federation of labour, Jon Barton, said.

"Now it is trying to become more of a movement. More and more students are being recruited on campus [to work as interns in unions] and we are putting 30% of our resources into organising. Last year 91,000 workers were organised here, and we've or ganised another 3,000 in the last month."

Another factor is the ending of traditional labour hostility towards illegal migrant workers. The unions are campaigning officially for amnesties for illegal workers, many of who are in the worst-paid jobs, which provide rich opportunities for union recruitment.

"There is a combination of forces propelling things," said David Koff, Here's senior research analyst. "You have a huge pool of immigrant workers and there is also this political power which the Latinos have now. There is also a level of cooperation between unions that did not happen even two or three years ago."

Last week more than 2,000 teachers rallied in protest against a pay offer. The previous day 300 government-employed homecare workers brought traffic in the centre of the city to a standstill.

Not that the employers are rolling over. Although earlier this year the striking LA caretakers who feature in Ken Loach's new film Bread and Roses won their campaign for higher wages, other disputes have been more prolonged.

Loew's hotel, where many senior Democrats are due to stay during their convention next month, has brought in management consultants, and the advertisers have been using non-union actors or filming abroad.

webTitle: Still proud, but Italy can't shake off the blues

fields.headline: Still proud, but Italy can't shake off the blues
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Never in living memory has the beautiful game caused Italy such anguish. An unnatural quiet fell across the country yesterday as disbelief turned to despair. Televisions were switched off and mourning declared. To lose a final was agonising, but to lose in such a manner, with victory   only 30 seconds away, was intolerable.
fields.body:
Never in living memory has the beautiful game caused Italy such anguish. An unnatural quiet fell across the country yesterday as disbelief turned to despair. Televisions were switched off and mourning declared. To lose a final was agonising, but to lose in such a manner, with victory only 30 seconds away, was intolerable.

"Mockery," "Anger," "Shattered Dream," "What Bad Luck," ran the headlines, but many Italians could not even bear to read post-mortems. Victory would have given Italy its first major championship title in 18 years. For a country with football in the soul, the wait has been too long.

Within seconds of the Azzurri's win over the Netherlands in the Euro 2000 semi-final, millions poured onto the streets for a night-long party. After France's 2-1 victory in Rotterdam, Rome remained silent and deserted save for tourists.

Some economists have speculated that victory was needed to inject consumer confidence into the sluggish economy. Of some consolation was the fact that Italy surpassed pundits' expectations of an early exit.

"Thanks anyway," said La Stampa's headline, catching the mood. Gazzetta dello Sport said: "Italy had shown world champ France that it could outplay it. This second place, even if full of regrets, is still a masterpiece."

The president, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, made the players Knights of the Republic, a symbolic honour. Their commitment, moral solidity and tenacity were a model for the nation, he said. Coach Dino Zoff, woke up to clemency from his tormentors in the press.

"I'm proud of this team. We gave it our all," he said, and to his astonishment everyone agreed. Almost everyone. Silvio Berlusconi, opposition leader and owner of AC Milan, said Mr Zoff "acted like he was the last of amateurs" for not assigning a man to mark the French player Zinedine Zidane.

"All it took was to understand this thing, and we would have won the game," said Mr Berlusconi, whom polls tip to be the next prime minister.

fields.headline: British 'torture chief' quits
fields.trailText: A British colonel accused of torture while running the secret police in Bahrain retired abruptly yesterday from his post as an adviser to the island's interior ministry.
fields.body:
A British colonel accused of torture while running the secret police in Bahrain retired abruptly yesterday from his post as an adviser to the island's interior ministry.

A statement by the Gulf News Agency said the prime minister, Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman Al Khalifa, met Ian Henderson and thanked him for his "long service in the security department".

Mr Henderson, 71, a Scot, took charge of Bahrain's security in 1966, five years before it gained independence from Britain. He had previously served in colonial Kenya, fighting the Mau Mau uprising.

Opposition groups in Bahrain, which has a population of 400,000, frequently complain of human rights abuses. In 1995 they accused Mr Henderson of "masterminding a ruthless campaign of repression". He denied the accusation.

Mr Henderson's retirement comes as the new ruler of Bahrain, Sheikh Hamad bin 'Issa Al Khalifa, sets about liberalising the state. Besides announcing steps towards democracy, he has released several hundred political detainees and set up a committee to monitor human rights.

An Amnesty spokesman said: "We've repeatedly raised our concerns about torture with the Bahraini authorities and with Henderson himself, since 1987.

"The government of Bahrain has consistently denied torture, but has never, to our knowledge, carried out a proper investigation."

Mr Henderson left his post as Bahrain's head of security two years ago to become an adviser to the interior ministry.

In January this year Jack Straw, the home secretary, announced that the organised crime branch of the Metropolitan police was investigating Mr Henderson's activities.

This came after it was reported that Mr Henderson had celebrated New Year at his country home on Dartmoor, which is marked with a 5ft-high gallows and a sign saying "Beware of the Dogs".

Lord Avebury, vice-chair of the parliamentary human rights group, suggested that Mr Henderson was liable to be arrested if he set foot in Britain again.

Scotland Yard confirmed yesterday that the papers in the case were still being examined.

fields.headline: A right royal farce
fields.standfirst: Adam Sweeting
fields.trailText: Wallis Simpson: The Demonised Duchess | Panorama | Buffalo - The African Boss
fields.body:
If she'd been born 60 years later, Wallis Simpson might have ended up as the toast of the international celebrity circuit, having dinner at the White House and hosting celebrity fundraisers for the Hollywood elite. In her obsession with staying slim and dressing as the acme of chic, she would have been the doyenne of contemporary catwalk culture. Instead, she became the person the Queen Mother most loved to hate, was accused of being everything from a Nazi sympathiser to a man in drag, and lived out her later years as the loyal but trapped wife of a man she never intended to marry in the first place. She came from the wrong generation to write a scandal-dripping autobiography, but imagine how much the News Of The World would have paid for the rights.

Wallis Simpson: The Demonised Duchess (C4) cast a sober eye over her life and reputation, and found an ambitious woman determined to escape from her beginnings as the barely tolerated daughter of the wealthy Warfields, of Baltimore. Like a doomed Edith Wharton heroine, rumours of illegitimacy blighted her social prospects.

Wallis's early years read like Graham Greene. She married an American navy flier, who drank too much and abused her. She followed him to China, where she had an affair with an Italian diplomat who later became Mussolini's son-in-law. She became renowned as an enthusiastic poker player, and travelled through China possibly on some kind of undercover assignment for the US government. Later, when she married shipping heir Ernest Simpson and started her affair with Edward, Prince of Wales, British intelligence supposedly compiled the "China Dossier", detailing her exploits in the Orient (rumoured to include a spell in a Shanghai brothel).

Her fatal mistake was to be too successful in the tricky sport of social climbing. She probably intended her affair with Edward to be an exciting diversion which whirled her into the aristocratic high life, but she hadn't foreseen that the pitiful prince would conceive a hopeless dependency on her. He was crowned Edward VIII in 1936, but when he planned to abdicate to be with her, she foresaw that she would bear the brunt of worldwide condemnation, and fled to France. Her worst fears came true, and the rest of her life was spent in gilded exile, first in the Bahamas during the war, then subsequently in Paris. The royal family's sole conciliatory gesture was to allow her to stay at Buckingham Palace for Edward's funeral in 1972. Wallis kept up appearances to the last, but this was a bleak and macabre tale.

In Cyber Attack!, Panorama (BBC1) probed into the murky world of computer hackers who are lurking at the end of a modem, waiting to break into your computer, steal your most valuable files and plunder your credit card details. They might zap your PC with a malevolent virus, like the recent Love Bug. Those with darker ambitions have hacked into computers at the Pentagon, and tampered with space shuttle missions.

This should have been scary and fascinating, but the film felt disappointingly flat. Perhaps that was because of its American bias, evident in interviews with grungy American computer-nerds and doom-prophesying American senators. Also, it could have made more of the looming threat that the more troublesome the hackers become, the more governments and corporations will retaliate with illiberal legisla tion and squads of "cyber police" with unlimited powers. Computers and the internet are supposed to be liberating tools, but could easily become catalysts for institutionalised repression.

Buffalo - The African Boss (The Natural World, BBC2) explored the social organisation of the buffalo of Tanzania, and found that any threat comes not from dysfunctional geeks bearing a grudge but from hungry lions. These are the buffalo's only natural enemies, unless you include Tom Conti's narration, which found the great thespian struggling awkwardly to impart a tone of knowing irony where it really didn't belong. The dazzling photography said it all, revealing how the buffalo order their affairs via a hereditary hierarchy, take votes on which way to travel, and present a coordinated defence against lion-attacks. If we're not careful, soon they'll be employing spin doctors and bidding to host the 2006 World Cup.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
It is not clear if Peter White's guest in No Triumph, No Tragedy (9.0am, Radio 4) is unique, but it's unlikely that many other nations have a blind judge sitting on their highest court. Judge Zakeria Yacoob (pictured) of the South African constitutional court says his blindness often proved advantageous. As a young lawyer he developed an exceptional memory for detail and, when he was working clandestinely for the African National Congress, he never had any compromising papers for the police to discover.

Gerry Northam brings some of the euphoria about last week's completion of the human genome project back into the real world in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). No one doubts the importance of DNA evidence in trials, but recent cases have highlighted the practical difficulties it can generate. At one extreme lies the reasonable doubts about its accuracy. At the other is the recent release of a murderer whose valid sample didn't meet procedural rules.

webTitle: Getting personal with Mark Borchardt and Mike Smith from American Movie

fields.headline: Getting personal with Mark Borchardt and Mike Smith from American Movie
fields.trailText: Full Names: Mark Christopher Borchardt and Mike Joseph Schank.
fields.body:
Full Names: Mark Christopher Borchardt and Mike Joseph Schank.

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym, and why

Mark: No.

Mike: I used to be called The Reaper.

Would you ever lie about your age

Both: No.

How would you describe yourselves in a lonely hearts column

Mike: Mike Schank from American Movie is looking for a good-looking female companion, and I value friendship more than sex.

What was the last illegal thing you did

Mike: I was going to a day programme for people diagnosed with different disorders, and I went there one time on three tabs of acid.

Who is the nicest person you've met

Mark: Mike Schank.

Mike: God, with all this clean and sober business.

Who would you most like to exact revenge on?

Mark: My boss.

Has anyone ever made you cry?

Mark: No.

Mike: One time this dude who did acid every day, he made me cry with his guitar-playing.

What would you advertise for free

Mark: Pabst Blue Ribbon beer.

Mike: A party.

What would you never advertise

Mark: Pepsi.

What wakes you up screaming at three in the morning.

Mike: I used to listen to a band called Venom that could do that pretty good.

What takes you to a happy place

Mark: My kids and my chick.

Mike: My guitar playing and reading the Bible.

 American Movie is out on Friday

webTitle: UN conservation monitoring unit is first for Britain

fields.headline: UN conservation monitoring unit is first for Britain
fields.trailText: The United Nations flag was raised in Cambridge yesterday over the world conservation monitoring unit, the first UN agency to be opened in Britain in 50 years.
fields.body:
The United Nations flag was raised in Cambridge yesterday over the world conservation monitoring unit, the first UN agency to be opened in Britain in 50 years.

The unit is part of the UN Environment Programme and provides basic information on the state of all animals and plants on the planet. Klaus Toepfer, the Unep executive director, said it provided an early warning system for decision makers in government, the private sector and conservation and development organisations.

Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, said in a message that environmental trends were "deeply worrying - and may even be getting worse".

He said: "Human beings continue to plunder the global environment. Unsustainable practices remain deeply embedded in the fabric of our daily lives. We are failing to protect resources and ecosystems. We are failing to invest enough in alternative technologies, especially for energy. We are even failing to keep the debate alive."

He said a big public information effort was needed, governments must make and enforce environmental agreements and laws, the effect on the environment of decisions must become central to policy, and all this must be based on sound scientific information. The monitoring centre was there to provide that.

"Unpleasant ecological surprises lie ahead but the start of the new century could not be a more opportune time to commit ourselves, people as well as government, to a new epoch of conservation and stewardship."

The British government has put £500,000 towards the centre and it is being supported by BP Amoco, Rio Tinto and Vauxhall, some of the big companies accused of damaging the environment.

Lord Holme of Cheltenham, an executive of Rio Tinto, the world's biggest mining company, is providing all his company's environmental assessments of its projects to the centre to be put on computer for public scrutiny and use, as is BP Amoco.

Asked if it was appropriate for a company with a reputation for damaging the environment to support such a venture, Lord Holme said. "You are five years out of date. The people who think life is about cooking in a wok and riding a bicycle, and believe that everything they use was parachuted in by some benign eco-god do not live in the real world. What they have to realise is that the minerals they and we use come out of the ground, and we still have to do that, but we act responsibly. We properly investigate the environment of places we want to develop, and have walked away from projects that are too damaging."

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, said: "This centre will operate with no political or industrial interference. It is an open, transparent process so everyone knows the facts. In that way the information can be properly used to inform decisions."

fields.headline: Daughter of a preacher man
fields.standfirst: One day you're trapping foxes in the Outback with your devout dad. The next, you're a country singer.  Adam Sweeting  meets Kasey Chambers
fields.trailText: One day you're trapping foxes in the Outback with your devout dad. The next, you're a country singer. Adam Sweeting meets Kasey Chambers
fields.body:
Even in Australia the idea of an Australian country singer sounds far-fetched, but 23-year-old Kasey Chambers has all the makings of the real thing. She has already sold 70,000 copies of her debut album, The Captain, to fellow Antipodeans, enough to earn a platinum disc down under.

She can stick that on the sideboard alongside her batch of best album and best female artist awards from the Australian music industry. Bizarrely, she still can't get on the country radio stations in her homeland though, she argues, "it's kind of a compliment when you listen to the crap they play". Now, armed with a Virgin Records deal, she's wondering if she can repeat her success in the rest of the world.

With her Goth-like eye make-up, studs in her nose and lower lip and a ring through her right ear, Chambers isn't much like anyone you'd associate with country music of any era. Then again, her life bears little resemblance to anything you've ever heard before either. While other Australian kids were raised on teen soaps and the Minogue sisters, Chambers was leading a nomadic lifestyle trapping foxes on the Nullarbor Plain. "The Nullarbor is a big desert that runs across the middle of the country," she explains. "Foxes had become a big problem in Australia, so farmers would hire us to hunt them. It was back when there was a big fur trade, and we'd sell the skins. I think it's a bit strange actually, but at the time it was normal for us. We'd hunt kangaroos, too, but only for food."

The Chambers family travelled around the Nullarbor by day, then by night they'd make camp and sing around the fire. It was here that Chambers's father Bill passed on his enthusiasm for country music, from Hank Williams and Jimmie Rodgers to Gram Parsons and Emmylou Harris. Since the family were Seventh Day Adventists, Bible songs and gospel music also figured prominently, and Bill taught his family so well they were able to form their own self-contained group, the Dead Ringer Band, comprising Chambers, her parents, and her brother Nash. They spent 10 years touring Australia, playing anywhere from the big cities to the outback of Queensland and the Northern Territory.

"I've travelled all my life and we enjoyed touring so much. You didn't have to have a nine-to-five job, so it was worth it just for that. You couldn't make a whole lot of money out of it, but who does in the music industry unless you're a superstar?"

W hile Chambers now steps out under her own name, it's still a family affair. Her father plays guitar throughout the album, while her brother Nash produced it. Since the Dead Ringer Band had made four albums of their own, Chambers and her folks already knew their way around the studio. Consequently, while it's still a debut solo album by a young artist, The Captain exudes a maturity and self-awareness you'd expect from somebody 10 years older, comfortably spanning bluegrass, hillbilly music and crunchy country rock. "Some of the songs are seven years old, and one of them was written during the recording of the album, so they're coming from everywhere," she says. "I kind of like the fact that it's the last 23 years of my life rolled into 42 minutes."

The Chambers family saga offers plenty of scope for a tunesmith with an eye for detail. In her song Southern Kind of Life, Chambers could be describing Texas or Tennessee, but the song is about south Australia: "My town wasn't even on the map, you could pass right through it in 20 seconds flat. Old friends and Bibles filled the house, no room for money and no money anyway."

These Pines strikes a distant echo of the Louvin Brothers' In The Pines, but Chambers is singing about Norfolk Island in the Pacific, not the backwoods of Alabama. "The Captain was this guy I had a relationship with - his nickname was Captain Eddie," Chambers reveals. "He's from Norfolk Island, where we recorded the album and where the Norfolk Pine comes from. I was touring in western Australia and I was homesick for Norfolk, so I wrote about those pines."

It looks like there may be a lot more touring in store, and a lot more homesickness. And, perhaps, a lot more songs.

webTitle: CCTV clues to death of black man in custody

fields.headline: CCTV clues to death of black man in custody
fields.standfirst: Deaths in custody: special report
fields.trailText: A black former paratrooper with a medal for Northern Ireland service died in handcuffs on a police station floor while officers thought he was asleep or play-acting, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A black former paratrooper with a medal for Northern Ireland service died in handcuffs on a police station floor while officers thought he was asleep or play-acting, an inquest heard yesterday.

Several different versions were then given by police to relatives of Christopher Alder, who was 37, and had been celebrating in a nightclub only hours before his death, the coroner's jury in Hull was told.

Closed circuit TV film of the dying man will be played to the three women and six men, along with eight barristers, including Michael Mansfield QC, representing Mr Alder's family.

Five detectives, who are shown in the film discussing what to do with the dying man as he lay slumped on the floor of the custody suite, have been suspended and are awaiting trial accused of misconduct in public office by failing to take reasonable and proper care of him.

The inquest heard that the former soldier, who had worked at a number of jobs to pay for a computer studies course, had earlier been half-dragged from a police van after a fight outside the Waterfront nightclub in Hull and later trouble at the city's Royal Infirmary.

The East Riding of Yorkshire coroner, Geoffrey Saul, told the jury: "There is nobody on trial here.This inquest is simply a fact-finding exercise.

"But we need to find out how a man in his late 30s, who was seemingly fit and well, went to a nightclub in Hull and a few hours later met his death."

The inquest heard that it was only after 12 minutes that one police officer noticed that Mr Alder had apparently stopped breathing and efforts were made to save his life. Officers gave first aid but it was too late.

Mr Saul said that the jury would be told that the cause of death was difficult to determine, and they would need to consider the "full picture" of events leading up to his death. Home Office pathologist John Clark said it was unlikely that a head injury suffered during a fight earlier was a direct cause of death.

The coroner said that Mr Alder had returned to Hull from Hampshire after his marriage broke up. He had gone to the nightclub on March 31, 1998, and got into a late-night argument with a Leeds man, Jason Ramm, who was then thrown out by security staff.

Mr Ramm lay in wait outside until the club closed at 2am and confronted Mr Alder, who fell over and cracked his head after apparently exchanging punches with another Afro-Caribbean man, Jason Paul, 29.

The coroner said: "Not all the witnesses agree exactly what happened, but it is suggested Mr Alder connected with blows to Jason Paul, who had been acting as a peacemaker, before Mr Paul hit him once in the face."

Mr Alder, who was brought up in Hull by Nigerian parents, was taken to Hull Royal Infirmary, where staff described him as "extremely troublesome".

The inquest heard that the doctor on duty did not consider the head injury serious but could not take an X-ray because Mr Alder would not co-operate. Two police officers escorted Mr Alder out and advised him to go home, but arrested him when he refused and took him to Queen's Gardens police station.

The inquest is expected to last four weeks.

webTitle: Veteran hovers into history as duty-free tide ebbs

fields.headline: Veteran hovers into history as duty-free tide ebbs
fields.trailText: It was the era which saw the birth of Concorde and the QE2 - but the withdrawal of duty free has finally seen off the hovercraft designed by Sir Christopher Cockerell in 1968.
fields.body:
It was the era which saw the birth of Concorde and the QE2 - but the withdrawal of duty free has finally seen off the hovercraft designed by Sir Christopher Cockerell in 1968.

The two vessels, the Princess Margaret (above) and the Princess Anne, revolutionary cross-Channel boats of the swinging 60s, are to be replaced in October, casualties of the company Hoverspeed which operates them. It marks the end of sea hovercraft services in Britain.

The hovercraft can carry 300 passengers and 50 cars from Dover to Calais in 35 minutes. Their replacements are the Seacat catamarans, which take 45 minutes to make the journey, but are more efficient. They can carry 600 passengers, and - crucially - 90 cars.

Since the abolition of duty free last year, there are fewer foot passengers wanting to load up on cheap drink and more motorists staying longer in France.

Geoffrey Eade, Hoverspeed's managing director, said last night: "The abolition of duty free has had a significant impact on cross-Channel services during the winter months.

"To continue on the old basis, operators would have to increase winter fares dramatically to recover lost duty free profits."

He said that the trend was towards people taking their cars to mainland Europe for shopping ashore , buying more goods but travelling less frequently.

Staff were told about the withdrawals last week, because they will lead to job cuts which are still being worked out by the company.

Hoverspeed said that the hovercraft were extremely reliable.

"They have been kept in good trim and we don't want to send them to the knacker's yard. There must be potential buyers out there for them."

The replacement vessel, the Seacat, costs £15m. Although it will take longer to complete the crossing, it is less noisy than the hovercraft.

Gwyn Prosser, MP for Dover, said: "This is the end of an era. We now have to be careful that there are no significant job losses, but the company has said it is trying to keep losses to a minimum."

webTitle: Why manliness will get a modern leader nowhere

fields.headline: Why manliness will get a modern leader nowhere
fields.standfirst: Ekow Eshun  on what Ken Follett really means by 'manly'
fields.trailText: Ekow Eshun  on what Ken Follett really means by 'manly'
fields.body:
Aside from illustrating the fickle nature of political friendships, Ken Follett's weekend attack on Tony Blair also highlighted the millionaire author's belief in an unwritten code of manliness. "What really bothers me is the morality of it all," he wrote in protest at the "malicious gossip" of the government's spin doctors. "If you are displeased with a colleague you should look him or her in the eye and say so. That's the behaviour my parents' generation called 'manly'. It's what we expect from leaders."

Follett is 52 this year, so when he talks about his parents, he is suggesting applying the standards of pre-war Britain to modern politics. Personally speaking, I would sooner accept the oily embrace of a New Labour apparatchik any day, rather than shake hands with the kind of square-jawed, straight-batting, old school tie-wearing English gent who used to run this country. Follett talks about morality and yet the generation he invokes believed in the primacy of a natural ruling class and was raised to accept the hypocrisy of Empire - the notion that British colonialism was bringing enlightenment and civilisation to benighted savages around the globe.

Maybe that's not quite what Ken had in mind. In which case it might be fairer to take a leaf out of one of his own books. Meet "maverick seismologist" Michael Quercus from the author's most recent tome The Hammer of Eden. "He was sitting at his desk in khakis, tan walking boots and a navy blue polo shirt. Michael Quercus was neither a peevish professor nor an academic fat cat. He was a hunk: tall, fit, good-looking, with sexy hair, dark and curly. She quickly summed him up as one of those guys who were so big and handsome and confident they thought they could do anything they liked."

Quercus is the kind of upstanding, uncomplicated man who should be the hero of an airport novel. You can judge his inner character from the wave of his sexy dark hair, for God's sake. But I can't help feeling that being "manly" in the real world is a tougher and more elusive challenge than Follett's breezy bestsellers suggest. Even if the author's own carefully maintained pompadour implies he thinks otherwise.

It used to be that boys learned how to be men by looking up to their dads. The archetypal father was like a rock: dignified, strong, capable of providing security and shelter for his family. Only now such certainties are being eroded as changing patterns of employment mean that men are no the longer breadwinners across increasing parts of the country. Already this is the case in Scotland and Wales, while in Birmingham, business and finance are now sectors dominated by women.

Last year, the largest ever study of young men suggested that the key factor in the development of successful, high-achieving boys was a mother who could provide listening and emotional support for her son. The corollary of these findings isn't that men are useless as fathers and providers. It is rather that the demands of leadership have changed. At work, as businesses grapple with the implications of the internet-driven new economy, flexibility, the ability to communicate and a readiness to hear new ideas have become the most prized abilities in a boss. Modern management theory talks of "leading from the centre", inspiring a team to success through support and encouragement, as an alternative to the rigid hierarchies and lack of openness often found in the old workplace.

While Follett bemoans Blair for his unmanliness, it's worth looking around to see who the male icons of the moment are. The hapless performance of the England team during the European championships barely gave much opportunity to study the form of those traditional schoolboy idols. Yet in captain Alan Shearer there was a doughty stiff-upper-lipped hero of the old school who, you get the feeling, would have led his men as readily into combat as he did on to the sports field. To my mind though, England's most inspiring figure is Tony Adams, the former alcoholic whose autobiography, Addicted, is an unflinchingly honest account of his battle with drink. If he'd written such a book back in the days of Follett's parents, Adams would doubtless have been bounced out of the England team for lack of moral fibre.

Yet it's precisely his willingness to admit his failings, rather than collude in the fantasy that real men are strong, silent and stoic, that makes him heroic. Like Adams, more men today are ready to take account of their own complexity, admitting to emotional vulnerability and the need for support, than in previous generations. They have no choice. It's either that or become a dinosaur in the workplace. Or worse, find themselves a stranger to their children. Because research shows that, among the next generation of young men, it's already commonplace to accept that "equality is a good thing" and to reject the belief that "boys have to be hard to survive".

Now all they have to worry about is how to get a bouffant like Ken Follett's.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Melanie Skykes | John Berger | ...and Columbo
fields.body:
Pity poor Melanie Sykes, who has launched a broadside against lad mag Maxim over some disappearing knickers. The Boddington's lovely is reportedly furious after the bikini briefs she was wearing were airbrushed out of a photoshoot, giving the impression that she'd posed naked. The row is reminiscent of Kylie Minogue's "whoops, there goes my thong" tennis trouble with GQ a few weeks ago. Of course, it's generally a Bad Thing when women discover that essential items of underclothing have been airbrushed into oblivion, and is resonant of the broadly Bad Way that women's bodies are perceived in society as a whole.

But one can't help but ponder the circumstances that lead up to these doctored shots. "Mmm, Kylie, we had this great idea, right, where you wear a tiny skirt and reach up to the sky, right..." Surely stable doors and bolting horses come to mind.

 Still, it's mean to mock. What sort of relationship do you have with your physicality after years in the public eye? The writer John Berger once wrote: "A woman... is almost continually accompanied by her own image of herself... She has to survey everything she is and everything she does because how she appears to others, and ultimately how she appears to men, is of crucial importance for what is normally thought of as the success of her life." How much more so for women who, seen through the prism of celebrity, can never be more than the sum of their parts.

 Talking of parts, would someone kindly inter in concrete the nonsense computer-generated configuration that is currently gracing our screens in the Triumph adverts. The techno-babe jigs around in her bra at an alarming rate, clutching her web-tastic breasts with abandon, before inquiring: "Isn't software amazing?" Not if this is the best it can do, darling. At least Lara Croft kicks occasional ass.

 Thanks to the eagle-eared reader who wrote to let us know about a particularly trying radio trailer for the Beeb's Cagney and Lacey night: a male voice sharing choice comments about Sharon Gless telling "how she went from fit to fat", and "the chunky one whose name no one can remember". Can't imagine Columbo getting similar treatment. But hey, he was just eccentric. He didn't commit the cardinal sin of Failing to be Fanciable Enough.

fields.headline: No: 1669 Mongolia
fields.body:
Status: Huge, landlocked country between China and Russia.

And homeland of the notorious warlord Ghengis Khan, of course. Funny you should mention that - Ghengis was spotted in Mongolia just the other day.

But he's been dead for nearly 800 years! Yes, but his memory was resurrected last week, when rock stars dressed in Khan outfits to rev up a crowd.

What for? Mass murder? No, for the parliamentary elections. The Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party put on the show in an effort to win votes. And though the final count's not in yet, it looks like they'll notch up an impressive win.

But I thought the MPRP were ousted in 1996 by a democratic coalition after 75 years of communist rule? This is the new improved MPRP. After getting the boot, party operatives visited Europe to pick up some tips.

Any good? "We were very much inspired by this 'New Labour' image of Tony Blair," says party chairman Nambaryn Enkhbayar, pictured above. "We have tried to keep our leftist tradition, but we have moved towards the centre. We now call ourselves a centre-left party."

"New MPRP" doesn't quite have that Blairite ring, though, does it? Enkhbayar wanted to change it but "there were no good names left".

C'mon, he's not even trying. How about the Mongolian Democratic Party? Taken.

The Mongolian Socialist Democratic Party? Gone.

The Mongolian Democratic New Socialist Party? Nope.

fields.headline: A man's place?
fields.standfirst: Suddenly, boys are happy to help in the kitchen. Grown men idolise Jamie Oliver. Is this the end for the traditional, feminine heart of the home, asks  Maureen Freely
fields.trailText: Suddenly, boys are happy to help in the kitchen. Grown men idolise Jamie Oliver. Is this the end for the traditional, feminine heart of the home, asks  Maureen Freely
fields.body:
Finally, after decades of nagging, we are beginning to get somewhere. The kitchen is no longer an exclusively female domain. More and more men are taking up cooking, and advertisers, supermarkets, and food manufacturers have had to think about how best to reach out to this new constituency. It's all very tricky, because it's not just a gender thing. It's also a youth thing.

The most famous chef in the country is not just male, after all. He's also about two-and-a-half years old. And it has to be at least partly thanks to Jamie Oliver that so many boys are beginning to see kitchens in a new light.

Only last week, for example, a national survey revealed that more boys than girls prepare food in the kitchen. Only 8% of boys said they never helped with the cooking, compared with 17% of the girls.

This should be good news. It should mean that women need no longer worry about "chaining themselves to their kitchens" (as my 70s friends and I used to say so smugly about our mothers) or drag themselves home after work every evening to spend another four hours at the sink (as so many of those same friends have been doing ever since).

In theory at least, women who share kitchens with men are left with more time for themselves. If kitchen tasks can be shared equitably, it has to mean that they become less of a burden for everyone.

But what about all the other things that go on in kitchens? The jokes, arguments and reconciliations, the aimless conversations, the games, the first footsteps and homework sessions, the gossip and, for goodness sake, the eating?

The kitchen used to be thought of as the heart of the household. In most houses I know, it's still the place where people congregate. But you wouldn't know that from the dismissive way they talk about kitchens in the plural. The consensus seems to be that they are nice places to be, so long as it's someone else who's doing the work.

Nora Seton, author of The Kitchen Congregation, and daughter of the feminist novelist Cynthia Propper Seton, takes a different view. She doesn't want anyone to help her run her kitchen. She thinks of it as her refuge and her fortress, the place where she can recede "with impunity" and think her own thoughts at the end of the day, while chopping up a red onion for the family supper.

She learned how to cook and run a kitchen by watching her mother, who seemed to have had no trouble blending her writing into the domestic routine. Nora, who was her fifth and last child, remembers how she would have little yellow pads stuck all over the kitchen on which she wrote lines or plot refinements for her novels. When she decided at one point to teach herself French by reading Proust, she covered the kitchen walls with vocabulary lists.

But she never intended her daughters to be tied to their kitchens. She wanted them to have full lives in the outside world, follow their interests, break new ground. She died in 1982, the same year Nora graduated from Harvard with a degree in art history and classics. Nora remembers being a light-hearted, "larky" sort of person before losing her mother. The tragedy sobered her up, she says, and led her to make a number of unusual choices.

The first was to go to "cow school" in Texas. She got her MA in agricul ture and economics, and went straight to work in the cattle industry. After she and her husband moved to Connecticut, she worked on a farm. And it was while she was working there that she began to write about food.

In the early 90s they moved to Switzerland for a few years, where she became pregnant with her first daughter. The baby died in utero in her ninth month. It was an ancient friend and neighbour who cooked and talked her through her mourning, and saw her through a second pregnancy and the birth of her son. Although she knew at the time how important this woman was to her, it wasn't until later that she began to look back at this friend's kitchen and her mother's kitchen and to see what important places they were.

Now that she had one of her own, she couldn't understand why women in kitchens didn't get more respect. "I thought there was nothing out there that made me feel dignified about my role in life." So she decided it was up to her to write it herself. The Kitchen Congregation, published by Weidenfeld and Nicolson, is not a tract, though. It's a beautifully written autobiography. It travels along a timeline of kitchens, beginning with her mother's and ending with her own.

It talks about what she and her mother and her friends cooked and what they talked about while they were cooking. It is full of old recipes, fresh insights, odd asides and extraneous advice. But, aside from a few mentions of her father, her husband and her son, it is empty of men.

When I ask her why, she insists it wasn't out of any desire to exclude them. "But I wrote this book for women. I had a story to tell, and I staged it in the kitchen because I loved the irony of finding myself back in the hearth. I wanted to capture women's way of speaking - the endless sentences, with metaphor upon metaphor, and the pauses for reflection. In my experience, men don't speak that way."

But plenty of men do cook, I feel I have to remind her. She concedes this point, but says there is a huge difference in her view between the "lovely way older men inhabit kitchens" when they get tired of the dog fight and more interested in domesticity, and the young chefs she had to deal with when she was working in the food industry.

Oh, how they loved to throw themselves around, showing off their muscles by carrying around huge pots, seeing themselves not as people who fed others but as "masterful architects of curious ingredients". This wasn't cooking in her view, it was "joyless gymnastics" and it would be a terrible shame if teenage boys, or teenage girls for that matter, decided this was what kitchens were all about.

On balance, she doesn't think they will. Her generation had entered adulthood "when feminism was just breaking the glass" she explains. When she hears about old classmates, it's always the same pattern. "There are a lot of pivots. They kept finding themselves where they'd never expected to be. There were so many opportunities, but so many big mistakes to be made. It's got to be easier for the next ones. They can learn a lot just by watching us gasping at the edge of the cliff."
