fields.headline: Germaine Montero
fields.standfirst: Singer who celebrated the demi-monde of France and Spain
fields.trailText: Although most of her long career was on the stage in drama, Germaine Montero, who has died aged 90, was a singer and actress of great power and individuality. She made her mark as one of the most original singers in the great tradition of Parisian chanson.
fields.body:
Although most of her long career was on the stage in drama, Germaine Montero, who has died aged 90, was a singer and actress of great power and individuality. She made her mark as one of the most original singers in the great tradition of Parisian chanson.

Born in Paris and educated in Versailles, Montero went to Spain to continue her studies, making her stage debut in 1933 as a member of Federico Garcia Lorca's company in Madrid. After the Spanish civil war and the death of Lorca, she returned to France, and immediately made an impact singing Spanish songs and appearing in the first Paris production of Lorca's Les Noces De Sang (Blood Wedding).

Encouraged by Lorca, Montero had begun to write poetry, and in Paris she became friends with the Prévert brothers, Jacques and Pierre. In 1951, she had her first great success as a chanteuse at La Fontaine, a cabaret run by Pierre Prévert in the rue de Ghrenelle.

Singing a mixture of modern songs and Montmartre classics - such as Aristide Bruant's Dans La Rue and A Saint Lazare - she suggested a cross between the pierreuse, or streetwalker, characters made famous by Yvette Guilbert and Eugenie Buffet, and a more radical, contemporary manner, in songs by Leo Ferré, Albert Vidalie and Yves Darriet, such as La Complainte De Jack l'Éventrier (The Ballad Of Jack The Ripper).

It was, above all, in a series of songs written for her by the poet Pierre Mac Orlan that she made her most significant contribution to French song. Set to music by Georges Van Parys and V Marceau, La Fille De Londres, Je Peux Vous Raconter and La Chanson De Margaret have a haunting, slightly bitter quality. Mac Orlan wrote: "She brings to her singing all her dramatic gifts, using them to make each text profound."

One of Montero's first stage appearances after the war was in a revival of Prosper, by Lucienne Favre, at the Renaissance theatre. The critic Jean-Jacques Gautier saluted her grasp of the necessary genre chaloupé in this melodrama. At the first Avignon festival, she joined Michel Bouquet and Jeanne Moreau in Maurice Clavel's updated version of the Hamlet saga, Le Terrasse De Midi. Playing in the classics, in boulevard melodramas and in modern plays, often as a member of Vilar's Thétre National Populaire, Montero was seldom absent from the stage in the 1950s and 60s.

She was a huge success as Brecht's Mother Courage, appeared in Claudel's Le Pain dur and L'Êchange, Anouilh's Le Bal Des Voleurs, Camus's Les Justes, and Lorca's La Maison De Bernarda Alba. In lighter vein, she was seen in revivals of Sardou's Madame Sans Gene, Prosper Merimée's Le Carrosse De Saint Sacrament and Marceau's La Bonne Soupe.

On screen, Montero appeared in Henri Jeanson's Lady Paname (1951), René Clement's Knave Of Hearts (Monsieur Ripois, 1954), Claude Lelouche's Robert Et Robert (1978) and Jean-Louis Bertucelle's Stress (1984). In 1985, she starred in a memorable television drama, Ana Non, by Jean Prat, playing the leading role of a woman returning to Spain in the 1960s to come to terms with history and her memories.

Montero was awarded the Légion d'Honneur; she was a Chevalier des Arts et Lettres and was three times awarded the Grand Prix du Disque. In 1944, she married Mario Berdschy.

 Germaine Montero (née Heygel), singer and actress, born October 22 1909; died June 29 2000

fields.headline: Joey Dunlop
fields.trailText: It had been an experience, said a brilliant, courageous British motorcycle racing champion, of total madness.
fields.body:
It had been an experience, said a brilliant, courageous British motorcycle racing champion, of total madness. The time was the mid-1970s; the event, the Isle of Man Tourist Trophy, on the island's 37.73-mile road circuit.

The champion had arrived, he recalled, 1,400ft above sea level, past Brandywell, heading towards Windy Corner, and the six miles downhill to the finishing line. Fog was shrouding the mountain. Only by coming out from behind his fairing could he see anything of the country road. He did not care if he was called a coward, he told me, he would never race on the island again. And he didn't. He was not the only one.

An average of two riders a year are killed at the TT races. In 1976, after 27 years, the TT lost its British Grand Prix world championship status; great riders and world champions like Phil Reid and Giacomo Agostini said it was just too dangerous. Some observers assumed that the races, which had begun in 1907, were doomed. The advance of Japanese and Italian technology had overtaken a public road circuit where - even more than on custom-made tracks - riders' reaction times literally separated life and death.

For a quarter of a century, Joey Dunlop, who has died in an accident aged 48, was one of those riders who challenged the post-GP theory. He first raced on the island in 1976, and his name - like that of Geoff Duke, Bob McIntyre, John Surtees and Mike Hailwood - was inextricably linked to postwar TT racing.

For, shorn of its grand prix status, the TT did not shrivel, as predicted. Certainly, without GP riders it lost something of its internationalism but, instead, it became a vast celebration of British working-class motorcyle sport. Devoid of the hype of Formula One - or even motorcyle GP racing - the Isle of Man TT is a place where, before lapping at 120mph, its stars, like Dunlop, would calculate gear ratios on the back of envelopes as they perched on their vans.

In 1977, Dunlop won his first TT race on a Yamaha. Since then, he never missed the event, except in 1989 when, after a crash at Brands Hatch, he arrived on crutches and was stopped from racing. For the last 18 years, he had been a factory rider for Honda.

Eight years ago, he equalled the record of Hailwood - probably the greatest British motorcycle champion - with 14 TT wins. Last month, he won the Formula One, Lightweight 250cc and Ultra Lightweight 125cc TTs, making a total of 26 TT wins. He was five times TT Formula One world champion, won the Ulster Grand Prix 24 times and, also in Northern Ireland, won 13 North-West 200 races.

Dunlop was born in Ballymoney, County Antrim. His first motorcyle, at the end of the era when British machines dominated world markets, was a BSA. He began racing at the age of 17 at Magaberry on a 192cc Triumph Tiger Cub - which he bought for £50. He initially financed his passion with building and driving jobs.

His motorcyle successes led to an MBE in 1986. In 1996, a CBE followed for his charitable work, which had taken him to Albania, Bosnia and Romania. Last month, he was given the freedom of Ballymoney. He enjoyed it all, he said - travel, distant places, and racing.

Modest and unassuming, Dunlop ran the Railway Inn in Ballymoney. On the Isle of Man, a pub, Joey's Bar, was named in his honour. His brother, Robert, is also a motorcyle racer. He is survived by his wife Linda, three daughters and two sons.

 William Joseph 'Joey' Dunlop, motorcyle racer, born February 25 1952; died July 2 2000

fields.headline: Sir John Balcombe
fields.standfirst: Brilliant judge who brought wisdom to matters of death and divorce
fields.trailText: Brilliant judge who brought wisdom to matters of death and divorce
fields.body:
The lawyer and judge, Sir John Balcombe, who has died aged 74, had a brilliant mind. He maintained an impressive practice at the chancery bar, which was followed by promotion to the high court and the court of appeal, where he won universal respect for his sound judgment and quick appreciation of the issues to be dealt with to ensure that justice was done.

John was the elder son of the owner of a company making gramophones, radios and televisions. After a scholarship to Winchester College, in 1943 he won an exhibition to New College, Oxford, which he took up after four years in the Royal Signals, including tours of duty in India and Egypt.

At New College, he obtained first-class honours in jurisprudence. He had, meanwhile, joined Lincoln's Inn, where he was called to the bar in 1950. He obtained a seat in chambers at 11 New Square, Lincoln's Inn, the head of which was the future law lord, Lord Cross. He steadily acquired a large practice, combining his first-class intellect with considerable skills as an advocate.

In 1964, John's chambers merged with those at 9 Old Square, where Peter Millet, another future law lord, was a member. Mergers of sets of chambers were not common in those days, and the success of the move was very much due to the influence of Balcombe and his experienced clerk.

In the same year, John represented the Earl of Sefton who, in 1945, had sold Aintree racecourse to Mirabel Topham, on condition that it should continue to be used for horseracing. Mrs Topham sold the land to developers, and the action by Lord Sefton resulted in the condition being enforced - so the land remained the home of the Grand National. He also acted for the widow of Dylan Thomas, in an action for possession of the original manuscript of Under Milk Wood, and, after taking silk in 1969, for Alan Klein, the then manager of the Beatles, in an action concerning the break-up of the group.

John was appointed a high court judge in 1977, and, somewhat surprisingly, assigned to the family, rather than the chancery, division. Yet his understanding and sympathetic approach to problems arising from divorce, and its effects on children, rapidly gained the admiration of all those who practised in that field. He was chairman of the Marriage Guidance Council from 1982-88.

His ability to adapt his chancery experience to other fields did not stop with his involvement with family law. When travelling on circuit, it sometimes happened that there were no family cases which needed to be tried by a high court judge. In such event, John always volunteered for other high court work - both civil and criminal. On one such occasion, at Nottingham, he took on a murder case; his conduct of the trial won the admiration of all concerned and, thereafter, he presided over many criminal trials. In 1988, he was promoted to the court of appeal.

Balcombe had many interests outside the law. He was an eminent livery man, and, in 1971-72, was master of the Worshipful Company of Tin Plate Workers. He was proud to be known as a freemason, where he was a distinguished member of the Chancery Bar and Old Wykehamist lodges. He became senior grand warden of the United Grand Lodge of England, and one of the presiding members of the masonic appeals court.

John was the elder son of the owner of a company making gramophones, radios and televisions. He obtained a seat in chambers at 11 New Square, Lincoln's Inn, the head of which was the future law lord, Lord Cross. fields.headline: Mexican revolution
fields.standfirst:
The old guard gets its marching orders

More about the Mexican presidential election
fields.trailText: If it is possible for a nation to surprise itself, then Mexico has managed it. The monolithic Revolutionary Institutional Party, in power and seemingly impregnable for the past 71 years, has finally been overthrown.
fields.body:
If it is possible for a nation to surprise itself, then Mexico has managed it. Shock might be a better word to describe the incredulous reaction of many voters to the news that, after so many false dawns and vain hopes, the monolithic Revolutionary Institutional Party, in power and seemingly impregnable for the past 71 years, has finally been overthrown.

The sheer effrontery of Vicente Fox in sweeping to an unarguably clear-cut victory in the presidential race with Francisco Labastida was compounded by surging advances for his National Action Party in both houses of congress and in separate state governorship contests.

Some in the electorate may feel the need to pinch themselves, given Mexico's long history of stolen and not infrequently violent elections, stretching back to 1940. The notorious 1988 triumph of Carlos Salinas, after a mysterious voting station computer breakdown counted out challenger Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, is still a relatively recent memory.

So, too, is the 1994 Zapatista uprising in Chiapas, a struggle spawned in part by the hopeless injustices and inequities of corrupt one-party rule, and the subsequent assassination of the official presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio. But with President Ernesto Zedillo (constitutionally debarred from running for a second term) conceding defeat on behalf of the PRI only three hours after the booths closed on Sunday, there is, despite these unhappy precedents, no doubting the reality of this national upheaval.

In truth, the PRI's grip has been slowly but surely slipping for some time. In the 1997 mid-term elections it lost control of the lower house, the Mexico City mayoralty, and a string of municipalities. But a series of democratic reforms, overseen and policed by the independent Federal Electoral Institute, have been crucial in allowing this natural process of separation and divorce to run its course.

The introduction of fraud-proof photo-ID cards, accurate electoral registers, campaign fundraising controls, equal access for political parties to the mass media, and election observers have combined with a system of proportional representation to defeat the politics of fear, money, and gerrymandering. For this, perversely, the PRI can take some credit.

As for Mr Fox, his centre-right programme differs little in its fundamentals from that of his predecessors. Right now, that does not signify much. What matters most is that the old guard is out.

webTitle: World class Fossil cliffs and factory towns nominated for heritage list

fields.headline: World class Fossil cliffs and factory towns nominated for heritage list
fields.trailText: Factory towns and sites in England and Scotland, and the spectacular cliffs and headlands of the Dorset and east Devon coastline, were nominated yesterday by the government to join the Pyramids and the Taj Mahal on the register of the world's most precious places, the world heritage sites.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy , arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Factory towns and sites in England and Scotland, and the spectacular cliffs and headlands of the Dorset and east Devon coastline, were nominated yesterday by the government to join the Pyramids and the Taj Mahal on the register of the world's most precious places, the world heritage sites.

The decision is a blow to the tourism and development hopes of other sites, including former iron working areas of Wales, the cathedral cities of Wells and St David's, and Whitby abbey in Yorkshire, which were among dozens of proposals being considered.

There are no specific grants or legal protection for world heritage sites, but inclusion shows outstanding international importance. Governments are expected to produce management plans for them, and to take special care in development issues.

The emphasis on industrial and scientific history in yesterday's nominations reflects the belief by both the government and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (Unesco), which maintains the register, that cultural sites, such as historic towns and cathedrals, are over represented: there are 445 cultural sites, 117 natural sites and 20 mixed sites on the list.

The UK's existing list reflects the same pattern, with only four natural sites out of 17 - the Giant's causeway in Northern Ireland, and three islands, St Kilda, and two tiny colonial outposts, Henderson island in the south Pacific and Gough island in the south Atlantic.

Europe is adding former coal mines, steel works, forests, and an entire huge redundant iron works in Germany to correct the balance.

Yesterday the government nominated the Dorset and east Devon coast, not just for its beauty but for the extraordinary fossil finds in its crumbling cliffs which helped shape the theory of evolution; the Derwent valley, for its pioneering 18th century textile mills which influenced the development of English factories and the entire developing 19th century industrial world; Saltaire, regarded as the finest surviving textile mill village; and New Lanark, another industrial centre expanded until it became internationally renowned as a model community.

The nominations, which the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said represented "the best of our cultural, industrial and natural heritage", will be sent today to Unesco, which has until next January to decide whether to accept them.

 Britain's world heritage sites, and the dates at which they were added, are:

Durham cathedral and castle (1986); Fountains abbey, St Mary's church and Studley royal park (1986); Ironbridge gorge (1986); Stonehenge and Avebury (1986); Blenheim palace (1987); Palace of Westminster, St Margaret's church and Westminster abbey (1987); City of Bath (1987); Hadrian's wall (1987); the Tower of London (1989); Canterbury cathedral (1988); the Gwynedd castles and town walls of Edward I (1986); St Kilda (1986); Giant's causeway (1986); Henderson island (1986); Edinburgh old and new towns (1996); Gough island wildlife reserve (1996); Maritime Greenwich (1996).

webTitle: Class gap in music lessons narrows

fields.headline: Class gap in music lessons narrows
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Working-class children are increasingly as likely as middle-class children to play musical instruments, a study out today reveals.
fields.body:
Working-class children are increasingly as likely as middle-class children to play musical instruments, a study out today reveals.

The associated board of the Royal Schools of Music suggests the government has gone some way towards halting the drop in the number of children playing instruments under the Tories, though it has not yet turned the tide.

The report by the board, which represents the four royal schools, shows the class divide in instrument playing is narrowing. Among children of parents in social classes D and E - semi-skilled and unskilled manual workers, and casual employees - 39% play an instrument, up four points on 1996 figures.

For children in social classes A and B - senior or middle-ranking managers and professionals - the proportion playing an instrument is down from 55% to 47% over the same period.

Overall, the proportion of 5- 14-year-olds playing an instrument remained steady at 41% between 1996 and 1999, after a fall of 4% between 1993 and 1996, which the board estimates meant lost opportunities for 300,000 children.

Richard Morris, chief executive of the associated board, said the 1988 Education Reform Act, which allowed schools to opt out of local authority control, splintered the system of area-wide music centres.

"It was very bad for instrumental music because obviously no individual school can employ its own french horn teacher. It needs to be organised at a level above the individual school - it doesn't work otherwise.

"That is a fundamental reason why instrumental music suffered during the early 1990s. I think the government has recognised that and has tried to do something."

The Department for Education is ploughing £150m into schools music over three years through its centrally allocated standards fund.

"Those measures are showing some signs of having stopped the rot," Mr Morris said, although he warned that too often money from the fund was being used by councils as substitute, rather than additional, money.

"About £40m of central funding was put into music services in 1999 but probably about £25m came out again, so the net benefit is still quite modest."

He urged the government to put in place a centrally organised, permanent system for funding music, which was not prey to the whims of local authority or national lottery funding.

Mr Morris said the impact of the 1988 act would be felt through the generations. The report shows that if children do not start learning music at primary school, they tend not to learn at all.

"The earlier weakness in numbers of players at the primary level is inexorably working up through higher age bands and remains an important warning as to the long-term effects of neglect in this area of education," he says in the introduction to the report, Making Music.

The number of 11- 14-year-olds playing instruments dropped by eight points to 40% in 1996.

The number of adults who can play an instrument dropped "significantly", from 30% to 24%, between 1996 and 1999. Ultimately orchestras had a smaller pool of players to choose from.

"I'm not saying all of them would have become Yehudi Menuhin, but all of them would benefit educationally and some might have become fine players."

Some 37% of boys play an instrument, up 4 points from 1996, and 46% of girls, down two.

fields.headline: Prodigy went missing 'to find space'
fields.standfirst:
Hunt fails to find girl student, 15, as experts question fast-track learning
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A teenage prodigy missing from her Oxford college for 12 days had called her dean to say she was safe and "needed space", it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A teenage prodigy missing from her Oxford college for 12 days had called her dean to say she was safe and "needed space", it emerged yesterday.

Sufiah Yusof, 15, who won a place at Oxford to read maths when she was 13, disappeared shortly after sitting her exams on June 22.

The teenager, who is in the third year of a four-year master's degree at St Hilda's, failed to board a train from Oxford to her family home in Coventry.

Sufiah called the college dean, Laura Newby, the day after going missing, to say she was safe but offered few clues as to her whereabouts.

University sources indicated Sufiah had recently become interested in politics and was known to have attended local meetings of the Socialist Workers' party. One theory is that she may have gone to London with a new friend made at a political meeting.

The teenager's distraught father, Farooq Yusof, yesterday said he was unaware of any problems Sufiah had, and he expressed grave fears that his "inexperienced and naïve" daughter might be in danger.

The 43-year-old father of five, himself a mathematician, said: "We are all desperately worried and feel so helpless."

The 15-year-old, who was educated at home by her Malaysian-born parents, disappeared without money, credit cards or a mobile phone, behaving "totally out of character".

Comforting his wife, Halimahton, 44, a chemist, and their four other children, Mr Yusof described Sufiah as a "conscientious and diligent" girl who rose at 4am each morning to pray.

He said he had worked with the police to pursue many avenues of inquiry, including examining possible friendships Sufiah might have made on the internet, but all had so far proved fruitless.

Elizabeth Llewellyn-Smith , principal of St Hilda's college, described the youngest student in the history of the college as a "pretty normal teenager" who had shown no signs of being under pressure.

She defended the special care arrangements put in place for Sufiah, which had included remaining under family supervision and strict prohibition from parties and bars.

Meanwhile, education experts warned that children like Sufiah attending university at a young age could suffer damaging effects if deprived of the chance to form vital bonds with their peers.

Ken Bore, director of the National Association for Gifted Children, said: "Normally we would not advise such an early entry because the young person's personal maturity is often not developed sufficiently to be able to function effectively with much older people.

He added: "I think it would make them feel isolated and also very unusual. Young people are very sensitive to peer pressure."

Jo Counsell, education consultant for the National Association for Gifted Children, described the experience of being fast tracked at the age of 10 as "very negative".

At 17 she dropped out of the Royal College of Music where she was studying violin because she felt she lacked confidence.

"I was bullied at school and unhappy even though I did well academically," she said. "Looking back it wasn't worth it. It took an awful long time to feel confident in myself."

Valsa Koshy, director of the Able Children's centre at Brunel university, called for further research into the effects of radically accelerated education .

"As a mother and an educationist who has been dealing with this issue for over seven years, my feeling is that without enough evidence we should not be encouraging very radical acceleration for children," she said.

She added that the case of Sufiah Yusof could provide a catalyst for serious debate on the issue.

fields.headline: Politics
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor rounds up the world of politics online
fields.body:
Inst of War and Peace
***
Aimed at: everyone

This Institute of War and Peace Reporting site publishes regular bulletins from reporters around the world; it sets its own political agenda, rather than following the lead of national media, and so is an excellent starting-point for discussions about what is a political issue and how states negotiate and fight with each other.

The Onion
****
Aimed at: older students and teachers

Satire is often the best way of getting pupils interested in the political process. The Onion is probably the web's most popular satirical organ. Among the mockery of small-town US preoccupations are several articles debunking the more ludicrous manifestations of American politics.

Politicians' addresses
****
Aimed at: everyone

MPs always like to hear from their younger constituents. Most have email addresses which are listed here.

10 Downing Street
**
Aimed at: everyone

Treads a fine line between celebrating New Labour's achievements and explaining how Number 10 operates. It includes a "fresh political thought for your day, every day", a quiz, question and answer sessions with ministers, and a guided tour of the building and its previous occupants. Visitors can also contribute to the "If I were Prime Minister" session.

Explore Parliament
*****
Aimed at: everyone

A new site produced by the parliamentary education unit. Games such as Quest (in which pupils have to solve riddles to find the mace) and the Political Puzzle (a jigsaw-type assembly activity) encourage children to explore the rest of the site, and schools can register to take part in an Act of Parliament and debate the contents of a Bill. Some activities are suitable for primary children. Both the Scottish parliament and the Welsh Assembly have their own education sites.

Welcome to Europa
**
Aimed at: everyone

Making European politics exciting may be one of the toughest tasks teachers face. Sadly, while it has improved significantly during the last two years, it is still one of the most impenetrable sites on the web. A-level students may find the Key Issues section of most use. It focuses on the euro, EU enlargement and the World Trade Organisation, while the Institutions page explains the functions of the various European bodies.

Parliament Channel
***
Aimed at: everyone

Broadcasting live streaming coverage when the House is sitting is this site's best feature. It's more likely to be useful for individual research than classwork, but it does define key terms such as Question Time. A limited archive of "special events" include Robin Cook during the Kosovo war, Tony Blair on the Good Friday Agreement and even Sir Geoffrey Howe's resignation.

Political Science
****
Aimed at: everyone

A vast, extremely useful set of regularly updated links, compiled by Keele university lecturer Richard Kimber.

CCTA
***
Aimed at: everyone

Where to find government bodies and the public sector quangos online.

Games such as Quest (in which pupils have to solve riddles to find the mace) and the Political Puzzle (a jigsaw-type assembly activity) encourage children to explore the rest of the site, and schools can register to take part in an Act of Parliament and debate the contents of a Bill. Some activities are suitable for primary children. Both the Scottish parliament and the Welsh Assembly have their own education sites. Welcome to Europa ** Aimed at: everyone Making European politics exciting may be one of the toughest tasks teachers face. Sadly, while it has improved significantly during the last two years, it is still one of the most impenetrable sites on the web. A-level students may find the Key Issues section of most use. It focuses on the euro, EU enlargement and the World Trade Organisation, while the Institutions page explains the functions of the various European bodies. Parliament Channel *** Aimed at: everyone Broadcasting live streaming coverage when the House is sitting is this site's best feature. It's more likely to be useful for individual research than classwork, but it does define key terms such as Question Time. A limited archive of "special events" include Robin Cook during the Kosovo war, Tony Blair on the Good Friday Agreement and even Sir Geoffrey Howe's resignation. Political Science **** Aimed at: everyone A vast, extremely useful set of regularly updated links, compiled by Keele university lecturer Richard Kimber. CCTA *** Aimed at: everyone Where to find government bodies and the public sector quangos online.

fields.headline: Mind that wrapper
fields.standfirst: Our beaches are valuable, so why don't we look after them? Jerome Monahan highlights the dangers of pollution
fields.trailText: Our beaches are valuable, so why don't we look after them? Jerome Monahan highlights the dangers of pollution
fields.body:
One in three of us taking our hols in Britain heads for the beach. Our love of the sand and the surf translates into a business worth about £4.6bn and employing over 500,000 people. But this annual invasion is just one of many factors putting a big strain on our 15,000 kilometre coastline. Our beaches are under pressure.

What can we do?

Easy - take your litter home, scoop your dog's poop and don't start fires in sand dunes. When exploring rock pools, put stones back the way you found them or the creatures that live under them may dry out in the sun.

Are holidaymakers the only people damaging the environment?

No, naturalists are worried about the impact of pleasure-boat anchors on native coral such as sea fans. In estuaries, fishermen digging for bait disturb the breeding sites of sea birds. Dredging for scallops (a kind of shellfish) can also cause serious harm to the sea bed.

Sometimes, councils cleaning beaches for us tourists cause harm. Removing the smelly seaweed that collects at the "strand line" may seem sensible but it affects the sand hoppers that live in the weed and play an essential role in the food chain. Evidence even suggests the weed binds the sand together and protects it from storm erosion. But such problems are tiny compared to the damage done to our shoreline by what we dump in the sea.

How does this waste get there?

Water companies discharge waste into the sea. Fertilisers put on the land by farmers make their way into rivers and flow into the sea. Out at sea, ships dump engine oil and litter. The first is probably the worst.

Among many options for disposing of sewerage, one, sadly, means pumping raw sewage directly into the water from outfall pipes. Eventually, the mess reappears.

The most thorough cleaning involves settling the sewage, filtering it and even releasing minute organisms into it that gobble waste-matter. Organisations such as Surfers Against Sewage are campaigning for waste water to be treated with ultraviolet light which kills any bacteria that might have survived the other processes.

Is human waste dangerous?

Yes, human faeces can carry the micro-organisms behind many infections and diseases. But before you abandon the sea for ever, rest assured that outbreaks of these serious diseases are very rare.

What laws control water purity?

A 1976 directive sets the standards for bathing water across the European Union. In Britain, the Environment Agency monitors the water at resorts during the bathing season and last year 90% of beaches made the grade and were eligible for a Seaside Award from Tidy Britain Group. But the directive is now out of date and some of the tests it requires may be missing dangerous micro-organisms (pathogens) that can survive in seawater for ages - some up to 100 days.

How can sewage affect the sea?

Sewage contains chemicals that feed the microscopic plant life in the sea and sometimes cause it to "bloom" on the sea surface. These blooms can cut off oxygen supplies to deeper water and the creatures living there.

When raw sewage is pumped directly out to sea, the other bits and pieces that we flush down the toilet can return on the tide to pollute our beaches. And this is only a fraction of the litter found on the sand.

Four times a year, the Marine Conservation Society gets volunteers to collect and analyse the rubbish on stretches of beach. In 1999, they found an average of 1,913 items of litter per kilometre they cleaned. Over a third was tourist rubbish and 10% was fishing-related such as off-cuts from nets.

What about beachcombing?

Litter can be fun. Sometimes ships lose their cargoes and beachcombers wait for them to wash up. Keep an eye out for Lego on the beach this summer - it could be part of a shipment of five million pieces that went overboard in 1997 off Lands End.

Surfers Against Sewage
The Marine Conservation Society needs volunteers for its next Beachwatch survey, September 16-17
National Maritime Museum Future of the Sea Gallery Find a checklist for recording interesting beach debris at: www.beachcombers.org. Be warned - the list mentions chemicals, lost military items and even bodies. If you do find anything like these on a beach, leave them alone and call the proper authorities. A Seaside Factpack is available at: www.britishresorts.co.uk.

fields.headline: Rules and regs
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor lays down the law in the virtual world
fields.body:
"Where no law is, there is no transgression" [Romans 4:15], or: "It's not my fault - you never told us we couldn't do that" [All children, regularly]. Don't be ashamed to read your children's email, or check the history menu on their browser to see which sites they have visited. If the home secretary has his way, the government will soon be able to do the same for you, and anyone who works in an office is already liable to be similarly monitored by their employers.

But it would be unfair to blame children for taking up undesirable pursuits if you haven't set ground rules - unless you decide not to impose any at all.

The principal of Summerhill School, Zoe Readhead, allows pupils to regulate their own use of the net. In four years, she says, no one has been disturbed by anything they encountered online. Pupils decide among themselves what sort of activity is suitable for different age groups at certain times of day. Readhead insists students can ask a teacher or older pupil to discuss anything they have seen without stigma or blame.

Summerhill is unique. Many schools understandably fear legal action by parents who are concerned about children's welfare and worried that pupils will misuse expensive resources. Somewhat surprisingly, the education department has not yet produced a standard "acceptable use" policy and suggests schools set their own code of conduct.

Two models have been put forward. One is written by the National Association for Co-ordinators and Teachers of IT and the other by the National Association of Advisors for Computers in Education. Both stress the importance of involving parents in the process and, when they are old enough, also bringing in children to encourage mutual responsibility.

Pupils should be aware, for example, that staff may occasionally read their emails. They should also be able to report a threatening mail and (for secondary pupils) know what kind of sites are banned. Prohibiting pornographic and racist sites is obvious enough, but beware the catch-all term "offensive": it will fail to cover a multitude of sins, including gambling and chatrooms.

Developing a code of conduct could be a subject for citizenship lessons. The rules developed by Yolo County in California, introduce additional ideas - notably balancing the right to freedom of expression with the right to freedom from harassment, even although they discuss US law.

fields.headline: Unchaining education
fields.standfirst: Join the campaign for useless education, says  Francis Beckett
fields.trailText: Join the campaign for useless education, says Francis Beckett
fields.body:
It is a truth universally acknowedged that anything which is sneered at by Her Majesty's chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, must have some pretty fine qualities. So when Woodhead's last annual lecture (what sort of pretentious fellow delivers an annual lecture?) was called Is Lifelong Learning a Utopian Ideal?, there must have been a good many people who looked with new respect at the idea of lifelong learning.

Mr Woodhead's views, unfortunately, are going to matter in further education. "What is lifelong learning realistically going to achieve and against what timetable?" he asked in his lecture. Was there any point in providing education for pensioners? What Woodhead really means is that providing education for pensioners isn't going to rescue the national economy, or prop up the bottom line of any company, so it's pointless.

May I therefore introduce you to the Campaign for Useless Education, or (because everything in education has to have an acronym), CUE? It was founded, as are so many great revolutionary movements, over Sunday lunch chez Beckett. One of our guests was Sir Roy Shaw, who, before his long stint as director general of the Arts Council, was a professor of adult education; and who is now the honorary life-president of CUE.

He told us that the worst thing you could do to education was to link it with employment, and he quoted R.H. Tawney: "The important thing in education is not getting on in life, but letting life get on in you." He complained that lifelong learning is being interpreted as retraining to equip yourself for new career opportunities, and that adult education is increasingly about learning how to use computers, and similar utilitarian skills.

We in CUE know that we are swimming against the prevailing current. This is the age of Education Business Partnerships and Skills Taskforces, when the purpose of education is supposed to be to equip people with the skills that industry and commerce say they need. It's the age when lifelong learning is defined - as a top IBM executive once defined it to me - as meaning: "We become technologically obsolete every five years and need retraining."

It's the age when educational establishments are supposed to forge partnerships with businesses. The school or college brings to the table its buildings, its teachers, its resources, its educational expertise, its enthusiasm. The business brings to the table a superannuated executive, too senior to fire but too tired to be any use, who can sit on committees, and whose hourly rate can be generously estimated and put down as the community contribution of a public spirited company.

The rot, as CUE's honorary life president told us in his inaugural Sunday lecture, set in when the Department of Education and Science was renamed the Department for Education and Employment. Education and employment must now be decoupled. We in CUE have dedicated ourselves to having it renamed the Department of Uneconomic Education, or DUE. Petition forms available on request.

fields.headline: Fighter control
fields.trailText: Fighter control
fields.body:
Bandits at 11 o'clock! I beg your pardon.

I said: Bandits, 11 o'clock. Shame. I don't like Bandits. What's happened to the Wagon Wheels?

Um. I don't remember anything about wagon wheels in the Battle of Britain. The what?

You know. Christopher Plummer, Susannah York... used her gas mask case to carry her lipstick Oh. I'm talking about elevenses. The standard's gone right down if they've started giving us those beastly Bandits.

I'm talking about real bandits. You know, enemy fighters. Good Lord. Whatever for?

I want to work in fighter control. I want to shove those little model planes around that huge table with those croupier stick thingies. I want to speak soothingly to our brave boys up there in their kites. I want to talk David Niven down. Oh dear.

What's up? Well. I don't think we use those stick thingies any more.

Chiz! What do you use? Well, it's much more screen-based these days.

Ugh. That's hardly glamorous. Sorry.

So, what do fighter controllers do? They keep a constant watch on airspace using radar to detect objects. They direct RAF fighter planes to intercept suspect aircraft by giving them details about their direction, speed and height.

But it is still all done in that terribly glam underground ops room when you can hear the clock ticking. Not necessarily. Fighter controllers are now able to fly as mission crew on early warning aircraft.

Whizzo! Yes. There are two types of fighter controller: weapons controller and fighter allocater. Both identify suspect planes and direct RAF aircraft towards them. You can be based in a control room or in the skies in an E-3D aircraft engaging in rapid response missions. In the Navy, fighter controllers primarily guide and control the Navy's Sea Harriers to intercept enemy aircraft.

Sounds frightfully important. It is. In times of war you are the tactical manager for your designated air battle zone as part of the front line.

Yuck! Tactical manager doesn't sound so brill. But what do I need? Well, training begins with an Air Defence Foundation course where speed, reactions and technical abilities are tested. System controllers do an identification and recognition course, and interception controllers do an interception control course. Later training is provided at the Front line unit.

Any entry requirements? You've got to be between 17 and 29. You must have been born in the UK or in a Commonwealth country, or the Republic of Ireland. And you'll need two A levels or three Scottish Highers, plus five GCSEs/SCEs (grade C/3 or higher) including English and maths. Graduate entrants may be offered enhanced promotion and starting pay.

How long are you expected to stay in? There are basically two sorts of commissions: permanent and short. Permanent means staying as an officer until you're 38 or you've done 16 years of service. Short means 12 years.

Tallyho! Quite.

 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

 For further details contact your local Armed Forces Careers Office.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: What should we expect the school to do to help my son to try and move up a set?
fields.body:
My son will be starting year 9 next term and finds he will be in the bottom groups in every subject that "sets". We know he's not brain of Britain but he does try hard. What can we do to support him, and what should we expect the school to do to help him to try and move up a set, at least in the core subjects?

Margaret McGowan is an adviser with the Advisory Centre for Education (ACE).

The first thing I'd advise you to do is to establish whether your son is making good progress according to his ability and age group. At both primary and secondary level, a form of "tracking" will take place, whereby the school can begin to measure the progress that pupils are making as they go through the school. Your son's form tutor should be able to collate this information for you.

The reason for finding this out before you do anything else is that there may be an underlying special educational need that has not yet been noticed. Where a child is quiet and conscientious, and is not obviously "struggling" or being disruptive in some way, it is possible that s/he can be overlooked.

If he has some sort of specific learning difficulty, your son may need specialist help and support to cope with the work being set and move forward with it. The special educational needs coordinator in your son's school would be able to guide you here.

It is also worth speaking to your son's subject teachers. Find out what would be expected of your son to enable him to move up a set. Most teachers/departments have clear entry and exit criteria in such cases.

But remember that once in a higher set your son will have to work at a different level and pace - this may be too demanding for him, and could discourage and demotivate him. You may have to discuss with your son and his teachers whether or not it is better to stay in a "bottom" set, but in fact achieve to a much higher level.

Everyone learns in different ways. Often an interactive method of learning can suit students who find academic work difficult - numerous educational websites can be invaluable if you have computer access.

Investigate what provision your son's school makes for additional help in school time. Many schools run homework clubs and/or subject-specific clubs at lunchtime. These can be an enjoyable way for pupils to learn more about a topic and build confidence.

For many children, there appears to be a "dip" in their learning around year 9, and so your son may be following this pattern. You need to discuss how this might affect your son going into year 10 and GCSE studies with the school, as he may only be entered for certain tiers as a result of his performance in year 9. Effective target-setting that is realistic and achievable could help to focus your son's learning over the next year.

But at the end of the day, if your son is trying his best, and is making good progress according to his abilities, you may simply need to boost his confidence and encourage him to continue the excellent work as he makes the transition into year 9.

 The Advisory Centre for Education's help line is 0207 354 8321.

 The DfEE publishes a booklet called SEN - a guide for parents, which aims to help parents to understand what special needs are, what schools can do to help and how parents can become fully involved in their child's education.

 The DfEE can also provide information on the Study Support initiative, which is intended to improve young people's motivation, self-esteem and help them to become more effective learners through activities outside normal lessons. Its main aim is to raise achievement. You can find out more about how Study Support can help by visiting pupils' websites at: www.dfee.gov.uk/clubclass (primary school pupils) and www.dfee.gov.uk/extratime (secondary school pupils).

Next week's query: Teachers say that children's numeracy and literacy levels drop alarmingly during the long summer break. Without wishing to impose a strict reading and counting regime over the next six weeks, I'd like to know how I can keep up my daughter's interest in books and numbers without creating a rebel at home!

Without wishing to impose a strict reading and counting regime over the next six weeks, I'd like to know how I can keep up my daughter's interest in books and numbers without creating a rebel at home!

fields.headline: Military might
fields.standfirst: Spare army capacity is being turned to good use
fields.trailText: Spare army capacity is being turned to good use
fields.body:
In a rare display of joined-up government last week John Spellar, Minister for the Armed Forces, and Malcolm Wicks, Minister for Lifelong Learning, clutched a gigantic silver spanner together in front of a damaged tracked army vehicle in the middle of a military base in Shropshire.

This fetching tableau, which also included a group of smiling trainee engineering apprentices, was a visual metaphor for an unusual act of collaboration between the two ministries.

With the end of the cold war, the army's civilian repair organisation - ABRO or the Army Base Repair Organisation - has more than halved in size. This has resulted in the organisation needing to train fewer civilian mechanical, electrical and electronic engineers to repair army equipment, such as tanks, guns, radios and bomb disposal equipment.

The ABRO repair facility in Donnington, near Telford, Shropshire, indentured just 18 MoD apprentices last year. And three of ABRO's seven UK repair centres have been operating with spare training capacity.

Two years ago Mr Spellar recognised that this capacity could be used to train additional apprentices who could be employed by industry, which was suffering from widespread, intermediate-level engineering skill shortages. Such an initiative would strengthen the country's reservoir of core engineering skills at relatively lit tle extra cost to the national economy. Mr Spellar managed to persuade the DfEE to pay for the wages of 21 additional apprentices. Fourteen of these recruits are just coming to the end of their first year of training at Donnington, while the other seven are training at two other repair centres.

Last Thursday the ministers visited the repair facility to celebrate the success of the joint venture.

The first year trainees, who are paid a weekly wage of £127, spend one day a week at Telford College of Arts and Technology studying for City and Guilds or BTEC qualifications, and the rest of the week learning skills such as welding and machining in the repair facility workshops.

All the apprentices are security cleared and have to sign the Official Secrets Act. First year apprentices, who are usually 16 or 17 years old, also spend one week on an outward bound course bonding into a team.

Jim Drew, ABRO's chief executive, described MoD craft apprentices as being the envy of the industrial world because they are so well trained. Malcolm Wicks, Minister for Lifelong Learning, said that since the second world war Germany had taken the professional skills training of its young people who did not go to university very seriously. The United Kingdom, he added, needs to get better at intermediate level skills training and this MoD/DFEE departmental collaboration was one way of providing more first-class training. The countries that take skills and training seriously, he added, are the ones that will prosper.

It is hoped that manufacturing companies will agree to sponsor future generations of additional apprentices who will also be able to benefit from using ABRO's world-class facilities and training expertise.

fields.headline: Other people's children
fields.standfirst: Government does nothing to stop "educational eugenics", says  Ross Rospigliosi
fields.trailText: Government does nothing to stop "educational eugenics", says Ross Rospigliosi
fields.body:
In further education, there are many mansions, but at its core is the vocational strand. This, I believe, has been undermined by some of the implementation, and funding, of NVQs.

Two major flaws contribute to the "millennium wobble" in NVQs' ability to inspire good vocational learning.

First is reliability. The National Council for Vocational Qualifications always placed validity above reliability in its priorities. Assessment is of actual performance in the workplace - really lifting real patients, really selling life policies with integrity, really baking croissants. Now, in many other models of teacher assessment, the permanent output of the activity to be graded is what is assessed. In these models, external moderators look at exactly what teachers assessed and decide whether they agree the grades.

But in NVQs, very little of the activity that is being assessed is visible to the external verifier. She has to rely on documentary evidence - a photograph of a muffin, a written and illustrated portfolio. For the actual time taken to weld a nuclear submarine plate, she is reliant on the word of the teacher and the examinee. This has to lead to suspicion of varying standards, and of cheating. And it has so led. Alan Smithers' Dispatches programme reached a wide audience and echoes many employers.

With a brilliant insight into commercial reality, the mandarins have decreed that examiners of NVQ are paid for passing the candidate, but not for failing her. The employer, teaching or training organisation that prepares the candidate gets up to 20% more funding for a success than for a failure. And the judges of success? Employees of organisations whose commercial viability depends on a high pass rate.

A second bleakness in NVQs is the insistence that they be criterion-referenced and not norm-referenced. Norm-referencing means the pass mark is raised or lowered to ensure only a percentage of the population passes. (The CSE Grade 5 or above was what in any year would be achieved by 75% of the population.) It allows standards to drift over time - under this system we would not rejoice in the marvellous improvement in 16-year-olds' maths, proved beyond the doubts of any but sourest cynics, by increasing percentages getting C plus in maths.

What norm-referencing did allow was comparison between subjects. A Tiddlywinks top grade could convincingly be compared with one in divinity, when understood to mean the standard of the ablest 10% in each subject. But take the norm-reference away, and mark what discord follows.

For reasons unfathomable to me, Keith Joseph ruled that norm-referencing was ideologically unsound, and called for criterion-referencing for all. Now the carpenter's NVQ had to be compared with the care-worker's, not by referring to the top mini-percentile, but by trying to dig up some criteria common to the two occupations. Hence the description of the levels common to different occupations: not excelling - being better than others - in the occupation's core learning, but progressing from needing supervision to being, yourself, a supervisor. You have a low-level NVQ in bakery, and want evidence you can produce butterier crumpets? Forget it; get out of those whites; stand at a till; supervise and schedule; be a boss.

So what is government doing to improve things? Not, as yet, redesigning the qualification, except to make it more solemn by removing some of the more side-splitting personnel-speak favoured by begetters of the qualification as is; nor by lowering the achievement percentage of funding as recommended by the Skills Task Force.

No: to ensure that vocational and craft learning maintains its current esteem, its qualifications will be more affected by achievement-based payment to teachers who examine, than are A/AS levels, where there is no incentive to the examiners to pass students since, not being the provider, they are not paid by their results.

A ghostly acronym haunts further education: OPC, Other People's Children, Plato's bronze and iron races, apt for brazen, iron-hearted educational eugenics, while the children of rulers, of the rich, of the opinion formers, guzzle on the gold standard of A/S.

 Ross Rospigliosi is principal of Plymouth College.

fields.headline: Bad language
fields.standfirst: Dick Evans responds to the vile racists who crippled his college
fields.trailText: Dick Evans responds to the vile racists who crippled his college
fields.body:
Any publicity is good publicity, it is said. But when that publicity unleashes a torrent of racist abuse from poison pen writers and the dark side of the internet, then you have to wonder if silent anonymity, like honesty, is not the best policy.

Following the recent, high-profile, publicity in a Sunday broadsheet about Stockport College and its alleged policy on banning certain words, it now seems opportune to put our side of the story forward in a truthful and reflective way.

The college does not have a policy of banning words, or indeed a policy that requires students to sign a contract banning such words. The initial article in the Sunday Telegraph was wrong, and all the subsequent publicity in the media further distorted these allegations. It was not so much a matter of the blind leading the blind, as a paperchase of the Gadarene swine. Our computers even crashed with the torrent of racist abuse sent in our direction.

The college, its staff and students, have learnt a great deal in the past few weeks. One thing is very clear, that this country has a long way to travel on equal opportunities and most certainly the issues associated with language and its use. It is a most complex topic and one, sadly, in which a number of people wish to trivialise and highlight prejudices, particularly towards people from ethnic minorities.

Numerous hate messages were received by the college, many anonymous, which have both upset and unsettled staff. What, no doubt, seemed to the newspapers and mass media an amusing story about the absurdities of PC language, triggered an obscene and frightening backlash somewhere in the depths of the public mind.

People who think there is no problem of racial intolerance in this country, particularly in the area of racism and the use of language, are deluding themselves. This incident indicates a set of worrying and latent attitudes and values towards equal opportunities. This is indeed cause for concern at a time following the Stephen Lawrence case and recent racist murders, as well as accusations of institutional racism in the police force and, indeed, some government departments.

Stockport College, in its own way, has for some time been attempting to tackle, through its equal opportunities policy and associated staff development, the issues around deeply insulting and racist language and its use. The college has nothing to apologise for. Like many other organisations, the college is attempting to make people aware of the discriminatory offence that certain words and expressions can have on individuals or groups in the college and in the community.

It is a complex issue and is not about revisiting the strange world of the 1980s when organisations were alleged to be renaming objects and cities like Manchester to make them gender neutral. No doubt many of the people who read the article remembered those times and imagined Stockport College was still engaging in a political drive to purge the English language of its sexist past.

What is even more disturbing is the number of letters we have had from celebrities and public figures, including former MPs, many of whom never even bothered to check the accuracy of the publicity with the college, but were extremely prompt in writing to the college to offer us their sententious thoughts. I would have thought, in such a difficult and contentious area, such tactics are highly questionable.

Language and its use is important, as it gives others messages about our attitudes to people both as groups and as individuals. It is important that people use language in a manner that supports groups and individuals, rather than treats them in a way which they find offensive. Because of the complexity of this issue, sometimes we are not aware that our language offends other people and this is the whole point of equal opportunities and its associated training.

What Stockport College is attempting to do, along with all other colleges and many other organisations, is to ensure that our language conveys respect for others. Language and how people use it shapes the culture of any organisation and is very much about engendering mutual respect and regard for all people or groups within the organisation and indeed within the wider community. An open and objective debate is long overdue.

 Dick Evans is principal of Stockport College.

fields.headline: We're your real mates
fields.standfirst: How the obsession with access to Oxbridge rattles the newest universities
fields.trailText: How the obsession with access to Oxbridge rattles the newest universities
fields.body:
The fuss about widening access to the more prestigious higher education institutions is sending anxious ripples through the newer universities, which see themselves as a natural destination for further education students.

Chiefs of the former polytechnics are grumbling that politicians and media are overlooking their close ties with colleges in focusing on the numbers of further education students getting into the Russell group of universities.

"We are the natural route for further education students to come through and yet we are completely ignored in this debate," said Geoffrey Copland, vice-chancellor of Westminster university.

"It's as if widening participation doesn't happen, and yet the figures speak for themselves."

According to the latest statistics, a majority of university entrants now came via further education, Dr Copland told the Commons all-party further education group. Trevor Watkins, deputy vice chancellor at the South Bank university told the MPs that the 10 institutions which last year sent it most students were all in the further education sector.

But if the post-1992 universities feel scorched in the fevered heat stoked up several degrees after one schoolgirl's failure to get into Oxford, the further education sector could, ironically, reap benefits.

The Commons Education select committee has suddenly shifted the focus of its current general higher education inquiry onto access, in the wake of the Laura Spence affair. It has summoned the Association of Colleges to present evidence next week on access from further education.

And the Higher Education Funding Council has stumped up money for a recruitment officer to boost the numbers of further education students applying and getting in to Oxford.

Clare Asquith, herself an Oxford graduate who joined as a mature student "in my 40s", took up this post in May. She is based at Mansfield College, which is heading a consortium of seven Oxford colleges pledged to improve access to further education candidates.

So far she has visited principals and staff at a handful of colleges which, in recent years, have entered students for Oxford, but who haven't got many in.

The response from the principals she has visited has been promising, she says. "They are happy to listen to what I've got to say. I show them what I think are the important bits of the prospectuses." For instance, competition for places in medicine and law is particularly stiff at Oxford, as it is at other universities offering these subjects. Laura Spence was applying to read medicine.

In some other subjects, including some which do not specify particular A levels, the ratio of applicants to places gives individuals a statistically better chance of getting in.

She answers principals' questions, which usually include a query about social division.

"I say that I suspect the media image of Oxford is off-putting and that everybody does find people who are like them, and that there are many students from state schools."

The workload at Oxford was heavy but, in her view, the university chose people who would be stimulated by this and were capable of fitting in many other activities.

"I haven't yet talked to students. The idea is that we return to the colleges bringing students from the same further education background to meet them."

Geoffrey Copland said he supported encouraging wider access to Oxford. "But I'm worried that expectations may be raised that won't be met. And I'm concerned about a public perception that there is only a certain number of good universities."

fields.headline: A quiet radical
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley  talks to the former bricklayer who's got the job of inspecting the nation's colleges
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley talks to the former bricklayer who's got the job of inspecting the nation's colleges
fields.body:
The new man in charge of England's post-16 education and training inspections does not intend to begin his regime with a seismic bang in the way that his boss, Chris Woodhead, did with the nation's schools.

When the latter took over responsibility for inspecting schools, you may recall, he alleged on BBC TV's Panorama that some 15,000 school teachers were incompetent.

Given that the proportion of lessons in further education deemed to be poor or very poor is around 6%, Stephen Grix, the new 44-year-old head of Ofsted's Post-compulsory Education Division, says such wholesale naming and shaming is unlikely.

The sometime bricklayer who left school at 15 with no qualifications, but became a lecturer in bricklaying by the age of 21, is passionate about the second-chance opportunities that colleges offer to those who missed out at school.

He himself went on to acquire a BEd, MSc and PGCE by day-release and full-time study, while rising quickly through the further education college ranks. His last role was principal of Sir George Monoux Sixth Form College in Walthamstow.

Although Mr Grix may not be planning a revolution in the inspection regime from April next year, he does intend to make some radical changes.

The Ofsted, Training Standards Council and Further Education Funding Council Common Inspection Framework, published in April for informal consultation, set out the general principles designed to guide future inspections of all college and work-based training. Mr Grix says that some 96% of responses from the sector agree with the key principles enshrined in this framework.

The main difference in the proposed regime, however, is that there will be much more emphasis on examining teaching and learning, and less on looking at cross-college themes such as quality assurance and equal opportunities. In future, cross-college themes will be examined via specific curriculum areas and by their effect on learners.

A second key change, Mr Grix said, is that the rationale behind college inspections has changed. In the last round of Further Education Funding Council inspections, the emphasis was on validating colleges' own self-assessments.

"We are now saying that self-assessment is still important, but it is not the sole purpose of inspection. It's about giving an independent public account of the quality of provision in a college as the basis for bringing about improvement, and to inform the Secretary of State about what is happening."

A third change, subject to the terms of the comprehensive spending review, will be to increase the number of days inspectors spend on-site during college inspections. In the last round of funding council inspections it averaged 55 days, whereas in the first round of inspections it was nearer 80 days.

At the moment the funding council inspects the curriculum by examining 10 programmes of activity. However, thought is now being given to whether categories such as leisure and tourism should be further subdivided, in order to make differentiated judgements about more segmented areas of activity.

In future Ofsted may decide to publish four-page summary inspections instead of detailed reports, while posting an extended inspection report on the internet.

College inspections will be conducted by joint Ofsted and Adult Learning Inspectorate teams under the leadership of Ofsted unless 90% or more of the work to be inspected is adult provision. The balance of the inspection teams will be shaped by the nature of the institution, for example, if it is a sixth-form college, the team will consist primarily of Ofsted HMIs.

The practice of including a college nominee in the inspection teams, to allow them to test emerging conclusions and hypotheses, will continue. However, in future the internal nominee may no longer be present at the final grading meeting.

Ofsted is not planning to contract out inspections to independent teams, but will use in-house HMIs augmented by part-timers. The number of HMIs responsible for 16 to 19 inspections will also be increased significantly.

Mr Grix added that Ofsted is also considering how to prevent some of the spectacular college failures of recent years, such as those at Bilston and Halton colleges. Earlier intervention by Ofsted inspectors might be facilitated by shorter lead times for inspections. At present, colleges have between a year and 18 months' notice of inspections, whereas schools get 6 to 10 weeks' notice.

It is somewhat paradoxical, Mr Grix said, that the further education sector is arguably the most audited sector ever, yet, despite this, there had still been several spectacular college failures.

While being keen to reduce some of the bureaucracy involved in ensuring compliance in management and governance issues, he says that in future the responsibility for compliance should lie primarily with the local Learning and Skills Councils. The 47 local councils will also assume responsibility for ensuring continuous quality improvement. Hitherto this has been a funding council responsibility.

Mr Grix said that it will be up to Ofsted to comment on the quality of corporate governance, for example, the extent to which governors have a clear view on setting targets for learners and are not just concerned with things such as whether they have got adequate standing orders or have signed up to the Nolan principles.

Sometimes the reasons why governors are unable to recognise weak college management is that they are out of touch with what is happening in the college. Some colleges have chosen not to have staff members on the college governing body, others do not have student representatives. In some instances governors deal simply with senior managers, who feed them a particular line about how an institution is doing.

As far as grading colleges is concerned, Mr Grix said that sometimes so much attention is given to grades that other key inspection messages are not picked up.

When Ofsted inspects schools, it tells the institutions what grades it has awarded, but does not publish them. It just publishes a list of strengths and weaknesses. Mr Grix is wondering whether the grades awarded for areas of activity post-16 should not in future be published, but just be shared privately with the institutions.

After some changes, the common inspection framework will go out for a second, formal consultation period towards the end of the summer once a Chief Inspector of Adult Learning has been appointed.
fields.bodyText: The new man in charge of England's post-16 education and training inspections does not intend to begin his regime with a seismic bang in the way that his boss, Chris Woodhead, did with the nation's schools. When the latter took over responsibility for inspecting schools, you may recall, he alleged on BBC TV's Panorama that some 15,000 school teachers were incompetent. Given that the proportion of lessons in further education deemed to be poor or very poor is around 6%, Stephen Grix, the new 44-year-old head of Ofsted's Post-compulsory Education Division, says such wholesale naming and shaming is unlikely. The sometime bricklayer who left school at 15 with no qualifications, but became a lecturer in bricklaying by the age of 21, is passionate about the second-chance opportunities that colleges offer to those who missed out at school. He himself went on to acquire a BEd, MSc and PGCE by day-release and full-time study, while rising quickly through the further education college ranks. His last role was principal of Sir George Monoux Sixth Form College in Walthamstow. Although Mr Grix may not be planning a revolution in the inspection regime from April next year, he does intend to make some radical changes. The Ofsted, Training Standards Council and Further Education Funding Council Common Inspection Framework, published in April for informal consultation, set out the general principles designed to guide future inspections of all college and work-based training. Mr Grix says that some 96% of responses from the sector agree with the key principles enshrined in this framework. The main difference in the proposed regime, however, is that there will be much more emphasis on examining teaching and learning, and less on looking at cross-college themes such as quality assurance and equal opportunities. In future, cross-college themes will be examined via specific curriculum areas and by their effect on learners. A second key change, Mr Grix said, is that the rationale behind college inspections has changed. In the last round of Further Education Funding Council inspections, the emphasis was on validating colleges' own self-assessments. "We are now saying that self-assessment is still important, but it is not the sole purpose of inspection. It's about giving an independent public account of the quality of provision in a college as the basis for bringing about improvement, and to inform the Secretary of State about what is happening." A third change, subject to the terms of the comprehensive spending review, will be to increase the number of days inspectors spend on-site during college inspections. In the last round of funding council inspections it averaged 55 days, whereas in the first round of inspections it was nearer 80 days. At the moment the funding council inspects the curriculum by examining 10 programmes of activity. However, thought is now being given to whether categories such as leisure and tourism should be further subdivided, in order to make differentiated judgements about more segmented areas of activity. In future Ofsted may decide to publish four-page summary inspections instead of detailed reports, while posting an extended inspection report on the internet. College inspections will be conducted by joint Ofsted and Adult Learning Inspectorate teams under the leadership of Ofsted unless 90% or more of the work to be inspected is adult provision. The balance of the inspection teams will be shaped by the nature of the institution, for example, if it is a sixth-form college, the team will consist primarily of Ofsted HMIs. The practice of including a college nominee in the inspection teams, to allow them to test emerging conclusions and hypotheses, will continue. However, in future the internal nominee may no longer be present at the final grading meeting. Ofsted is not planning to contract out inspections to independent teams, but will use in-house HMIs augmented by part-timers. The number of HMIs responsible for 16 to 19 inspections will also be increased significantly. Mr Grix added that Ofsted is also considering how to prevent some of the spectacular college failures of recent years, such as those at Bilston and Halton colleges. Earlier intervention by Ofsted inspectors might be facilitated by shorter lead times for inspections. At present, colleges have between a year and 18 months' notice of inspections, whereas schools get 6 to 10 weeks' notice. It is somewhat paradoxical, Mr Grix said, that the further education sector is arguably the most audited sector ever, yet, despite this, there had still been several spectacular college failures.
