fields.headline: Inscrutable East
fields.standfirst: A typhoon is blowing Asiaweek's attempt to rank universities off course
fields.trailText: A typhoon is blowing Asiaweek's attempt to rank universities off course
fields.body:
When the idea of an annual British-style league table for Asia-Pacific universities was suggested by Asiaweek magazine, the sceptics said it would never last. The region, which has more than half the world's population, was too large and diffuse, they said - and it just isn't the Asian way for national institutions to be compared in such an explicit fashion.

Three years on, it would seem the critics might have been right. The latest survey of the "best" universities in Asia, published in the June 30 issue of the Hong Kong-based magazine, is almost as notable for its missing institutions - in some cases entire countries and territories - as for its top place-getters.

Japan's Kyoto and Tohoku Universities again took the first and second spots among the 77 "multidisciplinary" institutions surveyed, although in reverse order from last year. Other institutions in that leading group were in Australia, Hong Kong and Singapore. Among 39 science-and-technology institutions, which the magazine rates separately, South Korea's elite Advanced Institute of Science and Technology retained its top ranking.

Faring considerably less well than in previous surveys, at least among participating institutions from the 14 countries surveyed, were national universities in Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines, where the magazine found that only about a quarter of each institution's full-time teachers and researchers have PhDs. With the exception of the University of Auckland, the country's largest, New Zealand's universities continued to rate poorly, in some cases worse than countries receiving foreign aid from the New Zealand government.

As with similar surveys published by the Financial Times, US News and World Report and Macleans magazine in Canada, Asiaweek's immodest aim is to measure the academic excellence of institutions by quantifying their achievements. Or, as Cesar Bacani, the survey's editor, explained in a recent interview at his Hong Kong office, "objectifying the myths".

"In Asia, unfortunately, it's often been the way that a university will claim to be the best university in a country or in all of Asia, and its basis for saying that is because they say that always been the case. Nothing else! You just have to take their word for it. But we feel that could be shortchanging the consumers."

Working with four assistants and the magazine's correspondents, Bacani now spends much of each year concentrating on the survey, along with another separate survey, published in May, of top MBA schools.

Results are based on a number of familiar categories: academic reputation; selection criteria; faculty resources; research output; financial ratio of students to academic staff members; graduate students; citations in international journals; and Internet bandwidth.

Once again, however, Japan's most prestigious institution of higher-learning, the venerable University of Tokyo, ranked top in the first two surveys, led the swelling group of institutions that did not return any of Bacani's telephone calls this year. Tokyo's president, Hasumi Shigehiko, has said that education and research at his institution "cannot be compared with that of other universities... Such characteristics are profoundly individual and extremely difficult to quantify."

With only two exceptions, Taiwanese universities pulled out en masse, leaving the magazine to take the unusual step of ranking the island's higher education on the basis of information supplied to it in previous surveys. In a letter on behalf of Taiwan's Association of National Universities and Colleges, Wei-Jao Chen said that while the rankings "are truly a valuable and trustworthy research done with profound investigation and solid critical analysis", local academics and universities shared the "general conviction that we are entitled to develop individually and autonomously according to our different historical backgrounds".

Citing similar reservations - while remaining leery of being judged alongside "national" institutions in Taiwan - most top mainland Chinese institutions opted out of the latest survey. Also joining the holdouts were some major Pakistani universities, as well as institutions in Thailand, India, Macau and half those in New Zealand.

Ian Smith, a deputy vice-chancellor at New Zealand's University of Otago (No 41), one of the four local institutions that did participate, has since called the data on which Asiaweek based its survey "simply unbelievable", "crazy" and "frankly bizarre". (The magazine intends to publish the full data on its website later in July.) Smith's institution, and two of the others participating from New Zealand, have said it will reevaluate its commitment to the next survey.

Even universities which have consistently fared well in the survey, such as those in Singapore, have criticised the methodology and the way universities are shown abruptly falling or rising, as if they were pop singles.

Before this year's results appeared, Hang Chang Chieh, a former deputy vice-chancellor at the National University of Singapore, said the magazine might do better to conduct its surveys and compile its rankings less often, perhaps "once every five years". Although not visibly concerned about possible rejection by the antipodeans, Bacani is disappointed at the snubs from universities closer to home, particularly in Japan. He thinks the institutional reluctance increasingly being encountered ultimately underscores the importance of his magazine's work.

"We do not present ourselves as experts, but we do present ourselves as consumers who, like anybody else, want and demand to know the quality of a very important product. If there were another body, an expert body, doing this for consumers in Asia then Asiaweek wouldn't be doing it. But there is no other body. Not one. It's sad."

fields.headline: Sweat and tears
fields.standfirst: A vast protest movement is sweeping US campuses. Its aim? To end the use of sweatshops to produce college-endorsed clothes
fields.trailText: A vast protest movement is sweeping US campuses. Its aim? To end the use of sweatshops to produce college-endorsed clothes
fields.body:
It's being dubbed the biggest act of American student unrest since the anti-Vietnam protests of the 1960s. In colleges and universities across the United States, students are protesting about the sweatshop factory conditions which they claim are commonplace in the production of American university-endorsed clothing and sportswear.

These factories are found throughout the debt-laden Third World in countries such as Guatemala, Nicaragua and Bangladesh. With over 220 college and university student groups now members of the newly formed umbrella organisation which is coordinating the national campaign, United Students Against Sweatshops, the sweatshop issue is now recognised as the single biggest and fastest growing campaign within American universities. This year alone university and college students have led 16 separate sits-ins of university buildings.

There is nothing in the UK university system comparable to the American practice of clothing and sports manufacturers providing lucrative sponsorship deals to universities and colleges, something which American campaigners cite as one of the main reasons for the campaign's success.

"Students have a more direct relation to sweatshop issues than they do to many other social justice and environmental issues," explains Andrew Cornell, a recent graduate from the University of Michigan and student sweatshop activist. "By buying clothing and shoes from companies that use sweatshops, students are supporting those companies. People are often more willing to get involved in a campaign that they are tied to personally."

Molly McGrath from the University of Wisconsin sweatshop campaign believes that it is the simplicity of the campaign that has lead to its popularity.

"A lot of the students involved in the campaign are generally like me, white kids who've never been involved in political or social justice activity before, but who recognise that our clothes shouldn't be made by people who are treated like slaves - it's an easy thing to understand."

Despite being dominated by a number of big name corporate players such as Nike and Reebok, the students make it clear that they are not interested in calling for a boycott of any one company.

"This is an industry-wide problem and is not specific to a handful of companies, which is why this campaign doesn't call for a boycott," explains Suzanne Webb from the University of Kentucky sweatshop campaign. "A boycott would only hurt the very people that we are working with."

Instead, the sweatshop campaign is now focusing on two key demands: that universities withdraw their membership of the industry-backed Fair Labor Association and instead sign up with the Workers Rights Consortium, a body made up of students, university officials and labour and human rights campaigners.

The reluctance of universities to agree to the these demands has led to a number of student occupations of university administration buildings such as the sit-in at the University of Kentucky this April which ended with police arresting students amid protests of heavy-handed tactics on the part of the university and police.

"Towards the end of the sit-in, people were getting shoved to the ground and grabbed by the neck by the police," says Amy Shelton, who was involved in the protest. "The police tried to herd the crowd of protesters over the top of people that had already fallen down. One student was hospitalised for a neck injury when she was assaulted by a police officer."

The response from industry has been similarly dramatic. This spring, Nike, the market-leader of the sportswear industry, announced that it was to cancel millions of dollars' worth of sponsorship from three US universities. The decision followed the announcement from the Universities of Oregon, Michigan and Brown University that they were to accept the student demands and become members of the WRC.

This move was just the latest in a series of successes for the sweatshop campaign. Apart from placing the issue firmly on the national corporate agenda, the campaign has forced sportswear giants such as Nike to retreat from their previously held position of never revealing the locations of their factories, to publicly listing all the factories that make clothes for five large American universities.

Nike has since gone on the PR offensive, with the Nike boss Phil Knight personally intervening in the damage-limitation exercise, claiming that: "We are very, very serious about providing good factory working conditions and continuously improve the working experience for all 500,000 people who make Nike products. We are committed to having the best monitoring and remediation process possible and to be open."

"These claims are baseless," replies Andrew Cornell. "Independent monitoring groups find shocking violations of working conditions every time they investigate clothing factories." In response to the Nike swipe that the full-time student campaigners are only interested in protecting their own jobs and embellishing their CVs, Cornell replies: "It's just ridiculous. One only needs to look at the salaries that non-profit organisations can afford to pay in order to see that we would be in business school sucking up to Nike recruiters if we were in it for the money."

Despite these apparent successes, Angela Hale from the UK based anti-sweatshop campaign Women Working Worldwide is sceptical about the overall impact of the student campaign. "American campaigners might shout louder than campaigners here in Europe, but whether this means that there's been any change to workers' lives is another matter. What happens in American campuses is not going to change working conditions of people in Thailand. That is going to happen through workers' organisations over there."

However, Hale concedes that the students have played an important role in the debate on sweatshops: "Raising people's awareness is important to make sure people know what's going on. Workers in the South can gain enormous strength and confidence and extra resources through knowing that student actions are taking place across America."

And for students like Andrew Cornell, letting the public know about the sweatshop issue is still their number one priority. "Once people find out about the atrocities committed in the factories where household brand-name clothes are made," says Cornell, "there is nothing no one can do to hold back the resentment towards these 'brand bullies'."

fields.headline: A-level agonies
fields.standfirst: A five-term school year offering places based on real, not predicted grades, may not be far away.  Lee Elliot Major  reports on some serious reforms
fields.trailText: A five-term school year offering places based on real, not predicted grades, may not be far away. Lee Elliot Major reports on some serious reforms
fields.body:
Moves to reform the university admissions system are expected to gather momentum this month when a review recommends the end of the traditional school year.

Proposals to finally replace the long holidays at Christmas, Easter and summer - originally designed to fit into the cycle of harvests and religious holidays - with more frequent breaks between five shorter terms could pave the way for an academic admissions system where students are judged on their A-level grades rather than their predicted scores.

It comes amid a raft of new studies investigating fairer ways to assess the academic potential of students, from US-style intelligence tests to the job-selection techniques employed by occupational psychologists. Already one university plans to introduce science reasoning tasks as part of its selection of medical students, after new research showed that A-level grades are often a poor reflection of students' true abilities.

To boost the numbers of students from state schools and poor backgrounds entering its medical school, admissions tutors at King's College, London plan to set practical tasks for students applying for courses starting next year. During the same day tutors will assess non-academic characteristics of applicants such as motivation, expectations and personality traits.

Last month, Sutton Trust head Peter Lampl reiterated his calls for a post qualification applications system for universities which, he believes, would help encourage more working-class pupils to apply to top universities. Lampl told MPs on the House of Commons education and employment committee about evidence suggesting that even with high, predicted grades, students from state schools are less confident about their prospects than those from private schools.

The move towards an admissions system based on actual, not predicted, A-level grades has long been discussed. But last spring negotiations reached an impasse when both university and school sectors refused to change their academic calendars. Most students make applications to universities some eight months before they know their exam results. And every year about 50,000 students, whose grades do not match university offers, enter a frenetic clearing process to apply for the remaining vacancies.

All this could change, though, when a commission by the Local Government Association on the school year concludes at the end of the month. It is widely expected to back calls for the school year to be split into five shorter terms and to get rid of the long summer break, organised in medieval times for children to help with annual harvesting work. Under the new school system, students would take A levels in the fourth term of the year, and receive results in July rather than August.

The universities and colleges admissions service (UCAS) says it has the computing know-how to introduce a fast track system for student admissions - with students applying electronically on the basis of their grades for courses beginning in October.

UCAS has also given the green light to new arrangements preventing admissions officers from seeing applicants' other university choices - so-called "blind decision-making".

But the use of A levels as the single gold standard for gauging academic abilities is also set to come under renewed attack. Research at King's College London shows that A-level grades often bear little resemblance to the abilities as measured by continuous assessment.

There are three main reasons for this: A-level candidates have good and bad days; markers have different opinions; and A-level questions change each year, benefiting some students and hindering others. A simulation of the results of students compared to their "true" grades - the average score over repeated examinations - reveals that half of candidates with the highest, simulated grades are in fact awarded grades that under-represent their achievement. But by the same token, some students gain an advantage by the unreliability of A-levels, receiving higher grades than they deserve.

The researchers conclude that reducing the grades required from those students with disadvantaged backgrounds could backfire, allowing in students whose real achievements are well below the level that is needed on the medical degree course. So instead, the medical school plans to introduce an alternative and more accurate selection system for students applying next year: scientific reasoning tasks set for groups of applicants, and lasting about 50 minutes. The tasks will allow tutors to gauge the ability of students to learn and reason as this takes place.

Meanwhile, the representation of university admission statistics last month by the Sutton Trust, suggesting that selection based on A-level results is prejudiced against candidates from poor families and state comprehensives, has prompted several studies into US-style intelligence tests to measure 16- to 17-year-olds' aptitude for university.

Apart from the Trust's own feasibility study, researchers at University College, London, are now investigating the use of scholastic aptitude tests (SAT) used by the top American universities to assess candidates' academic potential. The Qualification Curriculum Authority has also expressed interest in the tests.

The Committee of Vice-chancellors and Principals, meanwhile, is sponsoring a study into whether job analysis techniques employed by occupational psychologists can be used to identify the characteristics of "good students" by university admission tutors. It will also consider how universities adapt to the new broad A-level syllabus in schools, unveiled formally by the government last week.

The upshot of all this work is likely to be an admissions system more akin to the US model (see below) where tutors use a range of selection procedures. But Lampl, among others, warns that the US system should not be seen as the promised land.

Would academic tutors in the UK, for example, feel happy about giving applicants higher marks simply because one of their relatives had been at the university previously? And would they take kindly to a semi-quota system, which gives high priority to valedictorians - those ranked first in their school? Even chancellor Gordon Brown might resist such moves.

USA

Students apply direct to colleges (universities). Many colleges require two or three letters of recommendation from high school teachers, and a personal essay from the student. All colleges ask for records from the school of the student's academic achievement - and most colleges also want SAT scores.

Interviews are rare. Ivy League colleges and Liberal Arts colleges usually use committees to rate applicants on both academic and personal characteristics. Weaker grades can be discounted by impressive personal attributes, extra-curricular activities, etc. "Distinctions" are assigned, if the student comes from either an ethnic or geographic minority or if a sibling went to the college.

France

Students apply to a regional educational authority. Anyone passing the Baccalauréat is guaranteed a place at a local university. Institutions generally offer all courses and do not specialise. Students applying to the specialist, elite grandes écoles go to "preparation" colleges for two years first. Students apply to a central body, the Central Applications Office, similar to UCAS. Through it they can apply to any course at any Irish institution. Applications are made to a central body, the Universities Admissions Centre, and accepted on the basis of Higher Schools Certificate results. Students will also have to achieve the necessary SAT grades, a test based on the US model, and will also gain an advantage by demonstrating "co-curricular activities" - such as sports, the arts and community service. fields.headline: Small can be beautiful
fields.trailText: After years of turning cartwheels to encourage parents to come in their droves to our governors' annual meeting for parents, I have seen the light.
fields.body:
After years of turning cartwheels to encourage parents to come in their droves to our governors' annual meeting for parents, I have seen the light. It is quality, not quantity, that counts. In this case small really can be beautiful.

We had our meeting this week. We had eight parents, 13 governors and two non-governor members of staff. The discussion was lively and informative for all three groups. We joked, laughed and discussed fundamental educational issues. Every parent joined in - though some were more reticent than others.

It was not just a question and answer session but a discussion between equals. We ranged from the education of the whole child and the problems of a narrowing curriculum to the difficulty in recruiting quality staff, then on to the impact of information technology and the schools of the future. We talked of tracking pupils' progress through national curriculum levels. We touched on the skills these children will need when they leave school in 2013.

We do have other ways of finding out the views of the majority of parents. We had a good response to the parental survey, which formed part of the process of formulating the home/school agreement. They told us that the school had a lot to celebrate but that we still got things wrong occasionally. They were positive in their praise and still positive in their criticism. They pointed out things to us that were peripheral to governors and staff but of central importance to some parents and children. We have implemented many of their suggestions for improvement.

The last question at our meeting came from one of the governors, who asked the parents, "why did you come?" Their answer was twofold: to find out things they otherwise wouldn't, and to show commitment to the school.

I'm now ambivalent about them spreading the news that it was a useful meeting. What if hundreds turn up and spoil it? Somehow, I don't think I need to lose any sleep over it.

 Jane Phillips is a governor of two schools and vice chair of the National Association of Governors and Managers.

fields.headline: Acting up a storm
fields.standfirst: Drama has proved a turning point for disaffected pupils in Coventry
fields.trailText: Drama has proved a turning point for disaffected pupils in Coventry
fields.body:
Phillip Holland, 16, introduces himself as Phill. "That's Phill with two ls," he stresses. Obviously a lad who can already see his name up in lights. Maybe in the West End. Or maybe in his local theatre, the Belgrade in Coventry, where he has spent half a day of his school week for the past two years and much more of his spare time.

Phill is one of 48 year 10 and 11 pupils in Coventry who have been taking part in a course called Acting Out, designed for those who are disaffected with conventional schooling. It's one of 20 work-related projects nationwide funded by the Department for Education and Employment, but the only one attached to a professional repertory theatre.

Acting Out didn't get off to a good start. Indeed, it could have been christened Opting Out. That's exactly what 12 pupils and the first coordinator did after the first term. Enter, stage left, Georgina Egan, a dynamic Coventry woman of 32 returning to her home city after eight years working with young offenders in Ireland. "She picked it up at a difficult stage and pulled it together through sheer force of personality," says the Belgrade's artistic director, Bob Eaton. But what do the children actually do?

"They learn what it's like to be a group of performers and the team-building skills that involves," says Egan. "They're shown how to improvise and project their voices. It does wonders for their confidence and self-esteem. You wouldn't believe the difference between the first production and the second. They all work with a director to devise and produce a show to performance level."

It's fair to say that their productions have made an impression. Not least on Gerry Robinson, chairman of the Arts Council of England. At a recent press conference in London, he pledged himself to argue for increased funding for English regional producing theatres. Asked what had inspired his decision, he cited the work he had seen on a visit to the Belgrade and the Acting Out project in particular. So could it be that disaffected youth might have contributed to a much-needed financial lifeline for our hard-pressed provincial theatres?

Bob Eaton would like to think so. He was equally impressed when he called in to a local primary school to watch Ant Farm, a show which some of these youngsters had created and were now performing for seven- to 11-year-olds. "The air of discipline and commitment, the sense of excitement, pride and satisfaction with which they went about it was staggering," he recalls. "On that same day, an HM inspector was also at the school. It was evident to me that he too could hardly believe what he was witnessing."

After all, these children have not been meeting their potential at school. Indeed, that's why they're taking part in the project in the first place. Some have severe or moderate learning difficulties. Some have emotional or behavioural problems. Some, like Phill Holland, just don't seem to get on with the demands of the national curriculum. "I was doing the minimum level of work," he admits, "because I didn't want to be there.

"But I'd be letting the others down if I tried to do that in the theatre." Not that he'd want to. If the enthusiasm he has shown at the Belgrade could have been applied to his GCSE work, an evidently intelligent lad like him could be looking forward to some outstanding results in August. "Things bore me if I don't enjoy them," he shrugs.

He seems unconcerned, having already attained a first diploma in performing arts through Acting Out. That, in turn, has secured him a place on a BTec course in the same subject at a local further education college.

Linda Hirons, head of drama at Barr's Hill School where he is a pupil, is understandably disappointed that his on-stage talents couldn't be harnessed at GCSE level. But she remains upbeat about the benefits of the Belgrade project. "Overall," she says, "I feel that pupils who have stuck with it have gained a lot in terms of self-esteem and ability to work as a team."

Education department funding of £40,000 a year for the past two years will be considerably reduced after this summer. From the beginning of next term, schools will be expected to contribute to the tune of £200 per pupil.

"Budgets are tight," says Gareth Davies, deputy head at Bishop Ullathorne, "but I would support it. We've put two pupils through Acting Out. One has really taken off and the confidence it has given her has fed into her school work. The other's performance has been more patchy because of ongoing problems at home. Mind you, Acting Out has given him a huge amount of increased self-esteem and in drama he's been a real star, despite missing one lesson a week."

So pleased are the Belgrade with the talent they've unearthed that three performances of "Tap and Unwrap" by the Acting Out project have been scheduled in this summer's Arts Alive festival, alongside some of the top travelling acts from all over Europe. Scripted by freelance director Kathy Joyce, the play was devised by the pupils themselves. Turbulent teenage emotions and family relationships feature prominently. Phill Holland plays a domineering father who is trying to persuade his suicidal daughter to knuckle down to maths and science. At one point he thunders: "What good has art and drama done anyone?"

A rhetorical question, in the circumstances.

 Tap and Unwrap by the Acting Out project will be staged at the Belgrade's Arts Alive Studio from July 6-8. Box Office: 02476 553055.

webTitle: In search of the golden snitch

fields.headline: In search of the golden snitch
fields.standfirst: Quidditch is grounded as the game made famous by Harry Potter comes to a school in Powys
fields.trailText: Quidditch is grounded as the game made famous by Harry Potter comes to a school in Powys
fields.body:
Forget Euro 2000, Wimbledon and the Olympics - Quidditch is the sport to watch, as played at the Hogwarts school of witchcraft and wizardry.

If this isn't making any sense so far, then you're obviously not counting the days and making final preparations to queue up outside your local bookshop to try and secure a copy of the latest in the phenomenally popular Harry Potter series, written by JK Rowlings.

According to one of the many websites on the subject, rumour has it that the fourth book in the series, published on Saturday, will feature the Quidditch world cup final between Bulgaria and Ireland. Whether or not pupils from Newtown High School in Powys will represent Wales in future tournaments remains to be seen, but they kicked off their bid yesterday.

For anyone who isn't familiar with the books, suffice it to say that Harry Potter has not had a conventional life to date. Before he even reached the age of one, Lord Voldemort, who had planned to take over the world, had attacked him. Both his parents were killed in the battle against the "Dark Lord".

Harry discovered at the age of 11 that he was a wizard and started at Hogwarts. Here Harry has already encountered many threats to his life, detailed in books one to three, but one place that Harry does battle with his arch-rivals is on the Quidditch field.

Elaine Currie, head of drama at Newtown, explains that she started to harness the popularity of the Harry Potter books as a speaking and listening exercise in English lessons. But then she wondered if she could rewrite the Quidditch game to enable pupils to physically play the game on the school field. Paul Walby, a colleague in the physical education department, was asked to help make sure that this could actually work. To ensure competitors can take part fully, they also have to read the books.

In the books, Quidditch is played riding on a broomstick. As yet, Currie has not managed to replicate this small detail, but otherwise the rules are basically the same. A "quaffle" is used for scoring. This is a type of ball that is thrown through one of the goalposts in order to gain 10 points. Instead of the 50ft high goalposts of the original game, one team member - called the "hooper" - uses two large hoops and moves around in the goal area to try to prevent goals being scored.

Each team also has a "seeker" who tries to look for the opposing team's "golden snitch". The golden snitch is the most important ball in the game, and in the Newtown version is hidden in one of 10 locations on the pitch. To find the snitch, the seeker has to ask questions of the opposing team, who can only answer "yes", "no" or "irrelevant".

If the golden snitch is found, this is the end of the game, and the successful team scores 150 points. If the golden snitch is not found, then the match is played for 10 minutes each way and goal scores recorded to discover the winner of the match.

The tournament began yesterday, with 70 children in years 8 and 9 and a staff team, who will compete on the final day, July 20. The pupils have been busy practising their techniques at lunch times, as well as designing and making fantasy costumes befitting their temporary status as witches and wizards.

Currie has also been busy trying to persuade her colleagues to adopt a character from the books. "They quite often sidle up to me in the staff room and say, 'Oh all right then, give me a copy of the book' !" Currie laughs.

The tournament provides the perfect opportunity for staff and pupils to participate together as players and spectators in something that is essentially all about having fun. And if this should also encourage even more youngsters to spend their leisure time with their nose stuck in a good book, well, so much the better.

fields.headline: Earning to learn?
fields.standfirst: Will part-time work damage your child's exam results?  Ann Hodgson and  Ken Spours look at the issues as more and more schoolchildren take up paid employment
fields.trailText: Will part-time work damage your child's exam results? Ann Hodgson and Ken Spours look at the issues as more and more schoolchildren take up paid employment
fields.body:
Young people now finishing their A levels have juggled more paid work with their studies than ever before. A new report from the Department for Education and Employment notes that nearly half of all 16-year-olds, let alone 17- and 18-year-olds, in full-time education are also in employment. Will this affect their results, as many teachers fear?

Through a recent survey we have found evidence to suggest that working long hours can reduce both commitment to study and aspirations to excel. As a year 12 student confided: "In a perfect world, you'd give up your part-time work and concentrate on your A levels, but you need the money."

On the other hand, part-time work might be encouraging those young people who may have gone out into the labour market in the past to remain in full-time education because they can study and earn at the same time. "Work and study builds up the experience of moving on from compulsory education into a time of choice. I don't have to be doing A levels, I don't have to be doing work, but I choose to do both," says one year 12 boy.

The challenge is to establish a relationship between learning and earning that capitalises on the benefits of employment without jeopardising young peoples' qualifications. Hence the importance of finding a balance.

Sixth-form and college students have always had part-time jobs, of course, but these have usually been restricted to weekends and holidays. What our research into patterns of paid work among 2,000 14- to 19-year-olds in the south Gloucestershire area indicates is that 70-80% of 17- to 19-year-olds in that area now have part-time jobs; a significant number are undertaking more than 15 hours a week, and many are working during the week in term time as well as at the weekend and in their holidays. This appears to be the case in other parts of the country, too.

Employers, in retailing especially, are keen to recruit bright 16- to 19-year-olds to work part-time to cover unsocial shifts, which older employees (often women with families) are less willing to take on. The increase in the number of hours shops and supermarkets are open has led to a steep demand for more casualised labour. Many young people we spoke to as part of our study originally opted to take on employment on Saturday or Sunday, but they had gradually been drawn into additional hours during the week. The lure is very much financial. As one year 13 student said, "I didn't need the money before, but now I'd be lost without it."

The students we interviewed were very positive. They said they had gained a great deal from taking on a part-time job, though some of their friends experienced difficulties in balancing work and study. They spoke enthusiastically about how much more confident they had become as a result of working, particularly in dealing with people and handling money. They liked being financially independent. Many said that the workplace provided an additional dimension to their social life. Several asserted that they would not be able to afford further education unless they had a part-time job.

It was clear, too, from what the students said that their parents broadly supported them or even actively encouraged them to get part-time employment. Finally, when asked what effect they felt their work was having on their study, many claimed that it had made them more organised about getting their homework done and helped them with some aspects of their programme.

Teachers and lecturers, on the other hand, often voiced anxiety about the detrimental effects, particularly on A-level students. They complained about assignments being late; students being too tired to concentrate properly, not spending enough time on revision and even, in some cases, skipping classes to take on an extra shift at the local supermarket. They were particularly worried that students were not prepared or able to reduce their hours of work around exam time and were, in their view, jeopardising their A-level grades and their chances of getting into a more prestigious university or course.

What was clear from our interviews with young people, however, is that many of them are unsure about whether they want to go to university. We called these the "higher education waverers". This is partly because they are concerned about how much it is going to cost them: "It's the money really; I don't like the idea of having a debt hanging over me. It would be a big debt - thousands of pounds," said one year 13 boy. Moreover, several young people said they would be satisfied with getting a place at a local university, which would not be too costly and would allow them to stay at home and keep their part-time job.

"I'd like to go to UWE [University of West of England] if anywhere, because it's close to home and it would keep the costs down. I'd choose the course according to what they offer," said one year 12 girl.

Teachers also recognised that the patterns of application for higher education appear to be changing, and some thought that part-time work could well be playing a role.

"In one way the children are more mature than they used to be, because they've got their jobs and they don't need to go away from home to break with their parents, in the way people used to. In fact, they've got higher status with their parents as adults than perhaps we had, and therefore they don't need to make that cut. They can have the best of both worlds at home," said one sixth-form tutor.

Since a few of the local universities tend to make low A-level offers, and many students are relying on their results at A level to help them make up their mind about higher education, there is little incentive to give up their part-time work in order to achieve higher grades.

The relationship between part-time work and higher education is therefore a complex one: on the one hand, some students are using their earnings from part-time work to save up for higher education; on the other, their involvement in the labour market gives them a tantalising taste of affluence, which studying at university would be likely to deny them.

Not all teachers and lecturers see part-time work as a necessary evil. The more we discussed the issue with them, the more they appreciated the potentially positive relationship between learning and earning from an educational perspective. This was particularly the case with GNVQ teachers. As one said, "Teaching GNVQ business, it's quite useful a lot of the time for them to have some experience of the workplace. They also use their workplace for their assignments."

However, the majority of students did not make these connections so explicitly and were keen to keep work and study separate. Until now this has been possible because of the relatively low number of taught hours in A-level courses and the fact that application of work-related skills has been confined to vocational programmes such as GNVQ. This "convenient" relationship between the low-volume A-level curriculum and part-time work will change in September as a result of the Curriculum 2000 reforms of A levels, GNVQs and the introduction of key skills designed to broaden A levels.

Students who would previously have studied three A levels will, for example, probably be taking four AS levels in their first year of study next year. In some instances, these students will also be working towards a key skills certificate in communications, application of number and information technology. For most young people, the number of taught hours is likely to rise by at least five per week. Total study time, including independent study, will thus leave less time for part-time work.

There is a real danger, therefore, that students' legitimate desire to gain independence might undermine the thrust of the reforms to broaden their study. Since the reforms are not compulsory, students can drop subjects and this process may be aggravated by their work demands.

If our limited research in this area is anything to go by, employers are largely unaware of the effect their employment practices may be having on the education of the students who work for them.

Moreover, all the employers we spoke to were totally unaware of the implications Curriculum 2000 might have for work and study patterns.

However, at a seminar of teachers, lecturers and employers organised in south Gloucestershire by Learning Partnership West, which focused on the implications of part-time work for students on A-level programmes, it became clear that leading employers were more than willing to play a constructive role.

When Curriculum 2000 was explained to them, employers thought it possible to discuss with students how they might use "flexi-contracting" to accommodate the new study and assessment demands. They suggested, for example, that if they knew in advance when students were likely to be taking examinations (which will be a much more regular occurrence), they could arrange for reduced working hours at these times. Some employer representatives also showed an interest in helping with the development of key skills.

Teachers and lecturers in schools and colleges can also play their part in the process of finding a balance by panicking less about the potential negative effects and using their experience to help students manage their time more effectively.

There is a growing consensus that we need to accept part-time work as a reality and to harness its positive features. There is undoubtedly the need for a national study that will result in a more informed debate between schools, colleges, employers, higher education and young people to find the optimum balance for each person and to forge positive connections between education and work.

 Ann Hodgson & Ken Spours lecture at the Institute of Education, University of London. This article is based on a recent report entitled Earning and Learning, which is available from the Lifelong Learning Group, priced £10. Email Irene Kemp or phone 020-7612 6923
